	<item>
		<title>Microsoft SharePoint Governance Areas</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-governance-areas</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 05 Apr 2012 16:34:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=2485</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In my last blog, I discussed why it’s important to establish a ‘Governance Plan’ for your <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a> implementation.  Without some controls and guidelines for proper usage, it can quickly degenerate into a disorganized, difficult-to-use, non-solution.

So, how do you approach developing a Governance Plan for your Microsoft SharePoint environment?  It’s helpful to start by breaking it down into several separate, but related ‘Governance Areas’:
<ul>
	<li>Information Governance</li>
	<li>Applications Governance</li>
	<li>Operations Governance</li>
</ul>
When developing a <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint Governance plan</a> method and sequence is important.  There is a logical order to the list of Governance Areas, with each building upon the decisions made and guidelines developed in the previous area.

Information Governance primarily covers information architecture and security, which defines the navigation and site structure of your SharePoint environment, along with access controls and accountability.  This is the foundation upon which SharePoint success is built- ensuring that information is well-organized, well-managed and easy to find is of upmost importance.

Applications Governance deals with things like visual design, customization and automation.  SharePoint’s out-of-the-box usability is good, but some well thought-out enhancements to its aesthetics and user experience can really inspire people to embrace and adopt it more fully.  Actively managing those customizations and their deployment ensures a stable and predictable environment for end users.

Operations Governance includes all of the other things that have to happen ‘behind the scenes’ to ensure the availability and integrity of the SharePoint environment. Disaster recovery, monitoring, database maintenance and many other aspects of the deployment should be defined and documented, based on the ‘best practices’ and the particular needs of your organization.

As part of a comprehensive ‘Governance Plan’, each of the above ‘Governance Areas’ is important to consider carefully.  There are a variety of key decisions to be made in each area, and it’s critical to make well-informed choices and document the resulting guidelines and processes in a way that can be leveraged by all users of the solution.  When everyone clearly understands what they should (and shouldn’t) do in SharePoint, success is much easier to achieve and real business value follows. 

To learn more about Microsoft SharePoint, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Event" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint#sharepoint-event">Microsoft SharePoint event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Lanham SWC LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-lanham/22/125/a99" target="_blank">Jeff Lanham on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Search Engine Optimization</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/search-engine-optimization</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Apr 2012 00:56:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elliottbaretz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=2573</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Also known as “SEO”

Either way the name doesn’t do the thing justice. With the launch of our own <a title="SWC SEO" href="/solutions/digital-design">SWC SEO</a> practice I have gotten to know the power of this capability and its reach is way more than people think.

Generally speaking when <a title="SWC Search Engine Optimization" href="/solutions/digital-design">Search Engine Optimization</a> comes up most folks think the conversation is going to focus on how to get to the top of Google’s results page. Most people intuitively understand the importance of being on the top of a search list but the numbers are staggering. For me, there are two data points that I think say it all:
<ul>
	<li>Page one search result listings receive 95% of searchers clicks.  In other words, if you’re not on page one the best you can hope for is to win the battle for the remaining 5% of search clicks.</li>
	<li>The #1 search ranking receives 36% of the page clicks...In the world of SEO being the best is indisputable and disproportionately valuable.</li>
</ul>
So, yes, an important part of SEO is getting to the top of the Google (or Bing) search result list - but what may be more important than the result of SEO is the process in which SEO derives its results.

A great deal of SEO data comes from various applications that monitor, document and analyze web site activity, structure, and content.  This information is then juxtaposed against other sets of data that reflect the top performers in Google and Bing as well as (what most folks are interested in) how the competition is performing.  So basically, it’s the kind of information that tells you how your site is performing in the world of the Internet against the market and the competition. Things like:
<ul>
	<li>What key words the search engines are looking for when they scan your site</li>
	<li>What key words the search engines think you should be focused on</li>
	<li>What key words your competition is focused on and how you rank against those competitors – for each keyword</li>
</ul>
But that’s not all...(sorry, couldn’t help it).  In a typical SEO engagement we are also able to really decompose a web site’s performance and analyze trends and patterns related to site traffic and activity. With some careful consideration we can begin to deduce:
<ul>
	<li>Why viewers are coming to your website and how they got there in the first place.</li>
	<li>What parts of each web page are visually compelling and draw the most clicks.</li>
	<li>What messaging is working the best</li>
</ul>
In the end, all of this information provides us with a very clear sense for how to affect market strategy – not just for the company web site but for the company itself.

To learn more, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Digital Design and SEO event" href="/digital-design-and-seo-swc-luncheon">Digital Design and Search Engine Optimization event</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft Unified Communications…A Game Changer</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-unified-communications-game-changer</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 12 Apr 2012 18:09:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[adamferguson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=2872</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There are a whole bunch of reasons why I like working in the technology industry. It's fast moving and fun but what I like most of all is the profound impact that IT can have on business. Pretty routinely these days a technology comes around that radically effects how we operate - whether it's changing the cost of doing business, opening up new markets or just allowing us to work in new and exciting ways – Microsoft's Unified Communications (UC) is one of these solutions.

At the heart of <a title="Microsoft Unified Communications" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Microsoft Unified Communications</a> are <a title="Microsoft Exchange 2010" href="ht/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-exchange-2010">Microsoft Exchange</a> 2010 and <a title="Microsoft Lync 2010" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2010">Microsoft Lync</a> 2010. Together these products offer email, calendaring, Unified Messaging, Instant Messaging, Presence, conferencing and VoIP. All from a platform and experience that is tightly integrated with the Microsoft Office 2010 stack, is highly intuitive and user friendly.

In 2012 the real story of Unified Communications is the proven ability of Microsoft Lync to become a stand-alone telephony system. To offer the option of eliminating that old, clunky, proprietary PBX system back in the corner of your datacenter.

In making this trade our clients are finding great financial returns. In some cases it's as simple as not needing to invest in a new PBX environment. In other cases, it's the ability to reduce charges associated with call times. For almost everyone there are significant savings in moving to a Lync-hosted conference call service. Typically speaking the Microsoft Unified Communications platform will pay for itself within its first year of operations.

ROI aside, Microsoft Unified Communications is a game changer in how we communicate. Providing users with the ability to identify, communicate and collaborate with the right people at the right time – every time.

The technology that surrounds communications is more powerful than ever. At SWC, a full-service <a title="IT Company" href="http://www.swc.com">IT company</a>, we are working with our clients every day to make sure they are finding success with this new and exciting solution.

To learn more about Microsoft UC, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Microsoft Linc Exchange Event" href="/lync-exchange-2010-swc-luncheon">Microsoft Lync and Exchange 2010 event</a> or follow <a title="Adam Ferguson LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/adam-ferguson/32/71/4b4" target="_blank">Adam Ferguson on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>SWC Digital Design</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-media/swc-digital-design</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Apr 2012 13:36:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elliottbaretz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=3035</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s been a little over a year now since we launched our <a title="Digital Design" href="/solutions/digital-design">digital design</a> practice.  During that time we have produced more than a dozen sites, many of them on the <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a> platform. Today we proudly showcase these projects on our digital portfolio.  But it’s where that portfolio resides that – I think – truly represents our greatest first team milestone; and that is our company website: www.swc.com

Recently we re-launched www.swc.com. We have always been proud of our brand and, in particular, our website.  For years it has (we believe) represented our firm through a polished aesthetic and crisp communication style.  But like anything else, there was room for improvement.  Our new site reflects a number of enhancements that are worth noting.  It is also a great example of our ability to deliver superior websites through our digital design practice.

Professional designers are not just classically trained but are also passionate about design.  They understand what works and what doesn’t and appreciate the idea that strong design serves a functional purpose.  The new www.swc.com leverages a “TILE” structure which is designed to provide efficient communication while maintaining a compelling aesthetic.  This approach is gaining strong momentum in digital design trends and is notably featured in the upcoming release of <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Windows 8</a>.

As a consulting firm we are very focused on recruiting talented individuals that are team oriented and have a high level of integrity. This focus was recently recognized by Crain’s Chicago Business with SWC being ranked as one of the best places to work in the city. To underscore this commitment we paid particular attention to our <a title="IT Consulting Company Careers" href="/careers">SWC Careers</a> page, investing in the production of “must see” employee videos.

Search Engine Optimization has become a critical component of marketing.  Our digital design practice has begun to staff <a title="Search Engine Optimization Consultants" href="/solutions/digital-design/search-engine-optimization">SEO consultants</a> and is now delivering this capability along with our site design offerings.  As we recreated swc.com we paid particular attention to SEO – not just in how we structured the site or the content we placed within it but in our platform and the processes that we will leverage in the days, weeks and months to come.

Indeed there has been great change to www.swc.com but in so many ways this change has been good.  I am more proud today of our website then I have ever been. Of course, there is more to come.  We have many planned enhancements which should be stunning and I will (like a proud parent) keep you posted on these developments.  In the interim, I am hopeful to collect your reaction to what we have just published.  Please take a look at the site and let me know your thoughts.

To learn more, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Digital Design and SEO event" href="/digital-design-and-seo-swc-luncheon">Digital Design and Search Engine Optimization event</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>An Agile Approach to Business Intelligence</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/agile-approach-business-intelligence</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 18 Apr 2012 18:52:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=3211</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Contrary to popular belief, <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a> doesn't have to be horribly complicated, prohibitively expensive, or torturously long in getting accomplished.

At <a title="Chicago IT Consulting Firm" href="http://www.swc.com">Chicago IT consulting firm</a>, SWC, we focus on the middle market working with organizations that have hundreds or thousands of employees. Our clients tend to be very pragmatic in the way they do business. So, over the years we have learned how to create and deploy meaningful business intelligence assets that can be in production quickly and can drive meaningful ROI.

There are two key components in our approach to Business Intelligence – technology and methodology.

At SWC our core BI technology is <a title="Microsoft SQL Server" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server</a>. Its most recent edition – <a title="SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">SQL Server 2012</a>, just released offers several significant enhancements that extend the power of Business Intelligence in ways that we would have never imagined only a handful of years ago. Features such as Power View and Power Pivot allow end-users to quickly create rich, interactive analysis at a variety of levels – using intuitive and user friendly authoring tools. And because this is all part of the Microsoft stack experience, these very insightful views can be quickly shared throughout an organization using the collaboration capabilities of Microsoft SharePoint, Lync, Exchange and Office.

Beyond the technology is how SWC seeks to design and deploy Business Intelligence solutions. Over recent years we have adopted an "agile" development methodology. The idea with agile is to define and develop a discreet, pragmatic solution which is released incrementally for both production use and immediate feedback from users. From there we continue to build out the capabilities of the environment in this type of building block mode – iterating and constantly enhancing the features and capabilities of the business intelligence solution. Through this approach BI projects are affordable and impactful – two words that fundamentally define IT in the middle market.

Through the power of business intelligence we give our clients the ability to identify and understand the challenges and opportunities they face every day. We help them succeed and we help them succeed faster.

To learn more, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Business Intelligence Event" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence event</a> or follow <a title="Rachael Narel LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/rachael-l-narel-cisa/0/8a5/889" target="_blank">Rachael Narel on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Why SWC is Developing a SalesForce.com Practice</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/swc-developing-salesforce-practice</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 23 Apr 2012 18:31:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeffhoffmann]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=3362</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We’ve been delivering <a title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM" href="/solutions/crm">Microsoft Dynamics CRM</a> solutions since the earliest viable versions. We’ve developed one of the best Microsoft CRM solution delivery teams in the Chicago area. We have countless satisfied Microsoft CRM users. The Microsoft CRM 2011 release was one of the better new releases from Microsoft in a number of years. We continue to value the strengths of Microsoft CRM, including its unparalleled Outlook and <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a> integration capabilities and its economic value.

So why is SWC starting a <a title="Salesforce.com CRM" href="/solutions/crm">SalesForce.com</a> practice?
Several reasons:
<ol>
	<li><strong>Our customers asked us to.</strong> Many had chosen SalesForce.com before they met us. They liked the product, but had trouble finding a high quality provider to support their efforts. The mid-market is especially under-served when it comes to this technology.</li>
	<li><strong>We found that we were good at it.</strong> Implementing CRM solutions is as much about functional and process design as it is about technology. Those skills translate quite nicely from Microsoft to SaleForce.com. And our deep Java development experience helped us to master APEX.</li>
	<li><strong>We like the product.</strong> Many customers will be best served by the Microsoft’s value proposition. Many others will place a greater emphasis on the collaboration and social features that have come to differentiate SalesForce.com. Some will fall in the middle, served well by either solution. And we’ll help our customers navigate that choice.</li>
</ol>
So keep your eyes peeled over the next few months as we roll out events that will showcase both of these technologies in their best light. Most importantly, we’ll help you decide what’s right for you.

To learn more, please join <a title="IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants</a>, SWC for our next informative <a title="Customer Relationship Management Event" href="/solutions/crm">CRM event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Hoffmann LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-hoffmann/a/b59/704" target="_blank">Jeff Hoffmann on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Digital Design: An Integral Part of the Technology Experience</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-media/digital-design-technology-experience</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 May 2012 22:03:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elliottbaretz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=3755</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In so many ways design has become an integral part of technology. Today as individuals we are surrounded by computers, tablets, smart phones and now with the Cloud we have the ability to have extremely interactive, meaningful experiences anywhere and at any time. This is the Consumerization of IT - and it's fantastic. But with all of this has come a huge lift in user sophistication and generally speaking a tremendous expectation of the technology experience. We have become accustomed to consuming information - no matter where we are - whether at home or at work - in a way that is compelling and at the very least easy.

It's this concept that is at the heart of SWC Design. It's the idea that form - or design - is meant to enhance function. In practical terms this design philosophy is helping us provide our clients with tremendous advantages in the development of <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint environments</a>, eCommerce sites as well as mobile applications. We have always been a firm that has understood functionality and pragmatic efficiency – today we are enhancing that capability with very real, very sophisticated user experience and graphic design talent and expertise.

In developing our design practice we have also made investments in our ability to deliver around <a title="Search Engine Optimization" href="/solutions/digital-design/search-engine-optimization">search engine optimization</a> - or SEO. The idea behind SEO is to structure the architecture, code and content of a website in such a way that it finds preference with dominant search engines such as Google or Bing. We believe that if our clients are going to invest in creating compelling, aesthetically beautiful and functionally efficient websites they are going to want users to find them.

Mastering the art of marketing in the 21st Century requires an equal command of current technology and classical business acumen. Please join me for my <a title="Digital Design Services" href="/solutions/digital-design">Digital Design</a> and Search Engine Optimization event where I will explore and demonstrate how digital design, integrated marketing and search engine optimization (SEO) are driving growth and a competitive advantage for today’s market leaders.

To learn more, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Digital Design Event" href="/solutions/digital-design">Digital Design event</a> which will include Search Engine Optimization and website design.</content:encoded>

		<title>Agile BI Software Solution</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/agile-bi-software-solution</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 May 2012 21:48:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=3850</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Technology succeeds in <a title="Business Intelligence" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a> with a pragmatic approach to solution development. Watch our latest <a title="Agile Business Intelligence" href="/perspective/videos/agile-business-intelligence-bi-software-solution">Agile Business Intelligence</a> video to understand how SWC leverages <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server 2012</a> and an agile methodology to drive strong ROI and rapid production timelines.

To learn more, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Business Intelligence Event" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence event</a>, or follow <a title="Rachael Narel LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/rachael-l-narel-cisa/0/8a5/889" target="_blank">Rachael Narel on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How to Fast Track Business Intelligence</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/fast-track-bi</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 May 2012 19:36:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=3958</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The first step toward accelerating BI access is to examine what you are working with – what kind of information do you have access to and what kind of structure currently exists to provide that information to those users. Our <a title="Business Intelligence Solution" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">business intelligence solutions</a> help users build out a cube structure (that’s more robust) to join everything together, rather than having users spend days or even weeks copying and pasting information from various sources into Excel or Access databases. With a robust cube, users can then quickly get into the details and do the analysis they are looking for through Excel, various dashboard technologies, etc. Putting a better structure and data model in place is a key place to start.

The process of creating a comprehensive business intelligence solution can be long and arduous. At SWC, we have been utilizing an <a title="Agile Business Intelligence" href="/blog/business-intelligence/agile-approach-business-intelligence">agile</a> approach that allows you to take a project and break things down into smaller iterations, while still focusing on the overall big picture and end goal. This provides end users with production level and workable solutions faster so that they can start to see their reports and data materialize, allowing them to provide more focused feedback for future iterations. This way, they don't have to wait six months for you to provide data that they realize they don't want. Working with them to break it down into bite-sized pieces helps promote a quicker turnaround time and also gets them results that they can start working with while you are building out the next iteration.

Along with the previous point, one of the challenges that exist in this process is that users are only used to looking at data from a specific viewpoint. They have a hard time articulating requirements – often, they know what they DON'T want, but aren't necessarily skilled in outlining what they do want. Breaking it down allows them to get a better handle on their wants and needs, provide something tangible from them to assess and sparks conversations about deeper and more complex requirements that can then be delivered more rapidly because everyone is working toward the same specific results.

In terms of tools, <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server 2012</a> is top notch in terms of self-service BI and analytics. It still helps to partner with IT in order to determine what kind of data is needed and put the models in place to secure that data and structure it appropriately, but once those requirements are determined, the users can go in and retrieve unaided. They can create new reports and have better access to the data, in essence allowing any user to create a highly visual, richly interactive, and presentation ready solution. Cutting out the middle man obviously saves time and speeds things up. Since this is part of the Microsoft stack, users can share this information quickly with others using the collaboration capabilities of <a title="Microsoft Sharepoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a>, <a title="Microsoft Lync" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2010">Lync</a>, <a title="Microsoft Exchange" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-exchange-2010">Exchange</a> and Office.

To learn more, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>, or follow <a title="Rachael Narel LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/rachael-l-narel-cisa/0/8a5/889" target="_blank">Rachael Narel on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Chicago NATO Summit Disaster Recovery Plans</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/disaster-recovery-plans/chicago-nato-summit-disaster-recovery-plans</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 11 May 2012 18:52:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[michaellee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4002</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Chicago NATO Summit will be held downtown this year from May 20th to 21st. Many customers are wondering how this might affect them or how they can prepare.

The recent NATO discussions I have had with my customers and colleagues revolve around Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery Planning. Below are two articles I was published in related to these topics that I think are helpful.

Picking A Disaster Recovery Site (note: no longer a valid link)

<a href="http://www.readwriteweb.com/solution-series/2011/11/how-to-rank-your-apps-and-proc.php" target="_blank">How to Rank Your Apps and Processes According to the Fire Alarm Scale</a>

At SWC, we have already begun the process of getting our <a title="Chicago IT Service" href="http://www.swc.com">Chicago IT</a> customers ready by encouraging them to check remote system availability for their users and to review Business Continuity and <a title="Managed IT Solutions" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">IT Contingency plans</a> before the NATO Summit. Additionally, we have increased staffing at our Network Operations Center in Oak Brook, IL to provide remote support for them and their users.

For more information about the NATO visit to Chicago please visit: <a href="http://www.chicagonato.org/" target="_blank">http://www.chicagonato.org/</a>.

To learn more, please join SWC Technology Partners for our next informative <a title="Virtualization Events" href="/solutions/virtualization">Virtualization event</a> or follow <a title="Michael Lee LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelilee" target="_blank">Michael Lee on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>

		<title>SWC Interviewed on NATO Efforts By Two Prominent Chicago Media Outlets</title>

	<item>
		<title>The Evolution of Microsoft SharePoint</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/evolution-of-microsoft-sharepoint</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 24 May 2012 15:17:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4212</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I have been working with <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a> since the inception of the product in 2001.  Over time this platform has seen tremendous enhancements in capability and is considered by Gartner to be one of the leading search, portal and content management solutions available in today's market.  As a reflection of its success SharePoint is used by 78% of Fortune 500 companies and between the years of 2006 and 2011 Microsoft sold over 36.5 million SharePoint user licenses.

The challenge with Microsoft SharePoint has always been focus.  Inherently the platform can do so much that it can become difficult for our clients to understand where and how they are going to get their best return from the technology.  Of course there are a number of ways to address this challenge but at SWC Technology Partners, we have found that there are some critical elements that once addressed have exponential benefits.  The first is to adopt a pragmatic, goal oriented approach to the solutions roadmap – and to apply the 80/20 rule.  How is our client going to get 80% of the solution's value with 20% of its functionality?  How are they going to establish a beachhead of capability and then incrementally build from there?

<img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-4211" title="Microsoft Sharepoint Kensington College" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-sharepoint-kensington-college-300x183.jpg" alt="Microsoft Sharepoint Kensington College" width="300" height="183" />

With the solution roadmap in place we have learned that understanding the value of the user experience or the aesthetic of the site is absolutely critical to the solution's ultimate adoption.  The reality is that as humans we have a tendency to embrace those things we find exciting and easy to use.  At SWC, our <a title="IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants</a> have honed the ability to create rich and beautiful SharePoint environments – providing them with an intuitive, easy and rewarding experience.  In the end, we know that if they value going to SharePoint once then they are likely to return and, of course, likely to tell their coworkers. Go ahead and check out some of our <a title="SharePoint Design Portfolio" href="/portfolio/index.html">SharePoint designs</a> from our digital design portfolio!

<img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-4210" title="Microsoft Sharepoint Habiflex Engineering" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-sharepoint-habiflex-engineering-300x183.jpg" alt="Microsoft Sharepoint Habiflex Engineering" width="300" height="183" />

In business the power to share is a fundamental component to success and at SWC we are helping our Chicago area business clients become more productive through collaboration.

To learn more about Microsoft SharePoint, please join SWC for our next informative <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Events" href="/events">Microsoft SharePoint event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Lanham LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-lanham/22/125/a99" target="_blank">Jeff Lanham on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft Windows 8 and the Consumerization of IT</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/microsoft-windows-8-and-the-consumerization-of-it</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 May 2012 14:11:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4268</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[So, what does that mean?  "The consumerization of IT" – I like to think of it as the blurring of lines – the blurring of lines between our work and personal environments and the technologies that we use.  Today because of the Internet, the Cloud and mobile computing our expectations of technology have risen to new heights.  When we need information – we expect and most often demand – that we can efficiently find that information no matter what time it is and no matter where we are.  And the idea of accessing technology any different at work then we do in our personal lives seems a little silly.

It's because of the consumerization of IT that the release of <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Microsoft's Windows 8</a> is so critical to today's middle-market IT organization.  Windows 8 will provide today's user with the rich, intuitive touchscreen and tablet interface that they have become used to - and of course, with Windows 8 that touchscreen experience will extend to the laptop and the desktop.  But what Windows 8 will truly represent is the ability for today's IT manager to deploy this type of experience in a highly secure and managed infrastructure.

<img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-4278" title="Microsoft Windows 8 Touchscreen" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-windows-8-touchscreen-300x231.jpg" alt="Microsoft Windows 8 Touchscreen" width="300" height="231" />

Because Windows 8 is a Microsoft operating system running on Active Directory and is completely integrated within the other components of the Microsoft stack there is no compromise between user experience and user productivity or network management for that matter.  The collaborative powers of <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a>, Office and <a title="Microsoft Lync 2010" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2010">Lync</a> are seamlessly integrated with Windows 8.  The security, deployment and management tools of Systems Center are seamlessly extended into Windows 8 as they have been with its predecessors.

In many ways the success of IT is measured in how we empower those around us.  <a title="Microsoft Windows" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows</a> 8 is a product that is going to help us meet this mission head on.

To learn more about how Microsoft Windows 8 can help you and your business, please join SWC for our next <a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Event" href="/events">Microsoft Windows 8 event</a> or follow <a title="Pete Lee LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/pete-lee/4/b2b/989" target="_blank">Pete Lee on LinkedIn</a></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How to Break Business Intelligence Users’ Excel Addiction</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/break-bi-users-excel-addiction</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 Jun 2012 14:25:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4422</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Recently, a reporter asked me to comment on how organizations can adjust their <a title="Business Intelligence" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a> (BI) efforts to users' persistent "addiction" to Microsoft Excel and if I had any ideas for weaning users away from Excel in favor of more modern solutions?

I think there are two issues here. First, there are the users that should be using Excel because they are looking to do that deep dive analysis that requires them to slice and dice through the information. With the level of interaction and manipulation they want to do with the data, Excel is likely the most appropriate tool for them. The problem is that in many cases they are using it ineffectively. Often, in order to have access to all of the data they need to do their analysis they find themselves copying and pasting in information from various sources. They may download pieces of data from Access databases, move over columns from other reports, link to data in other spreadsheets, cut and paste from email, or manually enter various items. Additionally, if they are writing their own queries to various tables of information, they may be running into issues with data retrieval, bandwidth, or invalid returns. By the time they are done just sourcing the data they need, there usually isn’t much time left to do the real analysis needed.

Organizations can help better support these users by providing them with a centralized structure for all of that information. We have worked with many customers to utilize tools like <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server</a> to provide a centralized environment for the data which can then be presented to them in a more meaningful format. They can add speed to the analysis and take away the complexity as well by building out cubes for the key dimensions and measures the users need access to; providing them with accurate and accessible data which allows them to spend less time searching for answers. They can still use tools like Excel with Pivot Tables where they can now quickly select the fields they need for their analysis and start to drill into the data. This also allows for a centralized model for multiple groups, where each area or individual can still select a subset of that data for their own use.

There are other users, however, that have found themselves utilizing Excel due to the fact that they have no other solution to choose from. Or the data that is presented to them in reports or other solutions is more or less than what they need. These users then download the information they do have to Excel in order to massage, manipulate and augment that data rather than do analysis. Many of these users would be better served with dashboard or reporting solutions. The challenge here again is presenting these users with the data that they need and in a format they can consume. These users can benefit from the same strategy of a cube build that will then quickly provide them with the data they need in a dashboard, through a Pivot Table, or through more ad hoc or interactive reporting solutions such as PowerView. However, these can also be large, expensive and time consuming processes. We have had a lot of success with customers working with smaller iterations of projects such as these by doing initial pilots on a small area and by utilizing an Agile approach to building out an appropriate business intelligence solution. This provides faster deliverables that users can start to adopt right away, building excitement and momentum for continued use. It is also more cost effective and establishes a quicker ROI for senior management, providing further support for expansion to other areas.

One final thought is that in order for any of this to happen, the users need to have confidence in the data that is being presented to them. Many times when you start to move away from the manual processes they are accustomed to, there is a great deal of hesitation that the automation is pulling the right data. It is often appropriate to run both the old and new process in parallel for a period of time so that they can become comfortable with not only the new way of working but also that that information is accurate. This issue can be further mitigated with Data Quality solutions utilized to profile, validate and cleanse the data upfront. Having the users participate in creation of the validation rules for the data can also help alleviate this concern and there are some newer solutions, like SQL Server 2012’s Data Quality Services, that will provide views into the results of these activities for further validation of them.

To learn more, please join Chicago <a title="IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants</a> SWC for our next informative <a title="Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>, or follow <a title="Rachael Narel LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/rachael-l-narel-cisa/0/8a5/889" target="_blank">Rachael Narel on LinkedIn</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Why I Am No Longer Skeptical About Windows 8</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/no-longer-skeptical-about-microsoft-windows-8</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Jun 2012 14:44:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4455</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="IT Consulting Firm" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consulting firm</a> SWC has just completed its inaugural <a title="Microsoft Windows" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows</a> 8 Luncheon just outside of Chicago, and the feedback from the audience was what we expected. Some of them were skeptical whether Microsoft was too late to the mobile/touchscreen device market, while others were excited at the prospect of having a tablet device that can integrate into enterprise security and compliancy.  Mostly, everyone was curious how <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Windows 8</a> devices would fit in their environment with the success of <a title="Microsoft Windows 7" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-7">Windows 7</a>.  I admit that I went into Windows 8 with the same questions as everyone else.  So let’s address some of those <em>“assumptions”</em>:
<ul>
	<li><em>The Metro is gaudy and awkward looking.</em> The Metro interface is in fact fluid and easily customizable, even in the beta stages. I can’t wait to see some of the newer apps coming onboard.</li>
	<li><em>No start menu, no thanks.</em> The desktop is still there and no different than Windows 7.  The start menu is actually more easy to use because you can get to what you need without the desktop.</li>
	<li><em>What if I don’t want a touch screen?</em> Windows 8 is absolutely fully functional with a keyboard and mouse. In fact, I am typing this blog now from a keyboard and mouse.</li>
	<li><em>Microsoft Mobile or tablet is never going to catch on.</em> If consumerization will bring devices from life to work, I think it will have the same effect the other way around.  Let’s face it; Windows 8 will be the only mobile platform that can be a fully functional corporate device.</li>
	<li><em>This is a toy not an enterprise level OS.</em> If you like Windows 7, you will like Windows 8.  Same functionalities, more features.</li>
</ul>
Overall, the <a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Event" href="/events">Windows 8 Luncheon</a> was a fun event, where we gathered important feedback on what IT leaders are expecting. What we learned was that customers don’t want a platform to switch to just because it’s the next release of a Windows OS.  Customers want a platform that is easy to use and as aesthetically focused as Apple or Google, yet is not limited in terms of accessibility to critical workplace applications like <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a> and <a title="Customer Relationship Management" href="/solutions/crm">CRM</a>.  Is Windows 8 going to meet everyone’s high expectations?  We will soon find out, but one thing is for sure…I am not longer a skeptic!

To learn more about how Microsoft Windows 8 can help you and your business, please join SWC for our next <a title="SWC Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Microsoft Windows 8 event</a> or follow <a title="Pete Lee on LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/pete-lee/4/b2b/989" target="_blank">Pete Lee on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Will Windows 8 Take Over the Smartphone Market?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/will-windows-8-take-over-the-smartphone-market</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 21 Jun 2012 14:07:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4506</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Recently, I was asked if <a title="Microsoft Windows" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows</a> will make major gains in the smartphone market share within the next few years or if there were any variables that could shift trends in a different direction?

Well, I do believe that <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Windows 8</a> is going to make major gains in the smartphone market share.  Microsoft has completely shifted its OS philosophy to be more user centric with fluid tiles on the metro interface, easy to use apps, and personalization across multiple devices. This is the model that made both Apple and Google market leaders. However, Microsoft’s biggest differentiator is its ability to integrate Windows 8 Mobile into the workplace, and this is huge!  Previously, access to corporate wide applications, such as <a title="Customer Relationship Management" href="/solutions/crm">CRM</a> and <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a> have been limited by a lack of integration with the enterprise.  Furthermore, security, compliancy, and management concerns have limited integration of Apple and Google mobile devices, which has always been one of the major reason Blackberry still has a decent market share on the corporate side.  Lately, we have heard a lot about consumerization and how more and more devices blur the line of personal life and work.  Consumers want to use their devices in the workplace, but what we often forget is that consumerization can also work the other way around.  As more corporations adopt Windows 8 Mobile, due to its manageability and security, we will see a trend of consumers bringing “workplace” devices into their “personal” realm.

This does not mean that Apple and Google smartphones are going away anytime soon, but with the mobile market expected to double by 2014, this does mean that Microsoft Windows 8 has the potential with its user centric approach and enterprise integration to make major market gains.

To learn more about how Microsoft Windows 8 can help you and your business, please join Chicago area <a title="Chicago IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants SWC Technology Partners</a> for our next <a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Event" href="/events">Microsoft Windows 8 event</a> or follow <a title="Pete Lee LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/pete-lee/4/b2b/989" target="_blank">Pete Lee on LinkedIn</a>
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Three Main Components of a CRM System</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/the-three-main-components-crm-system</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Jul 2012 14:39:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[toddwickens]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4716</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Effectively managing the customer lifecycle – from marketing to sales to service – is critical to your company’s profitability and growth. That’s why many mid-market organizations have found value in choosing a <a title="Customer Relationship Management System" href="/solutions/crm">Customer Relationship Management</a> (CRM) system for their businesses. But, what many people don’t know is that a <a title="CRM System" href="/solutions/crm">CRM system</a> can be so much more than your basic <a title="Sales Force Automation" href="/solutions/crm">sales force automation</a> tool that captures account and contact data. So I wanted to tell you a little more about how a CRM system can really impact your business by exploring the three main components of today's solutions.
<h2>Drive Marketing Effectiveness and Maximize Marketing Spend</h2>
With a CRM solution, you can improve marketing effectiveness by providing marketing professionals with flexible segmentation tools, simplified campaign management capabilities, intuitive response tracking, and insightful analytics. This can lead to an increased pipeline full of qualified leads that can then be prioritized and routed to the right sales representatives. Having a single system for managing and tracking multi-channel marketing campaigns from lead to close allows you to easily create dashboards and reports to see which of your marketing efforts result in the most sales. A CRM solution gives you the power to demonstrate marketing’s impact on your organization’s bottom line and lets you begin reinvesting in the tactics and strategies that work best for your business.
<h2>Help Salespeople Win More Deals</h2>
All CRM systems provide the ability to build a complete customer history, resulting in increased sales productivity. This enables sales representatives to focus on turning opportunities into closed business with a single place for updating deal information, recording customer interactions, tracking competitors, and creating quotes. Your CRM system should enable your team to not only find the information and history they need, but also allow them to perform forecasting and customer planning activities, such as contract renewals and selling upgrades, etc. By reinforcing your sales process in CRM, sales representatives will gain a proven methodology for managing and closing deals.

Furthermore, a CRM system will allow representatives and managers to gain visibility across deals and prioritize their selling time, giving them the ability to close the right deals faster and increase their deal size. The system also eliminates painful administration tasks by automating work flows and approvals. Finally, a CRM system will give your sales manager the ability to create ownership and accountability, as well as oversight by tracking all sales representative activity.
<h2>Create Lifetime Customers with Attentive Service</h2>
Your CRM system does not stop when a deal is closed. Continue building your 360-degree customer view with your CRM's service module for your customer service and technical support teams. Empower your people with tools that simplify case management, streamline escalations, improve knowledge sharing, and enable more effective account management. The result of these tools and processes will help your organization contain service costs without sacrificing service quality. In fact, your customers will be delighted with service representatives who are armed with all of their customer history and the knowledge base necessary to efficiently and effectively resolve their issues.

To learn more about Microsoft Dynamics CRM and Salesforce.com, please join <a title="IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants SWC</a> at our next <a title="Chicago CRM Event" href="/events">Customer Relationship Management system solutions event</a>.
</content:encoded>

		<title>What Are Midmarket IT Professionals Saying About Windows 8?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/midmarket-it-professionals-windows-8</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Jul 2012 11:31:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4734</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC is currently hosting monthly Chicago area events on <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Microsoft Windows 8</a> and asking our audience comprised of midmarket <a title="IT Professionals" href="http://www.swc.com">IT professionals</a> what they think. Watch the short video below from our most recent event to learn more about what Windows 8 features are exciting to this IT leader and what his approach will be to deploying <a title="Microsoft Windows" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows</a> 8 in his environment.

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/33Kmrl_Ga_s?autoplay=1" title="Microsoft Windows 8 Pre-Release Event Chicago " rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/win-8-videoplay.jpg" width="620" height="380" /></a>

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft World Wide Partner Conference 2012</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-world-wide-partner-conference-2012</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 13 Jul 2012 11:47:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elliottbaretz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4834</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I’m coming off a week in Toronto where I attended the Microsoft Worldwide Partner Conference. It’s me and 16,000 of Microsoft’s best friends. In fact, it’s the largest turnout for this event ever. It is undeniably an epic scene.

Some may be surprised to learn of a turnout like this for a Microsoft gathering. For years Microsoft has taken a backseat to companies like Apple, Google, Facebook in the press and most certainly in the public markets. In some cases for good reason; the competition was delivering a better product. And the company has had its missteps as most recently demonstrated with the <a href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/07/04/microsoft-s-6-2-billion-writedown-shows-it-s-losing-war-with-google.html" target="_blank">6.3 Billion dollar write off of aQuantive</a> and the pending, <a href="http://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2012/07/microsoft-downfall-emails-steve-ballmer" target="_blank">scathing Vanity Fair article announcing Microsoft’s “Lost Decade”</a>.

But over the years Microsoft has placed a lot of bets and has won its share of big money battles, often in places that the public doesn’t clearly see. For SWC these victories are right in our sweet spot. Everyday our mid-market clients leverage <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server</a>, <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a>, <a title="Microsoft Unified Communications" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Unified Communications</a>, <a title="Customer Relationship Management" href="/solutions/crm">CRM</a> and Office to run efficient and innovative organizations. In many ways Microsoft “owns” the technology stack that runs business in the 21st Century. They dominate the back-office in much the same way they used to dominate the PC space.

What has plagued Microsoft over the last 10 years has been the consumerization of IT - the touch screen user experience and the online store, the Cloud and the ability for a browser and any device to provide the productivity value that was once reserved to the PC. Microsoft has known for years that in order to regain the dominance it once had it would need to dramatically address this issue. It would need to own the consumer experience as much as it has continued to own the back-office.

This was the sub-text to the week’s events here in Toronto. In some subtle and other not-so-subtle ways Steve Ballmer and his lieutenants announced that the time had come for Microsoft to attack. The message is this:
<ul>
	<li><a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Microsoft Windows 8</a> (<a href="http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2406841,00.asp" target="_blank">released to manufacturing in August and available to the market in October</a>) will provide the touch-screen user experience that will finally give Apple something to worry about.</li>
	<li><a href="http://lubbockonline.com/technology/2012-06-24/review-microsoft-surface-straddles-divide" target="_blank">The Surface Tablet running Windows 8 will be manufactured by Microsoft so that they can control the entire experience</a>. Gone should be the configuration mishaps and clunky form factors that result from a channel handoff to organizations like HP, Dell and Samsung. It’s a very dramatic move that will alienate some very big, powerful partners, but in the end, Microsoft had no choice. This decision speaks volumes in terms of Ballmer’s commitment towards this strategy.</li>
	<li>The <a href="http://www.techradar.com/news/gaming/xbox-took-40-per-cent-of-us-gaming-pot-in-2011-1054558" target="_blank">XBOX is a dominate gaming and entertainment appliance in today’s household</a>. We know it for Halo and Call of Duty and other interactive experiences but don’t forget it’s also a media unit for video and audio as well as a communications hub for instant messaging and VOIP. With Skype it’s also a video chatting portal.</li>
	<li>During this conference, <a href="http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-07-09/business/sns-rt-us-perceptivepixel-microsoftbre8680q8-20120709_1_windows-rt-yammer-worldwide-partner-conference" target="_blank">Microsoft announced the acquisition of Performance Pixel</a>. It’s this company that has perfected the technology that allows for the touch screen experience on large screens (when I say large, I mean 80 inch screens). Imagine the XBOX or Windows 8 experience on something like this…</li>
	<li>The Windows Stores will be everywhere come the holiday shopping season. There are nearly two dozen today but <a href="http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/microsoftpri0/2018654251_wpc_day_3_live_blog.html" target="_blank">Microsoft plans on producing a number of “pop-up” stores to fill the gaps come the fall</a>. Imagine crowds at Microsoft stores like we see today at Apple. If Microsoft’s plans come true it may happen.</li>
</ul>
The announcements aren’t over. We are told to stay tuned over the coming days as more of Ballmer’s plans unfold.

I have to admit, as a business person it’s intriguing to watch this play out. I have no doubt that Microsoft and Ballmer are going to achieve their goals and recapture dominance in the technology sector. It’s a matter of time and frankly a reality of cash (60 Billion of cash). What remains to be figured out is when will the money pay off? When will the investments create the promised value and when will the consumer and the public market reward Microsoft for its strategy?

As of July 12th at 2:05 Microsoft is trading at 28.77 per share. Any takers for Microsoft at 40 per share by January 1, 2013?

SWC is a <a title="Full Service IT Company" href="http://www.swc.com">full-service IT consulting firm</a> that services mid-sized businesses in Chicago and the Chicagoland area.
</content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="elliott-baretz"><![CDATA[elliott baretz]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="microsoft"><![CDATA[Microsoft]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="microsoft"><![CDATA[Microsoft]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="microsoft-windows"><![CDATA[Microsoft Windows]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="swc"><![CDATA[SWC]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="windows-8"><![CDATA[Windows 8]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>How will Microsoft SharePoint Bring Value to My Business?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-bring-value-to-business</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Jul 2012 12:08:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=4864</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The two most commonly asked questions about <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a> are, <em>"What is Microsoft SharePoint?"</em> and <em>"Why should I implement Microsoft SharePoint for my organization?"</em> Both are variations of the underlying question – <em>What value will it bring to my business?</em>

Basically, Microsoft SharePoint is a platform for quickly <a title="Chicago website design" href="/solutions/digital-design">building web sites</a> and web-based applications. As such, it can do and be a lot of different things. While that has, no doubt, contributed to SharePoint's success as a product, it makes it hard to understand what it's all about and how to get the most value out of it. So I have tried to break it down a little bit further for you in this blog.
<h2>Build Effective Communities</h2>
This covers perhaps the most fundamental usage of SharePoint – the <a title="SharePoint Intranet" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">corporate intranet</a> or organizational portal. These types of solutions allow organizations to disseminate information to employees in a richer, more interactive fashion than email or newsletters allow. Common examples include:
<ul>
	<li>News and Announcements</li>
	<li>Upcoming Events</li>
	<li>Shared Calendars</li>
	<li>Dashboards</li>
	<li>Links to Commonly Used Websites and Applications</li>
</ul>
The main benefits here are faster and easier access to information, tools and people, which can result in enhanced productivity.
<h2>Document and Content Management</h2>
Here, we are talking about two main areas. The first is managing the document lifecycle, from ‘cradle to grave.’ This includes file creation and receipt, collaboration, review, approval, and publishing, as well as addressing auditing and compliance requirements. The second area is content navigation and retrieval. Traditional folder structures are limiting – they provide a 'one dimensional' way of organizing files, which rarely works for everyone, all the time. SharePoint provides multiple ways of classifying files, which enables different methods of browsing and finding content, along with powerful search capabilities. These features can help people more quickly find the content they need, when and where they need it.

SharePoint also allows you to extend these concepts to parties external to the organization, in what's typically referred to as an ‘Extranet' scenario. You can enable secure outside access to a SharePoint environment, and allow customers, vendors and/or partners to view documents and information, or even communicate and collaborate interactively with your employees. This allows you to provide more value to your customers, and engage them more deeply. Unlike intranets and document management, which serve primarily to enhance productivity and reduce costs, extranets can actually drive top-line revenue in many cases.
<h2>Drive Organizational Efficiencies</h2>
Beyond the main areas we have already discussed, there are a variety of ways that SharePoint can help drive organizational efficiencies. It can serve as the platform for delivering all kinds of <a title="Business Intelligence" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">business intelligence</a> and data visualization assets. It can help streamline repetitive business processes and make them more transparent and manageable. Last but not least, it can provide effective, integrated solutions for a wide variety of typical business challenges. Common examples include:
<ul>
	<li>Benefits Management</li>
	<li>Employee / Customer / Vendor Provisioning Processes</li>
	<li>Service Request / Requisition / Ticketing Systems</li>
	<li>Any Review or Approval Routing Scenario</li>
</ul>
Hopefully, the 'value areas' described above have helped shed some light on the many ways that SharePoint can benefit your organization. Of course, the examples provided barely scratch the surface of what is possible. I encourage you to contact the <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Consultants" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint consultants</a> at SWC if you are interested in discovering what Microsoft SharePoint has to offer, and how to successfully implement it for your business.

To learn more about Microsoft SharePoint and Chicago area <a title="IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants SWC</a>, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Microsoft SharePoint Event" href="/events">Microsoft SharePoint event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Lanham LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-lanham/22/125/a99" target="_blank">Jeff Lanham on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Choosing the Right CRM Solution Part I</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/choosing-right-crm-solution</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 Jul 2012 13:51:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[toddwickens]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5026</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Customers drive your business success and the right <a title="Customer Relationship Management" href="/solutions/crm">Customer Relationship Management</a> (CRM) system can affect how your organization attracts new customers, manages opportunities and maintains high customer service levels. The first step to effectively managing this customer lifecycle is to choose your <a title="Customer Relationship Management Solution" href="/solutions/crm">CRM solution</a> wisely. In this two-part blog entry, we will take a look at some of the common features you should expect from all CRM solutions and then review the key strengths of Microsoft Dynamics CRM and Salesforce.com.

<a title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM" href="/solutions/crm">Microsoft Dynamics CRM</a> and Salesforce.com represent the premier CRM solutions available to the midmarket – and if you don’t believe me, check out these charts* from two top industry analysts, Forrester and Gartner. Both analysts rate them as solution leaders in the CRM space.

<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-5031" title="The Forrester Wave CRM Suites Q2 2010" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/forrester-wave-crm-suites-q2-2010-300x298.png" alt="The Forrester Wave CRM Suites Q2 2010" width="300" height="298" />

<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-5032" title="Gartner Magic Quadrant Sales Force Automation Q2 2011" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/gartner-magic-quadrant-sales-force-automation-q2-2011-293x300.png" alt="Gartner Magic Quadrant Sales Force Automation Q2 2011" width="293" height="300" />*Chart 1: The Forrester Wave™ CRM Suites for Midsized Organizations (Q2 2010)
Chart 2: Gartner’s Magic Quadrant for Sales Force Automation (Q2 2011)

While I feel that most CRM solutions offer the same basic core capabilities for managing marketing, sales and service, not every business is the same and each CRM solution offers unique strengths to meet your needs. For starters, let’s take a look at those core capabilities available in both solutions:

<strong>Accounts and Contacts:</strong> This is where it all started for CRM systems and allows for the capture, view and management of a complete, 360-degree view of your customers

<strong>Activity Capture:</strong> Your customer history is not complete without easily capturing each customer’s interaction from call logs to emails to meeting notes and documents

<strong>Marketing and Leads:</strong> Your sales pipeline starts here by managing all your marketing activities in one place; including managing lists and campaigns, tracking touches and prospect activity, and routing qualified leads to sales

<strong>Opportunities:</strong> Manage and close opportunities in a single place by standardizing and executing your proven sales methodology and recording customer interactions

<strong>Customer Service - Ticket/Case Management:</strong> Empower your people with tools that simplify case management, streamline escalations, improve knowledge sharing, and enable more effective account management

<strong>Workflow and Approvals:</strong> Automate approvals, eliminate redundant tasks, and experience widespread adherence to your business processes

<strong>Email and Calendaring:</strong> Integration with tools like Outlook and Gmail are now table stakes in the CRM space allowing for less administration and double entry

<strong>Dashboards and Reporting:</strong> Easily customize views for different roles

<strong>Mobility:</strong> View, capture, and manage activities from anywhere on your mobile devices

<strong>Configure to Your Sales Process:</strong> Map your sales teams' proven sales methodology to the technology

<strong>Collaboration:</strong> Purpose-driven collaboration with your peers to increase deal size and close opportunities faster

I know advocates of both vendors will tell you why their solution does these things better or has a better user experience or interface. But, if you're not sure which solution is best for you, let SWC provide you with a demonstration of both and help you decide for yourself. Just send us a <a href="mailto:info@swc.com?subject=CRM%20Demonstration%20Request" target="_blank">message</a>.

Stay tuned for my next blog, where I will dig into the key strengths that I believe differentiate these two CRM market leaders.

To learn more about Microsoft Dynamics CRM and Salesforce.com system solutions, please join Chicago area <a title="IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants</a> SWC at our next <a title="Customer Relationship Management Event" href="/events">Customer Relationship Management event</a>.
</content:encoded>
