	<item>
		<title>Choosing the Right CRM Solution Part II</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/choosing-the-right-crm-solution-part-ii</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 01 Aug 2012 03:18:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[toddwickens]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5320</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In my last blog entry (<a title="Choosing CRM Solutions" href="/blog/customer-relationship-management/choosing-right-crm-solution">Choosing The Right CRM Solution Part I</a>), I wrote about the commonalities between <a title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM" href="/solutions/crm">Microsoft Dynamics CRM</a> and <a title="Salesforce.com CRM" href="/solutions/crm">Salesforce.com</a> (SFDC). In this blog I will review the capabilities that illustrate key strengths and differentiators between these two market leading CRM solutions. Let's take a look:

<strong>On-premise capability:</strong> This one is as clear as they come; Salesforce.com was born in the cloud and some believe they may have started the cloud revolution. Salesforce.com does not offer an on-premise option. Microsoft Dynamics CRM offers a robust on-premise solution and has recently invested heavily in their on-demand, cloud-based version of Dynamics CRM. If you require an on-premise solution, Microsoft is the only way to go. <strong>Winner: Microsoft Dynamics CRM</strong>

<strong>Mobile capabilities:</strong> Both solutions offer the ability to connect on mobile devices. <a href="http://www.salesforce.com/mobile/apps/" target="_blank">Salesforce's app</a> is free at all pricing levels and easy to install on any mobile device. However, to customize the app, a top tier <a href="http://www.salesforce.com/crm/editions-pricing.jsp" target="_blank">subscription</a> is required. Microsoft will be releasing enhanced mobile capability with Microsoft Dynamics <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/news/press/2012/feb12/02-06CRMMobilePR.aspx" target="_blank">CRM Mobile in Q4</a> (delayed <a href="https://community.dynamics.com/product/crm/crmnontechnical/b/crmconnection/archive/2012/07/06/q2-2012-service-update-new-delivery-schedule.aspx" target="_blank">from Q2</a>), but it comes with a price tag of $30 per user per month. The Q4 service update will allow customers to access the complete functionality of Microsoft Dynamics CRM on virtually any device with a new cloud-based, cross-platform, native mobile client service. Because SFDC's app is free out of the box and readily available on all mobile devices, I'm giving it the advantage here. But…I do believe Microsoft will continue to invest in this critical functionality. <strong>Winner: Salesforce.com…but check back after Microsoft’s Q4 2012 release.</strong>

<strong>Integration and customization flexibility:</strong> Both Microsoft Dynamics CRM and Salesforce.com offer robust functionality out of the box. For complex environments requiring significant customization and integration with other back-office applications, Microsoft's on-premise solution offers the most flexibility. While both solutions offer an open architecture, as a cloud offering, we have found that SFDC has established some restrictions and limitations. There are some very large organizations using SFDC, so you know that they have found a way to make it work for them. This is not a deal breaker, but it may require some creativity on our team's part to meet your unique requirements. <strong>Winner: Microsoft Dynamics CRM</strong>

<strong>Rapid Innovation:</strong> Microsoft is Microsoft; they are capable of delivering a superior product when they make the investment and they have made that investment in recent years. Microsoft’s 2011 release was a significant upgrade and Dynamics CRM isn't their only software application. For Salesforce.com, this IS their space. They are a leader in this market space and are rapidly enhancing and expanding their footprint within the industry. As a pure cloud solution, SFDC is able to innovate and deploy updates and enhancements easier than Microsoft. <strong>Winner: Salesforce.com…with Microsoft quickly catching up!</strong>

<strong>Social Enterprise Capabilities:</strong> Similar to my point about innovation, Salesforce.com leads the way with their go-to-market strategy of building a “<a href="https://www.salesforce.com/solutions/" target="_blank">social enterprise</a>,” allowing you to connect customers and employees. They launched this revolution with the advent of Chatter and continue to expand with connections to other social tools like Facebook and LinkedIn. Microsoft countered <a href="http://www.salesforce.com/chatter/overview/" target="_blank">Chatter</a> with the <a href="http://crm.dynamics.com/en-us/nov2011" target="_blank">Activity Feed</a> functionality, but will need to further develop this area of their solution. While I believe the “social enterprise” has merit, we are a long way from our marketing, sales and service teams fully embracing this functionality, especially in the midmarket space. Thus, before you drink the “Kool-Aid” on SFDC's social capabilities; be sure this is truly a game-changer and deciding factor before over committing to this capability. <strong>Winner: Salesforce.com</strong>

<strong>Document Management:</strong> Document management capabilities in Microsoft Dynamics CRM are based on SharePoint. Users can take advantage of a wealth of document management capabilities including the ability to create custom content types, check-in/check-out capability, track changes, and version control. Salesforce.com used to market a solution they called Salesforce Content. However, it seems they have moved to suggesting customers <a href="http://blogs.salesforce.com/community/2012/04/chatter-files-a-better-option-for-attaching-files-to-records.html" target="_blank">publish documents via Chatter</a>. This suggests to me that they do not have a clearly defined strategy for document management or that it is not that important. I think it is critical – and did I mention that SWC has a phenomenal track record with Microsoft SharePoint deployments? <strong>Winner: Microsoft Dynamics CRM</strong>

<strong>Apps marketplace:</strong> If this topic is unfamiliar, think about Apples' App Store. Salesforce.com's <a href="http://appexchange.salesforce.com/home" target="_blank">AppExchange</a> has thousands of third party applications to extend a CRM deployment and is a leader in this space. Microsoft has a similar <a href="http://dynamics-crm.pinpoint.microsoft.com/en-US/home" target="_blank">Dynamics Marketplace</a>, but as a new offering, does not have nearly as many available apps. I expect Microsoft's offerings to continue to grow, but it will take some time before it can ever rival SFDC's AppExchange. <strong>Winner: Salesforce.com…but is this important to you?</strong>

<strong>Cost:</strong> Simply put, Salesforce.com is pricey. I remember being an early user/adopter of SFDC back in 2003. Back then, it didn't cost much – in fact, I think it was free. Having grown from a few thousand to 100,000 customers, they can now charge a premium for their solution. As a cloud solution, they charge a per user per month subscription fee at varying levels based on needed feature sets. <a href="http://www.salesforce.com/crm/editions-pricing.jsp" target="_blank">Salesforce’s subscription fees</a> range from $65 to $250 per user per month. Microsoft's cloud option, On Demand, is $44 per user per month. Pricing and licensing of Microsoft Dynamics CRM’s on premise solution is complex and can vary based on the existing Enterprise Agreement (EA) a company may have in place with Microsoft. You'll need to factor in server costs on top of your user licenses. <strong>Winner: Microsoft Dynamics CRM</strong>

<strong>User interface:</strong> Microsoft Dynamics CRM provides you with a CRM solution right within the familiar Microsoft Outlook application. If you know Microsoft Office applications, you can quickly adapt to the Dynamics CRM application. Salesfore.com's interface is similar to today's social media sites with a very friendly, web-based user interface. As previously noted, basic functionality of these tools is the same. For some, the user interface becomes a matter of personal preference. Would you and your users prefer and adopt a UI that looks and acts more like Outlook or Facebook? <strong>Winner: You decide!</strong>

Here’s a quick summary for those scoring at home:

<strong>Salesforce.com</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Rapid Innovation</li>
	<li>Mobile App</li>
	<li>Apps Marketplace</li>
	<li>Social Enterprise Capabilities</li>
	<li>User Interface (if you prefer a user interface more like Facebook than Microsoft Office)</li>
</ul>
<strong>Microsoft Dynamics CRM</strong>
<ul>
	<li>On-premise Option</li>
	<li>Value/Cost</li>
	<li>Document Management</li>
	<li>Integration Flexibility</li>
	<li>User Interface (if you like the Outlook user experience)</li>
</ul>
We have a lot more to talk about, so keep checking back for more blog entries about these two market leaders and SWC’s growing CRM practice!

To learn more about Microsoft Dynamics CRM and Salesforce.com system solutions, please join <a title="Chicago IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">Chicago area IT consultants</a> SWC at our next <a title="Customer Relationship Management Event" href="/events">Customer Relationship Management event</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What Are Midmarket IT Professionals Saying About Microsoft Windows 8 Series</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/what-it-professionals-saying-about-microsoft-windows-8</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 07 Aug 2012 05:10:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5352</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In my last blog I mentioned that SWC hosts monthly Chicago area events on <a title="Microsoft Windows" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows</a> 8 and we have been asking our audience of midmarket <a title="IT Professionals" href="http://www.swc.com">IT professionals</a> what they think. Below is our latest video and my thoughts.

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/YyjJWploa4w?autoplay=1" title="Chicago IT Professionals Discuss Windows 8" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/win-8-videoplay.jpg" width="620" height="380" /></a>

I think this is great feedback from the Loyola Tech Guys! In my experience, probably one of the hardest audiences to please is techies, because they are early adopters of technology and have very high expectation for performance and fluidity. Techies also typically have the most applications to use, so hearing that the guys at Loyola have been using <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Windows 8</a> in production helps us backup Microsoft’s vision of blending consumerization and the enterprise. This really addresses the issues that consumers have using multiple devices like the iPad and Notebook. Windows 8 address these issues and gives business and consumer users the convenience of having one device for everything. Windows 8 meets the consumer’s needs for touch, ease of use, personalization, etc. AND the enterprise’s need for management and security.

Additionally, after talking to many midmarket IT professionals, I have learned that concerns are real in regards to how Windows 8 will fit in desktop environment. This goes along with our message that if you’re running Windows 7 on the desktop or planning a Windows 7 upgrade, there is no need to rush into thinking about Windows 8. Get Windows 7 deployed first and we will get you ready for Windows 8.

Subscribe to our blog and stay tuned, as SWC will continue to produce more Windows 8 videos at our events to share with you.

To learn more about how Microsoft Windows 8 can help you and your business, please join Chicago area IT consultants SWC Technology Partners for our next <a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Event" href="/events">Microsoft Windows 8 event</a> or follow <a title="Pete Lee LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/pete-lee/4/b2b/989" target="_blank">Pete Lee on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>SWC’s BI Expert Speaks at the TDWI Chicago Chapter Meeting</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/swc-bi-expert-at-tdwi-chicago-meeting</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Aug 2012 13:08:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5400</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Join Chicago area <a title="IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants</a> SWC’s Rachael Narel at the TDWI Chicago Chapter’s August 10th Meeting on <a title="Business Intelligence Solution" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence Solutions</a>. Rachael will discuss why BI solutions get a bad rap for being complicated, expensive, and take way too long to implement. She will also go over the challenges many organizations face trying to achieve their end goals, including decentralized and complex data structures; users who are too busy to provide the necessary process input and have a hard time articulating requirements; and how to find a solution that provides the needed features within the allocated budget.

Most companies utilize a waterfall approach to Business Intelligence projects, but at this event, Rachael will share a better approach – <a title="Agile Business Intelligence" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">agile business intelligence</a> and the components needed for a successful and complete BI solution. An agile approach gives organizations a pragmatic solution released to users for production and immediate feedback. From there, organizations can continue to build out the capabilities in a building block mode, iterating and constantly enhancing the features and capabilities over time. The result is a more affordable and impactful Business Intelligence project, resulting in a faster ROI and increased user adoption and support.

Register <a href="http://bit.ly/Mj56nB" target="_blank">here</a> to attend this informative and free Business Intelligence event.

To learn more about Business Intelligence please join Chicago area IT consultants SWC for their next informative <a title="Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a> or follow <a title="Rachael Narel LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/rachael-l-narel-cisa/0/8a5/889" target="_blank">Rachael Narel on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A Few Ways to Keep Employees Engaged and Have Fun in the Workplace</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/ways-to-keep-employees-engaged</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 14 Aug 2012 05:30:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[franpeters]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5479</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There is currently a huge demand for IT workers to fill hundreds of available tech jobs and <a title="Chicago Area IT Jobs" href="https://careers-swc.icims.com/jobs/search?ss=1&amp;searchLocation=&amp;searchCategory=&amp;hashed=0" target="_blank">IT positions</a>, especially in Chicago. Some may even argue that Chicago is becoming the new tech hub. At SWC, we too are currently hiring for many open IT positions. This is a direct result of our growth and the success we have seen as a company. More importantly, it is a reflection of our corporate culture and the great employees we have here who provide excellent service to our customers.

We are honored to have been externally recognized by many organizations this year for being one of the <a title="Best Places To Work In Chicago" href="/awards">best places to work in Chicago</a>. Beyond being a great place to work and having a great corporate culture, as an HR professional I am constantly thinking of new ways to keep our employees engaged and add value to our organization. One way we do this at SWC is through various informational, mentoring and social activities, which we feel are designed to create a sense of shared responsibility for the company’s success, bridge the gap between departments, and facilitate cross-functional collaboration. Here are a couple of ways we have fun at SWC and keep our employees engaged:

<strong>Mentoring Activities</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Some teams assigned IT Career Managers to each new hire to serve as an IT mentor and point of contact when it comes to different assignments and exposure to new technologies.</li>
	<li>Employees are also informally mentored by senior IT consultants, with whom they work side by side in implementing customer projects, enabling on-the-job learning.</li>
	<li>All employees receive a formal annual review to set future goals and assist with career advancement within the organization</li>
</ul>
<strong>Informational Activities</strong>
<ul>
	<li>We host regular ‘Lunch and Learn’ sessions sponsored by different departments enabling employees to learn about specific technology topics (Business Intelligence, IT Managed Services, SharePoint, Unified Communications, etc.).</li>
	<li>Employees are also invited to attend our Thursday informational lunches and <a title="Chicago Area  IT Events" href="/events">IT events</a> held at local restaurants for customers and prospects.</li>
	<li>Company financials, achievements and new initiatives are shared at the annual company meeting every year, along with management’s vision for the company’s future.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Social Activities Inside the Office</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Breakfast and Lunch – We bring in breakfast several times a month and lunch at least two times a week in conjunction with company meetings. We also always have healthy snacks and beverages available for our staff.</li>
	<li>Friday Happy Hour – This takes place at 4 pm in the SWC kitchen every Friday.</li>
	<li>Monthly Birthday Spread – Each month we celebrate all employee birthdays by bringing in a dessert assortment.</li>
	<li>Parties – We have random parties throughout the year. The last one was a huge Friday the 13th celebration related to receiving 13th Best Place to Work status from Crain’s Chicago Business. We gave away 13 big prizes (Xbox, Corn hole set, personal training sessions, iPad, iPod, vacation day, etc.) and had it fully catered.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Social Activities Outside the Office</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Annual Golf Outing – Golf and dinner.</li>
	<li>Annual Meeting /Team-Building – All annual meetings are held off-site at a fun setting followed by a team-building exercise. Recent sites/activities have included a TopGolf and a corn hole tournament, a race track outing, arcade games at Dave and Busters, and beach volleyball.</li>
	<li>Cubs Game Outing – This year we are renting the Budweiser Pavilion.</li>
	<li>Holiday Party – SWC sponsors an annual holiday party including SWC-paid hotel rooms for all employees.</li>
	<li>Summer Outing – These have included a private yacht cruise party on Lake Michigan.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Corporate Wellness Initiatives</strong>
Our employee wellness program is also unusually comprehensive. Highlights include:
<ul>
	<li>On-site fitness center</li>
	<li>Corporate-sponsored fitness activities, including participating in and training for the 3.5 mile Chase Corporate Challenge during ‘Test Your Time Tuesdays,’ and the SkyRise Chicago Race up the Willis Tower, intramural team sports and bike club.</li>
	<li>Fruit and veggie delivery service every Tuesday</li>
	<li>Healthy snack delivery (Greek yogurt, etc.) once a month</li>
	<li>Complimentary annual health screenings and gift cards for all employees who improve their health scores on that annual assessment, plus a drawing for a $1,000 gift card to reward health improvements</li>
	<li>Quarterly chair massages open to everyone</li>
	<li>Complimentary counseling service through our Unum Work-Life Balance Program</li>
</ul>
Please connect with me on <a href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/fran-peters-phr/19/a70/154" target="_blank">LinkedIn</a>, if you have any other great ideas on employee engagement to share.

Also, if you are looking to jump start your <a title="Chicago IT Careers" href="/careers">IT career</a>, please contact SWC today. You can also visit our careers page to watch our employee videos and browse our open <a title="IT Career Benefits" href="/careers/swc-benefits">IT career benefits</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A Quick Introduction to Microsoft SharePoint Portal Solutions</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/introduction-microsoft-sharepoint-portal-solutions</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Aug 2012 22:17:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5509</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a> is a popular and robust platform for <a title="Digital Design Website Building" href="/solutions/digital-design">building websites</a> and web-based applications, including document management, team collaboration and workflow solutions. In this video I will be focusing on SharePoint as a way to build effective communities via intranet and portal solutions. By providing an attractive and easily accessible way for your employees to connect with the people, information and the tools they need to get their work done, you can improve their productivity significantly. My goal is to provide you with a brief demonstration that will give you some insight into how <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-bring-value-to-business">Microsoft SharePoint 2010</a> can be used as a compelling and informative portal solution.

<a title="Introduction to SharePoint Portal Solutions" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/PEUMBvUU1lk?autoplay=1" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/video-sharepoint-lanham.jpg" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>

If you are interested in learning more about Microsoft SharePoint please contact SWC and join us for our next informative <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Events" href="/events">Microsoft SharePoint event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Lanham LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-lanham/22/125/a99" target="_blank">Jeff Lanham on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_metadesc</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
		<title>Chicago Area Full-Service IT Solutions Providers’ Internship Program</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/chicago-full-service-it-solutions-providers-internship-program</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 21 Aug 2012 15:14:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[franpeters]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5521</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I am very proud of SWC’s Internship Program. We offer paid internships to students who are currently enrolled in a college or university and are in good standing. SWC gives students the opportunity to learn and broaden their skills sets through our human resources, marketing, sales and technology-focused internships. We hire hardworking, highly-qualified candidates that we feel fit our corporate culture well. SWC’s Internship Program is a mutually beneficial experience. Our interns are given meaningful tasks that have an impact on our business and as a result, we do hire many interns as full-time employees from this program.

Here’s what our current interns have said about their experience and what they have learned working at SWC:

Great internships are often hard to find, especially those that provide an excellent learning experience for students in the field of their choice. In most cases, interns are not given the real-world experience necessary to succeed in future positions. As interns at SWC Technology Partners, we are thankful for this excellent opportunity that we have been given to gain extensive real-world experience and to see what a motivational employee culture is all about.

It is difficult not to notice the excellent working environment at SWC. There are smiling faces at every door eager to help in any situation regardless of their position or rank in the company. It has been so motivating to work with people who love their jobs and are excited to start their day at SWC. As interns, we have been welcomed into the culture and were able to attend the several events that have been held this summer. The most recent was the Chicago Cubs outing to Wrigley Field where we got to enjoy an exciting game and delicious food with our colleagues and friends.

We also had the privilege this summer to plan the 2012 SWC Olympic Games. This was an employee competition that consisted of two weeks’ worth of exciting events. It was a wonderful experience for us to learn how a business operated and to manage a project from start to finish. It was thrilling to get to plan and organize each event. SWC was eager to let us contribute our creative input. We were so thankful too that our ideas were heard by upper management and allowed to be executed. We did not expect to have this much autonomy and voice as interns.

As a Human Resource intern, you really get the chance to focus on learning and understanding each step of the recruiting process. You gain the necessary people skills to discuss positions openly with potential candidates. You also get to work on exciting HR projects in support of company needs. Teamwork is a key factor in any section of the company, but the HR department especially values the need to work in a team. This is a great opportunity that has provided the groundwork of experience needed to help us to exceed expectations in future positions.

As a Marketing intern there always is a chance for learning and developing essential marketing tools. As a crucial part of the marketing team you work with potential clients and update information in the database. You get to attend the many luncheons the company holds by assisting in preparation and event details. The marketing team is always observant of your interests and works hard to give you experience in each of those areas. This internship allows you to experience different aspects of marketing which will help you to excel in the future.

This company has not only helped us to expand our knowledge and professional experience, but has shown us the direction we would like to take our careers. Without SWC, we might have been trapped in a company that only trusted us to pick up their coffee. Thankfully, we were trusted and supported along our journey. We are so grateful to have had this experience that prepared us for the future ahead. We would like to thank all of our mentors for their continued help and support.

– Sarah Derry, Andrew Mullins, Marne Warda

SWC Technology Partners is a full-service <a title="IT Solutions Provider" href="http://www.swc.com">IT solutions provider</a> servicing Chicago and Chicago area small and medium sized businesses.  If you are looking to jump start your IT career, please contact SWC today. You can also visit our careers page to watch our employee videos, view our <a title="Chicago IT Job Benefits" href="/careers/swc-benefits">IT job benefits</a> and browse our open Chicago area <a title="Chicago IT Careers" href="/careers">IT career</a> positions including, <a title="Chicago Associate Engineer Job" href="/careers/chicago-information-technology-associate-engineer-job">Associate Engineer</a>, <a title="Chicago Business Engagement Manager Job" href="/careers/chicago-business-engagement-manager-job">Business Engagement Manager</a>, <a title="Chicago Entry Level Inside Sales Representative Job" href="/careers/chicago-entry-level-inside-sales-representative-job">Entry-Level Inside Sales Representative</a>, <a title="Chicago Lync Unified Communications Engineer Job" href="/careers/chicago-microsoft-lync-unified-communications-engineer-job">Lync - Unified Communications Engineer</a>, <a title="Chicago Microsoft Systems Engineer Job" href="/careers/chicago-microsoft-systems-engineer">Microsoft Systems Engineer</a> and <a title="Chicago Application Software Developer Job" href="/careers/chicago-application-software-developer-job">Application Software Developer</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>My Favorite Features of Hyper-V 3.0 on Windows Server 2012</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/virtualization/favorite-features-hyper-v-windows-server-2012</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Aug 2012 15:00:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[michaellee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5529</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The recent release of <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V" href="/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v">Hyper-V</a> 3.0 on Windows Server 2012 is very exciting to all of us in the <a title="Virtualization" href="/solutions/virtualization">virtualization</a> industry. I was lucky to get my hands on the product early and thought I would share my top five favorite features and of course, the benefits of Hyper-V 3.0 on Windows Server 2012. We will also be discussing these in more depth at our next Chicago area <a title="Chicago Virtualization Event" href="/html/email/virtualization/event/8302012-virtualization.html" target="_blank">virtualization event</a> on August 30, 2012.
<h2>Hyper-V Replica</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Replicates virtual machines between Hyper-V 3.0 hosts.
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> Because our engineer testing it exclaimed, “This is awesome!”…No, really, it’s cool because you can replicate your virtual machines from your production site to your alternate/recovery site – all with the built-in capabilities of Hyper-V 3.0.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> If you’ve been holding off on a pragmatic disaster recovery plan due to cost and complexity, Hyper-V Replica would be a great solution upon which to build your DR strategy.
<h2>Storage Live Migration</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Migrates Hyper-V virtual disks from one storage array to another without any downtime.
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> Our engineers have been drooling over this feature ever since they saw it on a competing product. It’s built into the base functionality of Hyper-V 3.0, which means you don’t have to fork over a fortune for an upgraded license to take advantage of this “premium” feature.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> Next time you invest in a shiny new SAN and want to quickly make use out of that investment, use the Storage Live Migration feature instead of manually copying things around. You’ll be glad you listened….you’re welcome.
<h2>Shared-Nothing Live Migration</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Live-migrates virtual machines between hosts without shared storage.
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> This is a cool bonus feature that is actually quite useful. And yep, it’s built into Hyper-V 3.0.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> If you want to virtualize your servers and don’t have enough dough for a SAN at the moment, you can now take advantage of the planned downtime benefits of server virtualization without a SAN using Hyper-V 3.0.
<h2>SMB File Share Support</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Deploys Hyper-V over SMB (Server Message Block – Microsoft’s file sharing protocol) version 3.0. Hyper-V can now store virtual machine files on your network shares.
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> This is the icing on the cake (which, by the way is the most coveted part of cake in my household!) Microsoft really didn’t have to add this functionality, but now that they have, it just makes a lot of sense.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> If you want to quickly get up and running with <a title="VMware Virtualization" href="/solutions/virtualization/vmware">virtualization</a> and start piloting the technology using your file server infrastructure, this feature nicely fits the bill.
<h2>Live Snapshot Management</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Merges and purges virtual machine snapshots on the fly.
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> VM snapshots are very useful, but Hyper-V admins really disliked the fact that with the previous version, you had to take the VM offline in order to manage the snapshots. Well, Redmond heard the groans loud and clear! You can now clean up your snapshots while the VM is running. Tell your admins about this improvement, and then take two steps back and watch them jump up and down with unbridled joy….
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> If you have business-critical virtual machines that must run 24x7, and you’ve hesitated applying important patches due to the lack of an easy way to back out, this feature will make it much more manageable to keep those machines running in tiptop shape.

To learn more, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Virtualization Event" href="/events">Virtualization event</a> or follow <a title="Michael Lee LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelilee" target="_blank">Michael Lee on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Top Features of Microsoft System Center 2012</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/top-features-microsoft-system-center-2012</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Aug 2012 21:28:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradellison]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5559</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This year, SWC has had quite a few events focused on <a title="Microsoft System Center" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft System Center 2012</a>. This is Microsoft’s comprehensive management platform which gives <a title="Chicago IT Professionals" href="http://www.swc.com">IT professionals</a> the power to easily and efficiently manage their IT environments. <a title="Microsoft System Center 2012" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">System Center 2012</a> empowers your IT staff, by giving them a common management toolset for your organization’s private and public cloud applications and services, helping you confidently deliver IT as a service for your business. In this blog, I thought I would share a few of the features I really like for those of you who may be debating whether Microsoft System Center 2012 is a good solution for your organization.

The first Microsoft System Center 2012 feature I like is its User-Centric Management. The User-Centric Management feature gives users the ability to access their applications on all of the different devices they log on to. They can also take this feature to the next level and set-up different software policies for each device. For instance, someone may need to access all of their applications on their primary desktop computer, but may also need applications on their mobile device while they complete work at client sites. User-Centric Management is the perfect solution for this scenario. Additionally, I think users are surprised at how easy this feature is to use.

The second Microsoft System Center 2012 feature I like is its dependency-based software distribution. This is a great application management tool, which is responsible for defining and setting deployment rules on all of your users’ many devices. For instance, this rule will ensure that there is enough space on a user’s device and that all required software pre-requisites are met before a user can install any new hardware or software. The dependency-based software tool makes IT’s job a lot easier.

The third Microsoft System Center 2012 feature I like is its software portal, which delivers non-critical applications to users in an on demand webpage fashion. Users can then install the specific applications they want on their own, without having to bother or ask IT. IT managers also have the ability to push out applications to certain user and device groups, tailoring them to the specific needs and job functions of the users.

The Fourth Microsoft System Center 2012 feature I like is its smartphone support. As I previously mentioned, System Center is a comprehensive management platform, meaning it gives you the ability to manage all of your devices, which includes smartphones. One small disclaimer though, smartphone support is “lite management” and can only be used through an Exchange Active Sync connector. To gain more flexibility and ‘Full Management’ of your mobile devices, consider implementing a PKI Infrastructure and installing certificates on your mobile devices. This will then allow you to push the Configuration Manager Client to your devices providing richer management capabilities.

Finally, I really like the fact that we can now manage our storage, networking, and any other underlying fabric from within System Center 2012. System Center 2012 allows us to capture and aggregate knowledge about the infrastructure, policies, processes and best practices, and allows businesses to optimize IT structures, reduce costs, improve application availability and enhance service delivery. System Center 2012 is designed to bring cloud benefits to the enterprise datacenter.

To learn more about how Microsoft System Center 2012 can help you and your Chicago business, please join SWC Technology Partners for our next Chicago area <a title="Microsoft System Center Events" href="/events">Microsoft System Center event</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Chicago Area IT Solutions Provider SWC Focuses On Work-Life Balance</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/chicago-it-solutions-provider-work-life-balance</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 29 Aug 2012 15:12:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[franpeters]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5627</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Many <a title="IT Consulting Firm" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consulting firms</a> talk about work-life balance throughout the interview process, then you find yourself in an IT position where you’re traveling to various different client’s sites across the country, feeling the pressure to constantly be “on” and never having the chance to power off your business pager, laptop or smartphone. You may only work “40 hours” on the actual client project, but that’s in addition to your regularly scheduled travel time, endless client meetings and always worrying about their status, 24/7. At SWC Technology Partners, we really do have work-life balance and it is what sets us apart as an <a title="IT Consulting Company" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consulting company</a>. Located just minutes from Chicago in Oak Brook, IL, our IT consultants only travel locally (Chicago area) to client’s sites, as needed. At the end of the day our IT consultants go home to their families, not an empty hotel room.

So what does work-life balance really mean for you and your <a title="Chicago IT Careers" href="/careers">IT career</a>? At SWC we promote a healthy work-life balance program which encourages our employees to efficiently complete work in a 40 - 45 hour workweek, while offering flex time and alternate work schedules. Our IT consultants work extremely hard during the week. The office is a fast-paced, busy environment that requires team members to focus, and simultaneously balance multiple projects. However, at the end of the day and on weekends, we encourage our employees to go home and decompress, and to spend quality time with their families and friends. During this time away from the office, we do not want our employees to worry about what’s going on back at the office. At SWC, we believe downtime is critical – it allows employees to go home to refresh, regenerate and then come back to the office energized and ready to work. SWC views this downtime as a true value. Time outside the office environment is not only important for our employees’ personal health, but for the overall health of the company. We are committed to our client’s success and that means a determined effort, but there is no reason that we can’t have fun along the way.

Another important aspect of work-life balance is personal growth. At SWC, we have many employees involved in a number of community-based initiatives, as well as family-related and recreational activities. SWC proudly promotes a family-oriented environment, and this includes supporting employees who may be little league coaches, or their child’s soccer or basketball coach. SWC encourages this important aspect of family life, and never tries to hinder it. By offering our consultants a very adaptable work environment that accommodates these personal and family-related commitments, SWC believes a healthy balance between both work and home can exist. We recognize that our team members have personal lives and responsibilities outside of the work environment, and we continually strive to create a healthy, happy, engaging and fun atmosphere, both inside and outside the office. As the SWC family continues to expand, we continue to work hard to maintain that personal, family feel, and make it a goal that our company’s priorities realistically align with our employee’s priorities.

We have learned that leadership needs to be open to the idea of flexibility. Just because an employee leaves the office before 5:00 pm doesn’t mean the work won’t get done. It just may mean making a few adjustments to accommodate that particular team member. Figure out a solution to potential barriers that come up and move forward. There’s always a way to make it work, and both the company and the consultants will be happier at the end of the day. Please connect with me on <a title="Fran Peters LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/fran-peters-phr/19/a70/154" target="_blank">LinkedIn</a>, if you have any other great ideas on work-life balance to share.

If you are looking to make a change and find work-life balance in your IT career, please contact SWC today. You can also visit our careers page to watch our employee videos and browse our open <a title="Chicago IT Positions" href="/careers">Chicago area IT positions</a>.
</content:encoded>

		<title>IT Consultancy SWC Featured In Microsoft Windows 8 Article</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/it-consultancy-swc-microsoft-windows-8-article</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Sep 2012 15:07:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5707</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The highly anticipated release of <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Microsoft Windows 8</a> is upon us and <a title="Chicago IT consultancy" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultancy</a> SWC has been hosting monthly Chicago area and online events for midmarket <a title="Chicago IT Professionals" href="/swc-technology-partners/about-swc">IT professionals</a>. At these events, we have showcased Windows 8 and shared how it will empower their users. Additionally, SWC has been gaining a lot of media coverage around Windows 8.

I encourage you to read the following BusinessNewsDaily article repost, “<a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Consumerization" href="/swc-technology-partners/news/microsoft-windows-8-consumerization-meets-its-match">Windows 8: Consumerization Meets Its Match</a>” to learn more about how Windows 8 will impact consumerization and SWC’s approach to a deploying Windows 8 for your business.

To learn more about how Microsoft Windows 8 can help you and your Chicago business, please SWC Technology Partners for our next <a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Event" href="/events">Windows 8 event</a> or follow <a title="Pete Lee LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/pete-lee/4/b2b/989" target="_blank">Pete Lee on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Why IT Solutions Provider SWC Was The Right Choice For Me</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/why-it-solutions-provider-swc-was-the-right-choice</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 06 Sep 2012 19:09:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elainegreen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5723</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Upon graduating college, I had plenty of options to pursue a career in a variety of different industries. Many of my friends chose to go to larger companies that recruited heavily at my school, and while that was great for them, I’d like to share why I was drawn to the technology industry and specifically, Chicago area <a title="Chicago IT Solutions Provider" href="/swc-technology-partners/about-swc">IT solutions provider</a>, SWC Technology Partners.
<ol>
	<li><strong>Technology is ever changing.</strong> Working in the technology industry means always being on the cusp of what’s new. From a salesperson’s perspective, this means I’m able to have new and interesting discussions with my customers all the time. A solution that may not have been right for them in an older version may be just the right solution for them now, and I’m able to facilitate that decision process.</li>
	<li><strong>I’m helping customers solve real life issues.</strong> As an account manager for SWC, I am not selling a commodity… I’m selling a relationship. My customers have real life business challenges they are trying to overcome, and it’s my job to help them find the solutions and services that will best address those concerns. We are not successful unless our clients are successful, and it means a lot to me when I get to make a difference for my customer.</li>
	<li><strong>I work with intelligent people.</strong> John Wooden is quoted as saying, “Whatever you do in life, surround yourself with smart people…” At SWC, I benefit daily from the shared insight and education I receive from my colleagues and superiors. I appreciate the patience and effort of the practice leaders here who go above and beyond to help me understand our solution areas better.</li>
	<li><strong>We are family.</strong> I know it sounds cheesy, but I have made some very solid relationships with people in the office. The people that work at SWC are genuinely good folks, many of whom I am happy to call my friends. We share lunches, birthdays, and other life events... I will never forget when my work comrades organized a surprise wedding shower for me last year… and actually surprised me. It really meant a lot.</li>
</ol>
For these reasons and more, I am delighted with my choice to work in the technology industry, and to have found a company like SWC.

Feel free to connect with me on <a title="Elaine Green LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/in/elainecgreen" target="_blank">LinkedIn</a>, if you would like to learn more about SWC’s solutions. If you are looking to jump start your <a title="Chicago IT Careers" href="/careers">IT career</a>, please contact SWC today. You can also visit our careers page to watch our employee videos and browse our open <a title="Chicago IT Positions" href="/careers">Chicago area IT positions</a>.
</content:encoded>

		<title>Chicago Area SWC&#039;s Managed Services VP Susie Cummings Honored</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/chicago-it-managed-services-susie-cummings</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Sep 2012 19:16:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[susiecummings]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5793</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Chicago area <a title="Chicago IT Solutions Provider" href="/swc-technology-partners/about-swc">IT solutions provider</a>, SWC is proud to announce that <a title="Susie Cummings SWC" href="/swc-technology-partners/leadership/susie-cummings">Susie Cummings</a>, Vice President of <a title="SWC Managed Services" href="/solutions/managed-services">Managed Services</a>, was selected for Nine Lives Media’s fifth annual MSPmentor 250 list. This global list identifies the world’s leading <a title="Managed IT Service Provider" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">managed services provider</a> (MSP) executives, entrepreneurs, experts, coaches and community leaders.

Susie Cummings has built SWC’s managed services practice from an initial remote network monitoring service into a remote helpdesk, <a title="Virtual DBA" href="/solutions/managed-services/virtual-dba">vDBA</a>, <a title="Microsoft SharePoint" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a>, security, on-site customer staffing and virtual CIO service. Under her direction, SWC has also been selected as one of the MSPMentor’s Top 100 Managed Services Providers in the world in 2011 and 2012.

The full MSPmentor 250 is available at http://www.mspmentor.net/250

To learn more about SWC’s <a title="Manged IT Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">Managed IT Services</a> offering, please join us for our next Chicago area <a title="Managed Services Chicago Event" href="/events">Managed Services event</a> or online webinar.  Follow <a title="Susie Cummings LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/susie-cummings/9/224/ba9" target="_blank">Susie Cummings on LinkedIn</a>.

	<item>
		<title>What is the Private Cloud?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/what-is-the-private-cloud</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 13 Sep 2012 18:14:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradellison]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5803</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The <a title="Private Cloud" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/top-features-microsoft-system-center-2012">Private Cloud</a> is a new IT model that allows organizations to better pool, provision and scale their infrastructure. It allows organizations to focus on the services that provide value to the business rather than the underlying fabric that is needed to deploy those services. Simply put, a Private Cloud delivers business functions as services. The ‘<a title="CRM Cloud" href="/blog/customer-relationship-management/choosing-the-right-crm-solution-part-ii">Cloud</a>’ is nothing mystical; don’t feed into all the hype. The cloud is simply a more efficient way to utilize your infrastructure and resources to deploy services throughout your organization. It is geared toward allowing organizations to focus more on the service offering to the organization rather than the storage, networking, servers and other underlying fabric that are used to provide these offerings.

When we speak about ‘Services’ in a Private <a title="Windows 8 Cloud" href="/swc-technology-partners/news/microsoft-windows-8-consumerization-meets-its-match">Cloud</a>, we are really talking about Applications that are encapsulated with all of the necessary configurations, Operating System files and underlying fabric that is needed to deploy those applications within the organization. Long gone are the days of configuring a single purposed physical server for a Line of Business Application you may have; not to mention all of the overhead associated in configuring and maintaining the networking, storage and security aspects that are needed to support the application. By the time you are done you have incurred much more time and cost in setting up the infrastructure than actually working on deploying the application to the organization. This time and cost is then magnified should you ever need to reconfigure the application or server hardware for whatever reason. The Private Cloud concept was built to address these shortcomings, and allows for a much more versatile, scalable and manageable compute environment.

The proliferation of the Private Cloud is built around concepts such as Self-Service, Resource Pooling, Elasticity and Analytics. All of which are achieved by leveraging the underlying technologies you use in your organization today; such as <a title="Chicago Virtualization" href="/solutions/virtualization">Virtualization</a>, High Availability and Shared Storage. We can now begin to shift our attention away from the individual components that make up your infrastructure and begin to focus more on providing the services and applications that provide value to your organization.

The Private Cloud allows us to provision only the resources we require for a given service, and encompasses the necessary security access, hardware resources, and deployment methods required by those services, while being totally geographically independent. That’s right, the Private Cloud isn’t limited to a single location, but rather it is defined by a collection of resources within your organizations jurisdiction. So whether you manage the cloud resources yourself in-house or subscribe to a cloud hosting service, or both; System Center 2012 has the tools and capabilities to provide a robust, efficient, manageable and scalable Private Cloud.

To learn more about how <a title="Microsoft System Center 2012" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft System Center 2012</a> can help you and your Chicago business, please join <a title="IT Solutions Provider" href="/swc-technology-partners/about-swc">IT solutions provider</a>, SWC Technology Partners for our next <a title="Chicago Microsoft System Center Events" href="/events">Chicago area Microsoft System Center event</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft SharePoint 2013 and the Modern Office Experience</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-2013-modern-office-experience</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Sep 2012 16:14:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5861</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft has recently released the preview versions of several key products, including Office 2013 and <a title="Microsoft SharePoint 2013" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint 2013</a>. <a title="IT Solutions Provider" href="/swc-technology-partners/about-swc">IT solutions provider</a>, SWC has been hard at work reviewing the new technologies, in order to determine which improvements will provide the most benefit to our clients.

A lot of the changes in SharePoint seem fairly evolutionary – after all, it has been around since 2001 and is now a mature product. While Microsoft has certainly provided many exciting enhancements in SharePoint 2013, one thing seems clear – the platform will continue to provide the same bottom-line business value that it has for some time now. It's still all about connecting people, information and tools with each other, in order to enhance information worker productivity. That means that the same challenges still exist, and the same fundamental approach to success is required.

The potential for a more revolutionary change comes in to play when you look at the synergy between the 'next wave' of products, including Office 2013, <a title="Microsoft Lync" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2010">Lync 2013</a>, <a title="Microsoft Exchange" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-exchange-2010">Exchange 2013</a> and <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Windows 8</a>. Microsoft calls this the 'Modern Office Experience' – a convergence of productivity, mobile, cloud and social capabilities across all kinds of hardware, including desktop, laptop, ultrabook, tablet and phone devices. Other new products like the Microsoft Surface tablet are going to give users the same full-featured Office capabilities as on the desktop. More importantly, it will be fully connected, highly manageable and enterprise-ready!

Microsoft might be poised for a big comeback with the next wave of 2013 products and the 'Modern Office Experience'. While I love my iPad and iPhone, the concept of running the full Office suite and other Windows applications all on my devices is very exciting. And, since cloud syncing facilitates seamless data and content sharing across devices – all of the time – I will be able to access any application, anytime I want, with better social, communications and search integration than ever before.

If you are interested in learning more about Microsoft SharePoint please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Microsoft SharePoint Event" href="/events">Microsoft SharePoint event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Lanham LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-lanham/22/125/a99" target="_blank">Jeff Lanham on LinkedIn</a>. You can also watch our <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Services" href="/perspective/videos/microsoft-sharepoint-services" target="_blank">Microsoft SharePoint Services</a> video to understand how SWC delivers <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Solutions" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint solutions</a> that drive adoption, satisfaction and success. In business the power to share is a fundamental component to success and at SWC Technology Partners, we are helping our Chicago area clients become more productive through collaboration.

<a title="Chicago IT Professionals SharePoint User Adoption" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/A361WVZL--U?autoplay=1&amp;rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=405"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sharepoint-user-experience.jpg" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>
</content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How Microsoft System Center 2012 Manages the Private Cloud</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/how-ms-system-center-2012-manages-private-cloud</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Sep 2012 19:12:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradellison]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=5966</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In my last blog post I explained what the <a title="Private Cloud" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/what-is-the-private-cloud">Private Cloud</a> was. So now I wanted to discuss how we create this Private Cloud and how we manage it. <a title="Microsoft System Center 2012" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft’s System Center 2012</a> is designed and built around the concept of the Private Cloud and provides a complete toolkit for your organization to create your very own Private Cloud.

Here are the System Center tools that allow organizations to adapt their very own Private Cloud:
<h2>System Center Virtual Machine Managers (SCVMM)</h2>
Virtual Machine manager is a pivotal tool in creating and managing your Private Clouds. VMM allows you to create and manage multiple Private Clouds based on your organization’s needs, and enables you to set security scopes for each cloud you create. SCVMM also allows you to provision all of the underlying fabric such as: Networking, Storage, Security, <a title="Virtualization Chicago" href="/solutions/virtualization">Virtualization</a> and orchestrated software patching. Once the fabric has been configured we can then create and deploy entire services from the VMM Console or Web Console. Further, you can set Quota Points for the amount of resources your cloud users can utilize when deploying services or VM’s to your clouds. This ensures your environment doesn’t become over capacitated. Finally, SCVMM allows you to manage your <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V" href="/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v">HyperV</a>, <a title="VMware Virtualization" href="/solutions/virtualization/vmware">VMware</a> and <a title="Virtualization Citrix" href="/solutions/virtualization/citrix-xenapp">Citrix</a> Zen Server Hypervisors. This allows organizations to become more flexible and better prepared to support multiple Hypervisors. Say you are acquiring a company that uses VMware, and your current environment is based around HyperV. Thanks to VMM 2012, we can simply attach the VMware clusters to VMM within minutes and begin managing and provisioning them.
<h2>System Center Application Controller (SCAC)</h2>
Application Controller is a superset of features that ride on top of VMM. Application Controller allows you to manage your Private Clouds like VMM, but it also allows you to manage any Microsoft Online Services you may have, such as Windows Azure. In larger environments with multiple VMM servers, Application Controller can manage all of the VMM servers from one console. You can then share content from different VMM Libraries, move VM’s from cloud to cloud (even if they are on different VMM servers, or mixed between onsite clouds and hosted clouds), and create and deploy services to any of the VMM servers and clouds you have configured. Finally, the web console in Application Controller allows you to deploy services and VM’s; the VMM web console only allows you to deploy VM’s. By configuring security scopes based on your needs and by deploying services through the web console, you have greatly reduced the time it takes to deploy entire solutions to your organization, while maintaining a high level of security.
<h2>System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM)</h2>
System Center Configuration Manager is becoming the industry standard for desktop deployment and management. SCCM is a powerhouse when it comes to Operating System Deployment, Application Deployment, Mobile Device Management, Patch Management and Asset Management. Included in SCCM 2012 is Microsoft’s Endpoint Protection, which is Microsoft’s solution for antivirus and antimalware. SCCM now allows administrators to deploy very robust and flexible Endpoint Policies to the desktop. The SCCM integrated console now gives you access to manage every aspect of your desktop management. But we’re talking Private Cloud right? How does SCCM fit in?

<strong>What does this means for the Private Cloud?</strong>
SCCM isn’t a cloud solution per say, but it does however provide many features to the System Center tools that do provide your Private Cloud services. I have listed some of these features below.
<ul>
	<li>SCCM provides orchestrated patching to your VMM host machines. What’s even better is that it gives access to the PXE Services, OS Deployment Services and Software Update Services that VMM can then use to deploy baremetal servers from scratch and manage them throughout their lifecycle.</li>
	<li>SCCM can deploy AppV Applications, MSI, Mobile Cabinet Files and OSX applications (In SP1) which we can use to deploy to the resources in our Private Cloud.</li>
</ul>
<h2>System Center Orchestrator (SCO)</h2>
Orchestrator is a workflow management solution for the datacenter. It allows organizations to automate many of the mundane tasks that are inherent in any environment. Orchestrator gives your Private Cloud an efficiency boost as we can now automate thousands of tasks throughout the entire System Center Suite, Active Directory, and many 3rd party vendors and products. By doing this, we free up the time of our engineers to focus on more strategic tasks relating to the organization's IT environment rather than creating user accounts, deploying software, configuring backups, configuring alerting, or manually configuring VM’s. Simply download the proper Orchestrator Integration Packs, configure your Runbooks, set your schedules, and sit back and relax and watch as Orchestrator makes quick work for all of the repetitive tasks in your current environment.

For example, let’s say we have a single Orchestrator Runbook that we’ve created. In that Runbook, we can create, configure and deploy a VM, install software on that VM, create an AD User Account, add the user to specific Security Groups, and then link the new VM to the new User Account in SCCM. The user logs in to the new VM and is off and running within minutes. Your creativity and organizational needs are the ingredients needed to create a very powerful and robust Orchestrator Deployment. But how can we leverage Orchestrator for your Private Cloud?

<strong>What does this means for the Private Cloud?</strong>
As you begin your journey to you own Private Cloud, you will find yourself doing the same tasks over and over. Things like creating AD accounts, creating VM Templates and configuring backups for your new resources will consume much of your time; and will create inefficiencies along the way. By utilizing Orchestrator 2012 you can now automate these processes in an accurate and controlled manner, allowing you to focus on more strategic tasks.
<h2>System Center Operations Manager (SCOM)</h2>
Operations Manager is a comprehensive and robust monitoring and alerting platform. We can monitor and alert on Windows, Unix and Linux devices. But that’s only the beginning! We can also monitor networking devices, and.NET and ASP has been added to SCOM’s Application Monitoring capabilities. With the new features of custom Dashboards and Security Roles, we can create granular dashboards and scope them to the appropriate audience. The SCOM hierarchy is Highly Available right out of the box in 2012! No need for Microsoft Clustering and added complexity for a Highly Available SCOM implementation. Did I mention that it has a web console too! But how does this assist in your move toward your Private Cloud?

<strong>What does this means for the Private Cloud?</strong>
In terms of your Private Cloud, SCOM can group resources based on their roles and monitor accordingly. Say you have just deployed four Exchange Services in your Private Cloud. We can group the Exchange Servers in SCOM and install the Exchange 2012 Management Pack and scope it to this group. Within minutes, we are monitoring all of the critical process and services for the Exchange Servers running in your Private Cloud. As your cloud grows, rest assured knowing that SCOM is there to monitor and alert on all of the critical pieces that make up your cloud environment from the physical network all the way up to your applications.

To learn more about how Microsoft System Center 2012 can help you and your Chicago business, please join <a title="IT Solutions Provider" href="/swc-technology-partners/about-swc">IT solutions provider</a>, SWC Technology Partners, for our next Chicago area <a title="Microsoft System Center Events" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft System Center event</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft Windows Expert Answers Windows 8 Questions</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/microsoft-windows-expert-answers-windows-8-questions</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 Sep 2012 20:35:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=6073</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[My colleague, Mike Romp and I have been hosting monthly events on <a title="Microsoft Windows 8" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Microsoft Windows 8</a> and are very excited about the product’s official release on October 26th. Mike has been using Windows 8 on his tablet, since the preview was released in February, so I thought I would have him answer some common Windows 8 questions our customers have been asking.

<strong><a title="Microsoft Windows" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows</a> 8’s new features have a heavy focus on touch screens, what will users who have not upgraded their hardware get from the new OS?</strong>

While many of the improvements in Windows 8 focus on touch-centric UI improvements, there are several new features that will benefit users of non-touch hardware.

First, Windows 8 is faster than its predecessor in startup times – much faster. This is due to Windows 8’s ability to hibernate just the system kernel. Windows 8 will also run on any machine capable of running Windows 7.

Second, users who upgrade can run the new <a title="IT Professionals Microsoft Windows 8" href="/blog/microsoft-windows/what-it-professionals-saying-about-microsoft-windows-8">Windows 8</a> applications. This probably won’t be a deciding factor for many organizations, but the number of Windows 8 applications is expanding every day. Eventually, users will be able to run the exact same applications across all devices, from desktops to tablets to smartphones.

Windows 8 provides much better multi-monitor support. Multiple monitors are becoming increasingly prevalent in today’s workforce, and Windows 8 finally addresses this from a UI level. Not only can users apply different background images to different monitors, but the taskbar can now be duplicated across all monitors. Additionally, Windows 8 applications can run alongside legacy desktop applications when using a multiple monitor setup.

Finally, there are a lot of minor tweaks that probably won’t affect the average user, but will really improve the desktop experience for us tech folk. Client <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V" href="/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v">Hyper-V</a> finally brings a real hypervisor to the client OS. The improved Windows Explorer along with its enhanced file copy dialog makes a lot of everyday IT tasks a lot more streamlined. And then there are the little under-the-hood things like native USB 3.0 support.

It’s important to note that even if a company isn’t ready to jump in with both feet, it still has the option of rolling out a hybrid Windows 8 deployment. These organizations can choose to upgrade only the executive and mobile workforce, while leaving the rest of the company on Windows 7. The same deployment infrastructures used for upgrading to Windows 7 can be easily extended to support Windows 8.

<strong>What types of organizations can benefit from an immediate upgrade to Windows 8 and what types of organizations should wait?</strong>

Since one of Windows 8’s main focuses is on mobility, any organization with a significant mobile workforce will benefit from Windows 8. The tablet form-factor is here to stay; however, the selection of tablets prior to Windows 8’s arrival had a paltry array of enterprise and line-of-business applications. Windows 8 finally combines the convenience and empowerment of mobility with the productivity and security of an enterprise-grade operating system.

Organizations with a large, static workforce could probably hold off on Windows 8 for a while. While there are definite improvements, it may be hard for these companies to justify the additional user training that will be required for Windows 8.

<strong>What factors should a company considering upgrading to Windows 8 take into account?</strong>

Any organization looking to upgrade to Windows 8, or even <a title="Microsoft Windows 7" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-7">Windows 7</a>, should consider their current deployment infrastructure. The old block-level, hardware-dependent imaging solutions of the past should be replaced with intelligent, hardware-agnostic deployment solutions.

For companies with a Microsoft Enterprise Agreement, the natural choice is <a title="Microsoft System Center" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft System Center</a> Configuration Manager. For companies with tighter budgets, the freely-available Microsoft Deployment Toolkit fits the bill. Both of these products allow for simplified and automated image deployment, as well as integration with the User State Migration Toolkit to ensure that all user data and preferences are transferred during the upgrade process.

To learn more about how Microsoft Windows 8 can help you and your business, please join Chicago area <a title="IT Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consultants</a> SWC Technology Partners for our next <a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Event Chicago" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows 8</a> event or follow <a title="Pete Lee LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/pete-lee/4/b2b/989">Pete Lee on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>My Favorite Features of Hyper-V 3.0 on Windows Server 2012 – Part Two</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/virtualization/favorite-features-hyper-v-windows-server-2012-part-two</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Oct 2012 21:59:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[michaellee]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=6147</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last month I wrote a blog discussing my top five favorite <a title="Favorite Features Of Hyper-V 3.0" href="/blog/virtualization/favorite-features-hyper-v-windows-server-2012">features of Hyper-V 3.0 on Windows Server 2012</a>. The blog was very popular, so popular that I have created a second blog on more of my favorite Hyper-V 3.0 features.
<h2>Incremental Backups</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Track changed blocks of VM disks for improved backup efficiency
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> Whenever I speak at an event, I like to ask the audience thought-provoking questions such as, “Are the White Sox a better ball club than the Cubs?”, or “ Will the Bears beat the Packers?”, or better yet, “Who here loves managing server backups?”. There’s usually an impassioned shouting match with the first two questions, but the third one stumps us all and keeps everyone in the audience very quiet. I’d like to think this is because my questions are profound, but the reality of the situation is that nobody likes dealing with backups. NOBODY! So anything that takes some of the sting out of backups is always welcome. <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V Solutions" href="/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v">Hyper-V</a> 3.0 drastically improves backup efficiency thanks to the built-in ability to track changed blocks of virtual hard disks. Supported backup software can then back up just the changed blocks, slashing the time it takes to back up your VMs.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> Your backups are the defensive linemen against would-be-disasters. Improving the efficiency and quality of the backups and thereby enhancing the business’ ability to recover from an outage will make you a hero.
<h2>Offloaded Data Transfer (ODX)</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Achieve near-native copy performance of large amounts of data by offloading the operations to the storage device
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> If you’ve ever tried to perform virtual hard disk maintenance tasks such as merge, move and compact, you know how painfully slow they can be. Offloaded Data Transfer (ODX) in Hyper-V 3.0, when used with “copy offload” capable SAN hardware, lets the storage system perform the large file copy operations without the Hyper-V host reading the content from one storage array and write it to another.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> Get the most out of your Hyper-V host and storage hardware, which translates to lower CAPEX and OPEX.
<h2>Virtual Fibre Channel Support for VM</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Access Fibre Channel SAN LUNs directly from VMs
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> Let’s face it: Fibre Channel (FC) SAN is not cheap. Although iSCSI has gained in popularity, FC isn’t going anywhere anytime soon. If you have invested in FC SAN, you’ll be happy to know that now with Hyper-V 3.0, you can access the LUNs directly from the VMs, which extends the usefulness of the investment. For example, if you have systems that use direct access to FC storage and want to keep it that way, you can virtualize such workloads with Hyper-V. Support for FC in Hyper-V includes guest OS clustering, live migration, multi-path IO (MPIO), and N_Port ID <a title="Virtualization Services" href="/virtualization">Virtualization</a> (NPIV), opening up new ways to leverage your investment.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> Let your CFO know that you’ll be repurposing your existing hardware to improve the ROI and TCO. You might actually get that bump in the IT budget that you’ve been looking for. Everyone wins.
<h2>Dynamic Memory Improvements</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> Significantly improved virtual machine memory management
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> Windows Server 2008 R2 SP1 introduced dynamic memory for Hyper-V. In Windows Server 2012, significant improvements have been added to dynamic memory including Hyper-V Smart Paging for a more reliable VM restarts and the ability to change dynamic memory configuration on the fly. These improvements result in better VM density per host, reliability of Hyper-V operations, and a more flexible infrastructure.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> Your VP of Finance will like the fact that you are right-sizing the hardware instead over-buying “just in case.” Improving the reliability of the server infrastructure will make everyone happy.
<h2>Non-Uniform Memory Access (NUMA) Support for VM</h2>
<strong>What it is:</strong> NUMA support for VMs increases memory access performance
<strong>Why it’s cool:</strong> The basic concept of NUMA is that a processor can access memory that is local to itself faster than memory that is remote (on another processor). With NUMA improvements in Hyper-V 3.0, the guest OS and applications can make intelligent decisions for efficient memory mapping. Got a resource-hungry, NUMA-aware workloads like Microsoft SQL Server? NUMA can help you get even more juice out of that SQL VM.
<strong>Why it matters for business:</strong> Make your customers and business units happy by improving performance of demanding applications.

To learn more, please join us for our next informative <a title="Virtualization Events" href="/events">Virtualization event</a> or follow <a title="Michael Lee LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelilee" target="_blank">Michael Lee on LinkedIn</a>.
</content:encoded>

		<title>SWC Video Featuring Microsoft SharePoint Customization And Design</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/swc-video-microsoft-sharepoint-customization-design</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 04 Oct 2012 21:17:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=6175</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="Microsoft SharePoint Solutions" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a> is a leading search, portal and content management platform with over 36.5 million users. Unfortunately, SharePoint out-of-the-box can leave some businesses wanting a more visually appealing and functional platform. That’s why manufacturer and distributor of luxury home furnishings Holly Hunt engaged SWC's SharePoint and <a title="Chicago Digital Design Services" href="/solutions/digital-design">Digital Design</a> teams to create a compelling SharePoint intranet portal. SWC’s <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Design Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint design</a> gives employees an aesthetically pleasing user experience that encourages adoption and provides them the tools that they need to collaborate and get their work done.

<a title="Microsoft SharePoint Customization And Design By IT Solutions Provider SWC" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/X_TuBnUQGsA?autoplay=1" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/vid-hollyhunt-lrg2.jpg" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>
