	<item>
		<title>Microsoft Lync Weathers The Storm</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-weathers-storm</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Oct 2013 21:04:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradcooper]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10292</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Whether its rain, snow, sleet or hail, <a title="Microsoft Lync Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a> offers by far the best solution for bad weather! Unlike many other VoIP systems, which require complex VPN setups for their external phones, Microsoft Lync phones can be taken off-campus and simply plugged into a home network, so that users can sign in conveniently from wherever they are. For companies that have a mobile workforce or in the event of bad weather, Microsoft Lync can keep your office or call center up and running, on or offsite.

Microsoft Lync gives users the capability to make voice calls from their computers, smartphones and mobile devices or with a Lync enabled desk phone. Using these devices is easy; users just follow the same steps they complete in the office, enabling them to answer business calls as if they were on your corporate LAN.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-10295" title="Microsoft Lync Platforms And Devices" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-lync-platforms-devices-600.jpg" alt="Microsoft Lync Platforms And Devices" width="600" height="373" />

A great example of Lync weathering the storm is SWC’s <a title="Chicago Managed IT Services" href="/solutions/managed-services">Managed Services</a> Help/Service Desk. SWC’s <a title="Managed Help Desk Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-help-desk-service-desk-services">Service Desk</a> provides 24x7 support to many customers – rain or shine. During this past winter, massive amounts of snow threatened SWC’s service desk workers’ ability to get safely to work. Microsoft Lync came to the rescue, enabling employees to take their desk phones home with them the night before, giving them the option to answer direct calls and call center calls from the comfort of home, minimizing the risk of driving in the snow and hazardous conditions, but also ensuring continued operations and 24x7 service and support to customers.

Why risk your worker’s health or the health of your business when the roads are unsafe due to bad weather? With Microsoft Lync, there’s no need to have your workforce or your business suffer – just take your phones home and work as if you are in the office. Your employees will appreciate the flexibility and your customers will appreciate your ability to remain available for them during bad weather. Fall is here and winter is right around the corner – work safe, work anywhere with Microsoft Lync.

To learn more about Microsoft Lync 2013, please join us for our next <a title="Microsoft Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Microsoft Unified Communications event</a>.

If you enjoyed this post, please read a few of our recent blogs about Microsoft Lync and <a title="Unified Communications Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Unified Communications</a>:

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What’s a Great CRM Tool for Your Sales Team</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/whats-a-great-crm-tool-for-your-sales-team</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Oct 2013 13:35:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elainegreen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10317</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC offers <a title="Customer Relationship Management Services" href="/solutions/crm">Customer Relationship Management</a> (CRM) solutions that help sales teams effectively manage the customer lifecycle and cultivate market-share. We asked our sales team lead to share one of her favorite CRM tools that is helping make our sales team more productive. Watch this week’s “Ask SWC” video to learn more.

<a title="Great CRM Tool For Your Sales Team" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/VrKHUezPPn8?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

In this episode of “Ask SWC,” our Sales Team Lead, Elaine Green sits down to discuss her favorite feature of CRM, the contact dialer. The contact dialer is a CRM tool our sales team cannot live without. Within this custom built application, the sales team is able run advanced find searches within CRM based on certain criteria, such as area codes or job titles. They are then able to pull all of the data they find into a simple yet robust dialer screen. For example, the sales team can run a query on IT analysts to invite to an upcoming Chicago event. The tool instantly sorts through thousands of contacts providing the team with a list to directly target, saving them time. Using the contact dialer ensures our sales team is calling on the right contacts at the right time for the right event, making them more productive and efficient.

To learn more about how the right Customer Relationship Management system can profoundly affect how an organization captures and cultivates market-share, please join us for our next information <a title="Chicago CRM Events" href="/events">CRM event</a> or follow <a title="Elliott Baretz LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/elliott-baretz/6/582/272" target="_blank">Elliott Baretz on LinkedIn</a>.

If you enjoyed this post, check out a few of our past posts on Customer Relationship Management:

	<item>
		<title>Let Microsoft Lync Sweat The Small Stuff</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/let-microsoft-lync-sweat-the-small-stuff</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Oct 2013 17:30:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10349</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Throughout the course of the business day, do you realize how many “small things” take time away from big picture goals? Waiting for a colleague to reply to your email? Looking for the Sales Manager who may or may not be in the office? Scrolling through reply after reply on a long chain of emails, or even trying to cobble together different chains of emails that should all be in one place?

With <a title="Microsoft Lync Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a> at your disposal you can spend your time and energy on the big picture. Instant messaging through Lync provides real time communication. No more waiting for email replies; just send an instant message to your colleague. No more wandering the halls looking for people, when Microsoft Lync’s presence indicator provides visibility into the immediate whereabouts of your contacts – from their physical location to their current availability for chat or a phone call. It even gives you the ability to schedule an impromptu meeting with team members dispersed in several geographic areas.

Another useful <a title="Chicago Unified Communications" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Unified Communications</a> feature in Lync is its persistent chat capabilities. Persistent chat provides collaboration by consolidating group communication into a single location. Persistent chat rooms even retain that communication for future reference. Lync Meetings are also a great way to collaborate with team members near or far. With video and voice capabilities, as well as application, desktop and file sharing technologies native to Lync, there is nothing you can’t effectively and easily communicate.

Stop sweating the small stuff and let Microsoft Lync increase your productivity, enhance your visibility and improve your ability to communicate.

To learn more about SWC’s Microsoft Lync solution offering, please join us for our next <a title="Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Unified Communications event</a> or follow <a title="Anthony Caragol LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/anthony-caragol/6/48/488" target="_blank">Anthony Caragol</a> on LinkedIn.

If you enjoyed this post, please read a few of our recent blogs on Microsoft Lync:

<a title="How SWC &amp; Microsoft Lync Prevent Visibility Issues At Wittenstein" href="/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-prevents-visibility-issues-wittenstein">How SWC &amp; Microsoft Lync Prevent Visibility Issues At Wittenstein</a>
<a title="Microsoft Lync 2013: Cutting Costs and Helping Businesses Grow" href="/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013-cutting-costs-helping-businesses-grow">Microsoft Lync 2013: Cutting Costs and Helping Businesses Grow</a>
<a title="What Chicago Area Businesses Are Saying About Microsoft Lync" href="/blog/unified-communications/what-chicago-businesses-are-saying-about-microsoft-lync">What Chicago Area Businesses Are Saying About Microsoft Lync</a>
<a title="Microsoft Lync 2013 Resiliency Enhancements" href="/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013-resiliency-enhancements">Microsoft Lync 2013 Resiliency Enhancements</a>
<a title="New Microsoft Lync 2013 Server Features" href="/blog/unified-communications/new-microsoft-lync-2013-server-features">New Microsoft Lync 2013 Server Features</a>
<a title="Microsoft Unified Communications…A Game Changer" href="/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-unified-communications-game-changer">Microsoft Unified Communications…A Game Changer</a>
<a title="Using Microsoft Lync As A Phone System" href="/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-phone-system">Using Microsoft Lync As A Phone System</a>

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Are Your Favorite Career Development Initiatives</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-are-your-favorite-career-development-initiatives</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Oct 2013 14:04:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[patrickorourke]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10362</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC Technology Partners has won various <a title="SWC Awards" href="/swc-technology-partners/awards">awards</a> and recognitions for our workplace culture over the years, including Crain’s Chicago Business’ Best Places to Work and Chicago’s 101 Best and Brightest Companies to Work for. SWC’s award winning culture is focused on our commitment to employees and helping them succeed. Watch this week’s episode of “Ask SWC” to discover some of SWC’s career development initiatives.

<a title="Career Development Initiatives At SWC" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/cyZ-6nFtvhE?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

SWC has a variety of career development initiatives that help employees achieve long-term professional growth. Some of these initiatives include:
<ul>
	<li><strong>Employee Lunch and Learns:</strong> Employees get valuable insights to help them succeed through SWC’s monthly lunch and learns focused on new projects and up-and-coming technology. These lunch and learns help employees stay up-to-date on all of the information they need to know within the company.</li>
	<li><strong>Certifications:</strong> SWC supports and encourages employees to get professional technical certifications and to continue educating themselves on new technology. Employees at SWC are encouraged to ‘test out’ and gain hands-on learning experience with these new technologies in our onsite learning lab.</li>
	<li><strong>Mentorship and Career Development:</strong> SWC has a mentorship and career management program that helps customize career paths for each individual to make sure they are achieving their long-term goals for professional growth. Through this program employees gain valuable experience and exposure to new technologies by shadowing senior consultants, helping them expand their skillset and achieve more in the future.</li>
</ul>
SWC is always looking for talented and intelligent individuals who are passionate about technology and want to grow their careers. To learn more about SWC’s career initiatives head over to <a title="Chicago IT Jobs" href="/careers">SWC Careers</a> or follow <a title="Patrick O'Rourke Linked-In" href="http://www.linkedin.com/in/patricktorourke" target="_blank">Patrick O’Rourke on LinkedIn</a>.

If you enjoyed this post about SWC’s career development initiatives, please read a few of SWC’s other pieces on our award winning employee culture:

<a title="SWC Earns Fifth Consecutive Chicago’s Best and Brightest Companies to Work For" href="/swc-technology-partners/news/swc-fifth-chicagos-best-brightest-companies">SWC Earns Fifth Consecutive Chicago’s Best and Brightest Companies to Work For</a>

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: Salesforce Goes Social with Chatter</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/salesforce-goes-social-with-chatter</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Oct 2013 22:03:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[markjohnson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10398</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The word of the day is Chatter. What is Chatter? We like to think of it as <a title="Salesforce.com CRM" href="/solutions/crm/salesforce-com-customer-relationship-management">Salesforce.com</a>’s version of Twitter. Watch this week’s episode of ‘Ask SWC’ to learn more about this cool new feature and how it’s helping organizations connect with their customers in real-time and new ways.

<a title="Salesforce Goes Social With Chatter" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/9sg4M_K8cuo?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

Salesforce.com is a cloud based <a title="Customer Relationship Management Services" href="/solutions/crm">Customer Relationship Management</a> (CRM) solution for sales force automation, customer service, partner management and marketing and campaign management. The solution’s ability to be on top of every lead, opportunity and customer interaction provides a huge advantage for users. One of the ways the platform does this is through a new social business feature called Chatter.

Chatter helps Salesforce.com users to build secure online communities by connecting users, groups and customers in a constant dialog. Once a user logs into their Salesforce.com account, they can use the Chatter feature to hashtag different events and tag people, so that they will be included in conversations that are relevant to them. By looking through your Salesforce Chatter feed, you can see anything that you were tagged in or any topics that were hashtagged that you may be interested in learning more about. Chatter is a great new feature that helps users quickly find experts, increase resolution time, convert more sales and make decisions faster.

If you would like to chat about chatter, please join us for our next informative <a title="Salesforce.com Events" href="/events">Salesforce.com event</a> or follow our Go-To-Market leader <a title="Elliott Baretz LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/elliott-baretz/6/582/272" target="_blank">Elliott Baretz on LinkedIn</a>.

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft Unified Communications: A Process Transformer</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-unified-communications-process-transformer</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 17 Oct 2013 10:12:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[greghanus]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10413</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Most of the customers who contact SWC about our <a title="Microsoft Unified Communications Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Microsoft Unified Communications services</a>, are looking to replace their existing telephony solution. Initially, they are looking for something with new features that will allow them to continue to communicate and conduct business in the same ways they are used to communicating with one another. Microsoft Unified Communications has often been called a disruptor in this area and for good reason. Many clients, who have made the switch, have found that the old way of communicating and doing things can be transformed into something much better with <a title="Microsoft Lync Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a>. An example of one of these process transformations, one that our engineers are often asked about, is Microsoft Lync’s paging capabilities.

Many businesses migrating from an old PBX solution love their traditional paging systems. These systems work great for simple office announcements or to help locate users. But when we’re talking about the modern office environment and taking advantage of the latest technology and best of breed solutions, there are some issues with paging that don’t translate so well. A traditional paging system fails the modern office environment for many reasons – you can’t take it anywhere, the user has to be in the building for it to be effective, they tend to lock businesses into a platform and it’s basically becoming redundant in today’s mobile office.

Can a business have the modern office experience and keep their paging system too? The answer is yes! While it’s true that Microsoft did not include native support for paging in Lync as it translates to legacy systems, there is third party hardware that connects directly into Lync, or can connect to a universal paging system with an analog port. These Lync certified devices allow us to plug into outdoor intercoms, keypad intercoms and overhead ceiling speakers.

But – there are also many different process transforming scenarios that will arise with the whole new world of capabilities that Microsoft Unified Communications brings to a business, which makes the notion of paging users seem a little antiquated. Why page a user’s phone when you can send a quick IM, or page a user to see if they are available when you can quickly see their status through Microsoft Lync’s presence indicator? Not only are we able to reach out to users who are in the office, mobile clients also allow us to communicate and check presence for our out-of-office users with the same ease. It’s as if the end user was working near our desk. When we look at the possibilities of Microsoft Lync and Unified Communications, we find that some of the old ways of doing things like audible paging fade away with new simpler methods of locating people.

To learn more about Microsoft Unified Communications, please join us for our next <a title="Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Unified Communications event</a> or follow our Go-To-Market leader <a title="Adam Ferguson LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/adam-ferguson/32/71/4b4" target="_blank">Adam Ferguson on LinkedIn</a>.

If you enjoyed this post, please read a few of our recent blogs on Microsoft Unified Communications:

<a title="Microsoft Unified Communications…A Game Changer" href="/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-unified-communications-game-changer">Microsoft Unified Communications…A Game Changer</a>

	<item>
		<title>My Fantasy IT Team</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/my-fantasy-it-team</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Oct 2013 12:52:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[susiecummings]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10432</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Football season is finally underway, which is always a fun and exciting time for me, as friends and family gather together to watch the game. Many of them are cheering for their favorite teams, but some of them are rooting for the players that comprise their fantasy football teams. This got me thinking about IT and SWC’s midmarket clients. If they had the ability to pick a fantasy <a title="Chicago Managed IT Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">IT team</a>, who should be on it?

Depending on the size of the company, I think you would need at least three types of resources:
<h2>CIO</h2>
This person would have a broad understanding of technology and how technology can be used to improve the business, whether it’s being more competitive or setting up a foundation that will allow the company to grow, or putting the tools and resources in front of employees to allow them to do their jobs more effectively and deliver better service for their clients. This person definitely has a technology background, but a business focus – you need that person to be able to connect the two. Either one of them working independently is a recipe for disaster.
<h2>Engineer</h2>
The engineer is important because you need somebody to execute the plan. The CIO is going to come up with the strategic plan in working with the business and the engineer is going to execute that. The perfect engineer is someone who has all of the depth and breadth of experience that you need across a wide range of technologies that are very apparent in today’s businesses. Those people are hard to find, but would probably be at the top of my list!
<h2>IT Delivery/Support</h2>
This is someone who is delivering support to the end users. Someone who is really focused on customer service has a good technology background. They are very focused on problem solving and being tenacious and delivering that service, so that the users can effectively engage in technology to do their jobs better…we all know happy employees make the business more money.

If you would like to learn more about SWC’s <a title="Chicago Managed Services" href="/solutions/managed-services">Managed Services</a> offering or are looking for assistance in building your strategic fantasy IT team, please or join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Managed Services Events" href="/events">Managed Services event</a> or connect with <a title="Susie Cummings LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/susie-cummings/9/224/ba9" target="_blank">Susie Cummings on LinkedIn</a>.

If you enjoyed reading this post, please take a moment to read a few of Susie’s past posts on strategic IT managed services.

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Does ExactTarget Offer for Marketers?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-does-exacttarget-offer-for-marketers</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 24 Oct 2013 12:03:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elliottbaretz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10450</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of ‘Ask SWC,’ we discuss Connections 2013, ExactTarget’s recent digital marketing conference in Indianapolis, IN. Watch our video to learn more about this exciting event, SWC’s partnership with ExactTarget and what it has to offer digital marketers.

<a title="ExactTarget's Exciting Offerings for Marketers" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/z6YBoCCg0CA?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

ExactTarget is a cloud based, on-demand email marketing and digital communication platform SWC has helped customers integrate into their <a title="Salesforce.com CRM" href="/solutions/crm/salesforce-com-customer-relationship-management">Salesforce CRM</a> systems. The recent ExactTarget user’s event, Connections 2013 was a very impressive week full of education and inspiration focused on energizing marketers and industry experts to “lead from within.” Now that I am back from the conference, I’m still excited and enthusiastic about the product and it’s been a while since I’ve been to a conference and felt like that. You can just feel when you are with a company and they are at a special place, right now ExactTarget is a special company in a special place.

ExactTarget was recently acquired by Salesforce, the world’s number one sales, service and marketing app. The company will still, however maintain their autonomy and independence. They have a very clear mission in terms of what they are doing in the digital world and digital marketing place. I really think they have their act together and it’s just one of those things where I walked away from the conference thinking that this company is in that golden triangle right now.

Over the next couple weeks I am going to be spending some time wrapping my arms around the new announcements and enhancements ExactTarget is making to their platform, so stay tuned for those. Specifically the enhancements around predictive analytics and what it means to digital marketers. They have something new called Journey Builder, a cloud based lifecycle marketing application that delivers personalized customer experiences to large scale audiences. If you’re a marketing geek like me, it’s very exciting – technology finally catching up with the vision that all of us have had for some time.

If you want to learn more about ExactTarget, please join us for our next Mastering Digital Marketing through <a title="Chicago Salesforce.com Event" href="/events">Salesforce event</a>.

If you enjoyed this post, check out a few of our past posts on Customer Relationship Management:

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What is User Enablement Training?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-is-user-enablement-training</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Oct 2013 10:09:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[wendygrahn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10490</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Customer or user enablement training is a really important element of any technology implementation. This is often overlooked by customers and something most consulting firms don’t offer. Instead of just putting a technology solution in place and hoping the investment pays off, SWC offers user enablement training to ensure our customers are finding success and user adoption with the new technology solutions we implement. Watch this week’s episode of ‘Ask SWC’ to learn more about how user enablement training can benefit your organization and sets SWC apart from the competition.

<a title="SWC's User Enablement Training" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/EnKizRWbbj8?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

Customer enablement is a really important element in any technology implementation, whether it’s <a title="Microsoft Business Intelligence" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Microsoft Business Intelligence</a>, <a title="Microsoft CRM Consulting" href="/solutions/crm">CRM</a>, <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Consulting" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a>, <a title="Unified Communications Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Unified Communications</a> or any other technology solution. At SWC we actually offer this as a benefit to our customers through our consulting services, which is something unusual that we’ve found most consulting firms don’t do. Instead of just putting a solution in place and hoping the investment pays off, SWC adds that “extra bonus” of communication planning, training planning and user adoption planning. We roll all of this into a service or term we call user enablement training.

The first step is communication planning and it is really critical to the success of any project. Most customers actually forget about this step and then, once the solution is rolled out to their users, they wish they would have provided more information or communication at the beginning of the project to ensure its success and user adoption. At SWC, we try to get our customers thinking about this early on in the project, so that we can get users excited about the new technology investment the organization is making and ensure it will be adopted. SWC’s years of experience creating communication planning and user enablement programs, ensures our customer’s communication plans are written well and designed properly.

Once the solution has been deployed and put in place, we begin our user enablement training program, so that the customer and users actually know how to use the solution, further making sure the technology investment pays off. Our solution takes a technology project from just a check list of – “Yes, we implemented this solution for our users,” to a really great check list of – “Yes, we put this technology in place and our users actually using it and being more productive and finding success with it.”

By engaging SWC in customer or user enablement training an organization will receive communication planning upfront, an end user training program that might go on after the solution has been put in place and then finally our best practices for basic user adoption programs and a proven methodology on how to get your users excited about the solution. We want users to want to use it and feel like the organization has given them a new solution to enable them to do their jobs better.

For more information on great <a title="Technology Solutions Provider" href="/swc-technology-partners/about-swc">technology solutions</a>, especially SWC’s customer and user enablement solutions, visit our website at <a title="SWC Technolgoy Partners" href="http://www.swc.com">www.swc.com</a>.

If you enjoy this series, check out a few of our past “Ask SWC” videos:

	<item>
		<title>Is Anyone Really Using Lync As A PBX? (Spoiler Alert: YES!)</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/is-anyone-really-using-microsoft-lync-as-a-pbx</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Nov 2013 10:01:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10514</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I don't typically write blogs that reference other blogs, but one of the traditional fears around Lync as a PBX replacement is that it's too new or not mature enough. Those fears have mostly dissolved as Lync has proven itself repeatedly in the last few years in organizations of all sizes (and all sizes deployed by SWC). Here is a recent blog written by the Microsoft Lync team that was too interesting not to share: <a href="http://blogs.technet.com/b/lync/archive/2013/10/21/lync-voice-leading-in-enterprise-shipments.aspx" target="_blank">http://blogs.technet.com/b/lync/archive/2013/10/21/lync-voice-leading-in-enterprise-shipments.aspx</a>.

We all know that Microsoft Lync's market share may seem small compared to some of the tenured telephony giants, but its growing fast. In fact, <a title="Microsoft Lync Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a> is growing faster in the enterprise voice space than any other technology company in the world. Here are some stats on this from Microsoft:
<ul>
	<li>In 2013, almost 60% of enterprises (500+ seats) have deployed or plan to deploy <a title="Unified Communications Microsoft Lync" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Microsoft Lync</a>, including enterprise voice, this is up from 45% last year</li>
	<li>The proportion of enterprises with no plans to deploy Microsoft Lync for voice has dropped dramatically, from 21% down to only 7%</li>
	<li>One in four enterprises report Microsoft as their preferred vendor for IP-PBXs, this was unheard of in 2010</li>
</ul>
These stats are really exciting! For those of you unsure where Lync fits, or if it's mature enough to be your PBX platform, rest assured that not only are SWC's clients in love with it, but so is everyone else. It's a very exciting time and we're here to help!

To learn more about Microsoft Lync, please join us for our next <a title="Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Unified Communications event</a> or follow <a title="Anthony Caragol LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/anthony-caragol/6/48/488" target="_blank">Anthony Caragol on LinkedIn</a>.

<h2>Chicago area Microsoft Lync consulting services 630.572.0240.</h2>

If you enjoyed this post, please read a few of Anthony’s past blogs on Microsoft Lync:

<a title="Using Microsoft Lync As A Phone System" href="/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-phone-system">Using Microsoft Lync As A Phone System</a>
<a title="The End of Threat Management Gateway from a Unified Communications Perspective" href="/blog/unified-communications/threat-management-gateway-unified-communications-perspective">The End of Threat Management Gateway from a Unified Communications Perspective</a>
<a title="Microsoft Lync 2013 Resiliency Enhancements" href="/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013-resiliency-enhancements">Microsoft Lync 2013 Resiliency Enhancements</a>
<a title="We’re One Step Closer to Exchange 2013" href="/blog/microsoft-exchange/closer-exchange-2013">We’re One Step Closer to Exchange 2013</a></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Boogie Bot Costume Contest – Happy Halloween From SWC!</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/boogie-bot-costume-contest-happy-halloween</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 31 Oct 2013 10:30:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[boogiebot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10525</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC employees have been competing since early October in a Boogie Bot Costume Contest. Many employees decided to take on the challenge and create a variety of characters to showcase on SWC’s Facebook page. The rules were simple, dress up a Boogie Bot in an awesome costume and the Boogie Bot photo with the most ‘likes’ wins.
<h2>Take a look!</h2>
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-10522" title="Cheerleader Boogie Bots" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/cheerleader-boogie-bots.jpg" alt="Cheerleader Boogie Bots" width="535" height="276" />

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-10524" title="Trio Boogie Bots" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/trio-boogie-bots.jpg" alt="Trio Boogie Bots" width="535" height="234" />
<h2>And the Boogie Bot photo that got the most likes was...</h2>
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-10523" title="Star Wars Boogie Bots" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/star-wars-boogie-bots.jpg" alt="Star Wars Boogie Bots" width="535" height="337" />

Congratulations Rachael Narel, our <a title="Business Intelligence Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a> Go-To-Market Leader! Rachael dressed her Boogie Bots in Star Wars themed costumes and got the most likes on SWC’s Facebook Page. Head over to the <a title="SWC Facebook Page" href="https://www.facebook.com/SWCTechnologyPartners" target="_blank">SWC Facebook Page</a> to see the rest of our employee’s awesome Boogie Bot costumes.

At <a title="IT Consulting Firm" href="/swc-technology-partners/about-swc">IT consulting firm</a>, SWC, we like to work hard, but also like to have some fun. We are always looking for talented and intelligent individuals to join our team. If you are passionate about technology and want to grow your career, head over to <a title="Chicago IT Careers" href="/careers">SWC Careers</a> and apply for one of our open <a title="Chicago IT Jobs" href="https://careers-swc.icims.com/jobs/intro?hashed=0" target="_blank">IT positions</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Is The SharePoint Envisioning Process?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-is-the-sharepoint-envisioning-process</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 Nov 2013 12:32:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10544</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of ‘Ask SWC,’ our <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Solutions" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint Solutions</a> leader, Jeff Lanham discusses the SWC SharePoint Envisioning Process and how it’s helping customers create SharePoint solutions that are easy to use, engaging and increase user adoption. Watch our video to learn more.

<a title="SWC's SharePoint Envisioning Process" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/OG_k9JIOaAY?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

As more organizations have implemented <a title="Microsoft SharePoint 2013" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-2013">Microsoft SharePoint</a>, their internal skills and capabilities have grown. As a SharePoint consulting partner, SWC has always tried to look for areas where we can really provide unique value and extend the capabilities of our clients as they are looking to implement SharePoint. One of the ways we do this is through our proprietary <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Envisioning Process" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint/sharepoint-envisioning-process">SharePoint envisioning process</a>.

Our approach has been honed over the course of more than ten years of experience with Microsoft SharePoint and literally hundreds of implementations. In that time, we have found that an envisioning and design process at the beginning of a project can be a great way to help key stakeholders understand what the platform is capable of and how to get the most out of SharePoint from a business value prospective.

From there we proceed to craft several design concepts that run the spectrum from conservative and more traditional to a little more progressive and perhaps more visually exciting. We then work with the stakeholders to refine those designs into a final creative look and feel and also focus on building out the navigation structure and layout of the rest of the environment.

One of the best things about this approach is that it’s flexible and can scale to any size organization, sector or vertical. We’ve found it’s important to focus on the envisioning and design concept in the beginning of a SharePoint implementation, because a little bit goes a long way towards ultimately creating a more compelling initial experience for users that drives adoption and value.

To view some great examples on how SWC can give your SharePoint environment a fresh look and feel while focusing on usability, check out our SharePoint design portfolio at: <a title="SharePoint Portfolio" href="http://www.swc.com/design-portfolio/sharepoint" target="_blank">SWC.com/design-portfolio/SharePoint</a>

To learn more about how Microsoft SharePoint and <a title="Chicago SharePoint Consultants" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-2013">SharePoint consultants</a>, SWC, can help you meet your business objectives, please join SWC for our next informative Chicago area <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Chicago Event" href="/events">Microsoft SharePoint event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Lanham LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-lanham/22/125/a99" target="_blank">Jeff Lanham on LinkedIn</a>.

	<item>
		<title>How Do I Connect It To Microsoft Lync?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/how-do-i-connect-it-to-microsoft-lync</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 12 Nov 2013 14:38:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[gonzaloescarra]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10618</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you’re considering moving to <a title="Microsoft Lync 2013" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a> as your <a title="Unified Communications Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Unified Communications solution</a>, there is still a dependency on analog and legacy telephony devices such as common area phones, door phones, elevator lines or overhead paging. Such devices must work with Microsoft Lync endpoints if you want to ensure a successful PBX replacement. SWC has found that solutions provided by vendors such as AudioCodes or SNOM can help.

In order to interface with analog devices, Microsoft Lync needs to have a way to convert its SIP-based signaling and voice streams into a standard phone line. Devices called Media Gateways can accomplish that. Let's take the example of a door phone and how it would integrate into Microsoft Lync:
<ul>
	<li>The door phone connects to Media Gateway via an analog line</li>
	<li>When a caller presses the Call button on the door phone, the line goes off-hook</li>
	<li>The Media Gateway auto-dials the Lync Response Group (perhaps a receptionist) upon the line going off-hook</li>
	<li>The Lync user or group rings, answers and proceeds to talk</li>
	<li>The Lync user may trigger a door entry relay by passing DTMF tones when pressing # or *</li>
</ul>
A similar scenario would be used for phones used in elevators or analog common areas like warehouse service phones or emergency phones that can automatically dial 911.

Additionally, these Media Gateways are the interface that enables Lync to talk to legacy PBX systems, which helps in the case of a phased migration. Media Gateways can also be used to have a pool of Fax machines receive faxes through an all-digital SIP trunk or T1 line. Regardless of the scenario, having a Media Gateway as part of your Lync infrastructure enables flexibility and further extends Microsoft Lync's capacity to function as your business’ Unified Communications platform.

To learn more about SWC’s Microsoft Lync and <a title="Microsoft Exchange Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-exchange-2013">Microsoft Exchange</a>, please join us for our next <a title="Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Unified Communications event</a>.
<h2>Chicago area Microsoft Lync services 630.572.0240.</h2>
If you enjoyed reading this post, please take a moment to read some of our previous posts on Microsoft Unified Communications:

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: Microsoft Windows XP And What Happens On April 8, 2014</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/microsoft-windows-xp-and-what-happens-april-8-2014</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 14 Nov 2013 09:46:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeremyalt]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10641</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[April 8, 2014. What does this mean? To most people nothing. But to anyone in IT, they know it as the day Microsoft ends support for Window XP or anyone using Office 2003. Watch our recent episode of ‘Ask SWC’ to learn more about how we are helping our clients prepare for <a title="Windows XP End Of Life" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/april-2014-windows-xp-support-ends">Windows XP End of Life</a>.

<a title="Windows XP End of Life" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/GsOTNVx4Fyk?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

At SWC, a lot of our clients are still using Windows XP and Office 2003 and many of them do not have a plan to get off these platforms. We’ve worked with a lot of our clients to not just talk about a PC refresh, but also build a deployment strategy and plan for migrating from <a title="Microsoft Windows Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows</a> XP to <a title="Microsoft Windows 7 Consulting" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-7">Windows 7</a> or 8. We want to make sure that we are providing more than just the next generation of operating systems; we want to provide a plan that enhances the organization and provides a seamless transition for users.

If your business operates on Windows XP, SWC offers desktop deployment assessments to help prepare for Windows XP’s end-of-life. We have developed a proven methodology that allows us to identify where your organization’s vulnerabilities are and assist you with choosing the right desktop operating system to support your technical landscape and meet business objectives. Whether it’s Windows 7, <a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Consulting" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Windows 8</a>, virtualization, the cloud, mobile, or a hybrid approach, we’ll help you make sense of it all and choose the right platform or combination of platforms for your business.

If you enjoy this series, check out a few of our past “Ask SWC” videos:

	<item>
		<title>BYOD Policies And Mobile Device Management</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/byod-polices-mobile-device-management</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 20 Nov 2013 00:30:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[davidecclesambrose]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10659</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Bring your own device (BYOD) is the emerging trend of enabling employees to bring personally owned mobile devices, most commonly tablets and phones to use in the workplace. However, BYOD can cause some serious security risks for companies. In this <a title="Managed Services" href="/solutions/managed-services">Managed Services</a> blog, we will explore how an organization can get the most out of BYOD while reducing risk and cost.

With the rise in popularity of BYOD, one of the scariest things a business faces is allowing an employee’s personal devices to access to proprietary company data or records that contain customer’s personally identifiable information. A recent report, “<a href="http://www.ciscomcon.com/sw/swchannel/registration/internet/registration.cfm?SWAPPID=91&amp;RegPageID=350200&amp;SWTHEMEID=12949" target="_blank">BYOD Insights 2013: A Cisco Partner Network Study</a>,” found that 90 percent of employees are bringing their own smartphones to work but 40 percent of those phones were not password protected. In addition to these security risks, a BYOD policy can increase the demand of an organization’s IT staff to assist employees with getting their personal devices on the corporate network and enabling e-mail and calendar sync.

A BYOD policy and Mobile Device Management solution will allow companies to get the most out of BYOD while reducing the risk and cost. A Mobile Device Management suite allows the IT department to:
<ul>
	<li>Secure employee devices – both by enforcing password policies and enabling them to remotely wipe a device if it gets lost or stolen</li>
	<li>Manage the device – send encryption keys to the device for wireless networks or configuration settings for e-mail push</li>
</ul>
To learn more about creating and implementing an effective BYDO policy and Mobile Device Management, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Managed Services Events" href="/events">Managed Services event</a>.
<h2>Chicago Area Managed IT Services 630-572-0240</h2>

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Are Some Cool Microsoft Lync Features?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/cool-microsoft-lync-features</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 22 Nov 2013 06:10:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradcooper]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10684</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Let’s say you’re on an important phone call at your desk and you want to move to a conference room to gain a little more privacy. The best thing about <a title="Microsoft Lync Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a> is that you don’t have to schedule a room ahead of time or even leave the call. Watch this week’s episode of ‘Ask SWC’ to learn more about this cool new feature and how it is helping our customers communicate.

<a title="Cool Feature of Microsoft Lync" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/RbTrj0yrZ-c?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

With Microsoft Lync you don’t have to schedule the conference ahead of time to get a little more privacy when you are on a call. All you have to do is walk over to the conference room and if it has a Lync phone, just search for the phone in the contacts area of your Lync menu and transfer the call. It’s fast, easy and will save you time. And the best part is – if you have a <a title="Microsoft Unified Communications" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Microsoft Unified Communications</a> solution, the conference is free! Microsoft Lync 2013 is easy to use and its intuitive user experience continues to make the platform a compelling telephony solution for all of your organization’s instant messaging, presence, conferencing and voice needs.

If you want to learn more about Microsoft Lync, please join us for our next information <a title="Microsoft Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Microsoft Unified Communications event</a>.

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft Lync 2013 and the MSSQL 18456 Event</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013-mssql-18456-event</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 Nov 2013 16:01:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10698</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>Have you recently encountered the MSSQL 18456 Event?</em></strong> I’ve seen this come up in quite a few migrations after <a title="Microsoft Lync 2013" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync 2013</a> is installed and pools are paired. Since I couldn’t find much about MSSQL 18456 on the internet, I thought I would share my findings for everyone else who has experienced an endless number of MSSQL 18456 information events.

Once you encounter the MSSQL 18456 information event, fill the application event log with the message: “Login failed for user 'DOMAIN\SQLSERVERNAME$'. Reason: Failed to open the explicitly specified database 'xds'. [CLIENT: IP Address]”. This issue can occur if the Lync 2013 pools were set up and paired first, and the CMS moved later to one of the pools. If you see the message above related to your backup pool, the simplest thing you can do is remove the pairing from the topology, publish, then reestablish the pairing and republish. Another alternative is to create the database via the PowerShell using this command: Install-CsDatabase -CentralManagementDatabase -SQLServerFQDN-SQLInstanceName.

If you’d like assistance planning your path to <a title="Unified Communications Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Microsoft Unified Communications</a> please contact <a title="Contact SWC" href="/contact">SWC</a>, connect with <a title="Anthony Caragol LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/anthony-caragol/6/48/488" target="_blank">Anthony Caragol on LinkedIn</a> or join us for our next <a title="Chicago Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Unified Communications event</a>.

To learn more about Microsoft Lync, check out a few of Anthony’s technical blogs:

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Are Your Thoughts on Dreamforce 2013?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-are-your-thoughts-on-dreamforce-2013</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Dec 2013 23:08:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elliottbaretz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10738</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of ‘Ask SWC,’ our CRM Solutions leader, Elliott Baretz discusses his thoughts on Dreamforce 2013. Dreamforce is Salesforce’s annual user and developer conference. Watch our video to learn more about the biggest cloud computing event of the year and SWC’s partnership with <a title="Salesforce.com Customer Relationship Management" href="/solutions/crm/salesforce-com-customer-relationship-management">Salesforce</a>.
<a title="Thoughts on Dreamforce 2013" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/4U0YriJ7rVk?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>
Salesforce is a cloud based <a title="Customer Relationship Management Services" href="/solutions/crm">Customer Relationship Management</a> (CRM) solution that helps companies sell, service, market and succeed by giving them the ability to connect with customers and close deals faster. Dreamforce 2013 drew over 100,000 people this year, increasing San Francisco’s population by 15% – which was pretty amazing. I wanted to take this blog as an opportunity to share some of the information I learned at the event and some of the things that I found interesting and am excited about.

The first thing is Pardot, a marketing automation platform that helps bridge the gap between sales and marketing through powerful and targeted email campaigns that simplify lead generation and management. The tool’s ability to do Business to Business (B2B) marketing, scripting and automate B2B initiatives based on actions and scoring for prospects is very interesting.

Next is Journey Builder, an application that provides real-time automated and personalized customer campaigns to large scale audiences. As part of the ExactTarget suite, Journey Builder’s ability to leverage Salesforce to put together very sophisticated and elaborate marketing campaigns based on actions and sequences is quite impressive. One of the examples from the conference was how Ford leverages the product. When a vehicle owner hits a certain mileage, the platform alerts ExactTarget, which then triggers an email to the owner about maintenance or services that should be scheduled at that time. This is a great example of a cross sell or upsell.

It was also very exciting to learn more about the social media aspects of ExactTarget, Radian6 and Buddy Media. These are some tremendous platforms and great products that integrate into Salesforce for state-of-the-art reporting and analytic capabilities.

If you want to learn more about Salesforce or ExactTarget, please join us for our next Mastering Digital Marketing through <a title="Chicago Salesforce.com Event" href="/events">Salesforce event</a>.

If you enjoyed this post, check out a few of our past posts on Customer Relationship Management:
<a title="The Three Main Components of a CRM System" href="/blog/customer-relationship-management/the-three-main-components-crm-system">The Three Main Components of a CRM System</a>

<a title="Choosing the Right CRM Solution Part II" href="/blog/customer-relationship-management/choosing-the-right-crm-solution-part-ii">Choosing the Right CRM Solution Part II</a>
<a title="Maximizing User Adoption in CRM Deployment" href="/blog/customer-relationship-management/maximizing-user-adoption-crm">Maximizing User Adoption in CRM Deployment</a>
<a title="Common CRM Mistakes and How You Can Avoid Making Them" href="/blog/customer-relationship-management/common-crm-mistakes">Common CRM Mistakes and How You Can Avoid Making Them</a>
<a title="Best Practices for Marketing Automation in CRM" href="/blog/customer-relationship-management/best-practices-marketing-automation-crm">Best Practices for Marketing Automation in CRM</a>

If you enjoy this series, check out a few of our past “Ask SWC” videos:

		<title>Happy Holidays From SWC Technology Partners</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/2013-happy-holidays-from-swc-technology-partners</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 06 Dec 2013 04:19:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bobknott]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10859</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As 2013 comes to a close, we pause to reflect on another wonderful year in which we have worked very hard for our clients, helping them find success whether they are next door…or at the North Pole. We hope you enjoy this year’s holiday video production, “That’s So Rudolph.” It’s a humorous tale with a SWC twist and a reindeer game or two. Happy Holidays from all of us at SWC Technology Partners!

<a title="That's So Rudolph - Happy Holidays From SWC" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/LDBJNd6pnaY?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-thats-so-rudolph-video.jpg" alt="SWC Technology Partners That's So Rudolph Video" width="474" height="262" /></a>

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What’s So Great About Tableau?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/whats-so-great-about-tableau</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Dec 2013 21:21:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kathrynchrismer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10868</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of our favorite Business Intelligence tools at SWC is <a title="Tableau Solutions" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/tableau">Tableau</a>. Our customers really love it because it’s mobile and puts the power of data analytics in anyone’s hands. Watch our recent episode of “Ask SWC” to learn more about our favorite features of Tableau.
<a title="Take Charge of Data with Tableau" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/Ct8UgeifMew?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>
Tableau is a highly intuitive and visually rich <a title="Business Intelligence Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">business intelligence</a> application that can connect to a variety of <a title="Cloud Solutions" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud</a> and native data sources, including Salesforce.com and Google Analytics. By using a data buddy, you can combine all of these data sources into one dashboard by simply dragging and dropping the data in. Tableau’s user-friendly interface provides even the non-technical user with the ability to quickly analyze this data to instantly create visually rich, powerful and interactive dashboards.

Tableau’s recent release, Tableau 8 has offered users a lot of great updates including report subscriptions, one-step forecasting, JavaScript API and a mobile app. The mobile app is by far one of my favorite features, because it allows you to view all of your reports in real-time. You can also use almost all of the same features you would on your desktop version using the mobile app, including zooming, filtering and highlighting. You can even edit reports in real-time from your mobile app!

To learn more about BI and all of the exciting new features Tableau 8 has for the business intelligence community; please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>.

If you enjoyed this post from Kathryn, check out a few of our past posts on business intelligence:

	<item>
		<title>My Search For The Business Intelligence Chupacabra</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/my-search-for-the-business-intelligence-chupacabra</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 13 Dec 2013 05:24:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10896</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In popular culture the Chupacabra is an almost mythical creature sighted many times in the Americas but has never been confirmed as an actual member of our fauna. Many have sighted, photographed, or even dreamed about the Chupacabra, but we still don’t have any proof that this creature really exists or what it is. In regards to social media, many of us have amassed large amounts of raw textual data and so little has been done thus far to gain insight from it. Many of us have a desire to use business intelligence to analyze social media text to get accurate insights. Decision makers want to ask questions like, “What is my product or company’s social media sentiment?” So how do we measure and score sentiment? How do we separate fact from fiction or truth from sarcasm in an aggregate form? Thus we have a digital “Chupacabra” aptly named “Sentiment Scoring” or “Social Media Sentiment Score.” When you look at all the raw data, it just seems like a cruel riddle wrapped in an enigma of digital noise! But we know there is value to be had.
<h2>So How Did We Get Here?</h2>
A few months back I was looking at doing a complete refresh of SWC’s <a title="Business Intelligence Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a> demo environment. We use this environment to showcase BI tools and architecture to our customers and prospects. It was time to start over and go beyond rebranding the same old tired BI use cases we had grown all too comfortable showing in the past. There’s only so much you can do with a generic general ledger cube demo or Bike Sales data mining model. It was time to break out of the traditional BI mold and do something fun and insightful that has a message any analytics hungry BI prospect could get excited about. And so we invented “Hyena Power.” Hyena Power Inc. or HPI is a fictitious manufacturer of home hydrogen generators that consumers use to produce hydrogen for fueling cars, water heaters, home generators and the like. Fun concept right? We’ve had a lot of fun inventing this company and sometimes I’m almost bummed our product is fake, but boy does it make for a really interesting BI Technology demo. So HPI is a new company with a great product and a hunger to grow their customer base in orders of magnitude so that GE buys them out in a leveraged buyout. HPI has a very diverse marketing engine combining Social Media, Search, Online Webinars, call center and seminars/luncheons. On the social media landscape HPI uses Yammer. The Yammer feed is where the sentiment requirement comes into play. For our demo environment, we chose Yammer as a way to simulate what a real Facebook or <a title="SWC LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/company/swc-technology-partners" target="_blank">LinkedIn</a> feed might look like and how that data might be scored. So Yammer is a good alternative for Social Media prototyping and is similar to what we would actually do for a real company on <a title="SWC Facebook" href="https://www.facebook.com/SWCTechnologyPartners" target="_blank">Facebook</a>. Our goal at the outset of this demo exercise was to determine if we could put the Yammer data though a scoring algorithm and get insight into how our message is being perceived in the marketplace.
<h2>Putting It All Together</h2>
<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-10894" title="SWC Chad Dotzenrod Putting It All Together" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-chad-dotzenrod-putting-it-all-together-300x236.jpg" alt="SWC Chad Dotzenrod Putting It All Together" width="300" height="236" />

Before we get into the scoring, I thought I’d show you what we are trying to do from the visualization side. In the dashboard above, what we’re trying to do is provide visualization to the all the wonderful data we’re collecting from Yammer and various systems. On the bottom right, we have a heat map that shows a set of popular bloggers for HPI and what their sentiment scoring looks like in aggregate. In this chart red is bad (neutral or negative scores). At the top there is a very simple line chart over calendar weeks showing the count of positive, negative and neutral social media updates. What was interesting here is that HPI made a conscious effort to reduce neutral content and drive more positive scores and we see that correlation nicely. Finally, on the bottom left we used a packed bubble to visualize all of HPIs marketing efforts, including but not limited to social media.
<h2>How Did We Do It?</h2>
I wish I could tell you that we mastered the challenges of machine learning. But, we did not! However, we learned a lot from this project and got some great insights that helped us to build the 1.0 version rather quickly.
After spending several evenings on my tablet trying to educate myself on the concept of social media scoring, it became abundantly clear that I was way out of my pay grade and really should have taken more math when I was getting my undergrad at North Dakota State University (Go Bison!). So I was kind of stuck, but then I remembered my brother, <a href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/kevin-dotzenrod/1/1a4/793" target="_blank">Kevin Dotzenrod</a> works for Rupert Murdoch. Ok, he doesn’t directly report to him but he has met him a few times at work functions. So my brother Kevin has a colleague at Dow Jones, <a href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/doug-esanbock/0/711/107" target="_blank">Douglas Esanbock</a> who is their resident expert on sentiment scoring pertaining to news stories and all things social media. Doug and I traded a few emails and got on the phone to discuss the concept. What we arrived at was something very similar to <a href="http://sentiwordnet.isti.cnr.it/" target="_blank">SentiWordNet</a> research.
Essentially the scoring works like the following:
<ul>
	<li>Build vectors of positive words and negative words</li>
	<li>Cleanse your social media input and remove non-word characters and punctuation</li>
	<li>Parse the social media update into a list and score each word against the vectors</li>
	<li>Calculate a score of the matching results whereas a high number would be positive sentiment, a negative score would be negative sentiment and somewhere in-between would be neutral</li>
</ul>
I know some of you gearheads want more and I aim to please, so here’s a snippet of code in “R” that we used for the scoring. I will point that that much of the this code was inspired by <a href="http://jeffreybreen.wordpress.com/2011/07/04/twitter-text-mining-r-slides/" target="_blank">Jeffrey Breen</a>
<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-10895" title="SWC Chad Dotzenrod Snippet Of Code" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-chad-dotzenrod-snippet-of-code-262x300.jpg" alt="SWC Chad Dotzenrod Snippet Of Code" width="262" height="300" />
After playing with R and then getting serious about building the ETL prototype in SSIS we decided to forego R for the time being and use C# in an SSIS Script Data Flow component. That of which will be an upcoming blog topic we dig into deeper next month, when one of my colleagues, Patricia Motta, will tell us about her prototype scoring SSIS package. Until then, Happy Holidays!

To learn more about BI and all of the exciting new features SWC has for the business intelligence community; please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Events" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>.

		<title>CryptoLocker Virus Tips – Take Action Now!</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/cryptolocker-virus-tips-take-action-now</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Dec 2013 16:42:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[davidecclesambrose]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10903</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It has been three months since the Trojan horse malware CryptoLocker first appeared. The timing was no accident – you get an e-mail that appears to come from shipping carriers like FedEx and UPS just as holidays shopping season begins to ramp up, but once you click on the link to track the package – you’re infected. But is it still dangerous? The answer is: Absolutely!

The CryptoLocker virus relies on an advanced network of command-and-control servers and continues to be developed by the malware’s creators. If you have not heard about CryptoLocker, it is a very nasty virus which encrypts your computer files and holds them for ransom. The virus demands that users pay anywhere from $300 to thousands of dollars to get their files back. Unfortunately, this virus has been very successful in extorting money from its victims which has motivated hackers to keep on developing more viruses.

Each new iteration of CryptoLocker becomes harder and harder to detect and antivirus vendors are struggling to keep up. But – if your organization cannot rely on your antivirus software, what else can you do? Here’s a list of four things SWC recommends:
<ul>
	<li><strong>Educate users</strong> – Do not open unsolicited attachments, no matter how legitimate they may appear. If you were not expecting it don’t open it! If a user does get a suspicious looking attachment they should contact IT or <a title="Managed IT Help Desk Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-help-desk-service-desk-services">Help Desk</a> immediately.<strong></strong></li>
	<li><strong>Regular backups</strong> – Use a combination of volume shadow copy (previous versions) and offline backups. If users are still storing files on their local computers, you should look into folder redirection using domain-based group policy.<strong></strong></li>
	<li><strong>Keep your operating system and software up-to-date</strong> – If your organization is still running Windows XP and migration has not already begun, it’s time to get serious about making the move. With less than five months remaining before <a title="Microsoft Windows XP End Of Life" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/april-2014-windows-xp-support-ends">Microsoft will stop supporting Windows XP</a>, there is very little time left to develop a plan and begin testing applications; however upgrading should be any IT department’s number one priority going into 2014. Once XP is out of the way, your IT team can focus on keeping common applications and runtimes like Acrobat, Flash and Java up-to-date and deploying monthly security patches from Microsoft to workstations using Windows Server Update Services.<strong></strong></li>
	<li><strong>Revise IT policies to protect users from themselves</strong> – Users should not be logging into computers as local administrators. Use software restriction policies to protect against unauthorized software, especially in temporary folders and removable drives. Block executable files at your spam filter before the user ever receives it.</li>
</ul>
If you have questions about Cryptolocker, Ransomware or other threats to your security, please contact SWC. If you would like to learn more about <a title="Chicago Managed IT Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">Managed IT Services</a>, please join us for our next informative Managed Services event.
<h2>Chicago Area Managed IT Services 630-572-0240</h2>

	<item>
		<title>OAuth 2.0 – Google API Business Intelligence Implementation</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/oauth-2-0-google-api-bi-implementation</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 18 Dec 2013 13:50:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jasonbruno]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10912</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I recently had the pleasure of working with OAuth 2.0 in tandem with Google API’s for one of my clients and thought I would share my experience with all of you today.
<h2>What is OAuth 2.0?</h2>
OAuth 2.0 is an open industry standard and framework that provides a method for clients to access server resources on behalf of a resource owner by means of authentication from the resource owner with approval interaction between the resource owner and the HTTP service, or by allowing third-party applications to gain access on its own behalf. OAuth 2.0 can provide a process for end-users to authorize third-party access to their server resources without sharing their credentials (typically, a username and password pair).
<h2>That’s great and all, but what does OAuth 2.0 have to do with my BI Solution?</h2>
OAuth 2.0 is being used to obtain massive amounts of data on a daily basis from many different sources (RSS/ATOM feeds, Google Analytics, Google Drive, Google Calendar, Facebook, Twitter and the list goes on…).
<h2>How Does the Authentication Process Work?</h2>
There are a few different methodologies for how authentication can be obtained (Web Server Applications, Installed Applications, Client-Side Applications and Service Accounts) and you just have to decide which way works best for your use-case/application.
<h2>Web Server Applications via Google API</h2>
<img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-10909" title="OAuth 2.0 Photo 1" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/oauth-2-photo-1-150x150.jpg" alt="OAuth 2.0 Photo 1" width="150" height="150" />The authorization sequence begins when your application redirects a browser to a URL. The URL includes query parameters that indicate the type of access being requested. Google handles the user authentication, session selection and user consent. The result is an authorization code, which the application can exchange for an access token and refresh token. The application should store the refresh token for future use and use the access token to access an API. Once the access token expires, the application uses the refresh token to obtain a new one.
<h2>Installed Applications via Google API</h2>
The Google OAuth 2.0 endpoint supports applications that are installed on devices such as computers, mobile devices and tablets. When you register an application through the Google Cloud Console, you can select Android, iOS, Chrome or native as the platform. The registration process will result in a client ID and in some cases, a client secret which you embed in the source code of your application. The authorization sequence is obtained the exact same way as it is in the above mentioned Web Server Applications via Google API.
<h2>Client-Side (JavaScript) Applications via Google API</h2>
<img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-10910" title="OAuth 2.0 Photo 2" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/oauth-2-photo-2-150x150.jpg" alt="OAuth 2.0 Photo 2" width="150" height="150" />The Google OAuth 2.0 endpoint supports JavaScript applications that run in a browser. The authorization sequence beings when your application redirects a browser to a URL. The URL includes query parameters that indicate the type of access being requested. Google handles the user authentication, session selection and user consent. The result is an access token, which the client should validate before including it in a Google API request. When the token expires, the application repeats the process.
<h2>Service Accounts Applications via Google API</h2>
<img class="alignleft size-thumbnail wp-image-10911" title="OAuth 2.0 Photo 3" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/oauth-2-photo-3-150x150.jpg" alt="OAuth 2.0 Photo 3" width="150" height="150" />Google API’s can act on behalf of an application without accessing user specific information. When an application accesses these API’s the application needs to prove its own identity, but there is no need to gain a user’s approval. In enterprise scenarios, an application can request delegated access to some resources. Google’s OAuth 2.0 endpoint supports these type of server-to-server interactions which makes this the optimum choice for a Business Intelligence (BI) solution because we can use a script task and not require any user interaction to complete the authorization process. Once the service account is created, you have access to the private key and a client ID. You use the private key and client ID to create a signed JWT and construct an access-token request in the appropriate format. Your application then sends the token request to the Google OAuth 2.0 Authorization Server, which returns an access token. The application then uses the access token to gain access to a Google API. When the token expires (1 hour expiration time), the application should repeat the process.

To learn more about BI and all of the exciting new features SWC has for the business intelligence community; please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Events" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>.

If you enjoyed this post from Jason, please check out a few of our past posts on business intelligence:
