	<item>
		<title>SWC’s 2013 Tech Trends Poll</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/technology/swc-2013-tech-trends-poll</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 Dec 2013 15:32:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elliottbaretz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10930</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the past, <a title="IT Consulting Firm" href="http://www.swc.com">IT consulting firm</a>, SWC has surveyed Mid-Market IT and business executives, hoping to gather valuable insights on the trends, tactics and technologies that are creating the most impact on their businesses. Watch our 2013 tech trends video to view the results of our most recent poll.
<a title="SWC Technology Partners 2013 Cloud Survey Summary" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/EnfBs3qBJjM?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-tech-trends-survey-video.jpg" alt="SWC Technology Trends Survey" width="500" height="281" /></a>
<h2>Video Commentary &amp; Survey Results</h2>
Recently, we sent out a survey to Midwest, midmarket IT and business leaders and asked them how their organizations viewed the <a title="SWC Cloud Services" href="/solutions/cloud-services">Cloud</a>. It’s a topic that we’re all thinking about and trying to understand – how big this thing has become and we learned a few things.

Specifically, we asked, from a disaster recovery perspective – how many of you are using the cloud as an option and we learned that almost 10% of you are using it as a solution. Interesting enough, we learned that nearly 25% of you did not have a Disaster Recovery solution. This may be noteworthy as those folks move to implementing a Disaster Recovery solution; we may see the cloud number going up. Other findings included nearly 40% of you have your Disaster Recovery solution located in a dedicated <a title="Cloud Disaster Recovery Solutions" href="/solutions/cloud-services/recovery-cloud">Disaster Recovery</a> site and a little over 26% of you have it hosted with a third party provider.

The other question that we asked was relative to infrastructure – how many of you are leveraging the cloud to manage your infrastructure? What we found was that a little over 70% are still have their entire infrastructure on premise, with nearly 30% having some form of cloud based infrastructure, whether that’s private, public or in between.

Finally we asked how many of us are using the cloud to host, enable or manage applications and that number seems to be lower than the others, it’s about 13%. But these are massive implementations if we think about it – big enterprise applications that were built on-premise that have moved to a cloud based environment, such as Amazon or Azure.

As with all elements of the cloud we think that attrition plays a role, so as technologies become old and dated and investments need to be made, those investments will be made in the cloud. So today we have a number, but we think that number is going to grow into the cloud.

This poll has provided some interesting information that has to do with what’s going on today in our marketplace. If you have any thoughts in terms of what trends you would like us to talk about in our next poll, let us know by emailing <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">info@swc.com</a>. We look forward to getting more results to you in the future.

If you would like more information on past SWC Technology Trend Surveys, please visit: www.swc.com/perspectives/surveys
<h2>Additional insights from our survey can be found below:</h2>
<a title="SWC Tech Trends Survey Charts" href="/uploads/swc-tech-trends-survey-charts.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-10928" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-10928" title="SWC Tech Trends Survey Charts" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-tech-trends-survey-charts-195x300.jpg" alt="SWC Tech Trends Survey Charts" width="195" height="300" /></a>

	<item>
		<title>Technology Succeeds With Community</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/technology-succeeds-with-community</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 01:16:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elainegreen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10940</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I love this time of year. Sure, it can be filled with a lot of hustle and bustle, but it’s also a time where we reflect on what’s most important and spend time with those we care about. That’s why I wanted to share a cute video of the students from Alain Locke Charter School. They recently came to visit <a title="SWC Technology Partners" href="http://www.swc.com">SWC Technology Partners</a> this holiday season to sing carols and tour our office.

<a title="Chicago's Alain Locke Choir Visits SWC" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/wR65FSNby6E?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/alain-locke-choir-video.jpg" alt="Chicago's Alain Locke Choir Visits SWC" width="500" height="281" /></a>

At SWC, we value community outreach, and that doesn’t just mean writing a check to some non-profit that we have no relationship with. Through SWC, our employees have built a strong kinship with the faculty, staff and students of Alain Locke Charter School, and throughout the year we participate in various functions with them, including Reading Angels and the Robotics Club. Alain Locke is making some great strides in closing the achievement gap to help students not only compete nationally, but globally and it’s incredible to be involved in their mission.

<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-10939" title="alain-locke-swc-coat-drive" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/alain-locke-swc-coat-drive-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" />

As the weather began to change, we learned about a need from our friends at Alain Locke. Many of the students were lacking proper outdoor attire for the impending winter. Can you imagine not having a warm coat in the midst of our treacherous Chicago winter? It’s one of the countless things I know I take for granted. So, as an organization, we decided to host a coat drive. Our employees pulled their resources and we were able to purchase a coat for every child that needed one. It was so exciting to see everyone pitch in and when we had collected all the coats, I was honored to be a part of the distribution. It’s a perfect reminder that technology succeeds with community.

As we near the end of the year, I’d like to wish you and yours a warm and safe holiday season. To learn more about SWC’s community service initiatives, please visit: <a title="SWC Community Outreach" href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/community-outreach">www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/community-outreach</a>.</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Only 98 Days Left For Microsoft Windows XP!</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/only-98-days-left-microsoft-windows-xp</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Dec 2013 21:29:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[davidecclesambrose]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10953</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Four years ago Microsoft announced that <a title="Microsoft Windows XP End Of Life" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/april-2014-windows-xp-support-ends">Windows XP had reached the end of its mainstream support</a> and that although they would continue to provide security updates every month through April of 2014, customers should begin migrating to newer versions of Windows. Time is quickly running out and in just 98 days Microsoft will cease providing those important security updates; leaving organizations holding the proverbial hot potato. Windows XP will not just be outdated – it will be a liability, permanently at risk: zero-day forever.

Without advanced exploit defenses found in newer operating systems, like UAC (User Account Control) and ASLR (Address Space Layout Randomization), Windows XP was already affected by malware at a significantly higher rate, but malware is becoming more sophisticated and hackers increasingly patient. Security professionals believe that some hackers are already holding back discovered exploits, hoping that they go undiscovered and unpatched by Microsoft until the April deadline passes. Organizations can believe that their firewalls will block these threats but the reality is most intrusions begin as malicious websites or fraudulent e-mail attachments.

What is it, specifically, that is holding you, your department or your organization back? If you answered legacy applications then you are not alone. An independent survey by Avanade of 200 CIO’s and IT leaders revealed that 80% had concerns of unsupported Windows XP applications. But there is good news, SWC can help!

Talk to us about inventorying your organization. We can help you identify how many XP desktops are still in production with our <a title="Desktop Deployment Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/april-2014-windows-xp-support-ends">desktop deployment assessments</a>. SWC can help you discover which legacy applications are actually being used and how to begin compatibility testing. SWC can also help you virtualize those stubborn legacy applications that just refuse to work on newer operating systems.

If you would like to learn more about <a title="Chicago Managed IT Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">Managed IT Services</a>, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Managed Services Event" href="/events">Managed Services event</a>.
<h2>Chicago Area Managed IT Services 630-572-0240</h2>

	<item>
		<title>The Twelve Days Of SWC</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/twelve-days-of-swc</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jan 2014 21:05:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[annagreer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10960</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What is so great about working at SWC? It’s definitely our employees! We have an amazing team that is dedicated to excellence. Our employees really love working here, so in the spirit of the holidays I thought I’d share my <strong>Twelve Days of SWC</strong> list that includes some of the great benefits we offer from a recruiter’s perspective.
<ul>
	<li>On the 1st day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 2nd day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 3rd day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 4th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 5th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – quarterly massages, fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 6th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – a well-stocked fridge, quarterly massages, fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 7th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – financial incentives, a well-stocked fridge, quarterly massages, fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 8th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – comprehensive benefits, financial incentives, a well-stocked fridge, quarterly massages, fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 9th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – cool projects, comprehensive benefits, financial incentives, a well-stocked fridge, quarterly massages, fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 10th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – paid technical certifications, cool projects, comprehensive benefits, financial incentives, a well-stocked fridge, quarterly massages, fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 11th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – fun corporate outings, paid technical certifications, cool projects, comprehensive benefits, financial incentives, a well-stocked fridge, quarterly massages, fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
	<li>On the 12th day of SWC my recruiter gave to me – a fulfilling and rewarding career at SWC, fun corporate outings, paid technical certifications, cool projects, comprehensive benefits, financial incentives, a well-stocked fridge, quarterly massages, fresh fruit every Monday, flex-time with my family, a collaborative team environment and happy hour every Friday.</li>
</ul>
If you are looking to make a career change and want to join one of <a title="Best places to work Chicago" href="/swc-technology-partners/news/crains-chicago-business-swc-chicago-best-places-to-work-2013">Chicago’s Top 20 Best Places to Work</a>, please contact SWC today. You can also visit our careers page to watch our employee videos, browse our open <a title="Chicago IT Jobs" href="/careers">Chicago area IT positions</a> or learn about our <a title="IT Job Benefits" href="/careers/swc-benefits">career benefits</a>.

If you enjoyed this post on SWC’s corporate culture, please check out a few of our past posts:

<a title="Chicago Area IT Solutions Provider SWC Focuses On Work-Life Balance" href="/blog/careers/chicago-it-solutions-provider-work-life-balance">Chicago Area IT Solutions Provider SWC Focuses On Work-Life Balance</a>
<a title="A Few Ways to Keep Employees Engaged and Have Fun in the Workplace" href="/blog/careers/ways-to-keep-employees-engaged">A Few Ways to Keep Employees Engaged and Have Fun in the Workplace</a>
<a title="Ask SWC: What Are Your Favorite Career Development Initiatives" href="/blog/ask-swc/what-are-your-favorite-career-development-initiatives">Ask SWC: What Are Your Favorite Career Development Initiatives</a>

You can also watch a few of SWC’s videos on our corporate culture:

<a title="Reimagine Your Career" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/PtJXuLTIOq4?" target="_blank">Reimagine Your Career</a>
<a title="SWC Boogie Bots" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/kECxJgaPKho?" target="_blank">Boogie with SWC</a>

	<item>
		<title>If They Only Had Tableau</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/if-they-only-had-tableau</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jan 2014 23:48:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=10988</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignright size-full wp-image-10986" title="If They Only Had Tableu Photo 1" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/if-they-only-had-tableu-photo-1.jpg" alt="If They Only Had Tableu Photo 1" width="225" height="124" />I’m a car nut! Specifically, I’m in love with old classic cars from the 60’s. When I was nothing more than a twinkle in my Mother’s eye, my Dad was racing stock cars on dirt tracks in central MN in the late 60’s. My dad’s car was a late model Studebaker Hawk and he had a lot of fun with the hoppy. I sometimes wish we could see new chrome encrusted Studebakers coming out of South Bend IN again!

Which brings me to my next thought, “What if Studebaker and others had BI?” More specifically, what if they had <a title="Tableau 8 Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/tableau">Tableau</a>? Put aside the fact they would have needed a computer the size of my old high school to run Tableau in 1963 – but just imagine the possibilities! With that kid fantasy in mind, I put Studebaker and a few others back in business to present day. In the visualization, we have a dashboard of some classic bankrupt auto companies showing rate of return, dealer participation and product recalls (Sorry John Delorean – even in my fantasy world your cool stainless steel cars are crap!)
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-10987" title="If They Only Had Tableu Photo 2" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/if-they-only-had-tableu-photo-2-300x253.jpg" alt="If They Only Had Tableu Photo 2" width="300" height="253" />
Click <a href="http://public.tableausoftware.com/views/BankruptCarCompanyRateofReturn/ClassicDash?:embed=y&amp;:display_count=no" target="_blank">here</a> to access Chad’s visualization from Tableau

What was particularly fun about this exercise was the compounding Rate or Return viz. As of this writing, Tableau doesn’t yet have a built in ROR function. However, you can roll your own with a little table function magic, which is exactly what I did here. So my data set had rate of return for each calendar year but didn’t have a compound rate for many years and you can’t just sum the aggregate of yearly RORs. You need a product of all the year members filtered by the end user. The ROR formula works like this: (Period1 +1)*(Period2+1)…* (Period last +1)-1. In Tableau, we can reproduce this function by using the PREVIOUS_VALUE function in a calculation like this: PREVIOUS_VALUE(1)*(1+SUM([ROR])) and then the cumulative function used in the visualization would be this: [ROR Product] -1.

So why should anyone care? First of all, you simply can’t put this logic in your data warehouse and calculate it ahead of time. You don’t know which time period(s) the analyst is going to start/end with. In a data warehouse, if you were going to pre-populate the cumulative ROR, it would have to be since inception date and that would make for some really un-usable charts and graphs. Care to see cumulative ROR since 1902 anyone? I thought not. So the cumulative ROR as well as a host of other financial calculations that are dependent on chosen time periods can take advantage of these table calculations in Tableau. Another benefit to keeping analytic calculations in Tableau is speed of delivery. We don’t have to go back to the data warehouse and refactor, we don’t have to re-extract the dataset, we can prototype, experiment, test and retest until we have it right – all from the Tableau client. In my sample, I used Tableau Desktop pro, but I could just as easily have used the free version of Tableau Public to do the same exact visualization. Tableau is an amazing piece of technology. I just wish Studebaker had it when they needed it most!

To learn more about BI and all of the exciting new features SWC has for the business intelligence community; please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>.

If you enjoyed this post from Chad, please check out a few of our past posts on Tableau and business intelligence:

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Are Some Cool New Features of Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/cool-new-features-of-microsoft-dynamics-crm-2013</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 08 Jan 2014 11:10:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[markjohnson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11003</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of “Ask SWC,” we’re taking a look at <a title="Microsoft Dynamics Customer Relationship Management" href="/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management">Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013</a>, also known as the Fall 2013 rollout. The new release has completely changed. If you have Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2011, you will probably be in shock because it looks and behaves different than what you currently have now. Watch this episode of “Ask SWC” to see Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 in action!
<a title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 Preview" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/f6YpiUfamZU?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>
Microsoft Dynamics is <a title="Customer Relationship Management Services" href="/solutions/crm">Customer Relationship Management</a> (CRM) system that automates business processes giving teams the tools to make quick and educated decisions about customers to drive sales and build relationships. In my video, I demoed some new features in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013, including:
<ul>
	<li>The Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 Dashboard look and feel.</li>
	<li>New icons that help illustrate actions, for examples – account add and case creation. In Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 everything has its own different icon, which helps to give a visual representation of what is going on.</li>
	<li>Top navigation with nifty little boxes that populate depending on where you are. For instance, when I go to the sales section, everything changes and it shows you related items, such as opportunities and so on.</li>
	<li>Another cool feature demoed and added to Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 is a visual representation of your current view in the right column, depending on where you are in the system. You can show things like all active accounts listed by owner. This can be changed up and customized to show anything that you want. If you then switch views, it will update the graph, which is also a nice feature to have.</li>
	<li>I also like Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013’s new “Quick Create” feature. Unlike the past CRM version, you don’t have to do a lot of clicking around to create a new contact.</li>
	<li>In Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013, the idea of popups have completely gone out the window and everything is now an overlay, so you never have to leave your account view – and if you change your mind, you can easily click cancel. You do not have to go through multiple windows to get back to what you were doing, as you would have had to do in the past.</li>
	<li>The way that accounts and all records are displayed in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 has also changed. If you take a look, there is now Bing maps integration, so if you click on your account address, you can Bing map to where it is.</li>
	<li>Left navigation has also gone away in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013. The product has rolled everything up into one centralized view. Now all of my activities, posts, notes, contacts, opportunities and cases are listed right in front of me in one easy to use screen.</li>
	<li>Once again, I wanted to emphasize that the idea of popups are finally gone in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013. From my account view, I can easily create a new opportunity within an account by clicking on the plus sign, then a little pane overlays over the account and I can easily create an opportunity with the main focal points I want to capture.</li>
	<li>If I need more information on a contact or opportunity in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013, I can quickly click into that contact and you will notice there is a lot more information fills you can view or complete</li>
	<li>Another cool feature of Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 is the pipeline. It really helps you focus in on what you need to be doing at a specific stage in the sales cycle – in this case an opportunity. In my demo, I was in the qualified stage of an opportunity and the system only shows me core fields that I need to update for this stage. If I were to press through to the pipeline stage, you will see that the fields I should be focusing on change. Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 helps to automate the process so that you can focus on the stages and things that are needed to do at that point in the sales cycle. You can now do you job more efficiently because there is no need to go through tons of forms or fields and determine what needs to be updated or entered for each.</li>
</ul>
I hope you enjoyed my brief demo on Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013. Everything demoed today can be customizable to meet your unique business needs and the things your company wants to capture. Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 is a very a robust system and complete overhaul from Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2011 and I could spend hours talking about all of the enhancements and changes that were made. Hopefully this video has given you a better sense of what is new and what you have to look forward to when you upgrade to Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013.

To learn more about Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 and SWC's consulting services, call 630-572-0240.

If you enjoyed this post and want to learn more about Customer Relationship Management systems. Please read a few of our past posts:

	<item>
		<title>Business Intelligence – The Next Steps</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/bi-the-next-steps</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Jan 2014 15:08:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[billkubik]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11063</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Many times I’ve seen clients using <a title="Business Intelligence Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">business intelligence</a> to satisfy individual ad hoc and corporate reporting needs. While this is one way to use BI, there is so much more you can do with the data and the solution. We sometimes get wrapped up in our day-to-day reporting needs and miss the bigger picture. That is, to recognize (and remember) that the data in the data warehouses contain the corporate experience and history of running the business. There is a wealth of information in there to help supply answers to questions like:
<ul>
	<li>Where is our business going?</li>
	<li>What are our top customers like?</li>
	<li>Who are our less profitable customers and what should we do about them?</li>
</ul>
And also –
<ul>
	<li>How can we better partner with our customers so that we both are more profitable?</li>
	<li>What tools and knowledge can we bring to the customer’s table to gain a competitive advantage over our competitors?</li>
</ul>
I’m currently working with a client to develop a very cool BI solution which will take their reporting to this next level – true analysis of their business experience. We are creating tools that can be used to create a win-win situation for them as well as their customers. For example, intelligence cubes or <a title="Tableau Solutions" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/tableau">Tableau</a> dashboards.

The client is a leading handler of fleet vehicles for their customers and we are beginning with the data collected over the years for accident claims, routine vehicle maintenance and vehicle sales. The company has been in business since the late 1940’s and there is a wealth of historical data available.

The key item in this business is the vehicle and one of the tools we are building is the ability to create vehicle profiles by any of the hundreds of attributes available. Based on historical experience, we will be able to create very detailed ways to look at a vehicle and on average, what happens to it over its lifetime.

The profiles will allow our client to better set their customer rates based on experience and also enables them to help their customers choose the right vehicles for their needs:
<ul>
	<li>What is the average total cost for a vehicle like this over its lifetime?</li>
	<li>What is the vehicle’s propensity to be in an accident in this geography?</li>
	<li>When is the best time to replace these vehicles?</li>
	<li>If the vehicle is needed for application X, would it be better to get vehicle A or vehicle B? Which has a lower cost of maintenance?</li>
	<li>What geographical area is better to finally sell a vehicle of this type to gain the highest return?</li>
</ul>
These are just a few of the questions and answers that give our client that edge – both internally and externally with their customers. Business Intelligence is fascinating and the possibilities are endless.

To learn more about BI and all of the exciting new features SWC has for the business intelligence community; please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>.
<h2>Business Intelligence Services 630-572-0240</h2>

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Is Unified Device Management</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-is-unified-device-management</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jan 2014 11:06:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradellison]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11072</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Unified Device Management is a buzz term we are hearing more and more these days due to the consumerization of mobile products and the gaining popularity and acceptance of <a title="Bring Your Own Device Policies" href="/blog/managed-services/byod-polices-mobile-device-management">Bring Your Own Device</a> (BYOD) policies in the workplace. Watch our recent episode of “Ask SWC” to learn more about our favorite Unified Device Management tools.
<a title="Unified Device Management" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/Go0tIBFL2Ko?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>
BYOD is becoming more popular and common these days, as users want to choose the devices they work on inside and outside of the workplace. Traditionally this has presented a huge problem for IT departments in many organizations wanting to manage users’ devices in order to protect corporate data and applications and maintain security and compliance.

Unified Device Management is a great solution to both concerns and can be achieved by two Microsoft products – Windows Intune, a Mobile Device Management platform and <a title="Microsoft System Center Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft System Center 2012</a> R2 Configuration Manager. System Center Configuration Manager helps IT keep maintain security policies, update software, monitor statuses and give users access to the applications they desire on the devices they choose. While Windows Intune provides a cloud based solution to enable remote users to use the devices they choose. We like these two products because they are seamlessly integrated, so if you have System Center Configuration Manager 2012 on your internal environment to manage all of your internal resources, we can simply integrate that into the recent version of Windows Intune, which will provide an extension to managing mobile devices, work group computers and even your user’s home computers, should you need to.

Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager and Windows Intune will provide your organization with a platform for very deep and robust management of all of the PCs and devices in your environment, whether they’re internal, external, company owned or personally owned.

To learn more about System Center Configuration Manager and Mobile Device Management, please join us for our next <a title="Microsoft System Center Chicago Event" href="/events">Microsoft System Center Luncheon</a> or follow <a title="Brad Ellison Linked-In" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/brad-ellison/70/1aa/a03" target="_blank">Brad Ellison on LinkedIn</a>.
<h2>Microsoft System Center Solutions 630-572-0240</h2>
If you enjoyed this post from Brad, check out a few of our related posts on Microsoft System Center:

	<item>
		<title>Technology Meetups Make A Difference</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/technology-meetups-make-a-difference</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Jan 2014 02:01:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11123</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I was just starting my career at SWC back in the Winter of 2008 when I had an opportunity to visit Redmond and learn more about Microsoft BI and the new PerformancePoint product they were trying to get everyone excited about. It was a good event with lots of great presenters and topics. What was really interesting is that right before they escorted us off the campus, they gave us a sneak peak of their new Master Data Management product (MDS in a pre-beta state). While really sketchy on the details, <a href="http://donalddotfarmer.com/about-2/" target="_blank">Donald Farmer</a>, the godfather of Microsoft BI at the time promised this was going to be a big deal for Microsoft, BI and SQL Server when it launches!

Fast forward to present day – SQL 2012 has launched, <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/sqlserver/solutions-technologies/enterprise-information-management/master-data-services.aspx" target="_blank">MDS</a> (Master Data Services) is in its second release, new features have been brought to bear like the Excel plug-in and a much more strategic licensing model was crafted to get better MDM market penetration. All good things for MDM and SQL Server! However, the MDS product is still new to a lot of people, very few books have been written about MDS and not enough community support exists organically to take this product to the next level.

I could go on and on about how Microsoft needs to do a better job of supporting their MDS product or I could just do something about it. Doing something about it is what we chose. So back in the tail end of 2013, a group of us at SWC set out to start a <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Master-Data-Services-User-Group-Chicagoland/" target="_blank">Meetup</a> for MDS practitioners in the Chicago area. We called the group “Master Data Services – User Group – Chicagoland” and we invite anyone interested in MDS to attend whether they’re a DBA, BA, Architect or general user. The group has some simple goals: 1) Meet other MDM practitioners who share an interest in MDS 2) Learn new ideas, concepts, design patterns and best practices through our ongoing events 3) Support our members through professional collaboration. 4) Have fun and make new friends!
<table width="700" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<table width="720" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" bgcolor="#ffffff">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td colspan="7" height="40"> <img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-11128" title="Business Intelligence Community Meetup PinStripes Oak Brook" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/bi-community-invite-012314-600.jpg" alt="Business Intelligence Community Meetup PinStripes Oak Brook" width="600" height="295" /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="40"></td>
<td colspan="5">
<strong>Master Data Services User Group – Chicagoland</strong>
Please join our BI Community for our first monthly meetup at Pinstripes on January 23rd. This
complimentary event is open to those wanting to learn more and network with MDS BI users in a fun
and social setting.

<table width="640" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>

</tr>

</table>

<span class="sectiontitle">Who Should Attend?</span>

Anyone using, planning to use or just curious about Microsoft Master Data Services should attend. The group will look at various topics covering design, development and customization.
<span class="sectiontitle">RSVP on Meetup.com:</span>
<a href="http://www.meetup.com/Master-Data-Services-User-Group-Chicagoland/events/154045172/"><img style="display: block;" src="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/RSVP-now.jpg" alt="" width="133" height="52" /></a>
Can't make this event? Join our group on <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Master-Data-Services-User-Group-Chicagoland">Meetup</a> to learn more about us and our upcoming events.</td>

<h2>Coming soon…</h2>
On Thursday, January 23rd at 5:30PM, our Master Data Services group will have our first gathering! The inaugural event will be at <a href="https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;hl=en&amp;q=7+Oakbrook+Center+Mall,+Oak+Brook,+IL,+60523,+us" target="_blank">Pinstripes in Oak Brook</a> and will feature yours truly giving a talk on MDS and going through a demo on building a model in MDS. We fully expect that as our member roles increase, there will be all kinds of new and interesting topics presented by our members and special guests from the industry. We look forward to having you joining us for an evening of fun!</content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>SWC Featured On Telemundo News Broadcast</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/swc-featured-on-telemundo-news-broadcast</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 20 Jan 2014 19:33:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[gonzaloescarra]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11165</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last week, one of SWC’s Engineers was featured on Telemundo’s national evening news broadcast to discuss recent events regarding the Target data breach and CEO’s apology. The infiltration affected millions of customers, as cyber hackers forced their way into Target’s system, gaining access to credit and debit card information. Click on the photo to watch the interview (in Spanish) or read the video transcription below.
<a href="http://www.telemundo.com/noticias/2014/01/13/director-de-target-ofrece-disculpas" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11170" title="Gonzalo Escarra SWC Technology Partners Telemundo Taping" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/gonzalo-escarra-swc-technology-partners-telemundo-taping.png" alt="Gonzalo Escarra SWC Technology Partners Telemundo Taping" width="560" height="340" /></a>
<h3>Telemundo English Translation –</h3>
<h2>“Director de Target Ofrece Disculpas” – “CEO of Target Offers Apology”</h2>
Maria Celeste Arrarás, Anchor: Executive Director of the Target Company spoke exclusively with our sister network, NBC, and apologized for the infiltration of dozens of customers who ended up in the hands of cyber hackers.

Jose Diaz-Balart, Anchor: Mari, just this weekend the department store chain Neiman Marcus announced that they were also victims of this crime. Janet Rodriguez with details.

<strong>[Filtration of Information]</strong>

Janet Rodriguez, Reporter: Yesenia Rangel said that a purchase at Target caused her a big headache.

<strong>[Yesenia Rangel was affected by the theft of information]</strong>

Yesenia Rangel, Interviewee: I was sent an email telling me that it was one of the cards found at Target.

Janet Rodriguez, Reporter: She and millions more were affected by information leakage occurred at the end of last year. Today for the first time, the person in charge of the company gave an apology.

<strong>[Gregg Steinhafel, CEO of Target]</strong>

Gregg Steinhafel, CEO: I am personally very sorry that this whole thing happened.

Janet Rodriguez, Reporter: He says he is personally sorry for what happened. The investigation into the theft of over 100 million customers’ credit and debit card information of Target continues.

Gregg Steinhafel, CEO: What we do know there was a malware installed on our….

Janet Rodriguez, Reporter: What is known now, says the Executive Director, is that the cash registers were infected with a cyber-virus is known as malware.

<strong>[Gonzalo Escarrá, SWC Technology Partners Engineer]</strong>

Gonzalo Escarrá, SWC Engineer: A program specifically designed to cause harm or spy system information.

Janet Rodriguez, Reporter: In a letter, Democrats in financial services committee of the lower house, called on Republicans to conduct a hearing in Congress about what happened to Target. Meanwhile, the luxurious department store, Neiman Marcus, has also announced that cyber pirates attacked their system. They have not revealed how many customers may have been affected.

Gonzalo Escarrá, SWC Engineer: When you have physical access to the cash register or computer systems, one can insert a device into the computer it infects.

Janet Rodriguez, Reporter: It would be surprising for many more to affirm allegedly being hacked. So far, Macy's and Wal-Mart companies have ensured that their customers do not have to worry about. Meanwhile, the CEO of Target says they have already removed malware from their cash registers and ensures implementation of a new technology to protect themselves from theft.

<strong>[Janet Rodriguez, Reporter – Chicago, IL]</strong>

Janet Rodriguez, Reporter: Some customers tell us they have now lost all confidence in Target after this incident and ensure that there will be no security measure that can be implemented to make them pay by card.

Yesenia Rangel, Interviewee: I no longer trust Target to buy with a card, anymore. No more.

Janet Rodriguez, Reporter: Many say not it’s not worth the uncertainty and will spare themselves by paying cash.

In Chicago, Janet Rodríguez, Telemundo

<h2>SWC's Chicago Area Managed IT Services 630-572-0240.</h2>

			<wp:meta_key>_thumbnail_id</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft SharePoint 2013 Demo To Go</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-2013-demo-to-go</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Jan 2014 18:41:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11239</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I recently had some techie fun putting together a self-contained <a title="Microsoft SharePoint 2013" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-2013">Microsoft SharePoint 2013</a> demonstration environment that I can run on my laptop in 32GB of RAM. It includes virtual machines running pfSense (a Linux-based router/firewall), Windows 2008R2 Active Directory Domain Controller, SQL Server 2012 Enterprise, SharePoint Server 2013 Enterprise, Lync Server 2013, Office Web Apps 2013 and <a title="Tableau 8 Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/tableau">Tableau Server 8</a>. While it's true I can't run them all at the same time, it's still amazing to me that I'm able to do it at all. This setup enables me to demonstrate the value of SharePoint, including its great integration with the rest of the major Microsoft products, all without the need for an internet connection or any other servers!

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11233" title="Habiflex Homepage" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Habiflex1Homepage.png" alt="Habiflex Homepage" width="600" height="523" />
The core of the virtual demo environment is pfSense, Active Directory and SharePoint 2013 (with local SQL). These three VMs run very well in 16GB of RAM – once I 'warm up' the <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a> server by hitting some of the main pages, the response is quite good. In fact, it's faster than when I used to connect to a remote server at my office via the internet and DirectAccess. I'm sure it wouldn't stand up to a production scenario with multiple users, but it's great for demonstrations.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11234" title="Habiflex Leadership Site" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Habiflex2LeadershipSite.png" alt="Habiflex Leadership Site" width="600" height="549" />
I usually start up the Lync server as well, which needs 4GB of RAM. This enables the integration between SharePoint and <a title="Microsoft Lync Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Lync</a>. The most obvious manifestation is the 'presence indicator,' which is a little colored square that appears next to everyone's name, everywhere that names occur in SharePoint (or Office and other MS applications). The indicator turns green when the named person is logged in and available, yellow when they're offline and red when they're unavailable (like in a meeting or on a call). When you mouse-over the person's presence indicator, it pops up the 'people card.’ The 'people card' shows you relevant data about the person, including their picture, title, contact information and more. The 'people card' has buttons that allow you immediately start communicating with that person, via instant message (IM/chat), telephone, video, audio or web conference or email. In my demo, I'm actually able to mimic two people starting up a chat session, inviting others to participate, sharing desktops, and more.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11235" title="Habiflex Lync Practice Card" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Habiflex3LyncPracticeCard.png" alt="Habiflex Lync Practice Card" width="599" height="388" />
If the audience wants to see a demonstration of business intelligence solutions, I can turn off Lync and start up my BI demo server, which includes all of Microsoft SQL Server 2012's capabilities and Tableau Server 8. This VM needs 8GB RAM, and while it isn't the fastest, it's certainly adequate for a one user demo scenario. This allows me to show off various structured reporting scenarios with SQL Server Reporting Services. I can fire up Excel 2013, which is a great tool for exploring and analyzing OLAP cube-based data via PowerPivot or SQL Server Analysis Services. Excel tables, charts and graphs can then be displayed directly in SharePoint through Excel Services. I can demonstrate the types of scorecards and dashboards that can be built with SharePoint's PerformancePoint Services (PPS). I can compare and contrast PPS against Tableau, which is an increasingly popular third-party solution that provides some great data visualization capabilities, rendered inside SharePoint sites and pages.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11236" title="Habiflex Leadership Practice Dashboard" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Habiflex4LeadershipPracticeDashboard.png" alt="Habiflex Leadership Practice Dashboard" width="599" height="476" />
Finally, I can fire up my Office Web Applications virtual demo server (4 GB VM) and highlight its greatly improved capabilities for editing documents, spreadsheets, slide decks and notes directly inside a web browser. A nice side benefit to Office Web Apps is an improved experience when viewing search results in SharePoint 2013. When you mouse-over an Office file on the search results screen, it displays a popup window with an actual rendering of the file, so you can see what it looks like and make sure it's what you're looking for, before you open it.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11237" title="Habiflex Search Results" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Habiflex5SearchResults.png" alt="Habiflex Search Results" width="600" height="549" />
Altogether, it's been a fantastic experience for me to be able to present and demonstrate all the great capabilities and integration points of Microsoft's latest generation of technologies. It really helps my audience envision the value of the 'Microsoft Stack.' And, the best part is – it frees me from the pain and risk of needing an encrypted internet connection to remote servers, through spotty guest wireless routers!

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11238" title="Habiflex My Site" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Habiflex6MySite.png" alt="Habiflex My Site" width="600" height="469" />
To learn more about how Microsoft SharePoint, please join us for our next <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Chicago Event" href="/events">Chicago area SharePoint event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Lanham LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-lanham/22/125/a99" target="_blank">Jeff Lanham on LinkedIn</a>.
<h2>Microsoft SharePoint consulting services 630.572.0240.</h2>
If you enjoyed this post, feel free to check out a few of our past posts on Microsoft SharePoint:

	<item>
		<title>Do Tableau And MDS Make Strange Bedfellows?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/do-tableau-mds-make-strange-bedfellows</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 24 Jan 2014 07:15:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11253</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you’ve ever spent time reading <a title="Tableau Solutions" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/tableau">Tableau</a> marketing material or went to a Tableau launch party you know that Tableau is all about ease of access to data! Nearly every data source you can think of has a native connector built right into the product. You’d be hard pressed to find a data source that Tableau isn’t able to integrate with either natively or via an ODBC driver. But there is a data problem that can’t be solved with another new connector. What’s a Tableau user to do if the data doesn’t exist, or a relationship is missing, or the data requires manipulation? You do have some fairly robust options within Tableau Desktop to make data corrections. Just last week I used that feature to fix some geography data right in Tableau Desktop. But what if those corrections need to get back to the source system? Or what if lots of users are fixing data quality right from Tableau? That’s certainly a data governance issue for many organizations to be concerned with don’t you think?
<h2>Enter SQL Server Master Data Services</h2>
Lately we seem to be finding lots of good use cases for our customers who are on <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">SQL Server 2012</a> to leverage Master Data Services in many new and creative ways. What’s been particularly interesting is the usage of MDS to augment a Tableau project by providing those missing data sources or by enabling a missing relationship between multiple sources.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11257" title="Tableau Master Data Services Spreadsheet Snapshot" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/tableau-microsoft-data-services-spreadsheet-snapshot.png" alt="Tableau Master Data Services Spreadsheet Snapshot" width="600" height="211" />

So let’s talk about the missing data source problem first. Missing data is a classic <a title="Business Intelligence Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a> problem that needs to get solved. In the past, we would solve the missing data issue by creating a surrogate data source managed by some entity (user, team, or process). The data source oftentimes would be an Excel spreadsheet or in better situations, an actual table on SQL Server. The surrogate approach works functionally but there’s a huge downside due to the lack of process, governance, quality or all of the above. Now that Master Data Services has the Excel plugin, we can build models and entities to fill the missing data gap, users interact with the model via Excel, and business rules and MDS workflows ensure the quality of that data. In our BI demo environment at SWC, we use MDS to fill the data gap for campaign management. Our fictitious company didn’t have the money to pony up for a campaign management system so we built the campaign model in MDS. This approach works! If you were doing something like this in Excel or MS Access, you really need to think about a migration to MDS.

This leads me to the second problem we can solve for BI with MDS and that is the ability to manage and insert the missing relationships. Certainly there are plenty of examples where a savvy ETL developer can use logic to discover and infer the missing relationships in the data warehouse but there are situations where human intellect and decision making are necessary. If there are data sources you want to leverage in Tableau but lack the ability to blend them to the desired level of granularity, MDS could be the answer. On several projects we’ve wrestled with these data relationship problems and found the creation of a mapping entity in MDS was the cleanest, surest way to get the problem solved successfully.

Because we’re using MDS, not only do we benefit by having the missing relationship filled in but we also have a complete audit trail see what happened:
<ol>
	<li>Who setup the relationship?</li>
	<li>When was the relationship established?</li>
	<li>How many change iterations have occurred?</li>
	<li>Is the record valid based on business rules established by the business?</li>
</ol>
And there are many more benefits.

So back to Tableau. Many Tableau users love the ease of use of the tool and the ability to quickly bring ideas to life or answer questions with a compelling visualization. In situations where the data doesn’t exist, is incomplete, or is not blend-able via the Tableau data blending feature, we now have another data weapon at our disposal that can quickly be put into place to solve issues on the model side just like Tableau does on the visualization side.

<strong>Click on the image below to watch Chad’s demonstration of how Tableau and Microsoft Master Data Services work together.</strong>
<a title="SWC BI - Tableau And Master Data Services Demo" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/i_HbKG2W3rw?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-blog-post-general-play-video-placeholder.jpg" alt="SWC Blog Video Player" width="474" height="262" /></a>
<em>In this project (and in many others we have completed), the success of the Tableau dashboard we built was made possible by having a tool like Master Data Services to fill in some of the data gaps or incorrect data coming from source systems. In this demo we are using a fictitious company on Yammer to analyze data from social media using an algorithm to score social media updates as positive, negative or neutral. Using this tool, we can better understand the social sentiment of our product and company on various social media sites such as Facebook and Twitter.</em>

To learn more about BI and all of the exciting new features SWC has for the business intelligence community; please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Events" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>.

If you enjoyed this post from Chad, please check out a few of our past posts on Tableau and business intelligence:

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Do You Like Most About Working At SWC?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-do-you-like-most-about-working-at-swc-technology-partners</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 28 Jan 2014 17:45:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kathrynchrismer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11272</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of my favorite parts about working at <a title="Chicago IT Consulting Firm" href="http://www.swc.com">Chicago area IT consulting firm</a>, SWC is that they host a ton of awesome events and fun social gatherings. Watch my ‘Ask SWC’ video to learn more about the many benefits and fun events I enjoy working at SWC.
<a title="Best Part of Working at SWC" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/1Y0e-m0f1wM?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>
SWC has an amazing corporate culture and one of the things I like the most about our culture is all of the great events we have. Some of my favorites are our Cubs outings, Whirlyball Tournaments, Pinstripes bowling and bocce ball events and the amazing holiday party we throw each year. The holiday party is s a great evening downtown that the whole company attends. There is always a band, tons of food and beverages and the company even provides a hotel room for each employee and their guest. It’s so much fun and one of the things I look forward to each year working at SWC.

SWC truly encourages employees to socialize by sponsoring a multitude of fun events. Social activities within the offices include frequently catered breakfasts and lunches, monthly birthday treats and various parties to further boost morale. Another unique event for the company is the ‘SWC Olympics’ a two-week battle that pits various teams against each other in friendly competition with ping pong battles, Wii tournaments, dodgeball, poker, talent competitions and myriad of other events. Additionally, every Friday at 4 PM work ceases so that employees can meet in the kitchen to socialize over beverages and snacks.

If you are looking for an amazing career in IT or a career change, head over to <a title="Chicago IT Jobs" href="/careers">SWC Careers</a> and learn more.

	<item>
		<title>One System Center To Rule Them All</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/one-system-center-to-rule-them-all</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Jan 2014 10:22:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11284</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The latest suite of <a title="Microsoft System Center Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft System Center</a> products is reshaping the landscape of datacenter management and automation. Historically, a Microsoft-centric toolset, <a title="Microsoft System Center 2012 R2" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/microsoft-system-center-2012-r2">System Center 2012 R2</a> is changing this paradigm in a big way. Every single product has been extended to be both cross-platform and cloud-oriented. So, what does this mean for you?

It means that these improvements provide a unified single-pane-of-glass experience for help desk staff, a consistent set of automation tools for IT pros and a wealth of reporting statistics for business decision makers. This Microsoft System Center people-centric approach facilitates the latest trends, such as <a title="Bring Your Own Device Policies" href="/blog/managed-services/byod-polices-mobile-device-management">Bring Your Own Device</a> (BYOD) and the Consumerization of IT (CoIT) across public clouds and private clouds – so you can compute anywhere, anytime.
<h2>There are eight “pillars” of Microsoft System Center 2012 R2:</h2>
<ul>
	<li><a title="System Center Configuration Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">Configuration Manager (SCCM)</a> – A robust tool for application and operating system deployment</li>
	<li>System Center Endpoint Protection – An industry awarded antivirus that is both lightweight and powerful</li>
	<li><a title="System Center Operations Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/operations-manager-scom">Operations Manager (SCOM)</a> – Which provides detailed infrastructure monitoring – down to the code level</li>
	<li><a title="System Center Service Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/service-manager">Service Manager</a> – A help desk portal for self-service delivery and data analytics</li>
	<li><a title="System Center Orchestrator" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/orchestrator">Orchestrator</a> – A hub of datacenter automation and integration for complex sequencing</li>
	<li><a title="System Center Virtual Machine Manager &amp; App Controller" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/virtual-machine-manager-app-controller">Virtual Machine Manager (SCVMM)</a> – Infrastructure abstraction for private and public clouds</li>
	<li><a title="System Center Virtual Machine Manager &amp; App Controller" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/virtual-machine-manager-app-controller">System Center App Controller</a> – A self-service portal for application owners and operators</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/data-protection-manager" title="System Center Data Protection Manager" target="_blank">System Center Data Protection Manager</a> – A solution for backing up the entire infrastructure stack</li>
</ul>
Greater detail on the capabilities of each of these products, including their levels of integration within the suite and third party ecosystems have been explored in our upcoming series of blogs – you can access our most recent System Center posts <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/category/microsoft-system-center" title="Microsoft System Center Blogs" target="_blank">here</a>.  

To learn more about Microsoft System Center, please join us for our upcoming <a title="Microsoft System Center Event" href="/events">Microsoft System Center Luncheon</a>.
<h2>Microsoft System Center Solutions 630-572-0240</h2>
If you enjoyed this post from Kurt, please check out a few of our related posts on Microsoft System Center:

	<item>
		<title>Integrating Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/integrating-microsoft-system-center-configuration-manager-2012-r2</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 06 Feb 2014 15:53:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeffpoling]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11329</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Integrating Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2</h2>
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-11327" title="Jeff Poling SWC Technology Partners" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jeff-poling-swc-technology-partners.jpg" alt="Jeff Poling SWC Technology Partners" width="563" height="145" />
Business and IT are in constant motion – application and device deployments, operating system upgrades and patch management are continual tasks for even the smallest IT shop. Not only are there tasks to accomplish, but the world of IT is changing rapidly. <a title="Microsoft Windows XP End Of Life" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/april-2014-windows-xp-support-ends">Windows XP is rapidly approaching its end-of-life</a>. Users are more mobile and take advantage of a variety of devices and applications. How can IT support this dynamic business environment?

<a title="Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012</a> provides a comprehensive solution for addressing the needs of today’s IT organization. In a “single pane of glass,” applications and updates are distributed, operating systems are deployed, devices are managed and inventory is tracked.

Providing applications to business users when and how they need them is a critical part of IT’s role. With Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2, applications can be packaged in multiple ways, whether it’s traditional Windows Installer packages, App-V packages, or modern apps for Windows 8.1. Not only can applications be deployed in a variety of ways, but System Center Configuration Manager also provides the tools for putting applications directly in the hands of users. The Application Catalog provides a portal for users to obtain the software they need, when they need it. While enabling users’ access to applications, System Center Configuration Manager also provides IT the control needed to maintain the environment. Approvals can be set for applications so that compliance with licensing agreements is maintained. Critical security and other updates can be packaged and deployed as well. System Center Configuration Manager provides the ability to automate the process of downloading, packaging and deploying software updates using automatic deployment rules.

Windows XP is still a fixture in many environments. With the end-of-life for XP nearing, IT needs the tools to upgrade or migrate away from the old operating system. System Center Configuration Manager streamlines and simplifies the operating system deployment process using task sequences. In addition, it integrates with other tools from Microsoft such as the Windows Automated Deployment Kit (ADK) and Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT). IT can perform lite touch or zero touch deployments of modern operating systems as it seeks to fully move away from Windows XP.

Managing the proliferation of devices being used in the business environment is a critical part of IT’s role. System Center Configuration Manager can manage mobile devices using integration with <a title="Microsoft Exchange Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-exchange-2013">Microsoft Exchange</a> or using <a title="Cloud Solutions" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud</a> tools such as Windows Intune. In addition, cross-platform agents are available for Linux, UNIX and Mac. There also antivirus engines provided for across platforms. Using <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server</a> Reporting Services, System Center Configuration Manager can also provide detailed insight into devices and the environment through numerous out-of-the-box reports.

Whether it is application deployment, operating system upgrades or managing the variety of devices on today’s networks, System Center Configuration Manager provides IT the tools needed to manage an ever changing and evolving business environment.

To learn more about Microsoft System Center, please join us for our upcoming <a title="Chicago System Center 2012 Event" href="/events">Microsoft System Center Event</a>.
<h2>Microsoft System Center Consulting 630-572-0240</h2>

		<title>Ask SWC: What Does Microsoft’s Windows XP Anti-Malware Extension Mean?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-does-microsofts-windows-xp-anti-malware-extension-mean</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Feb 2014 16:10:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeremyalt]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11332</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft recently released that they will be providing an extension of anti-malware for Windows XP until 2015. But what does this mean? Watch our latest “Ask SWC” video to learn more.

<a title="Microsoft's Windows XP Anti-Malware Extension" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/pQH_zxyyQpQ?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC Chicago IT Consulting Firm" width="474" height="262" /></a>

In the last few weeks there has been a lot of uproar about <a title="Microsoft Windows Consulting" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft</a> extending the anti-malware updates for Windows XP until 2015. But what a lot of people don’t realize is that this doesn’t really do a lot for us and there are still some glaring security holes for those running Windows XP, as operating systems won’t be patched. Microsoft will not extend any support to anyone on Windows XP. The 2015 anti-malware extension means Microsoft will only provide updates for Microsoft Security Essentials and virus definition updates will be offered for <a title="Microsoft System Center Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft System Center</a> Endpoint Protection users.

The April 2014 deadline is still a crucial time, as Microsoft will only be giving antivirus protection through 2015 and no Windows XP security updates. A lot of our customers will continue to ask us how to get to Windows 7 or 8.1, and there are a lot of options SWC can offer around virtual desktops and virtual PC rollouts. If your business still operates on Windows XP, SWC offers <a title="Desktop Deployment Assessments" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/april-2014-windows-xp-support-ends">desktop deployment assessments</a> to prepare for Windows XP end of life. SWC’s proven methodology will help you identify where your vulnerabilities are and complete a seamless migration to the right desktop operating system for your business.

If you enjoyed this post from Jeremy, check out a few of our related posts on Windows XP end of life:

	<item>
		<title>Quick Tip After Moving The Central Management Store To A Lync 2013 Pool</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/quick-tip-after-moving-the-central-management-store-to-a-lync-2013-pool</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Feb 2014 19:31:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11499</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I wanted to share a quick tip after moving the Central Management Store to a <a title="Microsoft Lync 2013 Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Lync 2013</a> pool. We’ve seen this many times over, after you’ve followed the instructions from Microsoft’s Technet article: <a href="http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj688013.aspx" target="_blank">http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj688013.aspx</a> and you’ve run get-csmanagementstorereplicationstatus. You either see nothing – emptiness, or all replication shows false. The simple solution is to ensure that you’ve followed all the steps and then check all of your Lync services to ensure they started. The biggest offenders are Lync Server File Transfer Agent and Lync Server Master Replicator Agent. Start those services up and you should be fine in a few minutes.

If you’d like assistance planning your path to <a title="Unified Communications Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications">Microsoft Unified Communications</a> please <a title="Contact SWC" href="/contact">contact SWC</a>, connect with <a title="Anthony Caragol LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/anthony-caragol/6/48/488" target="_blank">Anthony Caragol on LinkedIn</a> or join us for our next <a title="Chicago Microsoft Lync Event" href="/events">Unified Communications event</a>.

To learn more about Microsoft Lync, check out a few of Anthony’s technical blogs:

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft System Center Licensing Key Points</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/licensing-key-points</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Feb 2014 16:20:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11538</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The licensing model for <a title="Microsoft System Center Solutions" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">Microsoft System Center</a> has changed significantly from the previous release and this has resulted in some confusion and uncertainty when it comes to the current wave. Not to worry – SWC can help clarify what you need. In this blog post, we’ll give you the key decision points and requirements for System Center licensing.

In System Center 2007, there was no unified suite, thus each product had to be licensed individually. This meant purchasing <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server</a> instances, use-rights for each management server and Management Licenses (MLs) for each device.

But all this has been greatly simplified now in <a title="Microsoft System Center 2012 R2" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/microsoft-system-center-2012-r2">Microsoft System Center 2012 R2</a>. For starters, the whole suite is licensed together – you get all of the products! And, the rights to use Microsoft SQL Server 2012 are also included.

A standard license is ideal for a lightly virtualized private cloud and grants rights to two Operating System Environments (OSEs) per license. For highly virtualized environments, a datacenter license offers the same feature set with unlimited OSEs.

As with all of the Microsoft Windows products, CALs are required for each physical and virtual machine. For additional details on Microsoft System Center licensing and product information, please visit Microsoft’s <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/licensing/about-licensing/SystemCenter2012.aspx#tab=4" target="_blank">FAQ</a> page or contact one of SWC’s Microsoft licensing specialists, to help you figure out the best way to deploy Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 in your organization.

To learn more about Microsoft System Center, please join us for our upcoming <a title="Microsoft System Center Event" href="/events">Microsoft System Center Event</a>.
<h2>Microsoft System Center Consulting 630-572-0240</h2>
If you enjoyed this post from Kurt, please check out a few of our related posts on Microsoft System Center:

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Is The New R Feature For Tableau 8.1</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-is-the-new-r-feature-for-tableau-8-1</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 Feb 2014 12:51:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11548</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Everyone is talking about R these days and no, that doesn’t make them pirates! R is a popular (and free) statistical language for predictive analytics that can now be integrated into Tableau 8.1, one of our favorite <a title="Business Intelligence Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">business intelligence</a> tools. Watch my recent episode of “Ask SWC” to learn more about R.
<a title="Tableau 8.1 and R" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/zdDXdHxtevw?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Tableau 8.1 and R" width="474" height="262" /></a>
R is a popular statistical language if you haven’t heard of it before. A lot of people are now using it for predictive analytics and advanced statistical analysis for things like linear regression, advanced “what if” analysis, data mining and also sentiment analysis. It’s great for people trying to do predictive analysis or a lot of analytics on big data or large data sets efficiently and effectively. The other benefit is that it’s free – R is an open source software environment and programming language. One of the nice things about the open source community is that they are always collaborating and developing new features and functionality to publish back to the community.

So why are we talking more about R now? In the past R was typically used by data scientists and people that were very technical. But now that R has been integrated with <a title="Tableau 8 Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/tableau-8">Tableau 8.1</a>, R features and functionality have greatly enhanced Tableau’s past predictive modeling type capabilities for trending and forecasting. Those functions and models can be used in Tableau by creating different types of calculated fields that dynamically evoke the R engine, passing the values to R and then R passes the values back to Tableau to produce great visualizations. Now people that have become very proficient in R will have the ability to use rich visualizations and people who are newer to R and looking to do more predictive modeling will have an entry way into the solution.

We have had heard so many positive conversations around this topic, that we are focusing our entire first meetup of our Business Intelligence Chicagloand group and community around it. Chad Dotzenrod will lead a discussion and demonstration for the group on Tableau and R. I’d encourage you to join us if you’re available and want to learn more on <strong>Thursday, February 20th at Pinstripes in Oak Brook</strong>. The event starts at 5:30 PM, the presentation will be at 6:00 PM, and then you can stay for bowling and bocce and lots of other fun discussions around BI.

You can register for the business intelligence meetup event at the following link: <a title="Business Intelligence Meetup" href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup2-20-14.html">http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup2-20-14.html</a>

If you are not able to make the event, we are doing a lot more in the way of technical blogs and providing more information to our business intelligence community groups. So if you haven’t yet subscribed to our blog yet, I encourage you to do so and stay tuned to SWC. We’ll continue to publish great content in the future.

To learn more about Tableau and all of the exciting new features R has for the business intelligence community, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a> or follow <a title="Rachael Narel LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/rachael-l-narel-cisa/0/8a5/889/" target="_blank">Rachael Narel on LinkedIn</a>.
