	<item>
		<title>No Biggie: Data As A No Brainer</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/no-biggie-data-as-a-no-brainer</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Feb 2014 13:24:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[patriciamotta]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11572</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>The Data, Information &amp; Knowledge Paradigm</h2>
As information scientists, our goal is to understand the structural and/or functional relationships among data, information and knowledge. Typically, information is defined in terms of data and knowledge in terms of information [1], so it is easy to characterize the three concepts as a continuum. Data is merely raw facts [2], observations and by itself is not usable until it is structured in a usable, relevant form. We call this relevant form information – the meaning we attribute to raw facts. Information is useful because it answers questions such as “who,” “what,” “where,” etc. [2]. Knowledge however is an elusive concept because it originates and is applied in the minds of “knowers,” [3] and then embedded in documents and repositories as well as in organizational routines, processes, practices and norms.
<h2>Business Intelligence and the Big Data Bottleneck</h2>
<a title="Chicago Area Business Intellgence Solutions" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a> studies data and information that play a key role in the strategic planning process of a corporation. Companies consume and process information, creating the knowledge to improve decision making, cut costs and identify new business opportunities or inefficient business processes that are ripe for reengineering.

As technology advanced, however, it brought a key problem: collections of data sets so large and complex that it became difficult – if not impossible – to process them using traditional database management tools and data processing applications. You may have heard of it. It’s called Big Data [4]. Some of the challenges of Big Data involve determining whether the quality of information is good and refining the information into usable knowledge.
<h2>Machine Learning: One Step Further</h2>
Big data requires exceptional technologies to efficiently process large quantities of data. One of the suitable technologies is called Machine Learning, a branch of artificial intelligence concerned with the construction and study of systems that can learn from data. For example, a system could be trained to understand a user’s past behavior as well as similar decisions made by other users; then use this model to predict the rating or preference that a user would give to a movie or book.

As the number of individuals that are active on a social networking continues to grow, the ability to understand what people say online by the application of data analytics becomes a “no-brainer.” Sentiment Analysis uses social media algorithms to understand the sentiment of customers in real time, knowing how they perceive new products, services or campaigns. It uses Natural Language processing to extract the subjective information with respect to some topic – the attitude of a speaker or writer and whether it is positive, negative or neutral.
<h2>Sentiment Analysis as a Strategic Advantage</h2>
Sentiment Analysis is strategic to any business. Imagine the potential of automating the task of analyzing what is said online providing insights into what customers are really looking for. It enables retailers to develop the product customers want instead of the product marketing departments think they want. Businesses can test hypothesis before spending any capital on product development by observing how customers feel about your brand, how they react to your marketing campaigns and more.

Machine Learning is the holy grail of analytics. It takes Business Intelligence to the next level, bridging the gap between data and real knowledge. It learns from experience automating the task of understanding contextual information, eliminating the need for human intuition and providing insight into the minds of knowers – the customer. There are a wide variety of learning tasks and successful applications. On my next post I will further explore the task of analyzing sentiment and once more try to persuade you that the pressure to exploit analytics as a strategic advantage is increasing for an obvious reason – the high cost of not knowing.

To learn more about business intelligence and all of the exciting new features SWC has for Big Data and the BI community; please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicagoland Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>.

<h2>Chicagoland Business Intelligence Meetups</h2>
The SWC Business Intelligence Community is also hosting monthly Chicagoland BI meetups. These complimentary events are open to those wanting to learn more and network with other BI users in a fun and social setting. Our next meetup is <strong>Thursday, February 20th at Pinstripes in Oak Brook</strong>. The topic is Tableau and “R” Integration, led by Chad Dotzenrod. The event starts at 5:30 PM, the presentation will be at 6:00 PM, followed by bowling, bocce and lots of other fun discussions around BI.

Please <a title="Register For BI Meetup Event" href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup2-20-14.html" target="_blank">register</a> for the business intelligence meetup at the following link:
<a title="Chicago BI Meetup" href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup2-20-14.html" target="_blank">http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup2-20-14.html</a>

If you can’t make this event, but are interested in future Chicagoland Business Intelligence events, please join our groups on meetup.

<a title="Business Intelligence Chicagoland Meetup" href="http://www.meetup.com/Business-Intelligence-Chicagoland/ " target="_blank">http://www.meetup.com/Business-Intelligence-Chicagoland/</a>
<a title="Master Data Services Chicagoland Meetup" href="http://www.meetup.com/Master-Data-Services-User-Group-Chicagoland/" target="_blank">http://www.meetup.com/Master-Data-Services-User-Group-Chicagoland/</a>

[2] Henry, Nicholas L. (May/June 1974). "Knowledge Management: A New Concern for Public Administration". Public Administration Review 34 (3): 189. doi:10.2307/974902
[3] Wallace, Danny P. (2007). Knowledge Management: Historical and Cross-Disciplinary Themes. Libraries Unlimited. pp. 1–14. ISBN 978-1-59158-502-2.
[4] White, Tom (10 May 2012). Hadoop: The Definitive Guide. O'Reilly Media. p. 3. ISBN 978-1-4493-3877-0

	<item>
		<title>Why SWC And IT Departments Like Office 365</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/why-swc-it-departments-like-office-365</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Feb 2014 18:16:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11661</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft Office 365 is a very popular product that we are hearing a lot of buzz about from our customers. This cloud based solution provides users with access to all of the Microsoft Office applications they use every day, on any device, from any location. The solution gives users Office access and functionality from work, home or even on the road using a large selection of smart and mobile devices. Another reason we like Office 365 is that the product offers stability, reliability and scalability. Microsoft prides itself on achieving 99.9% uptime, data center redundancy and scalability of their Office 365 cloud solution.

Perhaps my favorite benefits of switching to Office 365 are around email. Office 365 significantly reduces the hassles of patching, maintenance and/or upgrading complex on premise mail systems, as the responsibility and costs associated with on premise mail systems are shifted to Microsoft. This includes items such as hardware and maintenance, high availability/Disaster Recovery, backup and recovery, storage space and security and compliance. Office 365 users also have 50GB of email storage and new security tools and features such as <a title="Microsoft Exchange Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-exchange-2013">Exchange</a> online protection, data loss prevention and even journaling.

IT departments also enjoy the ability to add additional services and/or integration of services in the cloud with Office 365, without the costs of on premise hardware, maintenance, backup and support. This is great for products like <a title="Microsoft Lync Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a>, <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Solutions" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a>, SkyDrive, Office Web App Integration, etc. There is however an increase in cost per user/license depending on which service offerings you choose, but the cost can be tailored accordingly to each user’s requirements or services.

Finally, Office 365’s new Azure Directory Synchronization tool gives users the ability to synchronize local Active Directory account attributes and passwords. One caveat to this is that Active Directory synchronization will make the <a title="Cloud Solutions" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud</a> accounts “read only” and all changes must take place in the local Active Directory and this will not provide a “Single Sign On (SSO)” experience. An Active Directory Federation Service is required for this functionality.

If you’d like assistance planning your path to Microsoft Office 365, please contact SWC or join us for our next <a title="Microsoft Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Microsoft Unified Communications event</a>, where we will explore Microsoft Exchange and SWC’s on premise and cloud based email solutions.

		<title>Integrating Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection 2012 R2</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/integrating-microsoft-system-center-endpoint-protection-2012-r2</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 21 Feb 2014 15:58:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeffpoling]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11689</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s Friday afternoon and the weekend is so close. Then the phone rings. . . and rings again. Soon call volume on the help desk sky rockets and the nightmare begins – a malware outbreak! No one wants to get those calls, yet malware is a stark reality for IT staff and managers. Protecting corporate data and assets is a top priority. Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection provides the reliable protection that all businesses require as part of any “defense in depth” strategy for combating malware. Integration with <a title="Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager</a>, cross-platform support, simple configuration and robust reporting are the key to Endpoint Protection’s effectiveness as an industry-leading anti-malware platform.

Deploying and managing Endpoint Protection is accomplished through the Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager console. Having anti-malware management in the same console as application and OS deployment as well as compliance management and inventory provides a true “single pane of glass” view into the entire IT infrastructure. The same staff skillsets leveraged for deploying operating systems and applications can be utilized for rolling out anti-malware software, policies and configuration. Using Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager to deploy and manage Endpoint Protection also reduces the need for learning additional management tools and consoles.

In addition to Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager integration, Endpoint Protection also provides cross-platform anti-malware support. Client software is available both for the Mac platform as well as various Linux platforms. Cross platform support again means a single view into the environment that simplifies management and security of endpoints. Not only is there cross-platform support, but Microsoft recently announced that in spite of the <a title="Windows XP End Of Life" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/april-2014-windows-xp-support-ends">end of life for Windows XP</a>, anti-malware definition updates for the Windows XP platform will continue to be released. This means that while Windows XP systems are being decommissioned, the anti-malware platform can continue to be maintained.

Finally, the Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager console provides robust reporting for Endpoint Protection. An in-console dashboard is available for viewing quick statistics on definition status and malware detections. More detailed out-of-the-box reports are available using the SQL Server Reporting Services back-end provided with Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager. Having insight into the status of the anti-malware platform enables IT to quickly and efficiently remediate any issues.

Friday afternoon calls are never the first choice for any IT manager, but Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection has got you covered – protecting your environment and your weekend!

To learn more about Microsoft System Center, please join us for our next <a title="Chicago System Center Events" href="/events">Microsoft System Center Event</a>.<h3>Additional Microsoft System Center Posts</h3>

	<item>
		<title>SWC Video Featuring Custom Application Development Services</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/application-development/integrity-payment-systems-custom-application-development</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Feb 2014 17:59:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeffhoffmann]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11709</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When Integrity Payment Systems needed to build a custom merchant services application, they turned to SWC’s custom application development team. We created a solution that was scalable and secure, giving Integrity Payment Systems the ability to control every aspect of their customer’s experience as well as provide their employees with all of the information they needed to effectively do their jobs. Watch our video below to learn more about how Integrity Payment Systems has found success using SWC’s <a title="Custom Application Development Services" href="/solutions/custom-application-development">custom application development services</a>.
<a title="Chicago Area IT Consultants Create Custom Merchant Services Application" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/wVC9Fne6P6I?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/integrity-payment-systems-custom-application-development-video.jpg" alt="Integrity Payment Systems Custom Application Development Video" width="500" height="281" /></a>
Integrity Payment Systems is a merchant service provider and acquirer of merchant processing. The average person walking down the street probably has no idea how credit cards flow once they walk into a store. They think they swipe their card and Visa takes care of everything, but in between Visa and that card holder there is a whole industry of merchant service providers that ensure those merchants are set up to accept the card, that the card gets charged properly and that the merchant gets paid properly.

<a title="Integrity Payment Systems Case Study Video" href="/perspective/videos/integrity-payment-systems-custom-application">Integrity Payment Systems</a> is a unique business, it’s a closely held business and processes approximately $3.5 billion worth of credit card transactions each year. The company felt they needed to build a custom merchant services application that would give them control over every aspect of the customer experience as well as make sure that their own employees had to all of the information they needed to effectively do their jobs and provide exceptional customer service.

There are several things that are important when you’re implementing a merchant services application. First is the ability to scale the system very quickly. Second is having a robust Disaster Recovery solution that allows you to quickly get your systems back online – in hours and not days. Third is a very robust security posture, so that you can keep your clients data secure as well as pass all of the compliance audits that are necessary.

The thing that set SWC apart for Integrity Payment Systems was the way that they immersed themselves into their business. They basically came onsite and worked really closely with business users in terms of understanding how they did their day-to-day work. Integrity Payment Systems had a very compressed schedule for development for this project, so even after they went live on the new system, SWC resources still worked with them very closely in terms of extending and expanding functionality and also worked with their development team to transition the technology so that they felt comfortable supporting it.

<a title="Contact SWC" href="/contact">Contact us</a> to learn more or schedule a meeting with one of our Engagement Managers to assist you with your <a title="Custom Application Development" href="/solutions/custom-application-development">custom application development</a> needs.<h3>Additional Client Success Video Case Studies</h3>

	<item>
		<title>Have We Forgotten How to Fix Problems?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/have-we-forgotten-how-to-fix-problems</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 Feb 2014 20:49:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11845</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last week my check engine light came on. Rats! To pile onto the problem, the engine enforced some sort of safety governor that limited my speed to 40 MPH. Double rats! I knew this couldn’t be good. Later as I sat at the dealership waiting for the bad news, I learned a sensor in the throttle body had shorted out. Perfect, let’s get a new sensor and be on our way then – of course, the resolution was not so easy! The service tech went on to say that in this situation the sensor could not be fixed and the entire throttle body has to be pitched for a new one. I’ve heard this story before. About a year ago I had a sensor issue with the catalytic convertor and sure enough I had to replace the entire catalytic converter to fix that situation as well. It seems like nothing is truly repaired anymore these days. This is a really hard reality for me to endorse or even understand. I come from a family that ran a highly successful farm implement dealership back in the day. My Grandfather and his brothers serviced many products and encountered every manor of mechanical disaster. The fact that they sold great products was not what made them successful. They also serviced those great products and solved hard problems. I actually watched one of my uncles make the main engine bearings for an old engine instead of searching for the replacement part. But today, some of these mechanical skills are lost due to computer diagnosis and replacing whatever parts the software tells you to replace.

In my field, <a title="Business Intelligence Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a>, there can be a tendency to take the same approach. “Your <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">SQL Server</a> is too old and you need to upgrade or change vendors.” “Your SQL EDW is old school and you need to think about Big Data.” “Our team doesn’t use your ETL tool, you need to migrate to a new ETL tool.” And the list goes on. Now I’m certainly not advocating that keeping old technology around is always a good thing. I just feel like sometimes there is a tendency to hit the easy button and just start over with new parts. It doesn’t always have to be that way. Shouldn’t the focus be on gaining ROI and solving business problems? Sometimes too much money is spent on shiny new toys when the old toys just need a little care and maintenance.
<h2>Assessment And Diagnosis Are Important!</h2>
All of our BI projects here at SWC include time to do the assessment/discovery. Sometimes clients push back on that part of the budget, which is totally understandable. But the time we spend doing the assessment helps solidify what it is we are trying to solve. We always have some ideas on what we think we’re going to deliver but it’s good to have the assessment to confirm what we said during the sales process. The primary purpose of the assessment is to determine what is truly broken and if our approach will solve those issues.

We get the opportunity to fix a lot of BI dysfunction. If there wasn’t dysfunction, I’d probably be looking for a career change real quick! Often the dysfunction isn’t the tools and technology; it’s the process. So what good is it to replace one set of tools for another if the business process isn’t addressed. Or in other situations, are the present tools being leveraged to their fullest capability to solve the current problems. Good consultants dig into those topics. We apply the technology skills where necessary and we ensure that the customers problems are being solved both technically and functionally. I’m never going to rebuild the main engine bearings for a skid-steer loader, but I will steer my customers through a difficult BI landscape with many moving parts. And I don’t need a diagnostic report to tell me what to do!

<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-11844" title="Business Intelligence Tractor" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/business-intelligence-tractor-022614.png" alt="Business Intelligence Tractor" width="276" height="183" /><em>This picture is of a tandem four wheel drive tractor made from two two-wheel drive Minneapolis Moline U’s. My Grandfather and his brother built this one and several like it. At the time (mid-1960s) four wheel drive farm power was not a reality. But, the market demanded more power and they delivered it in a very creative way. I like to think we use that same can-do spirit here at SWC when we are solving hard technical problems, particularly in the BI space that I work in!</em>

<a title="Can’t afford BI? Try the BI Analytics Tools in Everyday Software" href="/swc-technology-partners/news/cant-afford-business-intelligence-try-bi-analytics-tools-software">Can’t afford BI? Try the BI Analytics Tools in Everyday Software</a>

	<item>
		<title>Ask SWC: What Is Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-is-microsoft-system-center-data-protection-manager</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 28 Feb 2014 20:24:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradellison]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11909</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today, I want to talk to you about <a title="System Center Protection Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/data-protection-manager">Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager</a>, a scalable and cost-effective solution used to backup, replicate and restore the critical data in your infrastructure. Watch my latest “Ask SWC” video to learn more.
<a title="System Center 2012 Data Protection Manager" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/dnePeTgYm9E?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="System Center 2012 Data Protection Manager" width="474" height="262" /></a>
<a title="Microsoft System Center 2012 R2" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/microsoft-system-center-2012-r2">Microsoft System Center 2012 R2</a> Data Protection Manager or DPM is specifically designed to protect and backup your critical Microsoft workloads, such as <a title="Microsoft Exchange Consulting" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-exchange-2013">Microsoft Exchange</a>, <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server</a>, <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Solutions" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a>, <a title="Microsoft CRM Consulting" href="/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management">Microsoft Dynamics CRM</a>, <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V" href="/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v">Microsoft Hyper-V</a> or <a title="Virtualization Solutions" href="/solutions/virtualization">virtualization solution</a> and file servers. In today’s fast paced IT environment, you can have all of the redundancy in the world built into your infrastructure – multiple firewalls, redundant switch core stacks, redundant ISP links and redundant servers, but still lack the ability to protect your data against corruption or loss. Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager gives your team the tools to backup and replicate your data every 15 minutes to disk, tape and/or offsite data warehouse locations such as Windows Azure or the <a title="Recovery Cloud Services" href="/solutions/cloud-services/recovery-cloud">SWC Recovery Cloud</a>. This provides you with the assurance that no matter what the situation, you will be able to protect and safeguard the critical data in your infrastructure. Additionally, Data Protection Manager provides IT departments with the tools necessary to design, implement and maintain a solid Disaster Recovery Plan.

Microsoft System Center 2012 R2’s newest release of Data Protection Manager provides enhancements and new features for Windows Azure Backup, SQL Server cluster support and deploying the solution in a virtual environment. If you’re looking for a strong solution for back up, replication and restoration of all of the data in your infrastructure, contact us to learn more about what Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager has to offer your organization.

For more information on how SWC can help you design, implement and support Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 and Data Protection Manager, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Microsoft System Center Events" href="/events">Microsoft System Center event</a> or follow <a title="Brad Ellison Linked-In" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/brad-ellison/70/1aa/a03" target="_blank">Brad Ellison on LinkedIn</a>

	<item>
		<title>The Microsoft SharePoint Jungle</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-jungle</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Mar 2014 16:15:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11934</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I have been trying to come up with a more compelling way to describe the challenges that organizations face when deploying <a title="Microsoft SharePoint Solutions" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">Microsoft SharePoint</a>. Talking about “implementation planning and design,” “organizational change management,” “user adoption” and “governance” only goes so far. What I want to do instead is “paint a picture” for people, to help them relate to something a little more tangible than those vague, conceptual phrases. I found my inspiration – where else? – on television!

When you roll out or deploy <a title="Microsoft SharePoint 2013" href="/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-2013">Microsoft SharePoint 2013</a> without the right strategy and approach, it's kind of like stranding all of your users in a deep, dark, remote jungle. They find themselves alone in the wilderness, facing a big intimidating and potentially scary thing. All that they knew and understood is out of reach and new obstacles and challenges stand in their way. Each and every individual has to explore and conquer the unknown, in order to survive.

Maybe some of those folks are unusually adventurous and are more comfortable wielding the machete and fighting their own way through the jungle. Perhaps some are natural leaders and will help the others learn how to cope or even thrive. But, the cruel reality is that most people will simply be wandering around lost and unsure what to do about it.

What can we do to help everyone make it through the SharePoint jungle and reach their goals successfully? First, we need to hack through all the vines to create a safe and comfortable place to live. Then, we have to provide a map to help people skirt the sinkholes, avoid the predators and get to where they need to go. We need to teach them the differences between the poison berries and the ripe fruit, so they can feed themselves. And finally, we need to define some simple rules, so they can all live together in peace and harmony for the rest of their time in the jungle, until they can be saved (by the coming weekend, of course!)

All of this is without a doubt, easier said than done. But, with the right skills, tools and plans, it IS possible to save your users from the SharePoint Jungle – before they are lost forever!

To learn more about how Microsoft SharePoint, please join us for our next <a title="Chicago Area SharePoint Event" href="/events">Chicago area Microsoft SharePoint event</a> or follow <a title="Jeff Lanham LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/jeff-lanham/22/125/a99" target="_blank">Jeff Lanham on LinkedIn</a>.<h3>Additional Microsoft SharePoint Posts</h3>
If you enjoyed this post, please check out a few of our related posts on Microsoft SharePoint:

<a title="Microsoft SharePoint 2013 Demo To Go" href="/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-2013-demo-to-go">Microsoft SharePoint 2013 Demo To Go</a>
<a title="The Importance Of Solution Design In A SharePoint Deployment" href="/blog/sharepoint/importance-of-solution-design-microsoft-sharepoint-deployment">The Importance Of Solution Design In A SharePoint Deployment</a>
<a title="Two Fundamental Approaches to Microsoft SharePoint" href="/blog/sharepoint/fundamental-approaches-microsoft-sharepoint">Two Fundamental Approaches to Microsoft SharePoint</a>
<a title="Designing Your SharePoint Architecture" href="/blog/sharepoint/designing-your-sharepoint-architecture">Designing Your SharePoint Architecture</a>
<a title="How will Microsoft SharePoint Bring Value to My Business?" href="/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-bring-value-to-business">How will Microsoft SharePoint Bring Value to My Business?</a>
<a title="A Quick Introduction to Microsoft SharePoint Portal Solutions" href="/blog/sharepoint/introduction-microsoft-sharepoint-portal-solutions">A Quick Introduction to Microsoft SharePoint Portal Solutions</a>

	<item>
		<title>#PiDayParty: It’s Time For You To Join In The Fun</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/pidayparty-time-to-join-in-the-fun</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 06 Mar 2014 20:44:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[franpeters]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=11991</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Pi Day is an annual celebration at SWC commemorating the mathematical constant π (Pi) and is observed on March 14 (or 3/14 in month/day date format), since 3, 1 and 4 are the three most significant digits of π in the decimal form. Pi Day is a big deal at SWC and this year we want you, to indulge in all of the Pi Day festivities we have come to know and love. Watch our <a title="#PiDayParty" href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23PiDayParty" target="_blank">#PiDayParty</a> video to learn more.

<a title="SWC Technology Partners Pi Day Promo 2014" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/AEw1T_C6Ex0?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-pi-day-party-blog.png" alt="SWC Pi Day Party 2014" width="400" height="281" /></a>
We’re having a <a title="#PiDayParty" href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23PiDayParty" target="_blank">#PiDayParty</a> at SWC. What is a #PiDayParty, you might ask. A #PiDayParty is an exciting lunchtime celebration for your entire office that includes pizza Pies, baked Pies, reciting of Pi, talking about Pi and even a Pie eating contest – if your office is brave enough.

Do you believe in Pi or have an office full of amazing coworkers who are worthy of a <a title="#PiDayParty" href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23PiDayParty" target="_blank">#PiDayParty</a>? Simply submit a photo or short video to us discussing anything Pi related and we’ll enter you into our contest. Need some inspiration? Download our <a title="Pi Day Party Sign" href="http://www.swc.com/pi/_/imgs/piday-sign.jpg" target="_blank">#PiDayParty sign</a>, grab your co-workers and strike a pose.

On March 14th we will award one lucky winner a <a title="#PiDayParty" href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23PiDayParty" target="_blank">#PiDayParty</a> (aka free lunch) for their entire office. Just think about how popular you would be if you hosted the ultimate #PiDayParty for your entire office. Your co-workers would probably carry you on their shoulders down your hall of cubicles, cheering and chanting your name! Can you imagine?

Okay – seriously, stop dreaming about a #PiDayParty and do something about it. Enter our contest now at: <a title="SWC Pi Day Paryty 2014" href="www.swc.com/PiDayParty">www.swc.com/PiDayParty</a>.<h3>Recommended Past SWC Posts</h3>
If you would like to learn more about topics related to this blog and SWC’s corporate culture, please check out a few of our past posts:
<a title="A Few Ways to Keep Employees Engaged and Have Fun in the Workplace" href="/blog/careers/ways-to-keep-employees-engaged">A Few Ways to Keep Employees Engaged and Have Fun in the Workplace</a>

If you are passionate about technology and want to grow your career, head over to <a title="SWC IT Careers" href="/careers">SWC Careers</a> and apply for one of our open <a title="Chicago IT Jobs" href="https://careers-swc.icims.com/jobs/intro?hashed=0" target="_blank">IT positions</a>.

	<item>
		<title>Let’s Talk Backup: Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager 2012 R2</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/lets-talk-backup-microsoft-system-center-data-protection-manager-2012-r2</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 11 Mar 2014 21:38:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12018</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/data-protection-manager">System Center Data Protection Manager 2012 R2</a> (SCDPM) provides unified data protection for Windows servers and clients, helping your organization deliver scalable, manageable and cost-effective protection and restore scenarios. Here are a few ways you can integrate Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager into your environment as a powerful backup solution.

Via an agent, System Center Data Protection Manager can perform disk-to-disk backups in real time. Different retention policies can be set for clients and servers, such as how often the backup jobs run and how long to retain the data on disk. Clients can even be backed-up over Direct Access and in cases when the client is disconnected from the network, the jobs still run locally, creating Volume Shadow Copies (VSS) which will then sync up to the SCDPM server when connectivity is re-established.

From there, several avenues are available. The data can be exported to tape for offsite long-term retention and SCDPM can share a tape library with other products, such as IBM Tivoli. Or multiple SCDPM servers can be configured to replicate with one another between sites. A third option is backup to Windows Azure storage, which is available right from the console. Any or all of these methods can be used to perform granular VSS backup/restore of <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V" href="/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v">Microsoft Hyper-V</a>, Exchange, SharePoint, Files and Active Directory.

As with the other products in the Microsoft System Center suite, <a title="SCDPM" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/data-protection-manager">SCDPM</a> has cross-platform capabilities. It can snapshot Linux VMs running under Microsoft Hyper-V while they are online, as long as current Integration Services are installed into the kernel. On clusters, SCDPM can integrate with SAN hardware to offload data transfers and minimize the time spent on redirected IO, reducing backup time. Most SAN vendors provide a VSS requestor that talks to a VSS writer installed on the SCDPM server and all cluster nodes. In cases where third party software provides a generic VSS interface, such as with Oracle databases, its data can be presented to SCDPM for application-consistent backups.

Information gathered by Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager can be disseminated throughout System Center, in order to increase its effectiveness and visibility. For example, SCDPM can enforce compliance baselines that detect whether or not a managed computer has the SCDPM agent installed, or whether backup jobs have been configured and trigger remediation as needed. In the event of problems with backups, failed jobs will be relayed to <a title="Microsoft System Center Operations Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/operations-manager-scom">System Center Operations Manager</a>, which can then trigger incident tickets in <a title="System Center Service Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/service-manager">System Center Service Manager</a>.

If you’d like to find out more about how SWC can help architect a backup solution for your networking environment, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Microsoft System Center Events" href="/events">Microsoft System Center event</a>.

	<item>
		<title>What’s New with MDS In SQL Server 2012?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/whats-new-mds-sql-server-2012</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 Mar 2014 20:35:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kathrynchrismer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12037</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A lot of people have been asking about Master Data Services as a <a title="Business Intelligence Solutions" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence Solution</a>. Watch my latest episode of “Ask SWC” to learn more about what’s new with Master Data Services in Microsoft SQL Server 2012.
<a title="MDS and SQL Server 2012" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/NBkMEJJsTOQ?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC MDS and SQL Server 2012" width="474" height="262" /></a>
Master Data Services or MDS is a great Business Intelligence solution that we offer our customers as part of the <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012 Services" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server 2012</a> stack. MDS can be used to connect to any domain and manage customers, products or accounts. SWC’s customers really like Master Data Services because it allows any business user to manage data themselves, significantly reducing the need for IT resources to spend their time fixing data or hierarchy definitions.

New MDS features include hierarchies, granular security, transactions and data versioning and business rules. Microsoft Data Quality Services can also be used to compare two data sources and provide suggestions and confidence of change accuracy. Perhaps, my favorite new Master Data Services tool is the Microsoft Excel add-in, which allows users to connect to the MDS database and load a filtered set of data to work with in Excel and then publish it back to the database. In Excel users can sort the data, filter it and make any changes in a familiar format, then apply those changes in the MDS database.

Finally, Microsoft has also made some improvements to their Master Data Services web interface, including an improved user interface. Silverlight has also been integrated to allow users to add, delete or move members in a hierarchy.

To learn more about Master Data Services or how SWC can help you implement this Business Intelligence solution, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Events" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a>.
<h2>MDS BI Community Meetup</h2>
SWC is hosting a Master Data Services Business Intelligence Community Meetup on March 20th at our office. Our MDS expert, Jeff Hellesen will lead a discussion and demonstration for the group on uncovering the power of Microsoft Data Quality Services. I’d encourage you to join us if you’re available and want to learn more. The event starts at 5:30 PM and the presentation will begin at 6:00 PM. Pizza and pop will be served and we hope everyone will stay after the presentation is over to network and meet other business intelligence professionals and keep the conversation going.

You can register for the business intelligence meetup event at the following link: <a title="BI Meetup" href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup3-20-14.html" target="_blank">http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup3-20-14.html</a>

If you are not able to make the event, I encourage you to subscribe to our blog, as we will continue to publish more technical content and provide additional information about our business intelligence community groups and technical webinars.

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft Lync Tip For Conflicting Conference Calls</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-tip-for-conflicting-conference-calls</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Mar 2014 20:53:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[gonzaloescarra]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12065</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Have you ever booked a back-to-back conference call using <a title="Microsoft Lync Consulting Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a> and had a client or coworker join the bridge, just as your wrapping up another call? It happens more than you think and there is a simple and quick way you can avoid this from happening the next time you decide to schedule a meeting using Microsoft Lync.

Microsoft Lync has a cool feature in the meeting options tab that builds private bridges or <strong>“meeting spaces.”</strong> Meeting spaces basically determine where you want to meet online. Here’s what you should do the next time you schedule a back-to-back conference call:
<ol>
	<li>Create a new Lync meeting, or open up an existing one (this can be recurring too!)</li>
	<li>On the top ribbon, click on Meeting Options<img class="wp-image-12062 alignnone" title="Microsoft Lync Ribbon" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-lync-ribbon-031714.png" alt="Microsoft Lync Ribbon" width="600" height="209" /></li>
	<li>Pick “A new meeting space (I control permissions)” and then customize the settings to suit your call’s needs. Typically all of your meetings are held in the same space with the same entry information. But when you choose a new meeting space, there is unique entry information and you will be able to control who gets admitted into the meeting and what they can do when they are there.
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-12063" title="Microsoft Lync Meeting Space" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-lync-meeting-space-031714.png" alt="Microsoft Lync Meeting Space" width="600" height="209" /></li>
	<li>You can then click on Remember Settings and it will keep the customizations so that every future meeting you create will then have a unique Conference ID.</li>
</ol>
For more information from Microsoft on Lync meetings, you can check out: <a href="http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/lync-help/set-options-for-lync-meetings-HA102809361.aspx" target="_blank">http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/lync-help/set-options-for-lync-meetings-HA102809361.aspx</a>

<strong><em>Note:</em></strong> If you’re the presenter and you’re done with the conference call, make sure you end it with <strong>“End Meeting,”</strong> otherwise other presenters or callers may remain in the bridge. Hanging up a meeting won’t end it unless you are the last presenter to leave the meeting.
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-12064" title="Microsoft Lync End Meeting" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-lync-end-meeting-031714.png" alt="Microsoft Lync End Meeting" width="600" height="218" />
To learn more about Microsoft Lync, please join us for our next <a title="Chicago Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Unified Communications event</a>.<h3>Additional Microsoft Lync Technical Posts</h3>

		<title>Ask SWC: What Are Some Tips To Protect Your Network from Hackers?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/tips-to-protect-your-network-from-hackers</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Mar 2014 04:13:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[viraldhimar]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12084</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[With the recent news of hacks and confidential information being compromised there are three important things you can do to help keep your network and data safe. Check out my “Ask SWC” video to learn more.
<a title="3 Tips to Protect Your Network" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/qEkIfARtggc?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Ask SWC MDS and SQL Server 2012" width="474" height="262" /></a>
In this episode of “Ask SWC,” I wanted to share three tips to help protect you and keep your company’s network safe, so that none of your confidential data will be compromised or stolen. Here are my top three safety tips:
<ul>
	<li>The first tip is to make you password at least 15 characters long</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>The second tip is to never click on any malicious link in a spam email</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>The third tip is to always remember to lock your computer when you walk away from your desk</li>
</ul>
If you need help with security objectives or would like to further discuss how to keep your company’s network safe, please contact SWC. If you would like to learn more about <a title="Managed IT" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">Managed IT</a> and Security Services, please join us for our next informative <a title="Managed Services event" href="/events">Managed Services event</a>.

	<item>
		<title>Why You Need to Upgrade to Operations Manager 2012 R2</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/why-upgrade-operations-manager-2012-r2</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Mar 2014 14:03:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12221</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="System Center Operations Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/operations-manager-scom">Microsoft System Center Operations Manager 2012 R2</a> (SCOM) provides deep application diagnostics and infrastructure monitoring that can help ensure the predictable performance and availability of vital applications. By integrating System Center Operations Manager 2012 R2 (SCOM) into your IT environment, you will have a comprehensive and unified view of your datacenter, private and public clouds.

When you upgrade to System Center Operations Manager 2012 R2 (SCOM), Microsoft’s extended network monitoring is available for newer SNMP devices and basic monitoring for older devices. Network devices provide out-of-the-box discovery, monitoring and reporting on items like:
<ul>
	<li>Memory utilization</li>
	<li>Processor utilization</li>
	<li>Port traffic volume</li>
	<li>Port error analysis</li>
	<li>Port packet analysis</li>
</ul>
System Center Operations Manager 2012 R2 (SCOM) can also show which downstream servers may be impacted by device outages based on dependency trees such as:
<ul>
	<li>Bridges</li>
	<li>Firewalls</li>
	<li>Load balancers</li>
	<li>Switches</li>
</ul>
HSRP groups and VLAN memberships are also tracked and visible in the Network Node Dashboard, which present Key Performance Indicators (KPIs).

When Microsoft purchased AVIcode technologies several years ago, it began integrating these .NET application performance monitoring tools into Visual Studio IntelliTrace diagnostics and into System Center Operations Manager (SCOM). In <a title="System Center 2012 R2" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/microsoft-system-center-2012-r2">Microsoft System Center 2012 R2</a> these can be found in the System Center Operations Manager (SCOM) web portal. This same toolset has been extended to support Java Enterprise Edition (JEE) applications via MBeans JMEs, such as Apache Tomcat and Oracle.

Alerting and notifications can then be integrated with Microsoft System Center Service Manager for ticketing incident management and data trending analysis in the data warehouse, which can trigger auto-remediation via runbooks in Microsoft System Center Orchestrator, executing tasks based on events and patterns.

When integrated with Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager, System Center Operations Manager (SCOM) enables Performance Resource Optimization (PRO) tips and can analyze common misconfigurations, such as automatically load balancing VMs between nodes of a cluster. In a similar fashion, integration with Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager allows backups to be tracked and remediated from directly within the System Center Operations Manager (SCOM) console. Or it can just publish the dashboards to Microsoft SharePoint via the System Center Operations Manager (SCOM) web parts.

Cross-platform features include agents for Linux, UNIX and Mac. In addition, there are third party Management Packs (MPs) available from vendors such as Citrix, Dell, HP, Veeam and many others – all of which can extend System Center Operations Manager (SCOM) and centralize complex sets of software and hardware details. And many of these are free, integrating cross-platforms via industry standard protocols, such as the Common Information Model (CIM) or Web Services Management (WSMAN), in addition to native Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).

Of course, traditional Windows MPs have all been upgraded to support the latest generations of Microsoft products, such as: DHCP, DNS, WDS, NPS, ADDS, ADSS, ADDT, ADCS and other related server technologies, including Microsoft Exchange, Lync and SharePoint.

If you’d like to find out how SWC can help you better monitor your environment using Microsoft System Center 2012 R2, please join us for our next informative Microsoft System Center event.

	<item>
		<title>Bulk Enabling First Time Lync Users</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/bulk-enabling-first-time-lync-users</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 31 Mar 2014 12:53:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12342</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When enabling users for the first time in <a title="Microsoft Lync Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a>, we get a lot of requests for bulk enabling based on group membership or other factors. If this is something that you would like to do, you don’t need a fancy tool, you just need to check out the get-csaduser command in Powershell: <a href="http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg398592.aspx" target="_blank">http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg398592.aspx</a>

<strong>Here’s a sample command to get you started:</strong>
<blockquote>get-csaduser -LDAPFilter {(memberOf=CN=Your Group Name,OU=Your OU,DC=domain,DC=com)} | enable-csuser -registrarpool "Yourpool.domain.com" -sipaddresstype emailaddress</blockquote>
<strong>If you wanted to enable all Microsoft Lync users by OU try this:</strong>
<blockquote>Get-CsAdUser -OU "ou=Your OU Name,dc=domain,dc=com" | enable-csuser -registrarpool "Yourpool.domain.com" -sipaddresstype emailaddress</blockquote>
I hope you enjoyed this quick tip on enabling users for the first time in Microsoft Lync. If you’d like assistance planning your path to Microsoft Lync please contact SWC, connect with <a title="Anthony Caragol LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/anthony-caragol/6/48/488" target="_blank">Anthony Caragol on LinkedIn</a> or join us for our next <a title="Unified Communications Event" href="/events">Unified Communications event</a>.<h3>Related Past Posts</h3>
To learn more about Microsoft Lync, check out a few of Anthony’s technical blogs:

	<item>
		<title>It’s The Data Quality</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/its-the-data-quality</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 02 Apr 2014 09:07:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12350</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Success in <a title="Business Intelligence Consulting" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">business intelligence</a> usually boils down to doing the simple things well. One area we never lose sight of at SWC is the focus and passion for “Data Quality” in all of our projects. Quality is not a feature you add in at the end of the project or mention in a design artifact. Quality has to be pervasive through the entire project and exist even after delivery has been wrapped up.
<h2>Embedding Data Quality</h2>
A few years ago the business intelligence team at SWC was taking stock of our approach to BI and looking for an opportunity to inject SWC IP into our projects. We were looking to do something that would separate us from our competitors and leave a long lasting impression on our customer base. We came to the realization that “Data Quality” on our BI projects was a substantial manual effort and seemed to be re-invented each time we did a new project. And so the advent of “Data Sentinel” came to fruition. The “Data Sentinel” or DS tool/framework was our answer to ensuring a repeatable process. The tool would ensure quality on all of our projects, be easy to use/configure and be extensible for those clients that desired to enhance the tool at their discretion. The tool was an immediate success! All of our customer’s using Data Sentinel continue to use, embrace and enhance its adoption to this day. We even have customers using Data Sentinel to monitor business KPIs for organizational health.
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-12347" title="SWC BI Blog Chad Dotzenrod Data Quality" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-bi-blog-chad-dotzenrod-data-quality-.png" alt="SWC BI Blog Chad Dotzenrod Data Quality" width="500" height="216" />
<h2>Keeping It Simple</h2>
One of core requirements when building Data Sentinel was that it had to be easy to configure/install. We envisioned that business analysts, data analysts, test engineers and developers of all skill levels would use the tool. Each Data Quality configuration has the following components:
<ul>
	<li>Regression tests need to live in a container or group so that they can be better categorized. Tests that are mission critical go in the mission critical test group and tests that are important to a particular division or group can defined in groups along the organizational structure. Any grouping structure needed can be defined.</li>
	<li>Within a group there will be one or more tests. Typically on a BI project, you will have a measure or KPI that is important to the organization and ensuring the quality of that measure means checking data at several junctures in the process. For example, if we had a measure for “Order Amount” we would need to check the aggregate at the semantic layer/cube, data warehouse, staging database and source system.</li>
	<li>Within a given test there will be one or more steps. Building on the example from #2, the test steps would be to get counts from each data retention point and require that the count for all the steps be equal. If the source system says MTD “Order Amount” is $7 million, then each of the data points after the source system also have to be $7 million as well. As you can imagine, if there is a breakdown early in the process, everything downstream is going to be inaccurate.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Making Quality Pervasive</h2>
We use Data Sentinel on our BI projects along the entire promotion path starting at the local development machine and from there depending on our customer’s SDLC we will have additional checkpoints along the way. A typical BI project assumes: Local Machine, Development Server, Smoke Test Server, QA, Stage and Production. The automated regression testing is always ongoing and because it is automated, we also tie it into the software build process so that we know immediately if a software build has introduced data quality problems. So in closing, by making data quality a major focus to our practice area and building tools that automate this time consuming test we get to spend more of our time solving the harder problems and let our framework ensure the quality of the solution.

To learn more about SWC’s business intelligence solutions, please join us for our next informative <a title="Business Intelligence Events" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a> or follow <a title="Chad Dotzenrod LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/in/chaddotzenrod" target="_blank">Chad Dotzenrod on LinkedIn</a>.

If you are looking to get more involved in the Chicagoland BI community, we suggest you join us for our <a href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup4-15-14.html" target="_blank">monthly meetup</a>.

	<item>
		<title>The Sky is the Limit: Improve Operational Efficiency with System Center Orchestrator 2012 R2</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/improve-operational-efficiency-with-system-center-orchestrator-2012-r2</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 08 Apr 2014 03:51:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12455</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="Microsoft System Orchestrator" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/orchestrator">Microsoft System Center Orchestrator 2012 R2</a> provides coordinated integration and automation of IT processes through the creation of runbooks that can help to define and standardize best practices and improve operational efficiency. We like System Orchestrator 2012 R2 because it combines functions for all of the other products in the Microsoft System Center Suite via workflows. There are also expansion packs that exist in order to interface with other products like HP iLOs, IBM Netcool Omnibus and VMWare vSphere. Robust PowerShell scripts can also be leveraged to communicate across platforms using standardized CIM and WSMAN protocols to retrieve information from Windows, Linux and UNIX computers.

For example, <a title="System Center Configuration Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">System Center Configuration Manager</a> can call runbooks in Task Sequences during Operating System Deployment. Events from System Center Operations Manager can also trigger automated remediation actions, such as triggering a failover to a standby Hyper-V replica and activating it. Or even coordinate a series of reboot cycles throughout the datacenter via Cluster Aware Updating.

All of this is great for the IT admin. But how can Orchestrator benefit the end-user? Microsoft System Center Service Manager provides a SharePoint-based self-service portal, which can be configured to present any number of offerings to corporate staffers, based on their roles and responsibilities. For instance, Human Resources must regularly request that Active Directory accounts be created and deactivated. By filling out a form, HR can submit all of the necessary user details to Service Manager, such as group memberships and submit it to the system. This will subsequently kickoff a runbook to perform the task, rather than asking someone in IT to handle it manually. This can include a multitude of related things like enrolling the user in Exchange and Lync, registering them for the appropriate communications channels and requisitioning a laptop.

Still not enough? Then program runbooks to use your own utilities and scripts – the sky is the limit! Or just contact SWC to find out how we can assist with your operational automation needs.

If you’d like to learn more about Microsoft System Center 2012 R2, please join us for our next informative <a title="Microsoft System Center Event" href="/events">Microsoft System Center event</a>.<h3>Additional Microsoft System Center Posts</h3>
If you enjoyed this post from Kurt, please check out a few of our past posts on Microsoft System Center:

<a title="Integrating Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection 2012 R2" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/integrating-microsoft-system-center-endpoint-protection-2012-r2">Integrating Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection 2012 R2</a>

	<item>
		<title>Windows XP Will Self-Destruct Today</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/windows-xp-will-self-destruct-today</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Apr 2014 03:00:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeremyalt]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12480</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today is the day we have been warning you about for some time. The day <a title="Microsoft XP End Of Life" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/april-2014-windows-xp-support-ends">Microsoft ends support for Windows XP</a> and even though all of the XP devices in the world will not be self-destructing today, there are some important things you need to know if you continue to use it as your operating system.

After today there will be no more security updates or support for Windows XP. This will leave users vulnerable to malware and other security risks. Even if you have anti-virus software, that may not be enough to protect your business or data from risks such as viruses, spyware and other malicious software. Additionally, if your business is governed by a regulatory requirements like PCI, you may find yourself incompliant.

Some Windows XP users have chosen to ignore the April 8th deadline, as Microsoft recently released that they will be providing an extension of anti-malware for Windows XP until 2015. However, this doesn’t do a lot for XP users and there are still some glaring security holes for those running XP, as operating systems will no longer be patched. The 2015 anti-malware extension really means that Microsoft will provide updates for Microsoft Security Essentials and virus definition updates for Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection users.

SWC has created some additional resources to help you better understand Windows XP end of life and the impact it can have on your business:
<a title="Ask SWC: What Does Microsoft’s Windows XP Anti-Malware Extension Mean" href="/blog/ask-swc/what-does-microsofts-windows-xp-anti-malware-extension-mean">Ask SWC: What Does Microsoft’s Windows XP Anti-Malware Extension Mean?</a>
<a title="Only 98 Days Left for Microsoft Windows XP" href="/blog/managed-services/only-98-days-left-microsoft-windows-xp">Only 98 Days Left for Microsoft Windows XP!</a>
<a title="Ask SWC: Microsoft Windows XP And What Happens On April 8, 2014" href="/blog/ask-swc/microsoft-windows-xp-and-what-happens-april-8-2014">Ask SWC: Microsoft Windows XP And What Happens On April 8, 2014</a>
<a title="CryptoLocker Virus Tips – Take Action Now" href="/blog/managed-services/cryptolocker-virus-tips-take-action-now">CryptoLocker Virus Tips – Take Action Now!</a>
<a title="Integrating Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/integrating-microsoft-system-center-endpoint-protection-2012-r2">Integrating Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2</a>

For those businesses still running Windows XP, SWC can help you upgrade to <a title="Microsoft Windows 7 Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-7">Windows 7</a> or <a title="Microsoft Windows 8 Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows/windows-8">Windows 8.1</a>. We also offer solutions for virtual desktops. Finally, SWC offers desktop deployment assessments to help you identify where your vulnerabilities are and seamlessly migrate your business to the right desktop operating system.

<h3>Additional Microsoft Windows Posts</h3>
If you enjoyed this post, please take a moment to read some of our other posts about topics related to Microsoft XP end of life, security and managed IT services:
<a title="Security Awareness: Tips for Protecting Your Online Identity from Hackers" href="/blog/managed-services/security-awareness-protecting-online-identity-from-hackers">Security Awareness: Tips for Protecting Your Online Identity from Hackers</a>
<a title="SWC Managed Services – A More Strategic Approach to IT" href="/blog/managed-services/swc-strategic-approach-managed-it-services">SWC Managed Services – A More Strategic Approach to IT</a>
<a title="The Fundamentals of Cyber Security" href="/blog/network-security/fundamentals-of-cyber-security">The Fundamentals of Cyber Security</a>
<a title="SWC Featured On Telemundo News Broadcast" href="/blog/swc-technology-partners/swc-featured-on-telemundo-news-broadcast">SWC Featured On Telemundo News Broadcast</a>
<a title="BYOD Policies And Mobile Device Management" href="/blog/managed-services/byod-polices-mobile-device-management">BYOD Policies And Mobile Device Management</a></content:encoded>

		<title>Ask SWC: What’s New in SQL Server 2014?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/whats-new-in-sql-server-2014</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 11 Apr 2014 17:17:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12517</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft just announced the release of SQL Server 2014 this week. As you know <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">SQL Server 2012</a> came out some time ago and was heavily focused on a lot of Business Intelligence improvements for the enterprise. Now all of a sudden we have many users adopting BI that are hitting our SQL Servers pretty hard. As a result, Microsoft has focused on more performance enhancements in the 2014 release. Watch my “Ask SWC” blog to learn more.
<a title="SQL Server 2014 New BI Features" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/OHPirpW4uwE?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="SQL Server 2014 New BI Features" width="474" height="262" /></a>
Microsoft SQL Server 2014 is a comprehensive data platform and <a title="Business Intelligence Solutions" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence solution</a>. Some of the new 2014 features include enhancements to in-memory built in technologies, so things run faster within the organization like Pivots. Microsoft has also included high concurrency to eliminate redundancy in the enterprise and additional performance improvements that have people reporting 25-35% faster performance for the BI assets they have running. Speaking of BI assets, along the way of SQL 2012, we moved forward to the new Power View asset from a Tabular model to a multi-dimensional cube being utilized in the backend, which is now officially integrated within the new SQL Server 2014 release. Additionally, Microsoft has extended the AlwaysOn functionality that was brought to us in SQL Server 2012. This is the ability to have replication to multiple locations, in the past there were only three servers and now you can leverage eight. There are also many backup opportunities as well as backup in the cloud with Windows Azure integration in SQL Server 2014.

Speaking of the cloud, this is going to be your first launch into Power BI integration in Office 365. We talked a little bit about the official launch of Power BI, a self-service business intelligence solution, a few weeks ago and SQL Server 2014 is going to enable that because with Microsoft you can not only use the cloud information, but you can also use the on-premise data as well. Microsoft SQL Server 2014 will definitely provide a powerful asset to your organization.

At SWC, we have a lot of exciting Business Intelligence events coming up in the next couple weeks that will give you the opportunity to come talk to us about new SQL Server 2014 features and functions as well as continuing the cloud discussion.

The first event is our traditional Business Intelligence luncheon on April 24th in Oak Brook, where I will explore a lot of different topics and technologies related to Business Intelligence. Click here to register: <a title="Business Intelligence Event April 24 2014" href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/bi/event/2014-bi4-24-14.html" target="_blank">http://www.swc.com/html/email/bi/event/2014-bi4-24-14.html</a>

On April 15th we are also going to have a BI Meetup in the evening at our Oak Brook office, which will be focused on Power BI. Click here to register: <a title="Business Intelligence Event April 15 2014" href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup4-15-14.html" target="_blank">http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup4-15-14.htm</a>l

If you are unable to make our events, we are creating a lot more technical blogs, so I encourage you to subscribe and stay tuned as we will continue to publish more great BI content in the future.

	<item>
		<title>Is My BI Fat? Database Partitioning Can Help!</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/is-my-bi-fat-database-partitioning-can-help</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Apr 2014 16:54:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12539</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Your data warehouse started so perfect! It was a lean mean analytical machine. Then reality set in. The users fed it all the data they could get their hands on. When it got fat and slow, they refused to put it on a diet because they need “everything!” Data archival just isn’t in the cards and never seems to be with any data warehouse these days.

What’s a <a title="Business Intelligence Technologists" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">BI technologist</a> to do? Enter database partitioning. Before we get into the details though, a few questions need to be answered:
<ol>
	<li>Does my data warehouse have tables that contain hundreds of millions of records?</li>
	<li>Are the queries accessing identifiable subsets of the data?</li>
	<li>Are the subsets of rough equal size and are there enough of them?</li>
	<li>If your data changes, will it stay in the same subset?</li>
</ol>
If you said yes to all of these questions, you might be a candidate for partitioning.

There are many ways to partition data and the strategy is often case specific. For our example we’ll assume that the best way to partition the data is to group the data by sales region. Imagine a company with five sales regions and billions of orders spread relatively evenly across all sales regions.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-12544" title="My Business Intelligence Map Of USA" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/my-bi-fat-map.png" alt="My Business Intelligence Map Of USA" width="500" height="282" />

Why would I partition this way? Primarily, sales data is generally analyzed by region and then by time and other attributes. Additionally, the sales regions are static and rarely change. When the company grows larger, new sales regions can be added or we can re-partition by region and additional attributes.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-12545" title="My Business Intelligence Map Of USA Key" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/my-bi-fat-map-key.png" alt="My Business Intelligence Map Of USA Key" width="500" height="251" />

<strong>What’s the overhead of partitioning?</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Licensing. Partitioning is often considered an advanced or enterprise type feature. This means that standard edition <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">SQL Server</a> will not support this feature and you will have to upgrade.</li>
	<li>These partitions don’t maintain themselves. Initial setup and ongoing care and feeding will be required.</li>
	<li>Partitioned tables will consume more disk space. This is a tradeoff for increased performance.</li>
	<li>Experienced resources that can design and implement the solution from a business and technical perspective will also be needed.</li>
</ul>
<strong>What to do?</strong>
<ul>
	<li>First and foremost, profile the data and how it is used in the business</li>
	<li>What parts of the information flow are experiencing the most pain? Some of you will experience painful data integration whereas others will see issues at the client interface layer. The symptoms vary by case.</li>
	<li>Design the partitioning strategy</li>
	<li>Assess how future growth and change will affect your partition strategy</li>
	<li>On a smaller scale, validate your strategy before committing too much time or resources.</li>
</ul>
You may want to consider bringing in experience consultants for guidance, design validation or actual implementation to ensure your project is a success.

To learn more about SWC’s business intelligence solutions, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Business Intelligence event</a> or follow <a title="Chad Dotzenrod LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/in/chaddotzenrod" target="_blank">Chad Dotzenrod on LinkedIn</a>.

If you are looking to get more involved in the Chicagoland BI community, we suggest you join us for our <a title="SWC Monthly BI Meetup" href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup4-15-14.html" target="_blank">monthly meetup</a>.<h3>Additional Business Intelligence Posts</h3>

		<title>SWC Ranks on MSPmentor’s Global Managed Services Providers List</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/swc-ranks-mspmentors-global-managed-services-providers-list</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 17 Apr 2014 08:12:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[susiecummings]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=12580</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC is proud to announce that we have ranked among the top 100 <a title="Managed IT Service Provider" href="/solutions/managed-services">managed services providers</a> in the world on the MSPmentor 501 Global Edition list this year. This is SWC’s fourth consecutive appearance on the list. SWC has also ranked among the top 100 on the MSPmentor 200 North America Edition, a sub list of the 501 Global Edition that focuses exclusively on Managed Services Providers (MSPs) in North America.

Appearing on these lists are an amazing distinction for us and affirms that we have the experience, people, process and technology to deliver a very high-value, high-touch service for our customers. One of the things that differentiates SWC’s managed services practice is the fact that we have been doing this for over eight years and have really grown and developed our offering from a solution focused on monitoring and management into a unique partnership in which we help clients develop operational roadmaps and strategic plans to ensure success.

In addition to the MSPmentor list, SWC recently appeared on a new list, CRN’s Managed Service Provider (MSP) 500 list. The list recognizes the top technology solution providers in North America whose innovative approach to managed services has helped customers cut costs, improve efficiencies and spend more time working on strategic projects that will impact the business.

To learn more about SWC’s <a title="Managed IT Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">Managed IT Services</a> offering, please join us for our next <a title="Chicago Managed Services Events" href="/events">Chicago area Managed Services event</a> or follow <a title="Susie Cummings LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/susie-cummings/9/224/ba9" target="_blank">Susie Cummings on LinkedIn</a>.

Click <a title="SWC 2014 MSP Mentor" href="/swc-technology-partners/news/swc-ranks-on-worlds-top-100-managed-services-provider-list">here</a> for more information on the 2014 MSPmentor 501 Global Edition list.

Click <a title="CRN's Managed Service Provider list" href="/swc-technology-partners/news/swc-named-to-crns-managed-service-provider-500-list">here</a> for more information on CRN’s Managed Service Provider (MSP) 500 list.
