	<item>
		<title>SWC Best Practices: What Are Some Mobile Security Risks?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/security/swc-best-practices-what-are-some-mobile-security-risks</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Sep 2014 22:51:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[tommymontgomery]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=13792</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Just like computers, mobile devices are susceptible to certain <a title="IT Security Services" href="/solutions/security-services">security</a> risks. Watch my best practices video to learn more about today’s security threats and what your organization can do to keep your data safe.

<a title="IT Security Best Practices - What Are Some Mobile Security Risks?" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/G44wgLOLXTk?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/tommy-montgomery-swc-it-security-services-video-player.png" alt="IT Security Services Video" width="400" height="281" /></a>

More than 55% of the Internet is consumed on a mobile device these days. Whether it’s a smartphone or a tablet, mobile devices are susceptible to certain security risks. Some of the same cyber threats and security risks we see on computers are now popping up on mobile devices, such as CryptoLocker. A few days ago there was a release about an Android CryptoLocker version – so it’s not just for PCs. Imagine how devastating it would be if all of the content on your phone or tablet was CryptoLocked and its not just work files that are being locked, its family photos, personal data – everything!

Every device is susceptible to a certain level of security risk, so you really have to be careful and protect against everything. One of the things we don’t see a lot of organizations implementing is mobile protection on their devices. They think it’s just a consumer device. But it’s really another PC, it just happens to be small and mobile. We find Android phones are a little more susceptible to security risks than iPhones because the openness of its open platform. But we’ve seen the same problems with iPhones as we have with Android devices a few weeks ago. In Australia, hackers were locking phones as well phishing for credentials and then using them to locate the servers of the iPhone to lock the devices. If you were hit, you would have to contact Apple to get the phone unlocked, which is very difficult to do.

Organizations need to keep security top of mind and protect all of the devices in their networks. Although mobile security isn’t really on the forefront right now. We have seen some botnets being developed for it. By the nature of mobile, you don’t have fast networks that devices are connected to all of the time. But as these networks become faster, I think we will see some more security risks. To be safe organizations should begin implementing mobile protection as part of their formal security program.

<h2>Chicago Area IT Security Services 630-572-0240</h2>

There is a lot of fear and uncertainty when it comes to today’s cyber security threats. Organizations need to be proactive by enacting a solid security program that includes the right tactics and tools to keep their data safe. SWC can help keep your organization secure by building a solid security foundation. Please join us for our next complimentary <a title="Chicago IT Security Event" href="/events">Security 2.0: Don’t be the Next Target</a> event to learn more about protecting your organization from today’s security threats.<h3>Recommended Security Posts</h3>
If you enjoyed this blog post from Tommy, please check out a few of SWC’s related technical security blog posts:

<a title="What Industries Are Facing the Most Security Issues?" href="/blog/security/swc-best-practices-what-industries-are-facing-the-most-security-issues">What Industries Are Facing the Most Security Issues?</a>

<a title="CryptoLocker Virus Tips – Take Action Now" href="/blog/managed-services/cryptolocker-virus-tips-take-action-now">CryptoLocker Virus Tips – Take Action Now!</a>
<a title="How Can You Protect Your Organization From An IT Security Breach" href="/blog/security/fireeye-protect-your-organization-from-an-it-security-breach">How Can You Protect Your Organization From An IT Security Breach?</a>
<a title="Security Awareness: Tips for Protecting Your Online Identity from Hackers" href="/blog/managed-services/security-awareness-protecting-online-identity-from-hackers">Security Awareness: Tips for Protecting Your Online Identity from Hackers</a>
<a title="Tell Me About The Heartbleed Bug" href="/blog/ask-swc/tell-me-about-the-heartbleed-bug">Tell Me About The Heartbleed Bug</a>

	<item>
		<title>A Month of Lync Updates</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/month-of-microsoft-lync-updates</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 05 Sep 2014 18:41:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=13814</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[August has been a big month for <a title="Microsoft Lync Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a> updates as we’ve seen Microsoft make some interesting patches available for the server, clients, phone edition and mobility. We strongly suggest you keep your Microsoft Lync environment up-to-date with all of these patches for the best possible Lync experience. Read my blog to learn more.
<h2>Lync Server 2013 CU5</h2>
The Microsoft Lync Server 2013 CU5 was just released. The new version includes several bug fixes, some of which have been anticipated for quite some time and others that have been asked for by our clients repeatedly. One of these fixes includes mobile numbers not showing up in the Lync mobile client.

The update can be found here: <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=36820&amp;751be11f-ede8-5a0c-058c-2ee190a24fa6" target="_blank">http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=36820&amp;751be11f-ede8-5a0c-058c-2ee190a24fa6</a>

To learn more about the Microsoft Lync Server 2013 CU5 bug fixes, please visit: <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2809243" target="_blank">http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2809243</a>

To learn more about Microsoft Lync Server 2013 CU5, please visit: <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2967628/en-us" target="_blank">http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2967628/en-us</a>
<h2>Lync Client</h2>
There are quite a few bug fixes for the Microsoft Lync Client in this month’s updates. The download can be found here: <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2881070" target="_blank">http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2881070</a> or updated via Microsoft update. In our deployments we’ve come across randomly updated and not-updated versions of this component in the Microsoft Office suite. We strongly urge you to keep these products up-to-date as there are often exciting enhancements, specifically for Microsoft Lync since the initial release. If you do not have a clear strategy for keeping clients patched, SWC can help through our <a title="Microsoft Lync Managed Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/microsoft-lync-managed-services">Microsoft Lync Managed Services</a> Offering.
<h2>Lync Phone Edition</h2>
On August 20th an update for the Microsoft Lync Phone Edition was released that made some serious changes. One big change was allowing non-EV users to login and use the phone as an audio endpoint. The other was a change to phone locking. From the update the issue is described as:

“You lock a Microsoft Lync Phone Edition telephone by engaging the "lock" button on the telephone or by locking the computer that is connected to the telephone. The Lync Phone Edition telephone is deployed for Enterprise Voice users. In this situation, you can still make calls by using the telephone.”

The Lync Phone edition update that specifically addresses this issue and can be described here: <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2988196" target="_blank">http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2988196</a>

A link to the common Polycom edition updates, specifically the Polycom CX500, Polycom CX600 and Polycom CX3000 can be found here: <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=23866" target="_blank">http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=23866</a>
<h2>Lync Mobile Client</h2>
Forgive me, for I am an iPhone and iPad user and Microsoft just released a new mobility update for these platforms that I am very excited about. The Lync mobile client update allows more conference control. It’s now easier than ever to admit users in the lobby or promote and demote presenters from your mobile device.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-13813" title="Month Of Microsoft Lync Updates Screenshot" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/month-of-microsoft-lync-updates-screenshot.png" alt="Microsoft Lync Screenshot" width="500" height="576" />

Now the iPad client also has a gallery view! You can see up to four live video streams when connected to a conference.

For more information on the Lync Mobile Client update, please visit: <a href="http://blogs.office.com/2014/08/26/lync-mobile-update-gallery-view-ipad-participant-management-ipad-iphone" target="_blank">http://blogs.office.com/2014/08/26/lync-mobile-update-gallery-view-ipad-participant-management-ipad-iphone</a>

August has certainly been an exciting month for Microsoft Lync updates. If you need help planning your updates or migration to Microsoft Lync 2013, please contact SWC or join us for our next <a title="Chicago Microsoft Lync Event" href="/events">Microsoft Unified Communications event</a>.

		<title>Tell Us What You Think: Net Neutrality</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/technology/tell-us-what-you-think-net-neutrality</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 08 Sep 2014 19:48:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[elliottbaretz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=13830</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Net neutrality is a big topic that will affect many organizations. <a title="IT Solutions Provider" href="http://www.swc.com">IT solutions provider</a>, SWC, wants to know what midmarket professionals think. Watch our recent video blog to learn more. Net neutrality… where do you stand?

<a title="Tell Us What You Think: Net Neutrality - What's Your View?" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/DUNsHfuZHrc?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-technology-partners-tell-us-what-you-think-series.png" alt="SWC Technology Partners - Net Neutrality" width="500" height="281" /></a>

Net neutrality is the principle that all content running through the Internet’s pipes should be treated equally. On April 23rd the FCC announced new proposed rules that would give Internet service providers the "right to build special lanes" that allow content providers to pay for a guaranteed fast lane of service. On May 15th the FCC decided to consider two options regarding Internet services:
<ol>
	<li>Permit fast and slow broadband lanes, compromising net neutrality</li>
	<li>Reclassify broadband as a telecommunication service, preserving net neutrality</li>
</ol>
Today the FCC is seeking public comment on how best to protect and promote an open Internet. It is a big topic and SWC wants to know what midmarket professionals think.

<em>“I think net neutrality is a very core issue and open Internet is pretty critical, it levels the playing field for new companies to come in and compete against large competitors, drives innovation and opens up information for people. To limit the limit the Internet or at least direct and optimum access of consumers to all of the Internet would allow people to buy preferential treatment which would completely eliminate that open field playing model that has made the Internet so great.”</em> – Matt, Director of IT

<em>“I think net neutrality is extremely worrying and has some very worrying implications and very chilling effects on freedom of speech and the freedom of expression online. I am all in favor of ISPs being treated as common carriers. I do not believe that traffic should be allowed to be prioritized in the fashion that a lot of people think is going to happen.”</em> – Shane, IT Manager

<em>“A problem that I see in our country is that the little people don’t have a voice and the Internet has always provided that voice no matter what form you wanted to have it, freedom of speech is very important and the fact that you have the ability to use that tool freely. I belong to a lot of different groups where their message has to get out from a not-for-profit standpoint and not-for-profits don’t have this ability to spend a lot of money on maximizing their message to the world because that is not the basis for a not-for-profit, they are using that money for whatever organizational goals that they have. So to say that they cannot necessarily be as competitive online impacts them tremendously.”</em> – Julie, Computer Operations Manager

<em>“I think net neutrality is very important and I think we need to maintain it. Don’t allow money to equal free speech.”</em> – Bo, Senior Support Specialist

<em>“Protecting net neutrality should be one of the FCC’s utmost priorities, they have to ignore the influx of cash from lobbyist and the big ISPs that are pushing for a premium Internet and listen to the rampant outcry of technologists and consumers alike who are clamoring for a neutral Internet.”</em> – Matt, Director of IT

<em>“I think people should really take it upon themselves to be informed about net neutrality. It’s a huge issue and it affects a lot more people than people seem to think it does. Take five, ten or 15 minutes and Google it, net neutrality and see what people are saying about it. There’s a wealth of information about it available now. Do a little homework, try to read articles from varied sources and get both sides of the story. I think it is very important for anyone who uses the Internet regularly, which let’s be honest is everyone, or almost everyone. Those numbers are not going down, it’s a very important issue for people to know about."</em> – Shane, IT Manager

Tell us what you think? Send your opinions to: <a href="mailto:tellus@swc.com?Subject=SWC.com%20Tell%20Us%20Inquiry">TellUs@swc.com</a><h3>Recommended SWC Posts</h3>
If you enjoyed this video blog, you might enjoy some of our similar past SWC TV posts:

	<item>
		<title>SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Overview</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-overview</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 12 Sep 2014 05:26:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeffpoling]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=13871</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Your <a title="Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2</a> environment is all set up, running and you are using it to deploy software in your environment. It is all working great until one day… it does not! The software deployment fails on one of your VIP's machines, or as I recently encountered, a package failed to install for no reason during a pilot deployment. SCCM is an amazing tool, but it also has a lot of moving parts. What do you do when the unexpected happens or when a task you need to accomplish does not work? Read my blog on SCCM troubleshooting 101 to learn more.

Here is what I do in those situations when I need to troubleshoot an error or an issue in SCCM. The specifics often depend on what component I am troubleshooting, but the general process is still the same:
<ol>
	<li>Note any error codes in the console</li>
	<li>Determine the log files to investigate</li>
	<li>Open the log(s) in CMTrace</li>
	<li>Study the log conversation</li>
	<li>Lookup error codes</li>
	<li>Solve the problem!</li>
</ol>
We will cover the steps in more detail in subsequent blogs, but let's start with what the console provides for troubleshooting. In SCCM 2012 R2, the console has a great Monitoring workspace.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-13867" title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 1 Monitoring" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-1-monitoring.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Monitoring" width="500" height="245" />

You can get information from the SCCM 2012 R2 Monitoring workspace, such as the status of content on distribution points or overall system status from the Monitoring workspace. For troubleshooting failures in software distribution, the deployments node is where to go for insight.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-13868" title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 2 Deployments Node" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-2-deployments-node.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Deployments Node" width="500" height="254" />

In the deployments node, you can see all deployments, both active and ones completed in the past. A quick glance will show completion statistics for the various deployments. If you need more information, you can double click a deployment and specific information for each system and status will be shown.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-13869" title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 3 Deployment Status" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-3-deployment-status.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 3 Deployment Status" width="500" height="250" />

The SCCM R2 deployment status will also show messages and some details about the success or failure of the deployment.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-13870" title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 4 Success" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-4-success.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 4 Success" width="500" height="245" />

If your deployment shows an error, the description is a good place to start troubleshooting. You can search online for the error message; however, as you can see in the screenshot above, sometimes the description is less than helpful. When you need more details, SCCM's extensive log files provide in depth information. The logs can be overwhelming, so we will cover how to use them in another post. For now, happy troubleshooting! And remember, SWC's System Center team has extensive experience with SCCM and is ready to help with all of your troubleshooting needs.

This blog, is part of a three part series. Below are subsequent SCCM 101 troubleshooting blogs:

<a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Log Files" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files">Part II - SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Log Files</a>
<a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101: An Example" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-example">Part III - SCCM Troubleshooting 101: An Example</a>

To learn more about please join us for our next complimentary Chicagoland <a title="Chicago System Center Events" href="/events">Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 event</a>.

	<item>
		<title>SWC Best Practices: Enhanced Managed Services</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/best-practices-enhanced-managed-services</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 16 Sep 2014 04:49:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[susiecummings]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=13889</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of the advantages that SWC brings to the table when it comes to <a title="Chicago Managed Services" href="/solutions/managed-services">managed services</a> is the fact that we have specialized consultants and resources around the architecture and implementation of today’s most prevalent technology solutions, such as Microsoft Exchange, Lync, SharePoint and CRM. Watch my best practices video to learn more about why partnering with an <a title="Managed IT Service Provider" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">IT managed services provider</a> is a best practice for many midmarket organizations.

<a title="Managed Services Best Practices: Enhanced Managed IT Services" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/ryfK14zn-3c?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/susie-cummings-managed-it-services-video-player.png" alt="Managed IT Services Video" width="400" height="281" /></a>

SWC offers <a title="Specialized Managed Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/specialized-managed-services">enhanced managed services</a> around the architecture and implementation of today’s most prevalent technology solutions, including Microsoft Exchange, Lync, SharePoint and CRM. SWC helps our clients by providing proactive support for these technologies post implementation on a 24/7 basis. Our enhanced managed services offering can augment an organization’s internal IT team, as many midmarket companies don’t need or simply can’t afford to staff a full-time resource for Microsoft Exchange, Lync, SharePoint or CRM. Most organizations chose to hire SWC for these enhanced managed services at the end of their Microsoft Exchange, Lync, SharePoint or CRM project deployments. In the event that there is an issue, we already know what has transpired through our monitoring, alerting and reporting services and have ready access to a resource who can get service up and running at the level our clients expect with a guaranteed SLA.

There are many benefits to partnering with SWC for enhanced managed IT services, including:
<ul>
	<li>A comprehensive service offering delivered through our Software, Infrastructure and Managed Services practices. Our engineers have deep and broad experience in many of the technologies most midmarket organizations use today.</li>
	<li>Access to a team of more 150 experienced Chicagoland consultants to monitor, track and repair any IT challenge – on a 24x7 basis</li>
	<li>A long-term partnership model focused on cost effectively developing infrastructure strategies and roadmaps to drive business impact and support business goals</li>
	<li>Solutions that are adaptive and flexible to meet the changing needs of your organization in a predictable month-to-month cost structure</li>
</ul>
To learn more about SWC’s Managed IT Services offering, please join us for our next Chicagoland <a title="Chicago Managed Services Events" href="/events">Managed Services event</a> or follow <a title="Susie Cummings LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/susie-cummings/9/224/ba9" target="_blank">Susie Cummings on LinkedIn</a>.

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft Azure Machine Learning – A Data Tool for the Masses</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/microsoft-azure-machine-learning</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 22 Sep 2014 15:37:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=13908</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When I was a freshmen at North Dakota State University in the fall of 1991, I worked as advertising manager at the college newspaper. It was a simple job, motivate the sales reps to sell as many ads as possible so that the editors can publish a big newspaper. Sounds simple doesn’t it? Of course, the size of the newspaper was always decided a few hours before we went to press and being able to predict the size was a difficult task since the only tools we had were Lotus 1-2-3. This decision was always made last minute with all of the data we had available. Times and technology were ripe for disruptive change in 1991!
<h2>Fast forward to 2014.</h2>
A lot has changed in my life since 1991. But what hasn’t changed is my desire to use information to make good decisions. The only difference is that we have compelling tools and technology to make decisions faster, more accurately and quite possibly much sooner than was ever possible. For years, industries like finance, insurance and retail have had access to these prediction tools and the IT infrastructure to operate them. A very expensive proposition in the past. Today, that game has changed. There are many lower cost options a business or individual can use to do the things the big boys have been doing for years. We’ve watched the rise of predicative open source tools like “R” and self-service tools like PowerPivot, <a title="Business Intelligence Tableau" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/tableau">Tableau</a> and Qlik become pervasive in many small and midmarket organizations. The promise of faster adhoc analysis and the ability to predict with easy to use tools are here now.
<h2>Enter Azure Machine Learning.</h2>
In July of this year, Microsoft made a major announcement in the predicative analytics space. The pre-release/beta announcement of Microsoft Azure Machine Learning was upon us. I’ve been dabbling in open source “R” for the past year and many times have become frustrated with my lack of skill in the details of predictive modeling using a command line interface. That confidence and frustration was completely eliminated once I started building models with Microsoft Azure Machine Learning.

<h3>Business Intelligence Solutions 630.572.0240</h3>

<h2>Operational Predictive Analytics Made Easy.</h2>
Microsoft Azure Machine Learning makes it easy to build experiments with a learning curve less steep than pure “R.” The tool’s success is going to come from making predictive models operational in a much shorter amount of time and at a lower cost. Can you say ROI? Microsoft has been committed to predictive analytics for many releases of <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">SQL Server</a> and while the tools work, making the results and usage of those models operational was a substantial customized undertaking. Microsoft Azure Machine Learning changes this by automating the deployment of proven experiment models to web services that can seamlessly be integrated with web applications and visualization tools.
<h2>How Can I Learn More?</h2>
On September 25th the <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Business-Intelligence-Chicagoland/events/203302332/" target="_blank">Business Intelligence Chicagoland meetup group</a> will be discussing and reviewing our work with Microsoft Azure Machine Learning. We’ll start with a demonstration of how to build a model and integrate with a website and then we’ll transition to a customer retention case study we’ve been working on and look at how the service can be utilized to solve real world business problems. I hope you can join us!

Please click on the link below to register for our upcoming Business Intelligence Chicagoland Meetup on <strong>September 25th</strong> on Microsoft Azure Machine Learning.

<a title="Business Intelligence Meetup" href="/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup9-25.html" target="_blank">http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup9-25.html</a>

To learn more about Business Intelligence Solutions, please join us for our next complimentary <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Event" href="/events">Chicagoland Business Intelligence event</a> where Rachael Narel will dispel the myths around today's miracle BI cures and spell out a realistic, pragmatic approach to accomplishing the robust executive dashboard your CEO is looking for.

	<item>
		<title>Five Questions to Ask Before Investing in a Cloud Service</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/five-questions-to-ask-before-investing-in-cloud-service</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 06 Oct 2014 22:26:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=13975</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the ever growing world of cloud services, it can be very difficult to figure out which <a title="SWC Cloud Services" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud vendor</a> is right for your organization. While some vendors might try to tell you otherwise, there are a number of different factors that need to be considered before investing in a cloud service. Read my blog on the top five questions you should ask before picking a cloud service to learn more.

At SWC, we have vast technical experience installing and managing a range of servers and applications and have the knowledge to help you determine which cloud service is best for your organization. The first step is to understand your requirements and then design the right approach. We work with a variety of today’s market leading cloud vendors who possess many different features and focus areas and can help you understand the cloud marketplace and find the right vendor or vendors for your organization.

<h3>SWC Cloud Solutions 630.572.0240</h3>

Here are five of the most common questions you should consider before investing in a cloud service:
<ol>
	<li><strong>What do you need the cloud service to do?</strong> Many organizations are feeling the pressure to go into the cloud, even if they aren’t sure what the benefit might be. The cloud is a wonderful tool, but it is still a tool and it is important to think in terms of how the cloud can improve your organization instead of how your organization can get into the cloud quickly. If you are unsure how to get started, SWC can work with you to <a title="Cloud Network Readiness Assessment" href="/solutions/cloud-services/network-readiness-assessment">evaluate your environment</a> and architect a clear, pragmatic and successful path to the cloud, making sure you get the best cloud experience possible.</li>
	<li><strong>What is the full cost of the service?</strong> One of the major benefits of many cloud services is that you only pay for what you use, but this flexibility can also lead to several unexpected charges. For example, two of the most popular cloud services – Microsoft Azure and Amazon Web Services charge not just for the compute and storage space being used but also for the amount of data transferred across the Internet and the amount of storage transactions (I/O) being performed. The cloud could be very costly for your organization if you don’t know which features are included and which features you have to pay for.</li>
	<li><strong>What level of support and SLAs are offered?</strong> Each cloud service offers different support and SLA options and with many vendors you have to pay extra for full support. One of the best benefits of a cloud service is that someone else has to worry about your hardware and uptime, so make sure that when there is a problem you have someone ready and waiting to resolve the outage and get you back online quickly.</li>
	<li><strong>How easy is it to get your data into and out of the cloud?</strong> When setting up a cloud service, you may have a lot of data that needs to be imported to get you up and running. Many cloud services have tools where you can send them hard drives or do batch imports of data through special tools. Before picking a vendor, see if they have a tool that will fit your needs so that you don’t have to manually recreate all of your data to get it into the cloud.</li>
</ol>
Alternatively, cloud services are constantly changing and at some point you may find that there is a better service available or that you need to bring your data back onsite. In that situation, does the cloud vendor have a good method for getting your data back to you in a usable manner? Some vendors try to lock you into their service by making data exports difficult. Make sure to investigate what steps are required to get data out of the system before choosing a cloud vendor.

Do you need to consider any legal compliance considerations? Security in the cloud is a very common question and a topic we will address in subsequent blog posts. Many cloud services are certified compliant against common security standards (ISO, SOC, PCI, etc.), but if your organization requires these certifications it is important to verify that with the cloud vendor.

As you can see there are many different aspects to consider when moving to the cloud and SWC can help you find a cloud solution that is right for your business. To learn more, please call 630-572-0240.<h3>Recommended Cloud Posts</h3>
If you enjoyed this post on the cloud, please read a few of SWC’s related blog posts:

<a title="Ask SWC: How Can A Company Move To The Cloud With Privacy Needs?" href="/blog/ask-swc/how-can-a-company-move-to-the-cloud-with-privacy-needs">Ask SWC: How Can A Company Move To The Cloud With Privacy Needs?</a>
<a title="Microsoft SharePoint: On Premises Or In The Cloud?" href="/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-premises-or-cloud">Microsoft SharePoint: On Premises Or In The Cloud?</a>
<a title="What is the Private Cloud?" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/what-is-the-private-cloud">What is the Private Cloud?</a>
<a title="Why SWC And IT Departments Like Office 365" href="/blog/unified-communications/why-swc-it-departments-like-office-365">Why SWC And IT Departments Like Office 365</a>
<a title="SWC’s 2013 Tech Trends Poll" href="/blog/technology/swc-2013-tech-trends-poll">SWC’s 2013 Tech Trends Poll</a>
<a title="What I Like About Microsoft System Center 2012" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/like-about-microsoft-system-center-2012">What I Like About Microsoft System Center 2012</a>

	<item>
		<title>SWC Best Practices: From a Security Perspective, What is the Worst Case Scenario?</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/security/it-security-worst-case-scenario</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Oct 2014 16:01:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[tommymontgomery]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14011</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Every day we are seeing a rise in the number of <a title="IT Security Services" href="/solutions/security-services">security</a> events with an estimated 117,339 daily attacks, it’s scary to think that your organization or the organizations you conduct business with might be vulnerable. However, this number is a low estimate as most organizations are unaware that they have been attacked or fail to report an security breach. Watch my best practices video to learn more about today’s security threats, the worst case scenarios and what your organization can do to keep your data safe.

<a title="IT Security Best Practices - What's The Worst Case Scenario?" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/eObMgv7E-5g?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/tommy-montgomery-swc-it-security-services-video-player.png" alt="IT Security Services Video" width="400" height="281" /></a>

In terms of worst case scenarios, we have seen a lot lately. Security is a serious matter and a lot of large corporations such as Target, Jewel-Osco, Home Depot and now JPMorgan have been the targets of security breaches and data hacks. In my opinion, there are two worst case scenarios when it comes to security. One is the Target situation, where their entire database of credit card numbers was leaked online. These credit card numbers weren’t encrypted, they were decrypted – or captured before encryption. That’s about as bad as it gets. The CEO lost his job, the CIO lost his job and a lot of shareholder’s lost value in the company. Once there’s a loss of confidence in the business, it’s hard to gain that back and Target is still fully feeling the effects of that.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14008" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/it-security-target-breach-credit-card-numbers.jpg" alt="IT Security Target Breach Credit Card Numbers" width="500" height="390" />

The second worst case security scenario is <a title="CryptoLocker Virus Tips – Take Action Now" href="/blog/managed-services/cryptolocker-virus-tips-take-action-now">CryptoLocker</a>. CryptoLocker is ransomware that infects an organization via an email attachment. We’ve had a lot of customers that are concerned about CryptoLocker and we’ve also seen a lot in the news about companies getting hit with CryptoLocker. CryptoLocker is one of the worst case scenarios in my opinion, because it infects a user’s computer and then searches for file shares that the users has access. The malware then CryptoLocks or encrypts all of the organization’s files the user has access to. That could potentially be devastating for a corporation.

Typically the hackers then hold the file shares hostage and say that once you pay a certain amount they will provide you with the key to un-encrypt them. We advise our clients not to pay this ransom, the hackers will just keep furthering the situation if you pay. The key to preventing CryptoLocker and related security breaches is to have good backups and also prevention in place. SWC can work with you on this and provide you with that prevention. These security breaches do not have to happen and they do not have to be caught after the fact. They can be prevented beforehand. Don’t be the next target, <a title="Contact SWC" href="mailto:info@swc.com?subject=I%20want%20to%20learn%20more%20about%20security%20and%20preventing%20Shellshock">contact us</a> today for an information security assessment to see where your organization’s vulnerabilities lie and how we can help you build a solid security foundation.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14009" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-it-security-assessment-service.jpg" alt="SWC IT Security Assessment Service" width="500" height="375" />

<h2>Chicago Area IT Security Services 630-572-0240</h2>

There is a lot of uncertainty regarding today’s cyber security threats. Organizations need a solid security program that includes the right tools to keep their data safe. SWC can help your organization build a solid security foundation. Learn more, by joining us for our next complimentary <a title="Chicago IT Security Event" href="/events">Security 2.0: Don’t be the Next Target event</a>.<h3>Recommended Security Posts</h3>
If you enjoyed this security blog from Tommy, please check out a few of SWC’s related security posts:

		<title>Microsoft Lync Helps Tandem HR Weather the Storm</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-helps-tandem-hr-weather-storm</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 14 Oct 2014 13:53:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[adamferguson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14022</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[With winter right around the corner, Tandem HR turned to SWC to deploy a telephony solution that would help make their employees more mobile and productive outside the office. We deployed Microsoft Lync, which enabled their team to work remotely and still answer client calls 24/7 – even during the worst Chicago snowstorm! Watch our client success video case study to learn more about how Tandem HR is finding success using Microsoft Lync and SWC <a title="Microsoft Lync Managed Services" href="/solutions/managed-services/microsoft-lync-managed-services">Microsoft Lync Managed Services</a>.

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/mL-0IOlmo9g?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox;width=720;height=480;"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-lync-tandem-hr.jpg" alt="Microsoft Lync Managed Services Solution Tandem HR" width="500" height="281" /></a>

Tandem HR is a human resource outsourcing company and professional employment organization. Tandem HR provides their clients solutions in the areas of benefits, employee assistance programs, human resources, payroll, risk and more. Before Tandem HR engaged SWC to deploy <a title="Microsoft Lync Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a>, the organization had been using a phone system with handset phones that required them to be in their office to check voicemails and answer client calls. Microsoft Lync has helped make Tandem HR mobile and more productive outside of the office. This was especially true last winter.

Since Tandem HR is based outside of Chicago, they experienced some terrible winter snowstorms last year. With their old phone system, employees had to be in the office to answer client clients, as the organization couldn’t give snow days when their clients were on the line. Microsoft Lync is an enterprise ready telephony solution that gives users the ability to make voice calls from their computers, mobile devices or using a Microsoft Lync enabled desk phone. When last year’s snow storms were heading in and Chicago was getting inches of snow and below freezing temperatures, Tandem HR employees were able to work from home and remotely answer their client calls using Microsoft Lync on their laptops, enabling the business to continue running 24/7.
When we deploy Microsoft Lync, we don’t walk away and except the customer to maintain it. It’s a partnership. Tandem HR signed up for SWC’s Microsoft Lync Managed Services offering giving them 24x7 monitoring and support. Tandem HR knew there was going to be a huge snowstorm and that they were going to close the office, which would present some call center challenges. The organization was able to lean on SWC, right in the middle of the night. A call came into the SWC Managed Services team and it was escalated to our Microsoft Lync team who was able to go in and remotely help them with everything they needed. The next day everything operated seamlessly and business ran as usual.

If you are interested in learning more about deploying Microsoft Lync solutions to help your organization weather this winter’s snowstorms, please join us for our next informative <a title="Chicago Microsoft Lync Event" href="/events">Microsoft Unified Communications event</a> or contact <a title="Adam Ferguson LinkedIn" href="http://www.linkedin.com/pub/adam-ferguson/32/71/4b4" target="_blank">Adam Ferguson on LinkedIn</a>.<h3>Client Success Case Studies</h3>

	<item>
		<title>SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Log Files</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Oct 2014 08:14:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeffpoling]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14050</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As my last blog mentioned, one tool in the <a title="System Center Configuration Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager</a> (SCCM) troubleshooting toolbox is the monitoring workspace console. The monitoring workspace console provides a wealth of information and is a great place to start looking when you receive an error message. But sometimes the console’s description may not provide enough information to help you troubleshoot the issue you may be having. That’s where the SCCM log files can help. Check out my recent blog on SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Log Files to learn more.

SCCM has extensive log files to help provide in depth information when you receive and error message. The location of the log files depends on the SCCM component generating the log, the specific configuration of site systems and clients in your environment. For clients, the logs are generally located in C:\Windows\CCM\Logs (This will be different for older versions of SCCM).

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14041" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-a.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="500" height="238" />

Once you know what log you need to examine, you can open the log file and start reviewing it. For example, if you are troubleshooting package and program deployment, you need to look at the execmgr.log on a client machine. By default, if you double click to open the log file, it will open in Notepad as a text file.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14042" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-b.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="500" height="326" />

Opening the log file in Notepad will certainly allow you to get information, but there is another tool in the SCCM troubleshooting toolbox that will revolutionize log file review – CMTrace.
CMTrace is a log file viewer that is now included with SCCM 2012 R2. It can be found on the SCCM site server in the installation location. In my lab, it is found here:

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14043" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-c.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="500" height="158" />

When you launch CMTrace for the first time, you will be prompted to make it the default viewer for log files. I always accept by saying “Yes.”

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14044" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-d.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="500" height="345" />

Now you can use CMTrace to view the execmgr.log. Potential errors and warnings are highlighted as shown and automatic scrolling is enabled so that the log can be viewed in real-time.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14045" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-e.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="500" height="307" />

If you need to examine multiple log files, you can use CMTrace to merge the files together. You click open, select the log file, and check the box for “Merge selected files.”

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14046" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-f.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="500" height="307" />

CMTrace opens all of the selected logs and merges them together for a complete view.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14047" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-g.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="500" height="305" />

Finally, CMTrace provides an error lookup tool. If an error code is referenced in the log file you are viewing, you can enter the error code into the tool and get a brief description of what the code means.

To use the error lookup, go to Tools | Error Lookup.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14048" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-h.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="371" height="284" />

Enter your error code and click Lookup.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14049" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files-i.jpg" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 Log Files" width="322" height="309" />

So far we have seen what the SCCM console provides for troubleshooting (check out Jeff’s past blog post – <a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-overview">SCCM Troubleshooting 101: AN Overview</a>) and looked at SCCM logging. CMTrace is a powerful tool for helping as we examine the many log files SCCM generates. Next time, we will look at a specific troubleshooting scenario and put all of our new knowledge to good use. If you are still having trouble troubleshooting your SCCM environment, SWC’s <a title="Microsoft System Center Services" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center">System Center team</a> has extensive experience with SCCM and is ready to help you with all of your troubleshooting needs.

To learn more about please join us for our next complimentary <a title="Chicago System Center Events" href="/events">Chicagoland Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 event</a>.

For a great description of SCCM log files, check out Microsoft’s Technical Reference for Log Files in Configuration Manager <a href="http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh427342.aspx" target="_blank">here</a>.

This blog, is part of a three part series. Below are additional SCCM 101 troubleshooting blogs:

<a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Overview" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-overview">Part I - SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Overview</a>
<a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101: An Example" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-example">Part III - SCCM Troubleshooting 101: An Example</a>

		<title>SWC Best Practices: Security Managed Services</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/swc-best-practices-security-managed-services</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 21 Oct 2014 09:49:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[susiecummings]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14081</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today a lot of our conversations with midmarket C-level executives are focused around the uncertainty of what’s really happening from an <a title="IT Security Services" href="/solutions/security-services">IT security</a> perspective. We have a number of prospects and customers that are constantly getting hit with viruses and security threats and they don’t know why. Watch my best practices video to learn more about why partnering with an <a title="Managed IT Service Provider" href="/solutions/managed-services/managed-it-solutions">IT managed services provider</a> for security services is a best practice for many midmarket organizations.

<a title="Managed IT Services Best Practices: Security Managed Services" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/gH1zjZwLk4k?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/susie-cummings-managed-it-services-video-player.png" alt="Managed IT Services Video" width="400" height="281" /></a>

I think there are a lot of C-level executives facing challenges around security and understanding what responsibilities they have. We have worked with a lot of clients who are middle market organizations serving enterprise customers that need to comply with their security requirements and ensure that the data they are sending is secure. Thus we have a lot of security work and as an extension of that we deliver <a title="Security Managed Services" href="/solutions/security-services/security-managed-services">security managed services</a> as a best practice.

The first step is to help our clients build a solid security foundation to protect their organization with next generation security solutions for today’s cyber threats. This includes market leading security tools for firewalls, malware detection and Network Access Controls to prevent attacks such as botnets and CryptoLocker. Once a security program has been put in place, our managed services security team begins completing daily security checks and quarterly security scans to make sure our customer are staying safe and compliant.

One of the things that has also been scary for a lot of organization is Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) and the lack of control IT has any more on the many devices that are engaging an organization’s environment and network. One of the areas SWC’s managed services security practice has done a lot of work on is determining what strategies need to be employed around BYOD and what kind of controls can be employed from a technology perspective to not only protect the organization’s data but also protect their client’s data as well and ensure compliance.

There are many benefits to partnering with SWC for security managed IT services. SWC’s approach provides our clients with not only a highly responsive team of subject matter experts, but also comprehensive coverage and predictable costs. Our security managed services offering includes:
<ul>
	<li>Vulnerability scanning</li>
	<li>Monitoring and management of firewalls</li>
	<li>Security log review</li>
	<li>Threat intelligence bulletins</li>
	<li>IPS / IDS tuning and management</li>
	<li>Next generation firewall and web application solutions</li>
	<li>Strategic IT roadmap and virtual CIO consulting services</li>
</ul>
To learn more please join us for our next complimentary <a title="IT Security Event" href="/events">Chicagoland security and managed services event</a> to learn more about the tools and tactics to keep your organization secure. Or contact us for a complimentary security assessment by calling 630.572.0240 or emailing <a title="Contact SWC" href="mailto:info@swc.com">info@swc.com</a>.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-14009" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-it-security-assessment-service.jpg" alt="SWC IT Security Assessment Service" width="500" height="375" /><h3>Recommended Managed IT Services Blog Posts</h3>

	<item>
		<title>Predictive Analytics Made Easy with Microsoft Azure Machine Learning</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/predictive-analytics-microsoft-azure-machine-learning</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Oct 2014 08:11:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14140</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="Microsoft Azure Machine Learning" href="/blog/business-intelligence/microsoft-azure-machine-learning">Microsoft Azure Machine Learning</a> is a new and powerful cloud based predictive analytics tool that gives users the ability to quickly forecast future trends and behaviors. Watch my “Ask SWC” video to see how easy it is to create predictive analytics models using Microsoft Azure Machine Learning.

<a title="New Features of Tableau 8.2" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/ody8vnzQ-AU?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Azure Machine Learning" width="474" height="262" /></a>

In my Microsoft Azure Machine Learning video, we built an experiment to predict possible buyers with a data set used to analyze prospective buyers and determine whether they were likely to buy our product or not. We also discuss how we were able to take the outcome of this experiment and make it into something that we could integrate with other applications to optimize the predictive analytics experiment. Through the sample we created I am able to go to my scoring model, set a publishing input and set a publishing output. The setting of the input and output will give Azure the information it needs to publish a web service.

<h3>Microsoft Azure and BI Solutions 630.570.0240</h3>

The publishing capability is one of the Microsoft Azure Machine Learning’s best features. There were predictive analytics and modeling capabilities in <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">SQL</a> a few versions ago that were fairly hard and time-consuming to use. Now that Microsoft has moved predictive analytics to the cloud with Azure, publishing is easy.

If you are interested in learning more about Microsoft Azure Machine Learning, SWC is sponsoring a <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Chicagoland Business Intelligence</a> Meetup on <strong>October 30th at Microsoft’s office in Downers Grove, Illinois</strong>. At this meetup we will show some practical demos to help you get up to speed with Azure Machine Learning. We will also discuss licensing and storage considerations, review end-to-end machine learning solutions integrated with a web app and review a real case study looking at customer churn. This complimentary event is open to those wanting to learn more and network with BI users in a fun and social setting. We hope you will join us by registering at the link below:

<a href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup10-30-14.html%20" target="_blank">http://www.swc.com/html/email/businessintmeetup/meetup10-30-14.html</a>

If you can’t make our meetup, SWC also presents complimentary monthly Chicagoland educational events on various technology solutions, including Microsoft Azure and Business Intelligence. Please visit <a title="SWC Events" href="/events">SWC Events</a> to learn more and register.

	<item>
		<title>Flexible and Scalable Web Hosting with Microsoft Azure</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/flexible-scalable-web-hosting-microsoft-azure</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Oct 2014 22:07:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14182</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[At <a title="IT Solutions Provider" href="http://www.swc.com">IT solutions provider</a>, SWC, we often get asked questions about web hosting. There is an ongoing debate over whether an organization should use a public hosting solution like GoDaddy or Network Solutions or their own servers. Public hosting solutions provide easy hosting and guaranteed uptime, but don’t always offer the full feature set an organization is looking for. Alternatively, some organizations opt to host their website on their own servers making internal IT staff responsible for the site’s maintenance and uptime. Microsoft Azure Websites provides a middle ground, read my blog to learn more.

<h3>SWC Cloud Solutions 630.572.0240</h3>

Microsoft Azure is a <a title="Chicago Cloud Services" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud platform</a> that offers fully hosted and customizable websites. The underlying maintenance and management of the system is controlled by Microsoft, so you’re guaranteed 99.9% uptime without your organization’s internal IT staff getting involved. The website can be configured either through a web editor or via file upload and Azure can also integrate with Git, TFS and GitHub for easier continuous deployment of site changes and updates. Azure websites also have all of the common programming languages available including .Net, Java, PHP, Python, etc.

However, unlike some other services, Azure Websites can go a step further because they can integrate with other Azure services. This allows Azure websites to have a database backend such as <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL</a>, MySQL, DocumentDB and others using Azure resources. If you already have these databases onsite and want to connect to your existing data sources, Azure makes that possible as well. This flexibility makes it is easy to setup any number of packaged templates – such as WordPress, Joomla or Drupal in a matter of minutes.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14181" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/azure-web-hosting-setup.jpg" alt="Azure Web Hosting Setup" width="500" height="348" />

One other area that sets Azure apart from many of the other hosting vendors is the new, more advanced auto-scaling feature. Many vendors including Azure will monitor your traffic and when a usage spike occurs, retroactively scale your services to try to keep up with the demand. In this scenario, anyone who tries to visit your site before the system can scale properly will have poor performance. But what about scenarios where you know in advance that your site is going to have higher than normal usage – such as when a new promotion or mailing goes out? Azure gives you the flexibility to preschedule your resources to scale up at a specific date and time and then once the usage goes back to normal, you can schedule your Azure website resources to scale back down.

Microsoft Azure Websites may be the solution for greater flexibility in your organization’s cloud hosting. Our goal at SWC is to be a partner to help find the right cloud solution, we work with a number of cloud vendors to ensure the right fit for your organization’s specific needs. Our cloud consultants have an extensive technical background and know what requirements to consider before moving applications and systems to the cloud, including when moving to the cloud is not recommended. We can apply that expertise to your environment. For more information on Microsoft Azure and cloud services <a title="Contact SWC" href="/contact">contact SWC</a> or attend one of our complimentary <a title="Cloud Events Chicago" href="/events">Chicagoland cloud luncheons</a>.

	<item>
		<title>Integrating Microsoft Lync and Dynamics CRM for Call Tracking</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/integrating-microsoft-lync-dynamics-crm-call-tracking</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Nov 2014 00:57:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14277</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A challenge most organizations face is trying to convince salespeople to log calls in their CRM system. Most salespeople complain that it takes way too long. But isn’t that the point of using a CRM system – being able to understand previous interactions you have had with prospects, leads or even current customers and react based on the results of those actions? Read my blog to learn more about a new tool that SWC has developed to integrate <a title="Microsoft Lync Services" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync </a>with Dynamics CRM for call tracking and how it will make call logging quicker and much easier for your sales team.

Microsoft has significantly improved the user interface and experience in their latest release of <a title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM" href="/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management">Dynamics CRM</a>. They have also reduced the number of clicks required to log calls with a new social pane. SWC has taken these improvements one step further by integrating Microsoft Lync and Microsoft Dynamics CRM for call tracking.

The SWC Lync Call Monitor was developed to allow users with Microsoft Lync 2013 enabled phone systems to monitor inbound call events and provide them with an easy mechanism for logging the call that took place with real-time information about the caller. All the user has to do is click to log it. The photo below shows the Lync Call Monitor, a small application that runs in a users’ background listening for inbound calls:

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14275" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-lync-call-monitor.png" alt="Microsoft Lync Call Monitor" width="500" height="96" />

The application automatically looks to match a contact in CRM when a call comes in. The user then has the option to open up the caller’s CRM contact record, or they can create a new CRM phone call activity for the contact. From there, SWC can customize the Lync Call Monitor solution to fit your organization’s unique business process needs.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14276" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-lync-In-bound-call-details.png" alt="Microsoft Lync In-bound Call Details" width="500" height="283" />

Make call logging easier for your sales team with Microsoft Lync 2013. Contact us for more information or attend one of our upcoming <a title="Chicago Technology Events" href="/events">Chicagoland technology events</a> to learn more about Microsoft Lync and Dynamics CRM.

	<item>
		<title>Everything You Need to Know About the Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 Release</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/everything-you-need-to-know-about-microsoft-dynamics-crm-2015-release</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Nov 2014 14:15:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[wallyseliga]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14287</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[By now just about anyone keeping tabs on <a title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM" href="/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management">Microsoft Dynamics CRM</a> has seen that CRM 2015 is scheduled to be released in Q4 of this year. I have seen some confusion around what the 2015 release brings, which portions of the release are already available and how the feature set differs for online and on-premise customers. I wanted to break it all down for you in my blog on everything you need to know about the Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 release.
<h2>Fall 2013</h2>
Microsoft released CRM 2013 – this version release provided a complete new user interface which added many brand new compelling features (check out our blog – <a title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 Features" href="/blog/ask-swc/cool-new-features-of-microsoft-dynamics-crm-2013">What Are Some Cool New Features of Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013</a> to learn more).
<h2>Spring 2014</h2>
Microsoft released some new features and fixed some standing issues in a large rollup called the “Spring 2014 Update” or CRM 2013 Service Pack 1. For on-premise customers, this was installed as a service pack executable on your CRM servers, while for online customers, the update was managed through the “install updates” button in the settings section of CRM.

The most sought after features of this release come in the form of Social Listening and Microsoft Dynamics Marketing Automation. Both of these solutions bring the Microsoft solution that much closer to functional parity with Salesforce, but at a lower price point without utilizing third party solutions like Radian6 and <a title="ExactTarget Business Solutions" href="/solutions/crm/salesforce-com-customer-relationship-management/exacttarget-digital-marketing">ExactTarget</a>.

<strong>Social Listening:</strong>
Social listening allows customers to track various social platforms of their customers and measure things like posting rates, geographic activity and sentiment about your brands, services and competitors. This service was available for online customers only and is included with the base licensing.

<strong>Dynamics Marketing:</strong>
Dynamics Marketing is a cloud based service model that allows for robust visual campaign setup and execution that integrates with your online or on-premise CRM. Emails are sent from Microsoft’s servers instead of your own network and they measure ROI based events like delivery, opens and click-through rates and then push the information back into CRM. They also will provide lead scoring based on responses to marketing activity. This service is available for online and on-premise customers and requires additional licensing of $125 per user per month.

I will dig in further on these two major feature additions over the course of my next two blog posts.
<h2>Q4 2014</h2>
In Q4, Microsoft will release Dynamics CRM 2015. The user interface remains largely unchanged, while many new features are added and many existing features are improved. The <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics/crm-customer-center/get-ready-for-the-next-release.aspx" target="_blank">Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 Release Preview Guide</a> seems to show the Social and Marketing features as being new, even though they have been in place since the spring update. There are however some additional improvements to this functionality and some great technical improvements such as:
<ul>
	<li>CRM 2013 brought us the visual sales process which allows us to see the sales stage of an opportunity and dynamically change the information captured in that stage. Now in 2015, we will be able to dynamically change the sales process and add branching logic based on the opportunities attributes</li>
	<li>Global search field present in the navigation will allow you to search for terms across all supported entities at once and provide results from in a single screen</li>
	<li>Increased sales order functionality mostly centering around the capability to create product bundles to promote upselling</li>
	<li>The social listening feature will now be available for on-premise customers</li>
	<li>Visual hierarchy feature will allow you to see in a “tree” structure how accounts are related to child accounts. This feature applies to products and users as well.</li>
	<li>Addition of “roll-up” fields and “calculated” fields that allow automatic summations and calculations. The calculations will run in an asynchronous process and will automatically calculate in batch when they are first added to an entity with existing records.</li>
	<li>There will be new security model changes that allow for visibility based on hierarchy in the organization</li>
</ul>
SWC has been an implementer of Microsoft Dynamics CRM since the product’s origination and have vast CRM customization and deployment expertise. If you would like to learn more about CRM 2015 or how SWC can help your organization drive sales, marketing and service processes through this platform, please contact us at <a title="Contact SWC" href="mailto:info@swc.com">info@swc.com</a> or call 630.572.0240. And stayed tuned for more information on our <a title="Microsoft Dynamics 2015 Event" href="/events">Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 event</a> in January.

	<item>
		<title>Performance and Schedule Autoscaling in Microsoft Azure</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/performance-schedule-autoscaling-microsoft-azure</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Nov 2014 20:47:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[benbrock]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14359</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Do you have a website or application that experiences heavy traffic in peaks during certain days, weeks or months of the year? Do your servers sit idle for extended periods of time? Are you paying to support your peak loads in off-peak times? If you answered "Yes" to any of these questions, Azure autoscaling may be something to consider. Read my blog on performance and schedule autoscaling in Azure to learn more.

<h3>SWC Cloud Solutions 630.572.0240</h3>

Azure is Microsoft’s <a title="Chicago Cloud Services" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud platform</a> for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS). Comprised of a growing collection of integrated services for applications, computing, data, networking and storage, Microsoft Azure has been ranked as an industry leader by Gartner due to its ability to help organizations do more, work faster and save money. Azure’s IaaS offering gives you the flexibility to define your environment requirements based on assumptions, then make adjustments once those assumptions are confirmed – in minutes. For example, if you expect 1,000 concurrent users to hit your site for the entire month of December during the peak shopping season, but later find that you only need to support that high load during the third week of December, Azure can be configured to dynamically adjust the number and size of servers as needed.

There are essentially two types of scaling options in Azure:
<ul>
	<li>Performance-based Autoscaling</li>
	<li>Schedule-based Autoscaling</li>
</ul>
Performance-based autoscaling in Azure monitors the average CPU usage and message queues. Azure can dynamically add Virtual Machine instances when CPU utilization exceeds a threshold set by an administrator, then turn the new <a title="Virtualization Solutions" href="/solutions/virtualization">Virtual Machine</a> off when usage returns to the target threshold. Similarly, the number of messages in a queue can be monitored and Virtual Machines can be turned on or off from what's known as an availability set.

If performance-based scaling is too reactive for your needs and the load on your servers is more predictable, schedule-based autoscaling can be used in a more proactive approach. For example, anticipated load based on events such as a go-live date, running of a TV commercial or a published registration date can be accommodated by configuring Azure to add resources on a targeted date and time. Used in conjunction with performance-based autoscaling, you can specify the number of additional Virtual Machines you think you will need, then let Azure add more if your target utilization thresholds are exceeded.

Azure's benefits can be summarized by speed, scale and economics. The autoscaling features in Azure reflect all three:
<ul>
	<li><strong>Speed</strong> – Setting up new environments can be done in minutes, with no manual intervention</li>
	<li><strong>Scale</strong> – Size your environment appropriately based on intermittent, short-term or long-term needs</li>
	<li><strong>Economics</strong> – Pay only for the resources used and then “turn it off” when they aren't needed</li>
</ul>
If you want to learn more about Microsoft Azure's autoscaling options, or are interested in a one day free on-site assessment to find out what it would take to move your environment to Azure, please join us for our upcoming Chicagoland <strong>Building and Migration Applications</strong> to <a title="Chicago Azure Events" href="/events">Azure event</a> or contact <a href="mailto:ben.brock@swc.com">Ben Brock</a>.

	<item>
		<title>SCCM Troubleshooting 101: An Example</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-example</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Nov 2014 06:04:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeffpoling]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14395</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you’ve read my last two blogs, you probably have a good understanding of <a title="Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager </a>(SCCM) and the monitoring workspace in the SCCM console, SCCM log files and CMTrace. In this blog, I wanted to walk you through a specific SCCM troubleshooting scenario. Read my SCCM troubleshooting 101 blog to learn more.

In this case, I created a simple package with a single program that I deployed to a collection.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14386" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-1.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 1" width="500" height="129" />

When I open Software Center on the client to install the program, it fails.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14387" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-2.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 2" width="500" height="279" />

In this case, the error seems to be pretty clear, but let’s dig into the logs to be sure. First, we are deploying a package and program, so we need to look at the execmgr.log.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14388" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-3.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 3" width="500" height="121" />
We can see from the execmgr.log that the content for this program is not available on the distribution point. I am pretty confident that I distributed the content for the package, but to be sure let’s look at the <a title="Microsoft SCCM" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">SCCM</a> console. Content Distribution status is shown in the Monitoring workspace and in the Distribution Status | Content Status node.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14389" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-4.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 4" width="500" height="154" />

The content for our package is on the distribution point, but why does the client think that it is not available? We know from the Technical Reference for Log Files in Configuration Manager that the cas.log on the client has information about content being downloaded to the client cache. Let’s look at the cas.log for more information.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14390" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-5.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 5" width="500" height="210" />

No warnings or errors are highlighted, but we do see an interesting log entry: “The number of discovered DPs (Including Branch DP and Multicast) is 0.”

If a client cannot discover a distribution point, there is a good chance it relates to boundaries. Based on the information in the logs so far, let’s investigate the configuration of boundaries in the environment. My lab is very simple, so I have a single boundary and a single boundary group.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14391" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-6.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 6" width="500" height="114" />

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14392" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-7.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 7" width="500" height="99" />

After looking at the boundary groups again, the problem with the program deployment is definitely a configuration issue. The Lab – Content boundary group does not have a site system designated for content.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14393" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-8.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 8" width="427" height="394" />

I added the distribution point to the boundary group and tried the deployment again. This time it was a complete success.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14394" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sccm-troubleshooting-101-9.png" alt="SCCM Troubleshooting 101 9" width="500" height="171" />

This is just one example of using log files and the Monitoring workspace in the SCCM console to troubleshoot and resolve errors. Hopefully this provides a foundation for any SCCM troubleshooting you need to do. If you are still having trouble with SCCM and troubleshooting errors, SWC’s Microsoft System Center team has extensive experience with SCCM and is ready to help you with all of your troubleshooting needs.

To learn more about Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 and all of finer features that will enable your business to drastically reduce the time, cost and complexity involved in managing and
monitoring today's fast paced IT environment please join us for our next complimentary Chicagoland Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 event.

This blog, is part of a three part series. Below are additional SCCM 101 troubleshooting blogs:

<a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Overview" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-overview">Part I - SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Overview</a>
<a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Log Files" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files">Part II - SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Log Files</a>
<h3>TECHNICAL MICROSOFT SYSTEM CENTER 2012 BLOG POSTS</h3>
If you enjoyed this blog, please check out a few of Jeff’s past technical Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 blog posts:

<a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Log Files" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-log-files">SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Log Files</a>
<a title="SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Overview" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-troubleshooting-101-overview">SCCM Troubleshooting 101: Overview</a>
<a title="Integrating Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/integrating-microsoft-system-center-endpoint-protection-2012-r2">Integrating Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2</a>
<a title="Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection 2012 R2" href="/blog/microsoft-system-center/integrating-microsoft-system-center-endpoint-protection-2012-r2">Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection 2012 R2</a>
