	<item>
		<title>What&#039;s New for Business Intelligence and Analytics in 2015</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/whats-new-business-intelligence-analytics-2015</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 Nov 2014 00:57:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14535</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The field of <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence" href="/solutions/business-intelligence">Business Intelligence</a> has been progressing at a rapid pace over the past few years. New tools and technologies are making it even easier for end users to quickly gain insights into the business in order to make critical decisions supporting organizational goals and initiatives. Read my blog about what’s new for business intelligence and analytics in 2015 to learn more.

Recently new business intelligence players have come to the market providing users with dashboard and reporting tools that include advanced visualizations. The customers we work with are very excited about the advances in mapping capabilities so that they can see aspects of their business across the globe and drill down to local levels; even layering additional public data such as median household income on those images so that they can make decisions about new business initiatives, marketing spend or product placement.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14534" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/business-intelligence-dashboard-team-analysis-report.png" alt="Business Intelligence Dashboard Team Analysis Report" width="427" height="322" />

Several leading vendors such as <a title="Business Intelligence Tableau" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/tableau">Tableau</a> and Microsoft are now integrating the ability to do predictive analytics within their solutions. We have had several local <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Events" href="/events">Chicagoland business intelligence events</a> recently around predictive and have found high attendance and interest in this topic as more companies are trying to get their hands around how to leverage predictive analytics for a competitive advantage without having to hire a data scientist. Organizations no longer need to just see past performance and if they are meeting current KPIs. They want to model out the future based on trends so that they can be ahead of the curve in having the right product or service available at the right time.

<h3>Business Intelligence Solutions 630.572.0240</h3>

In the past few years there have also been many advances in mobile technologies and as such many vendors are responding with better mobile capabilities for BI. We have found that field representatives, such as sales and executives are asking for more dashboard and reporting access while on their phones and tablets, and vendors have been responding with better integration. However, rather than being a competitive advantage, we are finding this to be an assumed requirement of any tool and most players have addressed this need for the end consumers.

We have also been seeing an uptick in customers moving to the <a title="Chicago Cloud Services" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud</a> with two main drivers behind that: solution and hardware costs. Typically it is much more affordable to purchase user licensing for the cloud, then there is less of a need to have as much hardware on-premise to support that. Microsoft launched Power BI within the past year which enables organizations to share Excel spreadsheets, reports and Power View assets through team sites in the cloud. One of their key differentiators is the ability to interact with both cloud and on-premise data which has been important for many customers who still have concerns about putting sensitive data in the cloud. However, within our customer base this seems to be a continued trend that is under consideration for the near future.

For any organization it is important to have a robust data context with high data quality as the foundation for any BI initiative. We have found that many companies will adopt a new tool for the front end, but neglect the data itself, rendering amazing charts and graphs with bad data and therefore making bad decisions. More and more customers have been working with us on master data and data quality strategies enabling them to have one centralized clean version of the truth for all reporting and analytics. We feel with all of the disparate systems, sources and higher volumes of information, including Big Data that this will continue to be a key concern for organizations in the near term.

If business intelligence is one of your organization’s top initiatives for 2015, please <a title="Contact SWC" href="/contact">contact SWC</a> to talk about BI strategy or join us for our next Chicagoland <a title="Chicago Business Intelligence Events" href="/events">business intelligence event</a>. SWC provides our customers with a choice when it comes to business intelligence and offer <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">Microsoft SQL Server</a>, <a title="Microsoft Office 365" href="/solutions/microsoft-office-365">Office 365</a>’s Power BI and Tableau.

	<item>
		<title>How to Move a Hyper-V Virtual Machine into Microsoft Azure Using System Center</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/move-hyper-v-virtual-machine-into-microsoft-azure-using-system-center</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Nov 2014 17:23:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14547</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[At <a title="IT Solutions Provider" href="http://www.swc.com">IT solutions provider</a>, SWC, we often get asked if it is possible to move a virtual machine from an existing on-premise Hyper-V environment into Microsoft Azure. The answer is yes! It’s actually an easy process using <a title="System Center Virtual Machine Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/virtual-machine-manager-app-controller">Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager</a> and System Center App Controller. Read my blog to learn more and see how this can be done.
<h2>Instructions for how to move Hyper-V Virtual Machine into Microsoft Azure using System Center:</h2>
Before you start, make sure that Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manger has been connected to your <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V" href="/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v">Hyper-V</a> environment and that App Controller is linked to both your VMM server and Microsoft Azure. It is also recommended that you pre-create any Azure networks, <a title="SWC Cloud Services" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud services</a> and storage groups that you might need. If you need assistance with the setup of either the System Center application or 

<strong>Once everything has been configured, follow these steps to migrate a virtual machine:</strong>
<ol>
	<li>Login to App Controller and find the virtual machine that you would like to migrate.</li>
	<li>Once the correct virtual machine is highlighted, click Store at the top of the page. When you store the virtual machine it will shut it down, so please make sure that you have scheduled downtime before starting this procedure.</li>
</ol>
<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14549" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/system-center-hyper-v-microsoft-azure-1.png" alt="System Center Hyper V Microsoft Azure" width="500" height="163" />
<ol start="3">
	<li>Once the virtual machine has been stored, a new menu will appear and you can choose <strong>Copy</strong> to start the Azure transfer wizard.</li>
	<li><img class="alignright size-full wp-image-14550" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/system-center-hyper-v-microsoft-azure-2.png" alt="System Center Hyper V Microsoft Azure 2" width="201" height="365" />The Azure deployment wizard will usually include a warning. This is not actually a problem, instead it is the wizard helping you decide what VM size to use in Azure. App Controller will look at the specifications of the existing virtual machine and recommend the minimum size to get the same or better performance in Azure. SWC always recommends reviewing the warning and ensuring that the recommended virtual machine size is met or exceeded to have a good experience in Azure.</li>
	<li>To start the wizard, first click on Configure and select the Azure cloud subscription you would like to use.</li>
	<li>Next pick your existing cloud service or create a new one. The cloud service is basically a container that will hold the virtual machine.</li>
	<li>Next select the proper networking. As we mentioned earlier it is recommended that you configure this ahead of time using the Azure portal to make sure everything is ready for the migration.</li>
	<li>Finally, configure the virtual machine properties. You will need to do all of the following:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
	<li>Name the virtual machine</li>
	<li>Select a size for the virtual machine (again consider the size recommendation from the wizard’s warning)</li>
	<li>Select your storage space for the virtual disk files</li>
	<li>Configure any networking and firewall rules you would like. If the server is a web server or FTP server, for example – this section would be the place to add remote access for those services.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="9">
	<li>Once you have confirmed everything is ready to upload, click the <strong>Deploy</strong> button and then let it run.</li>
</ol>
Depending on the size of the virtual machine and the available bandwidth this can take anywhere from 15 minutes to several hours to copy the virtual machine into Azure. Once the process completes the VM will be automatically started and will be available on the Internet and you can use App Controller or the Azure portal to further manage its settings.

Our goal at SWC is to be a trusted partner, helping you find the right cloud solution that matches your business needs and can help your organization grow. We work with a number of cloud vendors including Microsoft Azure and Amazon Web Services to ensure we find the right fit. SWC has an extensive technical background and cloud consulting experience, we know what requirements to consider when moving applications and systems to the cloud, including when moving to the cloud is not recommended. We can apply that expertise to your environment.

Would you like more information on Microsoft Azure, or want to see a demonstration of this process? Visit one of our upcoming Chicagoland <a title="Chicago area Cloud Events" href="/events">Cloud</a> or <a title="Chicago area System Center" href="/events">System Center</a> luncheons to learn more.<h3>Related Microsoft Azure Blog Posts</h3>
If you enjoy learning more about the cloud and Microsoft Azure, please check out a few of our past posts:
<a title="Five Questions to Ask Before Investing in a Cloud Service" href="/blog/cloud/five-questions-to-ask-before-investing-in-cloud-service">Five Questions to Ask Before Investing in a Cloud Service</a>
<a title="Performance and Schedule Autoscaling in Microsoft Azure" href="/blog/cloud/performance-schedule-autoscaling-microsoft-azure">Performance and Schedule Autoscaling in Microsoft Azure</a>

	<item>
		<title>How Search Engine Technology Is Changing the Way We Think About SEO</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/search-engine-technology-changing-seo</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Nov 2014 22:38:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[maryobrien]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14562</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[With the holiday season right around the corner, it’s time to start thinking about what to get that person on your list who has everything. When I am stumped, my go to gift is always the latest and greatest gadget. What do I suggest this year? Read my blog to learn more.

If you really want to go all out this holiday season, check out the new Google Glass. Okay – so $1,500 is a lot to spend on eyewear, but you can guarantee that the person receiving this gift has never experienced anything quite like it. Among Google Glass’ many incredible features, the one most relevant to <a title="Chicago Search Engine Optimization" href="/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization">Search Engine Optimization</a> (SEO) is its ability to listen to your request and not only respond with an answer aloud, but also display a visual. For example, if you’re looking for a place to eat, Google Glass will show step-by-step directions. You can also see an image of the restaurant, its reviews and even visit the website if you’d like. However this gets a little tricky when you’re browsing through a website in the corner of your lens!

Certainly <a href="https://www.google.com/glass/start/" target="_blank">Google Glass</a> has a long way to go before becoming mainstream. However, it is a huge step forward in the humanization of technology – and a good indication of where search technology is headed.

In today’s fast-paced world, technology is frequently changing the way people find and share information. In the case of our clients, technology changes the way potential customers find critical information about their business. As search technology continues to humanize – first with the smartphone, then voice-detection and now wearable search displays, we need to constantly change the way we think about <a title="Chicago SEO Services" href="/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization">SEO</a>.
<h2>SEO for the Future</h2>
While we may not be at the point yet where we need to create websites that fit into a person’s peripheral vision, the days of viewing a website on smaller screens such as a smartphone or tablet are here – and have been here for a while. Whether you’re on the bus or at the bar, it’s easy to see that everyone is attached to their mobile device. Not surprisingly, it is expected that by 2015, searches via a mobile device will surpass those on a desktop. If your website doesn’t already have a responsive mobile-friendly design, now is the time to get one.

Adapting to new technology does not end with the look and feel of your site. As Google becomes more sophisticated, you’ll notice that many of your searches are generating engaging displays in the search engine results page (SERP). These displays also take shape in mobile phones, tablets and <a title="Google Glass News" href="/blog/technology/swc-featured-on-telemundo-google-glass">Google Glass</a>.

To put this into real-world context, say for example you are searching for “bulls” in Google. The Search Engine Results Page (SERP) will render much more than simply a long list of links. In my case, Google knows that I live in Chicago and my search history tells it that I’m interested in sports, therefore it has a pretty good understanding of my intent and will show me results for the “Chicago Bulls” basketball team rather than information about “bulls” – the animal. And I’m not just given a link to the Chicago Bulls official homepage, I’m shown the Bulls logo, a quick description about the team, its arena location, coach, mascot and division. I can even scroll through the team’s roster and game schedule. At a glance, I have access to pretty much all of the answers I need before I even click into a website. This is a great example of how Google is evolving from being a “search engine” into an “answer engine.”

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14559" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/seo-search-technology-chicago-bulls.png" alt="SEO Search Technology Chicago Bulls" width="500" height="399" />
<h2>Semantic Search for Your Business</h2>
The very definition of “semantic” is finding meaning in language or logic. In the example above, the search engine knows what I’m thinking about and the information I’m seeking simply from the word “bulls.” Today’s search engines can not only recognize keywords, they can actually understand the meaning behind them. So what does this mean for your digital marketing or even business strategy? It means that keywords alone simply won’t cut it. Optimizing your website for today’s search technology means understanding the way search engines are categorizing and indexing information on your site, as well as understanding your customer and the types of questions and topics they are most interested in.

Perhaps one of the most untapped resources of today’s website optimization is semantic markup. This is essentially HTML that can be used on the back-end of your website to reinforce the meaning of information and help search engines understand what your website is about. It can increase the chances that information from your website will be highlighted in SERP via knowledge graphs, attracting greater attention and click-throughs. Although this concept has been around for years, it’s especially significant in today’s world where mobile and voice search are becoming the norm – both of which rely heavily on semantic markup to extract information from the Web.

Although we cannot predict where search technology will be in the future, we are able to identify strong trends towards semantic technology currently being deployed by search engines, laying the groundwork for what’s to come. Perhaps one day, we’ll be talking aloud to pieces of equipment strapped to our heads; maybe that piece of equipment will transform from “Google Glass” to “Google Contacts.” I can’t say for certain what will happen, all I know is that my website will be ready for it!

If you want to learn more about responsive websites and semantic markup, or are interested in SEO for your business, please join us for our next complimentary Chicagoland <a title="Web Design SEO Event" href="/events">Web Design, SEO &amp; Digital Marketing Strategy event</a>.<h2>SWC’s Website and SEO Services</h2>
SWC’s digital design practice includes website development and search engine optimization (SEO) services.
<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/ip9j7NL3S7U?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox;width=720;height=480;"><img src="/uploads/chicago-digital-marketing-seo-video.png" alt="Chicago Website Design and SEO" width="500" height="281" /></a>

	<item>
		<title>How Microsoft Azure Can Reduce Help Desk Calls and Increase Security</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-azure-reduce-helpdesk-calls-increase-security</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Nov 2014 06:16:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeremyalt]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14659</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Two big challenges for IT today are the volume of help desk calls and the growing need for enhanced security. In the past these two challenges were costly to overcome, required deep expertise in non traditional technologies or were prohibitive due to the time required for implementation. With Microsoft’s Enterprise Mobility Suite (EMS) which includes Azure Active Directory Premium, organizations can now quickly and efficiently achieve enhanced security and reduce help desk calls. Read my blog to learn more.

Enterprise Mobility Suite and Azure Active Directory Premium can greatly reduce the number of help desk calls your organization receives with self-service password resets. No longer are users required to log a ticket, call the help desk or wait for business hours to request a password reset. IT also doesn’t need to manage a third party product, since everything is based off of Active Directory! The integration between on-premises Active Directory and Azure Active Directory ensures all accounts are synchronized and resets happen in real time. All requests are driven via a web based portal within Azure that users can access anywhere and anytime. Once a user requires a password reset a simple verification step occurs through a text message, phone call or alternate email to ensure the users’ identity. Once the user’s identity is confirmed a verification code is provided so that the user can reset their password.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14661" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-azure-password-reset-screenshot.png" alt="Password Reset Screenshot" width="500" height="379" />
<p style="text-align: center;"><i>Password requirements will always follow your organizational polices defined within Active Directory.</i></p>

Enterprise Mobility Suite and Active Directory Premium also give organizations the use of Azure Multi-Factor Authentication for enhanced security. As we continue to see a growing mobile workforce that requires access to data from anywhere at any time, it is critical to ensure that the users logging into your environment are who you think they are. Microsoft Azure Multi-Factor Authentication provides additional security that’s instantaneously achieved. Azure Multi-Factor Authentication can be used within <a title="Microsoft Office 365" href="/solutions/microsoft-office-365">Microsoft Office365</a>, Azure Administrators or one of the thousands of SaaS applications available on the market today. Authentication methods include – apps for Android, iPhone and Windows Phone. These are delivered as automated phone calls or text messages.

SWC Technology Partners has a variety of free educational events to help get your Chicagoland business up to speed on all of Microsoft’s latest <a title="Cloud Technology" href="/solutions/cloud-services">cloud technology</a> solutions and help teach you best practices regarding security and IT strategy. Please visit our events page to learn more and register.

	<item>
		<title>Skipping Ahead to Windows 10</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/downloadable-windows-10</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Dec 2014 22:32:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14805</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Dynamic IT is changing the landscape of how we manage and deploy both software and hardware to corporate workers. Windows 10 is no exception. Microsoft’s newest iteration of Windows marks a significant milestone in its evolution and is well-worth paying close attention to. Read my blog to learn more about the new features in <a title="Microsoft Windows" href="/solutions/microsoft-windows">Microsoft Windows</a> 10 that are helping IT managers and decision makers stay ahead of the curve.

For client tablets, laptops and workstations, the <a title="Windows 10 Preview" href="http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/dn798751.aspx?ocid=wc-mscom-wol" target="_blank">Enterprise Technical Preview</a> of Windows 10 is currently available for download. The new OS should be immediately familiar to most users, as it was designed to cater to businesses and as such is modeled in the same vein as Windows 7 and the now-retired Windows XP. The most obvious and noticeable expression of this is the return of an enhanced start menu, which dates back to Windows 95! While legacy compatibility is important for continuity, there are many contemporary features to support new form factors, touch-based interfaces and high-DPI resolution displays. One notable security enhancement is the ability for BitLocker to containerize sensitive data so that it remains encrypted, even if it leaves the device.

<h2>Learn More About Microsoft System Center: <strong><span style="color: #f39000;"><a style="color: #f39000;" href="mailto:info@swc.com">Email</a></span></strong> or Call 630-572-0240.</h2>

Yet the revised client is only one part of the story. The Technical Preview of <a title="Windows Server" href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/evalcenter/evaluate-windows-server-technical-preview" target="_blank">Windows Server vNext</a> is also available and there are some significant feature advancements within that make it quite compelling – particularly in the area of <a title="Virtualization Consulting SWC" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/virtualization" target="_blank">virtualization</a>. Windows Server vNext will support rolling Hyper-V cluster upgrades, which will greatly ease the process of keeping a cluster current without having to rebuild it from scratch. Windows Server vNext’s Storage Replica can also perform similar functions for disks as Hyper-V Replica does for VMs – providing us with a game-changing approach to disk-based mirroring between servers. Finally, a Production Checkpoint of VMs is now application-consistent over and above a standard snapshot.

Need greater manageability? Download the <a title="System Center Preview" href="http://blogs.technet.com/b/server-cloud/archive/2014/10/01/announcing-availability-of-windows-server-technical-preview-and-system-center-technical-preview.aspx" target="_blank">System Center Technical Preview</a> (which will be released alongside the client and server) in order to leverage next-generation capabilities, termed Software Defined Everything as opposed to just Software Defined Networking. It is anticipated that this System Center upgrade won’t require a complete rebuild of the management platform either. But basic support for the new OS will be back-ported into the existing <a title="Microsoft System Center Consulting SWC" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/microsoft-system-center-2012-r2" target="_blank">Microsoft System Center 2012 R2</a> offering.

With constant change happening at breakneck speeds, some of you may be cautious about rapidly adopting the newest and latest technologies. Windows 10 is not completely new, all of the core Win32 API functions that business-critical apps have relied on for decades are still present within the OS and accounted for. This means the majority of existing software should work right out the gate and many of the other OS functions have been compartmentalized in order to cater to the form factors of different device types, such as tablets and smartphones.

<strong>The bottom line is:</strong> Windows 10 is a mature product at its core that continues to grow with new features and increase usability.

There are many reasons why you should start thinking about your organization’s transition into the next generation of Windows. To get ready for Windows 10, <a title="SWC Consulting Contact Information " href="http://www.swc.com/contact" target="_blank">contact SWC</a> to discuss the best long-term Dynamic IT strategy for your business.
<h2>Microsoft System Center Solutions</h2>
Please watch our video below to learn more about SWC’s approach to Microsoft System Center 2012 R2.

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft SharePoint Helps Empower and Enable Users at M. Holland</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/making-sharepoint-look-good</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Dec 2014 20:41:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=14864</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft SharePoint is a market leading search, portal and content management platform used by nearly eighty percent of Fortune 500 companies and millions worldwide to improve workforce collaboration, efficiency and productivity. For years, SWC has helped create <a title="SWC Sharepoint Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint solutions</a> that are engaging, easy to use and increase user adoption. Watch our client success video case study to learn about how SWC helped M. Holland find success by making SharePoint look good and perform well for their users.

<a title="M Holland Microsoft Sharepoint Enablement By SWC" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/s6UYIs9Pxuw?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-sharepoint-enablement.png" alt="Microsoft SharePoint Enablement" width="500" height="281" /></a>

M. Holland is the largest privately held thermoplastic resin distributor in North America with a rich history and more than 60 years of experience. One of the challenges the company faced last year was a reinvention of the intranet – a place where employees can go for company information, such as important documents needed to do their jobs more efficiently. M. Holland engaged SWC to help design a compelling user experience and intranet site that would be aesthetically pleasing and get more robust over time.

Prior to the reinvention of the intranet, SharePoint was an underutilized platform and it largely became a public drive for M. Holland. The new intranet gives employees a more robust experience, offering the ability to quickly retrieve and share company information. The M. Holland team now has quick links to the key information and documents they need to do their jobs more efficiently and effectively. The intranet has also become a center point for employee communication. There is now consistency when the company rolls out announcements to the organization using SharePoint.

<img class="alignnone wp-image-14878 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Success.png" alt="SWC Sharepoint Example" width="500" height="278" />
<blockquote>“What SWC did that we had not experienced before was they wanted to see how the average user was going to use the site and help develop it around them.”

<strong>– Pete Nutley, VP of Operations</strong></blockquote>
The thought leadership around how you architect one of those experiences to make it engaging for the user has proven to be SWC’s strong suit. SWC has been more than just a technology solutions provider to M. Holland, we are a trusted partner. It has been a great experience working together to enable M. Holland's business and empower their employees.
<blockquote>“They are not just a technical deliverer, they deliver on spirit and dream and intent and all of those other things.”

<strong>– Neil Goodrich, IT Manager</strong></blockquote>
If you are interested in Microsoft SharePoint and want to learn more about how SWC designs solutions that increase user adoption and enable teams to work smarter, faster and more efficiently than ever before, please join us for our next <a title="Chicago Sharepoint Information" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland SharePoint event</a> or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a>. You can also see us at <a title="Sharepoint Fest Chicago" href="http://www.sharepointfest.com/Chicago/" target="_blank">SharePoint Fest Chicago</a> on December 9 – 10th.<h3>Client Success</h3>
If you enjoyed this client success video case study, please check out a few of our related videos:

	<item>
		<title>Microsoft RemoteApp: Your Apps in the Cloud</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-remoteapp</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Dec 2014 23:12:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15025</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On December 11th, an interesting new feature in <a title="Azure Cloud Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">Microsoft Azure</a> called RemoteApp will be available for general use. Azure RemoteApp is Microsoft’s Remote Desktop Services in the cloud and offers a number of features to make your applications and services globally available. Read my blog to learn more about RemoteApp and how this new feature will benefit your organization.
<h2>How Can RemoteApp Help Me?</h2>
Microsoft has worked with a number of customers and realized that many organizations are looking for ways to more easily centralize and publish applications. With the ever increasing number of people teleworking and companies implementing Bring-Your-Own-Device (BYOD) policies it is more important than ever for organizations to be able to track application installation while still making sure that end users have the tools they need. RemoteApp solves these problems by allowing organizations to publish applications to almost any device with an Internet connection including Windows and Mac workstations, Android phones and tablets and iOS devices. These published applications are also streamed from the server so that they no longer need to be installed on individual machines, reducing the load on the IT department and simplifying licensing management.
&nbsp;
<h2>How Does RemoteApp Work?</h2>
RemoteApp relies on the same Remote Desktop Services technology that on-premises terminal servers use. However, RemoteApp takes it a step further and publishes the applications from these servers to an easy to use application. IT staff no longer needs to monitor and maintain a large RDS environment – Azure does all of the heavy lifting.

In addition, hosting your applications in Azure allows your organization to take advantage of the high availability of Azure’s infrastructure. Your RemoteApp infrastructure is extremely redundant and will be active even if your on-premises environment is down. This can benefit the end users not just for day to day use, but also in disaster scenarios where many users are without a workstation. If they are running their applications from the cloud, users can install the RemoteApp client on any machine and will have their applications ready in a matter of minutes.

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15026 size-medium" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Microsoft-Remote-App-300x287.png" alt="Microsoft RemoteApp" width="300" height="287" />
<h2>What Applications Can I Publish in RemoteApp?</h2>
RemoteApp has two different models – a “Quick Create” option and a “Create with VPN” option. Using “Quick Create,” a number of templates are available from Microsoft including one that includes Office 2013 pre-installed. Using these templates allows an organization to deploy RemoteApp within minutes and start publishing Office right away. RemoteApp does not include Office licensing so you will need to provide your own, however if you are running a version of <a title="Microsoft Office 365 Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365</a> that includes Office ProPlus you can use that license for RemoteApp.

For more advanced deployments, the “Create with VPN” option allows for RemoteApp to be connected back to your on-premises environment. The server used for this deployment can also be customized to include any of your custom applications such as Adobe products, Quickbooks or any other third party business applications. These applications can use the VPN tunnel to connect back to your on-premises domain, file servers and application servers so that you can continue to have the full RDS experience while in Azure.
<h2>How Is RemoteApp Licensed?</h2>
RemoteApp is licensed on a per user basis and users can receive two types of license – Basic or Standard. Basic licenses are for lighter weight applications such as Adobe Acrobat Reader, remote desktop services and text based third party applications. Standard licenses are designed for applications that may require more resources such as Office, Quickbooks and Adobe design products. RemoteApp also allows three different environments to be created so that some users can have basic licenses, some can have standard licenses and the published applications and type of RemoteApp deployment (Quick Create or Create with VPN) can be customized to fit each user’s needs. Keep in mind, with RemoteApp recently becoming generally available, some of the pricing and details are still in transition and this information might change.

If you are looking for a way to publish applications to your users or setup an easy way to keep your applications centralized and updated, let SWC work with you to investigate whether RemoteApp is a good fit for your organization. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Email SWC</a> for more information or call 630.572.0240.

<strong>Want to learn more? </strong><strong>Join us for our Chicagoland Luncheons</strong>

<a title="Microsoft Cloud Chicago Events" href="http://www.swc.com/html/email/cloud/2015-office365-cloud1-14-15.html" target="_blank"><strong>Empowering Users with Microsoft Office 365 and the Cloud</strong></a>

Today's market leaders are subscribing to cloud based solutions to run their business. Office 365 provides powerful and mobile business-class applications for organizations of any size – at a fraction of the cost. Join SWC to learn more about Azure, Office 365 and the new Enterprise Mobility Suite (EMS). Register now at <a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">SWC Events</a>.<h3>Recommended Past Posts</h3>
If you would like to learn more about Azure and the cloud, please read a few of our related blog posts:

	<item>
		<title>HAPPY HOLIDAYS FROM SWC</title>
		<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/work-life/happy-holidays-2014</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 12 Dec 2014 20:24:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bobknott]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15048</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As 2014 comes to a close, we want to thank everyone who has made it so special and wish you nothing but the best in 2015. Please enjoy this year’s video production. Happy holidays from all of us at SWC Technology Partners!

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/aymb4fVx32A?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox;width=720;height=480;"><img class="aligncenter" src="/uploads/holiday-video.png" alt="SWC Holiday 2014" width="500" height="281" /></a>

This holiday season, whether you’re singing carols or writing letters to Santa…
<p style="text-align: left;">Dear Santa, I really want that migration to <a title="Microsoft Exchange" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Exchange 2013</a>… PLEASE include <a title="Microsoft Lync" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365/lync-online" target="_blank">Lync</a>, I love <a title="Unified Communications Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications" target="_blank">Unified Communications</a>!</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Don’t forget to make a list, check it twice and then back it up in the <a title="Cloud Backup" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud</a>.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">And if that list is too long, consider making a pivot table using <a title="Microsoft SQL 2012" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012" target="_blank">SQL</a>.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Just make sure that your data is <a title="Cloud Security Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">secure</a>, we wouldn’t want a Grinch to steal it.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">No matter how you celebrate, take lots of photos and then share them with all your contacts in <a title="Customer Relationship Management" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm" target="_blank">CRM </a>or post them on <a title="Microsoft Sharepoint" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint" target="_blank">SharePoint</a>. Just make sure they’re HR appropriate.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">This year, we wish you enjoyable times with family and friends.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">May your chestnuts roast on an open fire and not your <a title="Managed Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/managed-services" target="_blank">servers</a>.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow… but not enough to shut down your call center.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">And if you find your tinsel in tangle… you know who to call. <a title="SWC Contact" href="http://www.swc.com/contact" target="_blank">Call SWC</a>!</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">From all of us here at SWC Technology Partners – Happy Holidays!</p>

<h3>Past Holiday Videos from SWC:</h3>
If you enjoyed this year’s holiday video, please watch a few of our past holiday productions:

<a title="SWC 2013 Video" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/2013-happy-holidays-from-swc-technology-partners">That’s So Rudolph</a>
<a title="SWC 2012 Holiday Video" href="http://www.swc.com/perspective/videos/swc-technology-partners-holiday-video-2012">Scrooge &amp; Marley</a>
<a title="Chicago Alain Locke Outreach SWC" href="http://www.swc.com/perspective/videos/alain-locke-swc-community-outreach">Technology Succeeds with Community</a>

	<item>
			<title>How Can Office 365 Help My Organization?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/what-is-microsoft-365</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 05 Jan 2015 14:15:13 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeremyalt]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15083</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Many of our customers often ask us how we empower users and enable IT. One way is through <a title="Office 365 Cloud" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365</a>. Watch my Ask SWC video blog to learn more about how Office 365 will benefit your organization.
	
	<a title="What is Microsoft 365" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/w_K_oM0RP1c?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Microsoft SharePoint Enablement" width="500" height="281" /></a>
	
	Office 365 is Microsoft’s SaaS or subscription-based productivity software that offers <a title="Cloud Technology " href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud versions</a> of all of your favorite Microsoft Office suite products. The solution empowers users by giving them a single portal to access all of these resources and enables IT by giving them a single pain of glass to manage all of their applications.
	
	<strong>Office 365 includes your favorite Microsoft solutions:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li><a title="Microsoft Exchange" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-exchange-2013" target="_blank">Exchange Online</a> for email and calendaring</li>
		<li><a title="Microsoft Lync" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013" target="_blank">Lync Online</a> helping workers better communicate through audio and video conferencing, IM, presence and voice</li>
		<li><a title="Microsoft Sharepoint" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint" target="_blank">SharePoint Online</a> for collaboration, search, portal and content management</li>
		<li><a title="CRM Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm" target="_blank">Dynamics CRM</a> to better track sales leads, improve marketing effectiveness and service customers</li>
		<li><a title="Business Intelligence " href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence" target="_blank">Power BI</a> for data analysis, <a title="Visualization " href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/virtualization" target="_blank">visualization </a>capabilities and reporting</li>
	</ul>
	<strong>There are many challenges that organizations face in the modern workplace that Office 365 can help solve for both users and IT departments. Office 365:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>Provides access to the applications users need in order to be productive in the office or on the go in a familiar Microsoft Office experience</li>
		<li>Helps cut hardware and operations costs for IT in a secure and an always available environment</li>
		<li>Allows users to Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) to the workplace without IT having to worry about managing a bunch of devices or data</li>
		<li>Reduces the burden on IT through automatic updates in the cloud</li>
		<li>Reduces licensing costs as organizations only pay for what their users use</li>
	</ul>
	SWC can help your organization get to the cloud faster. <strong><a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact us</a> today for a Microsoft-sponsored cloud assessment</strong> focused on requirements gathering, initial design considerations, additional services scope and putting together a cloud roadmap. Let’s talk Office 365. Call 630.572.0240 to learn more about how Office 365 will enable your organization to be more productive than ever.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	Did you know SWC has <strong>free</strong> educational events to help get you up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, <a title="Security IT Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">security</a>, IT strategy and even <a title="Digital Marketing " href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing" target="_blank">digital marketing</a>? Feel free to attend one or all of our complimentary <a title="Chicago IT Education Events" href="www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT and Digital Marketing Events</a>. </strong></strong><h3>Related Blog Posts</h3>
	If you would like to learn more about Microsoft Office 365 and the cloud, please read a few of our related posts:
	
	<a title="Microsoft Office 365" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/why-swc-it-departments-like-office-365" target="_blank">Why SWC And IT Departments Like Office 365</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Exchange" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/migrating-exchange-online-protection-office-365" target="_blank">Migrating From Standalone Exchange Online Protection (EOP) to Office 365</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Lync" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-online-transport-reliability-ip-probe-tripp" target="_blank">Microsoft Lync Online – Transport Reliability IP Probe (TRIPP)</a>
	<a title="SQL Server 2014" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/whats-new-in-sql-server-2014" target="_blank">Ask SWC: What’s New in SQL Server 2014?</a>
	<a title="SWC New Technology Services" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/ask-swc-what-new-technology-find-interesting" target="_blank">Ask SWC: What Is A New Technology That You Find Interesting?</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Azure " href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-azure-reduce-helpdesk-calls-increase-security?doing_wp_cron=1418743305.1970279216766357421875" target="_blank">How Microsoft Azure Can Reduce Help Desk Calls and Increase Security</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Azure System Center" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/move-hyper-v-virtual-machine-into-microsoft-azure-using-system-center" target="_blank">How to Move a Hyper-V Virtual Machine into Microsoft Azure Using System Center</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Azure Autoscaling" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/performance-schedule-autoscaling-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Performance and Schedule Autoscaling in Microsoft Azure</a>

		<item>
			<title>Deployments and Rollbacks in Azure</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/deployments-azure-microsoft-cloud</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 12 Jan 2015 14:57:49 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[benbrock]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15113</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[There was a time when deploying software was a time consuming, manual and stressful process. We would spend hours and sometimes days configuring release scripts with associated stops and starts for manual intervention to ensure the highest level of quality all the while ensuring that we always had a backup plan for rolling it back out if something went wrong. Even if everything did go well, a tester could derail the entire operation and trigger hours of work for a team responsible for executing a rollback procedure in the middle of the night... there's a reason Release Managers are hard to find! But those days are gone. Read my blog to learn more about how Microsoft Azure has revolutionized the way we think about deployments.
	
	Azure is Microsoft’s <a title="Microsoft Cloud Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud platform</a> for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS) that has revolutionized the way we think about deployments. Sure, we have made progress over the years and improved our scripts, environments and procedures to reduce manual intervention and enforce quality. But software deployment planning and execution has been optimized significantly with Microsoft Azure’s new service offerings.<strong>Let’s Consider a Real-World Scenario</strong>
	
	<em>Multiple developer teams check code into a repository throughout the day. The application is built, tested, and deployed to an integration server automatically with no manual intervention.</em>
	
	When the release is ready to be shipped, the code is deployed to a new QA environment, where software is installed and configured dynamically using the PowerShell Desired State Configuration extension. As the code is promoted through the environments, the process is considerably more hands-off (i.e. by using Agentless deployments) than it once was, but still gives release managers and testers the opportunity to validate the software in the QA and UAT environments and gate when it's ready.
	
	Prior to going to Production, code is deployed to a staging deployment "slot" using secure connections via SSL. The staging environment is warmed up and connected to live data sources where it's subjected to one last round of testing. When the team gives the “okay” to go live, the staging slot is "swapped" for the production slot and is instantly live. The previous production slot is saved as the "last known good site" and can be restored just as easily as it was replaced.
	
	In the process of going live, traffic redirection was seamless, no connections were dropped and there was no need to communicate unavailability to the applications consumers.
	
	<em>Admittedly, there was some work to make all of this magic happen, but the time saved and the ease of mind Azure brings through virtually eliminating problems introduced by manual errors or missed steps is well worth the investment.</em>
	
	Azure truly provides the opportunity to make software deployments a non-event so that you can focus on what really matters – the end user experience. If you want to hear more about Microsoft Azure's release management capabilities, or are interested in a one day free on-site assessment detailing what it would take to move to Azure and confirm the return on investment, please <a href="mailto:Ben.Brock@swc.com">contact Ben Brock</a>.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	Did you know SWC has<strong> free educational events</strong> to help get you up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, <a title="Security Services IT" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">security</a>, IT strategy and even <a title="Digital Marketing " href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing" target="_blank">digital marketing</a>? Feel free to attend one or all of our complimentary Chicagoland events. Visit <a title="Chicago IT Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT Events</a> learn more.<h3>Recommended Cloud Blog Posts</h3>

		<item>
			<title>What Can We Expect from Microsoft in 2015?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-2015</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 16 Jan 2015 15:07:48 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15133</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Lots of rebranding has been taking place with Microsoft products recently. Windows Azure is now Microsoft Azure, Windows Intune is now Microsoft Intune, System Center Advisor is now Azure Operational Insights and Microsoft Lync is now <a title="Skype for Business" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365/lync-online" target="_blank">Skype for Business</a>. Finally, Windows 9 is being skipped entirely and we’re going straight to <a title="Microsoft Windows" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-windows" target="_blank">Windows 10</a> (now in preview). With all these name changes, it’s hard to keep track of what’s what anymore. Read my blog to learn more about what we can expect from Microsoft in 2015.The names may be changing, but the story still remains largely the same. Each of the products I mentioned above still do what they were written to do, many have just become <a title="Microsoft Cloud" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud-based versions</a> of the equivalent on-premises software. The benefit is that new features are being added to make your daily IT tasks easier and more efficient. <a title="Microsoft System Center 2012 R2" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/microsoft-system-center-2012-r2" target="_blank">Microsoft System Center 2012 R2</a> is a powerful datacenter automation and orchestration platform for managing your private cloud while integrating with your public cloud services. With the nature of the cloud these days, you might be wondering if you even need to deploy System Center on-premises anymore or how the new versions of Windows Server will affect your organization. For now, a hybrid approach consisting of both private and public cloud utilization is still a good IT strategy. There is no one-size-fits-all, and each paradigm has its own set of strengths and limitations.
	
	Microsoft’s Enterprise Mobility Suite (EMS) is a compelling offering for Microsoft Azure, Intune and Rights Management that offers businesses a comprehensive set of tools for managing identity, information and infrastructure. Combined with <a title="Microsoft Office 365" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365 for Business</a>, EMS gives you a complete cloud-centric IT approach for a large part of your service needs for both employees and customers.
	
	But what about those who still need local devices to interact with these cloud services, i.e. smartphones, tablets, laptops and desktops. In order to deploy standardized operating system images on these devices, an on-premises tool such as System Center Configuration Manager is critical to executing these roll outs on your subnets. Similarly, while you can use Microsoft Lync in Office 365 for IM and presence, if you’re looking to replace your aging PBX and telephone systems, you’ll still need onsite <a title="Microsoft Unified Communications" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications" target="_blank">Unified Communication</a> servers to connect to your SIP trunk provider for audio and video conferencing.
	
	In summary, both the private cloud and the public cloud are needed. One cannot exist without the other. As such, your organization needs to have a comprehensive strategy that incorporates both elements in an effective and unified manner. SWC can help your business understand the rapid pace of Dynamic IT, so that you are better able navigate and adapt to the changing landscape and succeed in transitioning your network into the next level of IT.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	Did you know SWC has free educational events to help get you up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, security, IT strategy and even digital marketing? Feel free to attend one or all of our complimentary <a title="Chicago IT Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.

		<item>
			<title>Dynamics Marketing – Everything You Ever Wanted in a Marketing Automation Platform?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/dynamic-crm-2015</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 07 Jan 2015 14:58:21 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[wallyseliga]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15139</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a title="Microsoft Dynamics 2013" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management/crm-2013" target="_blank">Microsoft Dynamics</a> Marketing platform offers a breadth of new capabilities for today’s savvy marketer at an extremely attractive price. There is so much this platform can do for $125/user/month that you may get the feeling that it’s too good to be true. But once you do your homework, you will quickly realize that Dynamics Marketing has many of the same robust features you see in all of the top tier marketing platforms. Read my blog to learn more about all of the cool new features that come standard in Microsoft Dynamics Marketing, making it everything you ever wanted in a marketing automation platform.
	
	There are many blog and technical articles out there that do a deep dive into how to setup and execute marketing campaigns and many of the other capabilities in the Dynamics Marketing platform. In this blog I wanted to clarify some of the functionality and dispel any ambiguity about what this feature set provides.The <strong>Visual Campaign Designer</strong> allows you to design the flow of your marketing campaign with logic breaks, A/B testing and scheduling using activities and responses. It also allows you to see the results of your efforts by indicating the flow of the number of recipients affected through each message, offer or landing page.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15140 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM2015.png" alt="Visual Campaign Designer" width="500" height="307" />
	
	A few of the core activities and responses within Marketing Dynamics Marketing are:
	
	<strong>Landing Pages</strong> – These pages are easily created and hosted by Microsoft for you. Generally, these include a lead form which allows a prospect to enter demographic information for lead follow up and event registration. You can choose to embed these landing pages via an “iframe” onto your corporate webpage, then use messaging to drive traffic to the landing pages and measure how often users are clicking through to them.
	
	<strong>Scoring</strong> – Scoring activities conditionally affect a contact’s lead score based on their interactions throughout a campaign.
	
	<strong>Offers</strong> – Offers create promotion codes as a call to action for your customers. You can use offers to track how many times each code has been redeemed and you can also place limits on the number of redemptions available.
	
	<strong>A/B Testing</strong> – A/B testing allows users to provide two versions of the same message for distribution to a percentage subset of their target list to determine which version performs better. Then the system will automatically send the winning design or whichever messaging did the best to the remainder of the list.
	
	<strong>Triggers</strong> – Triggers allows you to conditionally react according to the delivery, open, click or bounce of an email message.
	
	Each of the tools can be dragged onto the Dynamics Marketing platform designer so that you can set the properties for that action. When creating an email, you can utilize the ‘drag and drop’ email designer to create an HTML email from scratch, or based off of a predefined template. The email designer takes a bit of getting used to and can feel a little bit clunky, but there is automatic validation that helps guide you through the process to make sure that you are including all of the elements necessary to keep you in compliance with bulk communication regulations – such as including a subject for the message, the required sender information and unsubscribe options.
	
	<strong>Campaign Execution Results</strong> are shown in near real time as recipients receive and open or unsubscribe. The open, click and unsubscribe statistics are displayed right within the visual campaign designer so you can see how the results flow through each campaign that you have created.
	
	The entire platform <strong>integrates easily</strong> with <a title="Microsoft Dynamic CRM" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm" target="_blank">CRM online or CRM on-premises</a> through an Azure hosted service bus. The integration provides a bi-directional sync of contact, activity and campaign information, which can be configured and mapped at a granular level.
	
	In the future, I will be creating more detailed blogs with information about how this platform leverages and integrates with CRM. In the meantime, feel free to <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">reach out to SWC</a> or attend our January 22nd <a title="CRM Chicago Launch Event" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland CRM 2015 launch event</a> to learn more.
	
	<strong>Complimentary "What’s New in Microsoft Dynamics CRM" 2015 Event</strong>
	Microsoft Dynamics CRM has helped organizations drive sales, marketing and customer service for years. The release of Dynamics CRM 2015 offers exciting new capabilities for mobile, campaign management and social insights on-premises or in <a title="Cloud Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">the cloud</a> with <a title="Office 365 Cloud" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365</a>. At this event, <a title="Jeff Hoffmann SWC" href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/leadership/jeff-hoffmann" target="_blank">Jeff Hoffmann</a>, Vice President of Business Applications and CRM expert Wally Seliga will get you up to speed with the new Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015. <a title="Register Chicago CRM 2015 Event" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Register Now</a>.<h3>Recommended Past CRM Blog Posts</h3>

			<title>Preparing for Server 2003 End of Life by Migrating to Microsoft Azure</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/server-2003-end-of-life</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 14 Jan 2015 14:00:24 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15146</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Do you still have a number of Server 2003 systems that need to be upgraded in your environment? Are you lacking the adequate computing or storage resources to make this a reality? Microsoft Azure may be a quick and easy way to get your systems up to date without having to purchase additional hardware. Read my blog on preparing for Server 2003 end of life by migrating to Microsoft Azure to learn more.
	
	<strong>In July of 2015, Server 2003 will no longer be supported by Microsoft.</strong> Many organizations still have systems running on the Server 2003 operating system and will need plan an upgrade path, however upgrading from Server 2003 to a newer operating systems can be difficult because most Server 2003 systems are running a 32-bit architecture. Server 2008 R2 and later require a 64-bit architecture. Therefore an upgrade may require a full reinstallation and most organizations do not have the resources (or the licensing) to perform this upgrade.<strong> Microsoft Azure may be an easy and quick way to get your systems up to date.</strong>
	Microsoft Azure is Microsoft’s <a title="Cloud Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud platform</a> for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS). The platform provides an alternative environment for new servers and offers a number of operating system options including Server 2012 R2.<strong> One of the many benefits of moving to a cloud environment like Azure, is that you no longer have to worry about installing and patching the operating system, Azure takes care of this for you and each of the virtual machines can be customized with an appropriate amount of compute and storage resources, so that you only pay for what you use on a monthly basis without the need to purchase expensive on-premises hardware.</strong> All operating system licensing is also included, eliminating the need for a license upgrade or new license purchase. And if you need to upgrade some of your applications such as SQL, that licensing can also be included in your monthly Azure cost.
	
	Another one of Azure’s benefits is it’s a high speed Internet connection to allow for easy communication to and from your servers. For a secure link to your on-premises environment, it is possible to setup an IPsec point-to-point tunnel between any business class firewall and Azure. <strong>For remote users, Azure also provides a VPN application for easy access from anywhere.</strong> Using these tools Azure can easily act as your remote datacenter allowing you to quickly and easily setup new servers and run your old 2003 systems side by side with your new 2012 servers.
	
	What if down the road you need to bring some of these systems back onsite? Azure makes it easy! You can simply migrate the virtual hard disk out of Azure and restart the virtual machine in your onsite Hyper-V cluster. Similarly, as your hardware ages it is very easy to migrate virtual machines from your on-premises Hyper-V into Azure to reduce your hardware footprint.
	
	Our goal at SWC is to be your partner, helping you find the right <a title="Cloud Services " href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud solutions</a> to match your business need and grow your organization. <strong>We work with a number of cloud vendors to ensure that we can find the right fit.</strong> SWC’s team has extensive technical backgrounds and know many of the requirements necessary to consider when moving applications and systems to the cloud, including when moving to the cloud is not recommended. We apply that cloud expertise to your environment.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	Did you know SWC has <strong>free educational events</strong> to help get you up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, security, IT strategy and even digital marketing? Feel free to attend one or all of our complimentary <a title="Chicago IT Seminars" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.<h3>Related Cloud Blog Posts</h3>

			<title>SWC Best Practices: Keeping Up with Today’s IT Environment</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/managed-it-services-midmarket</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 09 Jan 2015 14:59:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[susiecummings]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15151</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[There is a huge amount of work that needs to get done day in and day out in today’s midmarket IT environment, as well as the strategic planning activities that need to occur. <strong>We have found that many <a title="SWC Managed Services" href="http://www.swc.com/swc-managed-services/" target="_blank">internal IT teams are overwhelmed</a> and complaining that they need <a title="Managed Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/managed-services" target="_blank">additional IT resources</a> to help them keep up.</strong> Watch my best practices video to learn more about why partnering with an IT managed services provider is a best practice for many midmarket organizations.
	
	<a title="Managed IT Services Best Practices" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/Frv02sC66qo?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/susie-cummings-managed-it-services-video-player.png" alt="Microsoft SharePoint Enablement" width="500" height="281" /></a>
	
	When we say internal IT teams are having a hard time keeping up, it’s not to say that they can’t handle user requests or that they don’t know what technology to implement next. <strong>Keeping up also involves establishing a rigor and discipline around the everyday activities that need to be completed in order to advert business risk in an organization’s IT environment,</strong> such as making sure the backups are running successfully or the antivirus is up-to-date. The reason I mention these two things is because many organizations have no visibility into backups and antivirus and so they end up with a lot of surprises.
	
	We see it happen every day, all of a sudden a customer comes to us because their server crashes and they thought they had invested in a really great backup service that would get it back up and running in no time. What they quickly realize is that their service hadn't been backing up the data the way they though it had over the last couple weeks and now it's a huge problem. <strong>Most organizations have zero visibility into their backup plan, as well as many other IT surprises that are common in the midmarket,</strong> such as users whose desktops or workstations aren’t checking into the organization’s antivirus updates. All of a sudden they are panicking because a virus has started to propagate into the organization and the vulnerability is that they didn’t even know it was happening.
	
	What SWC Managed Services does is layer on top of an organization’s internal IT. We provide the rigor and discipline to check the things that fall under the daily IT production support related activities, so that you know they are getting done by a team of people whose job it is to do them. This way your internal team can focus on more strategic projects to help achieve your business’ goals.
	
	<strong>There are many benefits to partnering with SWC for IT managed services, including:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>Leveraging a highly responsive team of IT subject matter experts</li>
		<li>Comprehensive coverage of your IT environment– on a 24x7x365 basis</li>
		<li>IT roadmap and strategy support for your business goals</li>
		<li>Cost-effective, flexible support options to fit your IT needs</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>Is Technology Moving Too Fast for Your Business?</h2>
	To learn more please join us for our next <a title="Managed IT Services Event in Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Managed IT Services Chicago Event</a> or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> for a complimentary managed services assessment by calling 630.572.0240.<h3>Recommended IT Best Practices Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this best practices post from Susie, please check out a few of our past posts on related topics:
	
	<a title="Security Managed Services Best Practices" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/swc-best-practices-security-managed-services" target="_blank">SWC Best Practices: Security Managed Services</a>
	<a title="SWC Managed Services – A More Strategic Approach to IT" href="/blog/managed-services/swc-strategic-approach-managed-it-services">SWC Managed Services – A More Strategic Approach to IT</a>

		<item>
			<title>User Experience: The Makings of a Sustainable SEO Strategy</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/user-experience-making-sustainable-seo-strategy</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 20 Jan 2015 15:04:36 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mary]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15448</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Since the dawn of search technology, there has been a lot of speculation around how to achieve the coveted <a title="Search Engine Optimization Services" href="/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization">first-page position on Google</a>. Understandably enough, Google has always been tight lipped about their algorithm by only revealing vague details around significant updates or occasionally confirming or shutting down popular rumors, such as whether social media plays a role in ranking – which Google recently sorta’ kinda’ debunked (more on this later). But even when Google gives us small glimpses behind the curtain, a sustainable SEO strategy does not depend on the unveiling of Google’s secret algorithm. I’m afraid Google will never let this happen. Read my blog to learn more about the makings of a sustainable SEO strategy.
	
	By now we know that a sustainable SEO strategy has nothing to do with “cracking the code” or “gaming the system.” As many can attest, past attempts to outsmart the search engines by using keyword stuffing or link farming ended with disastrous results after Google’s Panda update in February 2011 and Penguin update in April 2012.
	
	Of course, it is important to stay abreast on the changes we observe in the search engine results pages (SERPs) and draw conclusions based on the way search technology is evolving. For instance, when it comes to the theory of social media, Google has said both, “yes” they do use social signals and then more recently, “no” they do not use Facebook or Twitter in their ranking algorithm. But what about other social signals like Google+? Both Google and Bing have invested a lot of time and resources into adding social search functionality over the past year. Why would they do this if social signals weren’t important? Given these trends, it’s safe to say that social signals will have an impact on ranking in the near future, if they don’t already.
	
	With Google’s continuous updates and contradictions about what is and is not a ranking factor, it can be difficult to keep up. As SEOs, it’s our job to ensure we are providing our clients with the best combination of “signals” we have available at the time. Sometimes these signals are obvious – such as ensuring your site architecture is “crawlable,” while others are based on the strong implications and lots and lots of testing, such as social signals. Whichever strategy works best today, it will certainly change again and in the future. Heck, it’s probably changed since you started reading this blog! However, there is one rule in which Google has never wavered. As Google’s head of Webspam repeatedly asserts:
	<blockquote><em>"Instead of chasing after the search engines, chase after the user experience because the search engines are chasing after the user experience"</em></blockquote>
	<strong>– Matt Cutts</strong>
	There you have it. A good SEO strategy puts the user first at all times. After all, both search engines and marketers ultimately want same thing – a satisfied customer. As search engines continue to make significant changes to please users, shouldn’t your website be doing the same thing?
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-seo-stats-infographic-012015.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-15447" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-seo-stats-infographic-sm-012015.png" alt="SWC SEO Stats Infographic SM" width="500" height="764" /></a>
	Much like the vague details we get about Google’s algorithm, the term user experience is also extremely vague. Below I’ve laid out the two primary components of a website with good user experience.
	<h2>Quality Content</h2>
	Quality content may be the oldest trick in the book, but it remains the most important on-page ranking factor moving into 2015. In 2011, Google admitted to using real people to evaluate thousands of websites based on the site’s content. This type of human feedback has since been incorporated into the algorithms to provide better results. As search engines continue to build upon an endless collection of data, they become more sophisticated in understanding the kinds of websites people like. Bounce-rate and time-on-page are two metrics we can use to help us understand customer satisfaction. Keep in mind, a high bounce rate and low time on page in some cases means the user came to the site, immediately found what they needed and left – so it’s important to not rely on these two metrics alone.
	<h2>Professional Design</h2>
	In addition to quality content, people will form opinions about your brand based on its appearance – the search engines know this and have become extremely accurate at predicting and serving the kinds of websites that appeal to user’s preferences. A <a title="Website Design Services" href="/solutions/digital-marketing/digital-creative-design">professionally designed website</a> should not only have aesthetic appeal, it should also load extremely fast and take very little time and effort to navigate to the information the user is seeking. This is especially critical in 2015 – the year when mobile users are expected to surpass desktop users. Google has been dropping hints for a while that they understand the mobile user experience, and just recently started rolling out “mobile-friendly” tags in the search engine results page (SERPs) to indicate which pages will provide a good user experience versus a bad one. If your site is not built to adapt to mobile devices with larger font size, modified navigation and bigger buttons for touchscreens, expect to see a big drop in traffic moving into the New Year.
	
	Putting the customer first often means incorporating the latest technology and modern trends, as well as constantly monitoring and modifying based on the results. In doing this, you can better understand your customer and secure more return visits, site engagement, shared links and bookmarking – all of which are signals that get picked up by search engines. Interactive marketing is all about user choice and companies that respect the user will be successful.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	For more information on digital design and usability best practices, contact SWC or join us for our next complimentary Chicagoland <a title="Website Design SEO Event" href="/events">Website Design and SEO event</a>.<h3>Recommended Search Engine Optimization Posts</h3>
	<a title="How Search Engine Technology Is Changing the Way We Think About SEO" href="/blog/seo/search-engine-technology-changing-seo">How Search Engine Technology Is Changing the Way We Think About SEO</a>
	
	<h2>SWC’s Website and SEO Services</h2>
	SWC’s digital design practice includes website development and search engine optimization (SEO) services.
	<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/ip9j7NL3S7U?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox;width=720;height=480;"><img src="/uploads/chicago-digital-marketing-seo-video.png" alt="Chicago Website Design and SEO" width="500" height="281" /></a>
	</content:encoded>
