			<title>Social Listening in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/microsoft-crm-social-listening</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 23 Jan 2015 20:32:06 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[wallyseliga]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15511</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft Social Listening in <a title="Microsoft Cynamics CRM" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management" target="_blank">Dynamics CRM 2015</a> provides sales, marketing and customer service teams with powerful social tools to help them connect with customers and prospects and determine social insights and sentiment. Read my blog to learn more about some of the exciting new features in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 Social Listening tool.
	<h2>Getting Started</h2>
	Social media is a very simple concept by nature, so it only seems natural that Microsoft’s new Social Listening services are simple to setup and use.
	<ul>
	<ul>
		<li>Start by signing up via the <a title="Microsoft Office 365" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Microsoft O365</a> portal and administering which users have licenses for Social Listening</li>
		<li>Setup which search topics you want to monitor for social media buzz</li>
		<li>Sit back and wait for the data to accumulate as the platform “listens” for posts to be made that match the “include” and “exclude” terms that you setup in your search topic</li>
	</ul>
	</ul>
	<h2>Analytics Dashboard</h2>
	The power of the platform comes with the pre-built drillable analytics dashboards which allow you to analyze and identify trends. The analytics dashboards can be viewed directly from your CRM system dashboards, user dashboards and entity forms so that sellers and marketers can make decisions based off of metrics such as trends over geography and sentiment.
	
	One of the worries I initially had about the platform was that it would only search across social profiles that were previously setup in my CRM database. That is not the case. Buzz about your search topics are accumulated across all publically accessible profiles and you are only limited by your monthly quota of search results that are retrieved and stored for analysis. By default, this is 10k posts and you can increase that quota if needed.
	
	Unfortunately, the analytics dashboards and “listening” only starts once you have setup your search terms. You might have to wait a couple days or weeks to see any definition of trending. It will take diligence and some thoughtful planning to make sure that you are capturing enough relevant post information to be able to make decisions. You will also want to monitor and adjust your search terms frequently to make sure that relevant information is being returned and that you are poised to understand new trends over time.
	
	All of the items on the dashboard sample below are drillable down to the post level where you can see exactly what people are motivated to write about.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15512 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-social.png" alt="Microsoft CRM" width="500" height="259" />
	<h2>Microsoft Dynamics CRM Social Care Framework</h2>
	Additional power comes with the Social Care Framework, which is a set of code libraries and a sample project that allows a developer to create a social solution that meets the needs of the business. This generic framework allows you to route social information into your CRM system in an actionable way.
	
	For example, would you like to create an activity for a sales rep to follow up on whenever someone tweets in regards to a specific term or hashtag? The specific implementation and routing of the actionable data can be customized to fit your organization’s needs. Subscribe to SWC’s blog, as I will follow up in my next post on what can be accomplished with this framework and how it is used.
	
	If you would like to learn more about social listening or Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> or call 630.572.0240.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15514 size-large" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/OG-Tag-CRM-Social-1024x538.png" alt="CRM and Social Listening" width="1024" height="538" />
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	For more information on Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 and social listening join us for our next complimentary Chicagoland <a title="CRM Chicago Event" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">CRM event</a>.<h2>RECOMMENDED CRM BLOG POSTS</h2>

	<a title="Customer Relationship Management Dynamics" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/dynamic-crm-2015" target="_blank">Dynamics Marketing – Everything You Ever Wanted in a Marketing Automation Platform</a>

		<item>
			<title>Ask SWC: Malware Protection &#124; How to Prevent Another Sony Hack</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/security/sony-hack-malware-protection</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 30 Jan 2015 18:00:46 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[tommymontgomery]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15538</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[By now you have probably heard about the cyber-attack against Sony Pictures. This was the most devastating cyber-attack that we have seen against a corporation thus far. While we still don’t know a lot of the technical details about how the attack happened. We do know how the attack began. Read my “Ask SWC” blog to learn more about advanced malware protection, the Sony cyber-attack and how to <a title="Security IT Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">keep your organization’s data safe</a>.
	
	<a title="New Features of Tableau 8.2" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/XWN-ea92qKU?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="New Features of Tableau 8.2" width="474" height="262" /></a>
	
	<h2>The Sony Cyber-Attack</h2>
	The cyber-attack against Sony started with a simple phishing email that contained an attachment. This attachment was a malicious piece of malware that was not detected by traditional antivirus software. Sony at the time did not have an advanced malware protection system that would prevent these types of attacks. We continue to see the same method of attack used against companies. While advanced malware detection is not the only solution that is needed, it is one that companies continue to overlook.
	<h2>Advanced Threat Detection Technology</h2>
	SWC Technology Partners has a security solution offering through our <a title="Security Managed Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services/security-managed-services" target="_blank">managed services</a> practice that helps protect organizations against similar cyber-attacks. We assist our clients by building a solid security foundation that includes market leading security tools for malware detection, firewalls and Network Access Control. These tools are all behavioral based and help prevent exploits such as Crypto-Locker and botnets that traditional signature based antivirus software programs are no longer effective at detecting. One of our favorite tools is FireEye, a threat protection platform that can identify behavioral based malicious activity and stop advanced malware and zero-day attacks.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	For more information on advanced malware protection and security best practices, Contact SWC or join us for our next complimentary <a title="SWC Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland security event</a>. At this event, our security expert Tommy Montgomery, CISSP, ISSMP, CISM, GCFW and Certified Ethical Hacker will teach you more about the products, tools and tactics necessary to keep your organization secure and stay ahead of the bad guys.<h3>Recommended Security Blog Posts</h3>
	Want to learn more about cyber security? Check out some of our past posts on related topics.
	<a title="What Industries Are Facing the Most Security Issues?" href="/blog/security/swc-best-practices-what-industries-are-facing-the-most-security-issues" target="_blank">What Industries Are Facing the Most Security Issues?</a>
	<a title="What Are Some Mobile Security Risks" href="/blog/security/swc-best-practices-what-are-some-mobile-security-risks" target="_blank">What Are Some Mobile Security Risks?</a>
	<a title="How Can You Protect Your Organization From An IT Security Breach" href="/blog/security/fireeye-protect-your-organization-from-an-it-security-breach" target="_blank">How Can You Protect Your Organization From An IT Security Breach?</a>
	<a title="Security Awareness: Tips for Protecting Your Online Identity from Hackers" href="/blog/managed-services/security-awareness-protecting-online-identity-from-hackers" target="_blank">Security Awareness: Tips for Protecting Your Online Identity from Hackers</a>
	<a title="Heartbleed Is Much Worse Than We Thought" href="/blog/technology/heartbleed-is-much-worse-than-we-thought" target="_blank">Heartbleed Is Much Worse Than We Thought</a>
	<a title="Website Security Scenarios" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/it-security-worst-case-scenario" target="_blank">From a Security Perspective, What is the Worst Case Scenario?</a>
	<a title="SWC Featured on Telemundo" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/swc-featured-on-telemundo-news-broadcast" target="_blank">SWC Discusses Target Security Breach On Telemundo News Broadcast</a>
	<a title="Cyber Security and Protection" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/network-security/fundamentals-of-cyber-security" target="_blank">The Fundamentals of Cyber Security</a>
	<h2>SWC Security Assessment</h2>
	Is advanced malware infiltrating your organization? <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> for an information security assessment.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-14009 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-it-security-assessment-service.jpg" alt="SWC IT Security Assessment Service" width="500" height="375" />  </content:encoded>

			<title>Client Success: Preferred Meals Website Redesign &amp; Mobile Application</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/uncategorized/website-redesign-mobile-application</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 09 Feb 2015 21:45:32 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15658</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC worked with Preferred Meals to rebrand and build a custom website that is easy to navigate and provides a more user friendly experience. Watch our client success video case study to learn more about how SWC helped Preferred Meals find success though our <a title="Website Design Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/digital-creative-design" target="_blank">custom website design </a>and application development services.
	
	<a title="Preferred Meals Website Redesign" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/VEsL0weV-8Y?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/SWC-Video-Case-Study-Template-Preferred-Meals.jpg" alt="Website-Redesign" width="500" height="281" /></a>
	
	Preferred Meals is a school food service provider. They are a nationwide company servicing schools from coast to coast across the U.S. providing healthy, nutritious and safe meals to districts both large and small.
	<h2>The Project</h2>
	One of the most recent projects Preferred Meals engaged SWC Technology Partners to complete was a revamp of the Preferred Meals website – <a title="Preferred Meals Website" href="http://www.preferredmeals.com/" target="_blank">preferredmeals.com</a>. This project included changing the name of the company, rebranding the organization and building a website that was not only a “view only” website, but would also engaged the parents.
	
	Preferred Meals new website provides a tool for parents, as they previously didn’t have a strong connection with the parents of students who were eating their meals. The organization now provides a place where parents can go to find all of the information they need about their child’s meals. Parents can now search their state, district and school and are brought to a webpage that is customized with the school’s logo and has their child’s daily menu, weekly menu and monthly menu, as well as all of the nutritional information they need to make healthy decisions about their meals.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15675 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/PMS-screenshot1.png" alt="PMS-screenshot" width="500" height="317" />
	<blockquote>I really enjoyed working with SWC on our website. Their experience, expertise and approach allowed me to feel comfortable and confident in what we were doing as a team. I love the site’s design and I am so happy with the copy, images… everything.</blockquote>
	<p style="text-align: right;"><strong>– Clare Keating, Vice President of Marketing</strong></p>
	<p style="text-align: left;">Another important element of the website redesign SWC had to take into account was mobile technology, so that users could look at the website on their iPhones, iPads and any type of mobile device. It was a really exciting project because the SWC team had to adjust and adapt the design from the website to a mobile device to be able to surface customers in both environments as more and more people are using mobile technology and not necessarily going directly to the website to get that information.</p>
	
	<h2>Success</h2>
	SWC received a Best in Class Award from the <a title="Web Design Award" href="/swc-technology-partners/news/swc-wins-best-in-class-design-accolade-from-interactive-media-awards">Interactive Media Awards</a> for the Preferred Meals website redesign. The Interactive Media Awards honor organizations for their outstanding achievements in website design and development.
	<blockquote>SWC Technology Partners – the big word for me in the name of the company is partner. They’re talented people, they’re engaged and they’re passionate about what they do. It’s not a customer-supplier relationship. We’re in it together and we win together.</blockquote>
	<p style="text-align: right;"><strong>– Vito Trifiletti, Senior Vice President of Information Services</strong></p>
	If you want to learn more about SWC's website design and development services, please join us for our next complimentary Chicagoland <a title="Web Design SEO Event" href="/events">Web Design, SEO &amp; Digital Marketing Strategy Event</a> or <a title="Contact SWC" href="mailto:info@swc.com" target="_blank">contact us</a>.<h2>CLIENT SUCCESS</h2>
	If you enjoyed this SWC client success video, please check out a few of our past videos:
	<a title="Sharepoint Design Example" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/making-sharepoint-look-good" target="_blank">Microsoft SharePoint Helps Empower and Enable Users at M. Holland</a>

		<item>
			<title>Creating an Azure Environment On-Premises with Windows Azure Pack</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 12 Feb 2015 15:46:13 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15729</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Do you have a number of users who are frequently requesting virtual machines? Are you constantly getting requests for similar demo or lab environments? Do you have a number of end users who need to manage virtual machines in your cluster? These are common problems that organizations experience. While many may think giving end users access to the <a title="System Center Virtual Machine Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/virtual-machine-manager-app-controller">Virtual Machine Manager</a> or <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V" href="/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v">Hyper-V</a> cluster is the answer, it’s not always a practical or secure solution. To solve this problem, Microsoft now offers Windows Azure Pack. Read my blog to learn more about how Windows Azure Pack can help you create your own Azure environment within your on-premises environment.
	
	Windows Azure Pack is a free add-on application that integrates with Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager to create an Azure environment in your on-premises environment. Using Windows Azure Pack, you can allow your end users to login to a web interface and spin up or remove resources including virtual machines, databases and websites. Just like Azure, all of these resources can be limited so that each user can only use a fraction of your total environment and each user is then responsible for managing their own usage. Windows Azure Pack also includes usage statistics and if needed, you can also define pricing structures so that administrators can charge back usage costs to individual departments and teams within the organization.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15730 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Azure-pic1.png" alt="Azure-pic1" width="500" height="341" />
	
	The Windows Azure Pack interface looks similar to the current Azure web interface, giving a consistent experience across all sites. If you prefer, the Windows Azure Pack can also be branded using your organization’s logos and graphics to give the end user a more consistent experience with your internal resources. From within the interface users can also manage and request changes to their plan, making it easy for self-service.
	
	On the backend, the Windows Azure Pack integrates with your existing Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager (VMM) environment for easy setup. Different clouds can be assigned to different Windows Azure Pack users to ensure continued separation of resources into their appropriate backend clusters. Virtual machine templates available in VMM can also be used in Windows Azure Pack to allow for a library of available images. Windows Azure Pack also includes a feature for Virtual Machine Roles which allows end users to select fully customized servers with pre-installed applications.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15731 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Azure-pic2.png" alt="Azure-pic2" width="500" height="96" />
	
	If you are in need of a user friendly self-service interface for your on-premises virtual environment, contact SWC Technology Partners to discuss installing Windows Azure Pack. Or for more information on Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager or Windows Azure, visit one of our complimentary <a title="Midwest Technology Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland technology events</a>. Our goal at SWC is to be your trusted partner, helping your organization find the right Microsoft System Center and <a title="Cloud Solutions Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud solutions</a> that match your business needs and help your organization grow.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	Did you know SWC has free educational events to help get you up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, <a title="Security SOlutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">security</a>, IT strategy and even <a title="Digital Marketing Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing" target="_blank">digital marketing</a>? Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.

			<title>The Ever Changing Landscape of Identity Management</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/identity-manager-2015</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 26 Feb 2015 17:32:31 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15793</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Managing your corporate identities is crucial in the hybrid IT world of cloud-connected devices combined with traditional on-premises environments. For a long time, Microsoft has had a versatile stack of software tools to facilitate identity controls, but the products have recently gone through many rebrands or renames, making it hard to keep track of them all. This holds true for the upcoming vNext version of the product, <a title="MMS Preview" href="http://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-rebrands-identity-manager-again-and-delivers-new-public-preview/" target="_blank">Microsoft Identity Manager 2015</a> (MIM). Read my blog to learn more about Microsoft Identity Manager 2015 and the ever changing landscape of identity management.
	
	First a little bit of history: Back in the year 2000, Microsoft Metadirectory Server (MMS) was released, which then became Microsoft Identity Integration Server (MIIS) in 2003. These initial versions of the product built out the <strong>Synchronization Service</strong>, which to this day remains a core component of modern day <a title="Cloud Deployment Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud deployments</a> by way of the <a title="Synchronize Directory O365" href="http://blogs.office.com/2014/04/15/synchronizing-your-directory-with-office-365-is-easy/" target="_blank">Office 365 DirSync</a> tool. It is also the “magic under the hood” behind the <a title="Synchronization Services O365" href="http://blogs.technet.com/b/meamcs/archive/2013/02/18/sharepoint-2010-2013-user-profile-synchronization.aspx" target="_blank">User Profile Synchronization Service</a> in <a title="Microsoft Sharepoint" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint" target="_blank">SharePoint </a>Server. For customizability to interface with in-house Line-of-Business (LoB) applications, extensibility modules could be written using C# and VBS code, compiled into Dynamic Link Libraries (DLLs).
	
	By 2007, this small but powerful tool morphed again into Microsoft Identity Lifecycle Manager Server (ILM) before becoming more well-known as Forefront Identity Manager (FIM) in 2010. These versions added a graphical web portal known as the <strong>FIM Service</strong>, which extended the capabilities of the product by allowing policy-based decision trees and workflow processes to manipulate <a title="FIM Overview" href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff621362(v=ws.10).aspx" target="_blank">metaverse</a> properties. Support continued to be added for connectivity to additional external systems, so identities could be linked across databases, ERP, SAP, Human Resources and so on. Extensibility was further refined by incorporating <a title="Windows Powershell" href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn640417(v=ws.10).aspx" target="_blank">PowerShell Connectors</a>, which made the product that much more robust.
	
	And now, with yet one more rebrand under its belt, we arrive at the latest incarnation Microsoft Identity Manager 2015 (MIM)! The new version of the product makes big strides in aligning on-premises identities in a cloud-based IT world. Some of these advancements have already been released as part of <a title="Microsoft Azure Directory" href="http://windowsitpro.com/azure/microsoft-azure-active-directory-sync-tool-gets-silent-release" target="_blank">Azure Active Directory Sync Services</a>, which simplifies onboarding to the cloud and supports advanced features like multiple-forest password synchronization with non-AD directories. And this is just the tip of the iceberg! When the full version of MIM is released, even the most intricate topologies will have a way to unify their private and public clouds in an automated and consistent manner.
	
	SWC has strong experience and expertise helping businesses deploy and manage complex identity management solutions. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact one of our engagement managers</a> to find out how we can help you deploy your solution!
	
	<strong>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</strong>
	
	Did you know SWC has free educational events to help get you up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, security, IT strategy and even digital marketing? Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.<h3>Related Blog Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Kurt, please check out a few of his past technical blog posts:
	
	<a title="Microsoft 2015" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-2015" target="_blank">What Can We Expect from Microsoft in 2015?</a>
	<a title="Windows 10" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/downloadable-windows-10" target="_blank">Skipping Ahead to Windows 10</a>
	<a title="Microsoft System Center" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/endpoint-protection-2012-r2" target="_blank">Microsoft System Center Endpoint Protection 2012 R2</a>
	<a title="help desk service" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/using-service-manager-complete-help-desk-solution" target="_blank">Using Service Manager As A Complete Help Desk Solution</a>
	<a title="IT Delivery" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/making-optimized-it-delivery-reality" target="_blank">Making Optimized IT Delivery A Reality In Your Organization</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Virtual Machine Manager" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/why-we-love-microsoft-system-center-virtual-machine-manager" target="_blank">Why We Love Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager (And You Should, Too!)</a>
	<a title="IT Operation Efficiency" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/improve-operational-efficiency-with-system-center-orchestrator-2012-r2" target="_blank">The Sky is the Limit: Improve Operational Efficiency with System Center Orchestrator 2012 R2</a>
	<a title="Operations Manager 2012 R2" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/why-upgrade-operations-manager-2012-r2" target="_blank">Why You Need to Upgrade to Operations Manager 2012 R2</a>

			<title>SWC’s Approach to Technology Consulting in Chicago</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/chicago-it-technology-company-video</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 19 Feb 2015 20:23:28 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[bobknott]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15812</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[For more than 35 years, SWC Technology Partners has excelled at delivering technology solutions that optimize productivity, strengthen customer relationships, enhance data sharing and drive profitability. Learn more about SWC by watching our new corporate video.
	<h3>SWC Company Video</h3>
	<a title="IT Consulting Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/xXxxfVUCQ_8?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-awards.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>
	
	SWC’s mission is helping midmarket customers succeed. We do that with technology and we do that with a lot of passion.
	We spent a lot of time trying to come up with three words that describe what we do at SWC and at the end of the day, it’s very simple – its <strong>business, technology, success</strong>. Our focus is working with our clients, understanding their business, developing technology solutions that help them achieve those goals and then we’re collectively focused on success. And that not only means success for our customers but success for our employees as well as they spend day in and day out at work and try to evolve their <a title="IT Careers at SWC" href="http://www.swc.com/careers" target="_blank">careers</a>.
	
	<h2>Chicago Area IT Consulting 630-572-0240.</h2>
	
	What makes our approach unique is our wide array of services that allows customers to come to us to put together a comprehensive strategy and have one partner who can put all of the pieces together. Our customers like the fact that they can count on a single provider to not only handle their <a title="Application Development" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/custom-application-development" target="_blank">software needs</a>, their <a title="infrastructure cloud computing" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">infrastructure </a>needs, their <a title="Digital Marketing Agency" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing" target="_blank">digital marketing</a> needs, but also their support needs. When we are able to tie all of that together and do it over 1, 3, 5, 10 years and continue to satisfy our customers, that’s when it feels great, that’s when our relationships are deep and that’s when the value of SWC really comes across.
	
	But it’s not about providing the services, it’s also having the mindset of how you can help the customer succeed. What are the innovative breakthroughs using technology that will create opportunities for the business or overcome the challenges that they face. One of the things that we really enjoy is solving problems for customers and it’s not really about a project, it’s about that partnership, it’s about solving customer problems or helping that organization grow in a certain way.
	
	And at the end of the day it’s about being a <a title="SWC Awards" href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/awards" target="_blank">premiere IT partner</a> to our customers and helping their businesses succeed.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	SWC hosts free Chicagoland educational events to help get organizations up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, <a title="Security IT Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">security</a>, IT strategy and digital marketing. Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Networking" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.

	<a title="IT Careers Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/PtJXuLTIOq4?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-careers1.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>

		<item>
			<title>SharePoint On-Premises vs. SharePoint Online (Office 365 Cloud)</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/cloud-based-sharepoint</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 23 Feb 2015 18:46:35 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15873</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Some time ago, I wrote a SWC blog called <a title="Microsoft Sharepoint Cloud" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-sharepoint-premises-or-cloud" target="_blank">Microsoft SharePoint: On-Premises or in the Cloud</a>. It attempted to describe the basics of <strong>“what is the cloud”</strong> and <strong>“what the implications of hosting SharePoint in the cloud are.”</strong> Since then, the world has continued to evolve and Microsoft has continued to improve its <a title="Cloud Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud service</a> offerings to include <a title="O365" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365</a> (O365) and <a title="Azure" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-azure-reduce-helpdesk-calls-increase-security" target="_blank">Azure</a>. Read my blog to learn more about the benefits of hosting Microsoft SharePoint on-premises vs. online with Office 365.
	<h2>The Benefits of Office 365</h2>
	We are now seeing many organizations are moving to Office 365, often starting with a migration to <a title="Microsoft Exchange" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365/exchange-online" target="_blank">Exchange Online</a>, usually accompanied by an implementation of Active Directory Federation Services in Azure. This offers a great value proposition for many different sizes and types of organizations:
	<ul>
		<li>Top-of-the-line email services</li>
		<li>Much less management</li>
		<li>High availability</li>
		<li>Disaster recovery</li>
		<li>Overall lower total-cost-of-ownership</li>
		<li>Familiar end-user experience of Microsoft Outlook</li>
	</ul>
	As a result, we see a lot of organizations investing in Enterprise-level licensing for Office 365 (perhaps along with Azure). That means they also have full access to <a title="Microsoft Sharepoint" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint" target="_blank">SharePoint Online</a>, which is SharePoint 2013 hosted in Microsoft's Office 365 cloud infrastructure.
	<em><strong>Naturally, those organizations want to take advantage of the services they are paying for, but it isn't clear how best to do that without major effort and/or risk.</strong> </em>Most of these organizations already have some sort of internal (or on-premises) implementation of SharePoint, often an earlier version of the product rather than the current 2013 version. <strong><em>How can they leverage SharePoint Online without throwing away the investment they've made in the existing environment and, more importantly, without losing the content and information it contains?</em></strong> Well, there are only a couple answers. Since you can't do an “upgrade” (more technically, a “database attach upgrade”) when moving to the SharePoint Online (O365) environment, that leaves “migration” and “hybridization.”
	<h2>Option 1: Migration</h2>
	Migration refers to the notion of moving or copying (migrating) content from the existing on-premises SharePoint server(s) into your SharePoint Online environment. This can be done manually with out-of-the-box tools that SharePoint provides, including the “Explorer View” feature… but it can be a time-consuming and effort-intensive endeavor. Alternatively, content migration can be automated, either via scripting or any number of commercially available “migration tool” products. Tools can help do the job faster, potentially while preserving or even remapping the logical structure of the environment, but an additional investment in the right tool is needed.
	<h2>Option 2: Hybridization</h2>
	Hybridization is scientific term, which in the context of SharePoint and is intended to mean “implementing a hybrid on-premises AND in-the-cloud environment.” In simple terms, we're referring to the idea of using Microsoft SharePoint Online alongside of, or in addition to, the existing in-house SharePoint deployment. There are multiple ways to organize a hybrid environment and different “workloads” (or usage scenarios) that can be distributed across the on-premises and in-the-cloud environments. In some cases, you might leave the existing intranet, team collaboration, and document management sites in place on the old on-premises server while using SharePoint Online for any new use cases (sites, processes, communities, etc.) that arise. You might decide to move as much of the existing site structure and content to SharePoint Online as possible, while continuing to leverage the in-house server for integration scenarios that may not be available in SharePoint Online due to some limitations in the current Office 365 hosting model. You could choose to migrate your site collections from on-premises to in-the-cloud over a period of days, weeks, or even months, eventually decommissioning the on-premises servers once all the relevant content has been moved. You will then have completed a full migration to “in-the-cloud,” but you'll be in a hybrid state throughout the process.
	
	Whether you already own SharePoint Online (stand-alone or as part of an Office 365 bundle) or are considering investing in Microsoft's software-as-a-service offering of SharePoint 2013, there are a number of significant things to consider and decisions to make. Hopefully, this article has helped explain some of the options and their implications, at least at a higher level. Of course, SWC's experienced SharePoint architects and engineers are available to help you understand the details and make the best business and financial choices for your own organizations. As always, please feel free to reach out to SWC for any assistance you might need.
	<h3>SWC’s Approach to SharePoint Solutions</h3>
	Watch our video to learn more about SWC’s approach to deploying meaningful SharePoint solutions that increase user adoption and drive success.
	
	<a title="IT Consulting Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/A361WVZL--U?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sharepoint-jeff-lanham.jpg" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	SWC hosts free Chicagoland educational events to help get organizations up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, security, IT strategy and digital marketing. Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Networking" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.

		<item>
			<title>Need a SQL Server DBA? Ever Considered Utilizing a Virtual DBA?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/sql-server-virtual-dba</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 02 Mar 2015 23:06:26 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Shirley Noa]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=15963</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Many midmarket companies have SQL Servers to support, but not enough work or budget to justify the expense of a full-time SQL DBA. SWC offers an alternative to complement your internal IT team’s need for SQL expertise. Read my blog to learn more about the benefits of a SWC’s virtual database administrator solution.
	
	SWC’s <a title="Virtual Database Administrator" href="/solutions/managed-services/virtual-dba">Virtual Database Administrator</a> (vDBA) Team has helped many Chicagoland organizations improve performance, ensure availability, implement best practices and complete project-based work for their SQL Servers. Since SWC employs a team of dedicated technical experts, we can complement your IT team and provide leadership with the strategic planning necessary to create a technical roadmap for future growth, consolidation and upgrades. Our vDBA service is a fraction of the cost of a full-time DBA.
	
	<strong>Virtual? What’s that?</strong>
	We’re glad you asked! While “virtual” tends to be computer-focused, our vDBA team is very real. However, they administer servers via remote access to your company’s <a title="Microsoft SQL Server 2012" href="/solutions/business-intelligence/microsoft-sql-server-2012">SQL Servers</a> from our corporate office located in Oak Brook, IL. This allows for 24X7 coverage of your core production systems and data.
	
	<strong>But what if my company has an IT fire and I need the DBA on-site?</strong>
	Should the situation arise in which physical attendance is needed, the service includes availability of one of our local team members to travel to your company within the Chicagoland area and surrounding suburbs.
	
	<strong>How do I know if I need a VDBA or if there is a problem with my SQL environment?</strong>
	SWC offers Microsoft SQL Server Assessments to ensure your SQL environment is optimally performing. The assessments follow best practice recommendations and help resolve SQL Server performance issues, improve reliability, cut costs and consolidate applications.
	
	The first step is completing our free online <a title="Preliminary Assessment " href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/managed-services/virtual-dba/database-assessment" target="_blank">Preliminary Database Assessment</a>. Following completion of the preliminary assessment, we schedule a meeting to review the results as well as a few recommendations to better optimize and support your environment.
	<h2>What does SWC’s vDBA service include?</h2>
	SWC’s fixed monthly vDBA offering includes:
	<ul>
		<li>24X7 monitoring of application health, hardware and resources</li>
		<li>Triage, analysis and remediation of hardware, OS and SQL alerts</li>
		<li>Daily maintenance plan output validation</li>
		<li>Weekly data and log review focused on performance improvement</li>
		<li>Monthly SQL health report and recommendations (growth, query, optimization, etc.)</li>
		<li>As needed server update installation, database code review and maintain service log documentation</li>
	</ul>
	Manage your IT budget by lowering expenses and investing in a vDBA to complete your team.
	
	<h3>SWC’s Microsoft SQL Server &amp; VDBA Solutions</h3>
	Watch our video below to learn more about SWC’s approach to SQL Server and Virtual Database Administrator Services.
	
	<a title="Virtual Database Administrator SWC Technology Partners VDBA Services" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/zluF1f06mpM?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/featured-video_rachel-narel.jpg" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a><h3>Recommended Past Posts:</h3>
	If you are interested in learning more about virtual database administrator services, please read a few of our past posts:
	
	<a title="VDBA Services" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/virtual-dba/swc-virtual-database-administration-vdba-solution" target="_blank">SWC’s Virtual Database Administration (VDBA) Solution</a>
	<a title="SQL database managed services" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/virtual-dba/day-in-the-life-of-vdba" target="_blank">A Day in the Life of A VDBA</a>
	<a title="SQL Server 2008 R2" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sql-server/microsoft-ends-support-sql-server-2008-r2" target="_blank">PSA: Microsoft Ends Mainstream Support for SQL Server 2008 R2</a>
	<a title="Virtual Database Administrator Service" href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/news/swc-offers-virtual-database-administrator-vdba-solution" target="_blank">SWC Offers Unique Virtual Database Administrator (VDBA) Solution</a>
	<a title="Managed IT Services Oak Brook" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/swc-strategic-approach-managed-it-services" target="_blank">SWC Managed Services – A More Strategic Approach to IT</a>
	<a title="SQL DBA" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sql-server/digital-cholesterol-sql-system-performance" target="_blank">How is digital cholesterol impacting your SQL system performance?</a>
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	SWC hosts free Chicagoland educational events to help get organizations up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, <a title="Security IT Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">security</a>, IT strategy and digital marketing. Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Networking" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.
	<h3>SWC Chicago IT Events</h3>
	<a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/-sTYLZEMuYQ?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-events.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>

		<item>
			<title>Creating Great Solutions Efficiently Using Open Source Frameworks Augmented by Some Homegrown Glue and Standardization</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/application-development/custom-application-solutions-efficiently</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 06 Mar 2015 21:59:01 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Bob Compere]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16040</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC has always been a framework company. When I started at SWC in 1988, we had a powerful <a title="Custom Business Application" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/custom-application-development" target="_blank">application development</a> tool called “Fast Programming” that enabled developers to build large complex business applications very efficiently. “Fast Programming” allowed developers to deliver full featured business application rapidly without reinventing any wheels project to project.<h2>Chicago Area Custom Application Development 630-572-0240</h2>In 1999, SWC embarked on an effort to develop tools and methodologies to build systems using Java as efficiently as we had done in the years of “Fast Programming.” The product of this effort was our Java Catalyst framework which we have now used for 15 years to deliver applications. Catalyst provides many of the same advantages that we enjoyed with “Fast Programming” including the ability to build complicated things efficiently, pre-built infrastructure elements and a standard way to build applications.
	
	When we built Java Catalyst there were not a lot of great open source choices for full featured frameworks.
	<ul>
		<li>Apache Software Foundation was founded in 1999</li>
		<li>The first version of Struts came out in May 2000</li>
		<li>The first version of Spring came out in October 2002</li>
	</ul>
	Everything was just getting started and we needed a solution that included a lot of out-of-the-box oomph! So we built Catalyst ourselves. The framework took advantage of some open source libraries but in large measure it is an in-house framework. Later, we built a similar .NET framework called Catalyst.net which likewise enabled us to efficiently build applications based on .Net.
	
	Fast forward to the 201x’s and the open source world is very different. There are now several very full featured open source options for frameworks and just about anything else you would want to build. There are great online resources, such as maven repositories, stack overflow, github and many others. None of this existed 10-15 years ago. There is a large body of quality solutions to almost any problem. These solutions have been built and debugged by a large community of really smart people.
	<h2>So how should an organization like SWC adapt our approach?</h2>
	For the last three years we have been building Java applications using the Spring Framework and .Net Applications with MVC and entity framework. Overall this has been a very positive thing.
	
	<strong>One thing you run into when you develop using open source is that there are choices… a lot of choices!</strong> Every problem has multiple solutions, each with pros and cons, each with a learning curve, each with potential incompatibilities with other choices you have made. On top of the choices, there are gaps. Capabilities that SWC had solutions for in our own frameworks that either do not exist or are implemented in a way that requires more time and effort than we are used to. SWC, as a software development team that creates many distinct unrelated custom solutions, cannot afford to figure out this labyrinth of options and challenges every time we start a new project.
	
	There is a solution to these challenges. We can build something that allows each new project to benefit from what was learned and built on in previous projects. In the past we just built all of the upgrades into our internal frameworks. With open source, it is similar but there are differences. We can build IP, but now we must work inside the context of the framework that we do not control. Using these frameworks, we have built base libraries to reduce/eliminate code that is redundant from project to project. These libraries will evolve similarly to how our frameworks to in-house did, improving from project to project. We also are standardizing on a set of open source libraries to be used. This reduces effort spent on project startup and configuration. This will not be a static set of libraries. We will tend to stick to tried and true component choices until there is a need to try new options. Libraries that prove to provide advantages will be added to our standard offering. Project standardization and rapid project setup is being accomplished by template and archetype projects. This means that when a new SWC project is started it will automatically be configured with the standard SWC IP pieces and the open source libraries we have standardized.
	
	This approach of selecting the best open source options, adding IP of our own to fill gaps, providing base solutions needed by all projects, and creating standard project templates and archetypes is enabling SWC to create systems using open source technologies with the efficiencies we enjoyed with our in-house frameworks. <strong>Building better systems for our clients at a reduced cost.</strong>
	<h2>Let’s Build Some Cool Stuff Together</h2>
	Watch our video below to learn more about SWC’s custom application development capabilities.
	
	<a title="Custom Application" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/hsLhW7R4Md4?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/it-solutions-provider-swc-cool-stuff.png" alt="IT Solutions Provider SWC Cool Stuff" width="620" height="380" /></a><h3>RELATED PAST POSTS</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Bob, please check out a few of our past related posts:
	<a title="SWC Business Application Development" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/custom-application-development-what-sets-swc-apart" target="_blank">Ask SWC: When It Comes To Custom Application Development What Sets SWC Apart From The Competition?</a>
	<a title="SWC Business Application Services" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/application-development/integrity-payment-systems-custom-application-development" target="_blank">SWC Video Featuring Custom Application Development Services</a>
	<a title="SWC Custom Application Example" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/salesforce-com-crm-appexchange-launched-new-company" target="_blank">Compete: How Developing a Solution for the Salesforce.com AppExchange Launched a New Company</a>
	
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Don&#039;t Take the Bait - Tips for Protecting Yourself Against Phishers</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/security/email-phishing</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 11 Mar 2015 14:09:13 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[tommymontgomery]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16107</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the past few years, attackers have gotten lazy. Instead of constantly trying to find new vulnerabilities by fuzzing away at applications, they have decided that it’s much easier to use social engineering to attack your weakest link, your users. Users in general are happy to help out when an email comes in asking them to click a link, open an attachment, or even send over financial details for wiring money. With more and more being piled onto employees’ plates today, they rarely question what is being asked of them which leads to a serious weakness in <a title="IT Security Services" href="/solutions/security-services/security-managed-services">IT security</a>. Attackers know this and have decided to exploit this weakness. Read my blog to learn more.
	
	Enter the Email Phishermen, aka attackers who send malicious emails. There are two types of email phishing: general mass mail phishing where a large non-customized net is cast into the vast ocean of users with hopes of tricking a user to click a link, open an attachment or perform an action. Then there is a much more dangerous form of phishing called Spear Phishing. Spear phishing involves collecting and using detailed information about a victim using open source intelligence (OSINT) in order to further the chances that the victim carries out the requested action in the email. This intelligence information comes from benign places such as LinkedIn, Facebook, Twitter and even your company’s own website. Anything that you post online can be used in the attack. Once enough information is collected, the attackers craft an email with this customized information and send it to his or her victim. The emails typically contain a malicious link, attachment or request to turn over information or wire money. The body of these emails is written with information that the victim relates to and is thus tricked into trusting that the email is legitimate.
	
	<em><strong>Here is an example of a spear phishing email:</strong></em>
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-16108 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/phish-email.jpg" alt="phish-email" width="500" height="300" />
	
	You’ll see in the email above that everything seems legitimate until we look closer at the details. The first thing that stands out is the signature block, the salutation “Kindly” is almost never used in the United States, but is commonly used by foreign attackers. We also see that the full name is used in the opener and in the message body there is an urgency for you to open the pictures. All things that are not normally included in casual conversation emails in the U.S. Finally, we notice the file that is attached that lists its extension as .JPG which is correct for an image file but upon further inspection, you will see that Windows is actually telling us this is a Screen Saver file. This is an indication that the malicious file is being masqueraded as a JPG file. Together these are all signs pointing to a malicious phishing email.
	<blockquote>Identifying phishing emails has become even more difficult as attackers improve their techniques. These same types of phishing attacks led to the recent compromise of companies such as Target, Home Depot, Anthem Blue Cross, Sony and many others.</blockquote>
	
	SWC offers a full <a title="SWC Security Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">Security Awareness Training Program</a> that teaches your users how to spot malicious phishing emails and files. Our courses will walk your users through common techniques used, how to spot these attacks, what to do if you receive a phishing email as well as general end user security best practices. SWC also offers a phishing service where we take on the role of an attacker and send phishing emails to your users. This service allows you to determine if a weakness exists with your users and to what extent the weakness exists. This service provides a real world experience that tests your user’s security in a non-malicious way before the attackers do.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-16121 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/security-awareness-training.jpg" alt="security-awareness-training" width="500" height="441" />
	
	SWC has had several clients who’ve been victims of phishing attacks and fake tech support calls resulting in Cryptolocked systems, infected systems and even intellectual property theft. After completing our Security Awareness Training Program, these companies were able to dramatically reduce their risk of falling victim to these types of scams and meet compliance requirements.
	
	For more information about our Security Awareness Training and Phishing Service, please <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">email SWC</a> or call 630.572.0240.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	For more information on advanced malware protection and security best practices, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> or join us for our next complimentary <a title="Security Chicago Event" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland Security Event</a>. At this event, our IT security expert <strong>Tommy Montgomery, CISSP, ISSMP, CISM, GCFW and Certified Ethical Hacker </strong>will teach you more about the products, tools and tactics necessary to keep your organization secure and stay ahead of the bad guys.
	<h3>SWC Chicago IT Events</h3>
	<a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/-sTYLZEMuYQ?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-events.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a><h3>Recommended Security Blog Posts</h3>
	Want to learn more about cyber security? Check out some of our past posts.
	
	<a title="Cyber-attach Prevention" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/sony-hack-malware-protection" target="_blank">Malware Protection | How to Prevent Another Sony Hack</a>

		<item>
			<title>Twitter Strikes Deal to Show Tweets in Google Search Results</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/twitter-google-deal</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 12 Mar 2015 14:16:52 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mary]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16123</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Google and Twitter have joined forces in the latest “firehose” deal which gives Google full access to Twitter’s feed, allowing Google to index tweets in real time. If you recall, a similar deal was hatched but then later revoked in 2011, when Twitter took away Google’s access to their feed. Despite limited access, Google has continued to use traditional methods of crawling Twitter content for the past several years – a less than favorable approach due to the sheer volume of tweets published each day (around 500 million), making it impossible for any search engine to capture and index relevant tweets in real time. Now, with access to Twitter’s API, also known as “firehose,” Google can once again index tweets as they happen without crippling the social channel with too many requests.
			
	The two companies have yet to provide much more information for what to expect, other than a launch date sometime during the first half of 2015. But that doesn’t mean a frenzy of speculation and excitement hasn’t already erupted around the topic of social media and its future impact on the search engine results page (SERP) and <a title="Search Engine Optimization Services" href="/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization">search engine optimization</a> (SEO). Read my blog to learn more about what to expect from searchable tweets in the near future.
	<h2>What Does Google and Twitter Get Out of the Deal?</h2>
	Before we jump into how this impacts your business, it’s important to first understand why the world’s largest search engine and the one of the largest sources of breaking news have decided to come together. Last year, Twitter created indexable landing pages for their top 50,000 hashtagged pages that Google and other search engines could crawl and index. So it doesn’t come as a huge surprise that Twitter is continuing to grow its relationship with the search engines by providing Google even more indexable content. The more tweets that appear in the search results, the greater opportunity Twitter has to grow their audience and hopefully steal attention away from the other channels. Google, in turn, gets real-time relevance from more than 500,000 tweets per day without having to wait for a breaking story to gain relevance across the Web first. Now, Google can index tweets as they’re happening and gain an edge over other search engines who can’t keep up with as much timely content. Not to mention, it is very possible that data associated with a tweet might help Google better tailor content and messages to their users.
	<h2>What Does My Business Get Out of the Deal?</h2>
	While it’s obvious that this recent partnership is mutually beneficial to Google and Twitter, what’s in it for us? If a tweet that goes out this morning could appear in Google’s search results that same day, we now have yet another opportunity to increase our brand’s presence in Google’s SERP by increasing our Twitter activity. It also means that, perhaps, one of the fastest ways to get timely promotions and content indexed by Google is to share them on Twitter in conjunction with updating your website.
	
	The impact that this new partnership will have on the overall ranking of your brand is still TBD, however it punctuates the importance of social media to your search marketing efforts as a whole and further asserts the role social plays in the modern landscape of SEO. The general consensus among SEOs is that there is no denying a correlation between social media and better rankings (note: correlation is not the same as causation). A good social media strategy relies heavily on a good content strategy, which should rely heavily on SEO. In other words, good content tends to be shared, and good content also tends to rank well.
	<h2>Start Doing This Right Now…</h2>
	Once Google and Twitter’s new “firehose” deal takes effect, don’t expect every tweet you push into the Twittersphere to go directly to the top of Google’s search engine results page – this would create disastrous results for the search engines and the people who use them. Instead, Google will have to create a method for determining which tweets deserve a place in the SERPs. Since Google values the same things people do, it makes sense that a tweet with higher engagement (retweets and favorites) will be more likely to show up than a tweet that receives little to no attention from fans. Therefore, investing more time in improving your Twitter engagement and amplification is an obvious first step in leveraging Google’s new Twitter deal.
	
	<strong>How to Increase Engagement on Twitter</strong>
	<ul>
		<li><strong>Quality content:</strong> Share content that people will want to retweet and favorite</li>
		<li>I<strong>mages:</strong> Studies show high impact images get better engagement</li>
		<li><strong>Hashtags:</strong> Increase visibility with hashtags</li>
		<li><strong>Length:</strong> Longer tweets tend to have higher engagement. You have 140 characters – use them!</li>
		<li><strong>Links:</strong> Include links when it’s appropriate. Always link to authoritative sites that provide value to your fans.</li>
		<li><strong>Frequency:</strong> The more active you are on Twitter, the more likely you are to make connections and gain new followers</li>
		<li><strong>Analysis:</strong> The more you Tweet and track your engagement, the better you’ll understand what type of content resonates with your unique audience</li>
	</ul>
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-16125 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/blog-image-500px.png" alt="blog-image-500px" width="500" height="259" />
	As the indexing of tweets takes effect in the coming months, we may discover other ways to optimize Twitter for Google SERPs. Until then, preparing for the shift by investing more time in Twitter engagement is a wise move. If you’d like to learn more about <a title="Social Media SEO" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/social-media" target="_blank">social media marketing</a> and how to leverage this platform for <a title="Search Engine Optimization" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">SEO</a>, please <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">connect with our Digital Marketing team</a> or attend our next <a title="Technology Events Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland Digital Marketing event</a>.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this digital marketing post, please check out a few of our related past posts:
	<a title="User Experience SEO" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/user-experience-making-sustainable-seo-strategy" target="_blank">User Experience: The Makings of a Sustainable SEO Strategy</a>
	<a title="Technology and mobile SEO" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/search-engine-technology-changing-seo" target="_blank">How Search Engine Technology Is Changing the Way We Think About SEO</a>
	<a title="What is SEO" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">Search Engine Optimization</a>
	<a title="Website design" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/uncategorized/website-redesign-mobile-application" target="_blank">Client Success: Preferred Meals Website Redesign &amp; Mobile Application</a>
	<a title="website design" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-design-2/digital-design-seo" target="_blank">Digital Design and SEO</a>
	<h2>SEO Stats You Need to Know</h2>
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15447 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-seo-stats-infographic-sm-012015.png" alt="SWC SEO Stats Infographic SM" width="500" height="764" />

			<title>Skype for Business is Coming!</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/skype-for-business-release</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 19 Mar 2015 13:40:33 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16163</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft announced last November that the next version of Lync will be branded <a title="Microsoft Lync new name" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications/skype-business" target="_blank">Skype for Business</a>. This came as a surprise to many, but isn’t altogether surprising that Microsoft would want to align the two juggernauts. Alone, Skype’s statistics are impressive:
	<ul>
		<li>Over 300 million active and connected users per month</li>
		<li>2 billion minutes of calls made in one day</li>
		<li>140 million active Skype users on iOS and Android</li>
		<li>More than 300 billion minutes of video a year</li>
		<li>And Skype calls account for 38% of global international calling minutes</li>
	</ul>
	With Microsoft Lync taking the lead in new <a title="Microsoft UC" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications" target="_blank">Unified Communications</a> deployments and Gartner’s positioning of Microsoft as the leader in their 2014 <a title="Microsoft Gartner" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-leads-gartner-magic-quadrant-unified-communications" target="_blank">Magic Quadrant</a>, it’s clear that companies are realizing the value and reaping the benefits.
	
	Until recently, we didn’t have a firm release date for Skype for Business other than the first half of 2015. It has now been announced that we can expect both the on-premises and online releases in May (according to Microsoft insiders, but could be as soon as April)! Stay tuned as we will discuss new features, upgrade strategies and introduce you to the client over the coming months and please reach out to SWC or come to one of our upcoming <a title="Internet Technology Luncheons" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a> if you have specific questions about Skype for Business or would like to know more!
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-16164" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Skype4Biz-203x300.png" alt="Skype4Biz" width="300" height="444" />
	
	<em>More Skype for Business details and date announcement information can be found at <a title="Skype for Business" href="http://blogs.office.com/2015/03/16/get-ready-for-skype-for-business/" target="_blank">Microsoft’s site</a>.</em>
	<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>

	<a title="Microsoft Lync Managed Services" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-helps-tandem-hr-weather-storm" target="_blank">Microsoft Lync Helps Tandem HR Weather the Storm</a>

		<item>
			<title>A/E/C Marketing Tactics Shift With Ever-Changing Internet Landscape</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/aec-marketing-tactics-shift-ever-changing-internet-landscape</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 24 Mar 2015 14:06:30 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Kristen Schmid]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16170</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Buildings, parks, green space, neighborhoods, cities, water supply, energy works—these all comprise our <em>built environment</em>, or the “human-made space in which people live, work and recreate on a day-to-day basis.”
	
	As the built environment sprawls forward to fit a rapidly growing population, technology has become more and more essential in order to break down silos and direct architecture, engineering and construction (A/E/C) businesses towards more efficient and interoperable design, construction and infrastructure models.
	
	A/E/C businesses have long relied on reputation, trade shows and repeat business to grow, but advances in technology and interoperability have necessitated a change from these traditional models and marketing strategies. Now, your website is your portfolio, online reviews are your reputation and talent recruiting tools and content like videos and blog posts are your trade shows.
	
	In fact, 78% of US Internet users research products and services online —a number that likely will increase in the coming years. What’s more, <strong>B2B buyers have completed nearly 60% of the purchase decision online</strong> before even engaging the supplier sales representative.
	<h2>The New Outlook for A/E/C Marketing</h2>
	Just how important is <a title="SWC Digital Marketing Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing" target="_blank">digital marketing</a> to the A/E/C industry? In a 2015 Construction Marketing Outlook survey:
	<ul>
		<li>83% of respondents said they plan to increase their <a title="SWC SEO Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">Search Engine Optimization (SEO)</a>, website development and social media tactics</li>
		<li>71% plan to increase content marketing</li>
		<li>56% plan to increase mobile marketing</li>
		<li>And 31% plan to increase paid search (PPC)</li>
	</ul>
	These digital marketing pushes aren’t just the latest fad, they represent a shift on how many in the A/E/C industry now approach their marketing and advertising strategy.
	<blockquote>Bottom line: if you aren’t meeting your competitors on these fronts, you may be losing business.</blockquote>
	SEO has been a particular strong push for A/E/C businesses and one that SWC places a high priority on when building and <a title="SWC Web Design Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/digital-creative-design" target="_blank">redesigning websites</a>. Why? <strong>95% of search engine traffic originates from page 1 of search listings.</strong>
	SWC takes a user experience-directed approach to SEO strategy. In other words, SEO is not implemented for search engines’ sake, but rather for the end user. As Aaron Wall, founder of SEObook.com affirms:
	<blockquote>The success of a page should be measured by one criteria: Does the visitor do what you want them to do?</blockquote>
	Every step of SWC’s digital marketing strategy—from the design to the content—has the user in mind.
	
	As ideas like alternative energy solutions and smart cities evolve, so must the technologies that govern them and thereby the marketing strategies that make them visible.
	
	Join SWC as we showcase "best-in-class" examples of web design, SEO and digital marketing strategy at our next upcoming <a title="IT Events in Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland event</a>.
	
	Sources:
	
	<em>Exceptional Social Media and Marketing Statistics for 2014”’, Webbiquity, April 2014
	“The Digital Evolution in B2B Marketing”, Google &amp; Corporate Executive Board Company, 2012
	2015 Construction Marketing Outlook- Survey Results, Construction Marketing Association Blog</em><h3>RECOMMENDED POSTS</h3>
	If you enjoyed this digital marketing post, please check out a few of our related past posts:
	
	<a title="Website Design" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/uncategorized/website-redesign-mobile-application" target="_blank">Client Success: Preferred Meals Website Redesign &amp; Mobile Application</a>
	<a title="SEO Usability" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/user-experience-making-sustainable-seo-strategy" target="_blank">User Experience: The Makings of a Sustainable SEO Strategy</a>
	<a title="Wearable technology" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/search-engine-technology-changing-seo" target="_blank">How Search Engine Technology Is Changing the Way We Think About SEO</a>
	<a title="SEO" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">Search Engine Optimization</a>
	<a title="Website Design" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-design-2/digital-design-seo" target="_blank">Digital Design and SEO</a>
	<a title="Website Design Marketing" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-design-services/five-principles-successful-website-design" target="_blank">Five Principles Of Successful Web Design</a>

	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-15447 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-seo-stats-infographic-sm-012015.png" alt="SWC SEO Stats Infographic SM" width="500" height="764" />

		<item>
			<title>What are Some Business Intelligence Trends for 2015</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/2015-bi-trends</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 27 Mar 2015 13:46:45 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachaelnarel]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16193</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[There are going to be a lot of exciting trends for <a title="Business Intelligence Services," href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence" target="_blank">business intelligence</a> in 2015. Watch my “Ask SWC” video to learn more.
	
	<a title="New Features of Tableau 8.2" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/HJsGO-zR4mo?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Business Intelligence Trends 2015" width="474" height="262" /></a>
	
	<h2>Social</h2>
	When we talk about social and business intelligence there are two aspects to this. The first is that people are going to be a lot more social around business intelligence, meaning they are going to be collaborating around dashboards and different types of reports, sharing this information and having a more engaged, less static situation.
	
	Secondly, companies are looking for more social data about their organizations. Items are being posted on Yammer, Facebook and many other different social media channels and they are going to be bringing in a lot of that data to run analytics on what consumers are saying about their company, products or services, and also what some of their business partners are saying about them as well.
	<h2>Cloud</h2>
	And because organizations are going to have all of this vast data (and there’s so much data out there) you are going to see a greater move toward <a title="Cloud Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services?doing_wp_cron=1426780434.4199190139770507812500" target="_blank">the cloud</a>. The cloud is a lot more secure and it’s a lot more cost effective. Therefore, people are going to be putting a lot more of their business intelligence assets and data up in a cloud structure.
	<h2>Predictive Analytics</h2>
	Another trend that is really going to be taking off more this year is predictive analytics. More and more of the vendors that are out there today are making predictive analytics easier to use within new dashboard technologies, so <strong>you no longer have to be a data scientist to analyze the results</strong>. This also touches the ability to data mine and get ahead of different types of business trends instead of just being reactive and looking at performance or operational metrics. Predictive analytics is really going to become a big competitive advantage for your organization this year.
	<h2>Want to learn more?</h2>
	Join us for one of our complimentary <a title="Business Intelligence Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland Business Intelligence events</a> or register for our upcoming <a title="Business Analysts network" href="http://www.meetup.com/Business-Intelligence-Chicagoland/" target="_blank">Chicagoland Business Intelligence meetup</a>.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Rachael, please check out a few of our past posts on Business Intelligence:
	
	<a title="Analytics for Business" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/whats-new-business-intelligence-analytics-2015" target="_blank">What’s New for Business Intelligence and Analytics in 2015</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Azure" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/microsoft-azure-machine-learning" target="_blank">Microsoft Azure Machine Learning – A Data Tool for the Masses</a>
