			<title>Three Pillars of IT Service Management</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/pillars-itsm-service-management</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 31 Mar 2015 13:27:15 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[John Kuchta]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16295</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[When embarking upon the effort of <a title="ITSM Consulting" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/managed-services/it-service-management-itsm" target="_blank">implementing an ITSM framework</a> within your organization, centralize your focus on these three key areas: People, Process and Technology. Although it is perceived that the focus on these areas are often overemphasized in sales and marketing strategies, it is necessary to understand that it is not just the technology that contributes to a successful ITSM deployment, but the process of implementing it and the people involved as well.
	
	I’ve seen many organizations purchase the latest and greatest tools and then attempt to retrofit their processes and organization to the out of the box functionality of that tool. The result is always the same, the engagement fails and the tool often winds up as “shelfware.”
	
	It is only upon the assessment of each of these three areas – People, Process and Technology, in which a successful deployment of <a title="IT Managed Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/managed-services" target="_blank">IT Service Management</a> can be obtained.
	<h2>People</h2>
	Be sure when undertaking the assessment of “people” that you avoid the pitfall of only assessing the IT staff. A successful assessment needs to include the entire organizational structure as a whole. The ITSM mission and vision will fail unless it is embraced throughout all facets of the organization. In fact, an ITSM implementation often requires a culture change within the organization.
	
	During the assessment of your personnel, the following entities should be included when assembling your ITSM support structure:
	<ul>
		<li>Staff optimization (sizing)</li>
		<li>Staff capabilities (skillsets)</li>
		<li>Structure (appropriate support tiering)</li>
		<li>Communication channels</li>
		<li>Roles and Responsibilities</li>
		<li>Relationships between support structures</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>Process</h2>
	Process and Procedures will need to be based on and aligned with ITIL Best Practices. The ITIL framework provides the best model for implementing structured, well defined, formalized processes. Ensure as well, that the processes are aligned with your organizations “business strategy.” The strategy should include the appropriate metrics, key performance indicators (KPIs) and service levels to allow for efficient maturity baselines and improvement targets.
	
	The processes should be structured to impose the necessary controls for optimization, yet be flexible enough to adapt to additional growth within your organization, i.e. repeatable.
	<h2>Technology</h2>
	To tie it all together, only “Best-of-Breed” tools should be considered when implementing technology within your ITSM framework. Those tools should include components for the critical processes defined and deployed within your organization. If you implemented Incident, Problem, Change and Service Level Management processes, then your tool of choice should contain subsequent modules for each. Although it is possible to operate with multiple tools, it will often detract from your ability to obtain acceptable OLA and SLA targets due to the integration components or manual processes that may be necessary to implement.
	
	The technology solutions considered should also possess the appropriate automation functionality that allows you to achieve the goals established within your processes. In addition, tools should contain the capabilities to synchronize to all other technology utilized by your organizations resources.
	<h2>SWC’s Approach to IT Service Management</h2>
	SWC provides end-to-end ITSM expertise, from strategy and design to transition and operations with a focus on continual service improvements. What sets SWC apart from other IT providers is our experience in all areas of ITSM. <strong>Backed by a team of ITIL certified subject matter experts, our services are designed to go beyond basic back-end support. </strong>We take a holistic approach to IT managed services by assessing your current state and providing recommendations on how to leverage the right people, processes and technology to achieve a more comprehensive and desirable solution.
	<h2>Want to learn more?</h2>
	If you would like to learn more about ITSM services, contact us at 630.572.0240 or attend our complimentary upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland Managed Services event</a>.
	<h2>How Mature are your IT Operations?</h2>
	Download our checklist to see where your organization ranks.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/ITSM-Checklist.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16347 size-medium" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/blogCTA-300x178.png" alt="blogCTA" width="300" height="178" /></a><h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from John, please check out a few of our best practices blog posts on related topics:
	<a title="IT Support Resources" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/managed-it-services-midmarket" target="_blank">SWC Best Practices: Keeping Up with Today’s IT Environment</a>

	<a title="IT Service Desk Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/best-practices-does-outsourcing-my-service-desk-make-sense" target="_blank">SWC Best Practices: Does Outsourcing My Service Desk Make Sense?</a>

			<title>Built-in Mobile Device Management Is Now Freely Available for Office 365 Commercial Plans</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-mobile-device-management</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 02 Apr 2015 15:47:31 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeremyalt]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16453</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[In what is possibly the biggest splash since the Wave 15 roll out in early 2013, Microsoft announced on March 30th that mobile device management (MDM) capabilities are coming to <a title="Microsoft O365" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Microsoft Office 365</a>.
	
	Today, more businesses are adopting a <a title="BYOD" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/byod-polices-mobile-device-management" target="_blank">bring your own device (BYOD)</a> policy to support their users anywhere, anytime and on any device. With this support comes the necessity to deliver the same experience without having to worry about infrastructure, security, compliance and other factors.
	
	Some have turned to third-party MDM solutions for this support, but with Microsoft’s new rollout it’s possible that you may not need that third-party solution after all.  As long as you have an Office 365 commercial plan (including Business, Enterprise, EDU and Government plans), <strong>you’ll receive all of these MDM features at no additional cost.</strong>
	
	On March 30th Microsoft began rolling out new MDM capabilities that will help you manage access to Office 365 data across devices and operating systems. These features will help you:
	
	<strong>Secure corporate resources (conditional access):</strong> Set up <a title="Managed it services" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/swc-best-practices-security-managed-services" target="_blank">security policies</a> on devices that connect to Office 365 to ensure that Office 365 corporate email and documents can be accessed only on phones and tablets that are managed by your company.
	
	<strong>Manage devices:</strong> Set up security policies like device level pin lock and jailbreak detection to help prevent unauthorized use and protect corporate data in the event a device is lost or stolen. You can administer policies within the O365 admin portal and view reports on which devices have been connected or blocked.
	
	<strong>Selectively wipe Office 365 data:</strong> This is perfect for when an employee leaves your organization and you need to remove corporate data from a device while leaving their personal data intact.
	
	All of these capabilities are powered by <a title="Microsoft Intune" href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/server-cloud/products/microsoft-intune/" target="_blank">Microsoft Intune</a>, which provides mobile device management, mobile application management and PC management capabilities from the cloud. However, any organization can get advanced protection beyond the new MDM O365 rollout with Microsoft Intune.
	
	Microsoft Intune enables you to restrict user actions such as copy/cut/paste when dealing with corporate data and then, for instance only be able to save that data on the corporate OneDrive for Business account. It also allows you to <a title="BYOD" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-is-unified-device-management" target="_blank">manage devices</a> from the cloud or from your existing System Center Configuration Manager. Lastly, Intune can deploy certificates like VPN and email profiles on your device or to a group of users. You can even provide your users with a secure portal where they can enroll their own devices and install apps.
	
	These features are all very important in separating work life from personal life and preventing users from accidentally intermixing the two on their devices.
	
	Interested in realizing the potential Office 365 and mobile device management can have on your business? <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact SWC</a> and we’ll put together an Office 365 and MDM roadmap that is specifically tailored for your cloud and BYOD business needs.
	<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Jeremy, please check out a few of our blog posts on related topics:
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/byod-polices-mobile-device-management" title="Bring Your Own Device" target="_blank">BYOD Policies And Mobile Device Management</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/why-swc-it-departments-like-office-365" title="O365" target="_blank">Why SWC And IT Departments Like Office 365</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/what-is-microsoft-365" title="Office 365 Solutions" target="_blank">How Can Office 365 Help My Organization?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/migrating-exchange-online-protection-office-365" title="Cloud-based EOP" target="_blank">Migrating From Standalone Exchange Online Protection (EOP) to Office 365</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/cloud-based-sharepoint?doing_wp_cron=1427981350.4832599163055419921875" title="Sharepoint in the cloud" target="_blank">SharePoint On-Premises vs. SharePoint Online (Office 365 Cloud)</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/skype-for-business-release" title="S4B Microsoft" target="_blank">Skype for Business is Coming!</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/downloadable-windows-10" title="Microsoft Windows 10" target="_blank">Skipping Ahead to Windows 10</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-remoteapp" title="Microsoft Azure" target="_blank">Microsoft RemoteApp: Your Apps in the Cloud</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-2015" title="Microsoft 2015" target="_blank">What Can We Expect from Microsoft in 2015?</a><h2>How Can Office 365 Help My Organization?</h2>
	Want to learn more about how Office 365 can help your organization? Watch Jeremy’s Ask SWC video below.
	
	<a title="What is Microsoft 365" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/w_K_oM0RP1c?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Microsoft SharePoint Enablement" width="500" height="281" /></a>

			</wp:postmeta>

				<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_metadesc</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[BYOD is reshaping the way IT manages corporate information. Learn how Microsoft MDM makes it possible to manage and secure corporate data on any device.]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:postmeta>

		<item>
			<title>Skype for Business Client Release Date Announced</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/skype-for-business-release-date</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 07 Apr 2015 13:40:37 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16484</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[As you know, we're all eagerly anticipating the <a title="Skype for Business" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications/skype-business" target="_blank">Skype for Business</a> server release on May 1st. But in other exciting news, we now have a confirmed release date for the client! On <strong>April 14th</strong>, an update to Office 2013, <a title="O365" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365 ProPlus</a> and Office 365 Business Premium will be available from Microsoft. This means that the first Skype for Business client is not a separate install, but rather a patch delivered to the existing Lync 2013 client.
			
	If you are using <a title="Microsoft Lync" href="/solutions/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-2013">Microsoft Lync</a> on-premises, your users will experience no visible changes when the client is patched. However for Lync Online, now Skype for Business Online, the users' experience will default to the new Skype look and feel. Of course, if you're running your server on-premises or online you have full control over what your users will see.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-16487 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/skype-resized.png" alt="skype-resized" width="500" height="360" />
	
	For more information on this exciting update and to learn how you can control which user interface is presented to your users, please head on over to the <a title="Microsoft News" href="http://blogs.office.com/2015/04/01/whats-new-in-skype-for-business-and-how-you-can-take-control-of-updates/" target="_blank">Microsoft Office blog</a>.
	
	If you need help planning your upgrade strategy to Skype for Business or Microsoft Office 365 please reach out to SWC or come to one of our upcoming <a title="Chicago Unified Communications Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a> to learn more.<h3>RECOMMENDED POSTS</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Anthony, please check out a few of our past posts on Microsoft Unified Communications:
	
	<a title="S4B release" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/skype-for-business-release" target="_blank">Skype for Business is Coming!</a>

		<item>
			<title>How to Get More Out of the Cloud for Less</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/more-cloud-for-less</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 08 Apr 2015 13:48:36 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Sebastian Blicharz]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16490</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you’re thinking of moving to the cloud, the first thing you should ask yourself is “What are the benefits of the cloud to my organization?” Why should you, for instance, move to <a title="Windows Azure Pack" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack" target="_blank">Microsoft Azure</a>? The answer is threefold:
	<ol>
		<li><strong>Speed:</strong> Procuring and provisioning servers is done rapidly in the cloud. Your reduced “time to develop” and “time to market” means your IT can be much more agile in servicing the needs of the business units or developers.</li>
		<li><strong>Scale:</strong> The cloud gives you an almost infinite set of computing resources. Your applications will enjoy massive global scale, and can easily scale up or down depending on the demand. You use just enough resources for your needs—nothing more, nothing less.</li>
		<li><strong>Economics:</strong> You pay for only what you use in the cloud. This will save you money on apps that have variable computing needs.</li>
	</ol>
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-16494" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/OG-apps.png" alt="OG-apps" width="500" height="263" />
	The beauty of the cloud lies not only in its scalability, but its flexibility. You can choose how little or how much you want to manage. For instance, the Software as a Service (Saas) model allows the third-party provider to host and manage <a title="SWC Cloud Services" href="/solutions/cloud-services">applications in the cloud</a>, thereby freeing up your organization’s resources from daily upkeep.
	
	In the Platform as a Service (PaaS) model, developers gain a framework where they can customize applications. With PaaS, the provider can manage the virtualization, servers, storage and networking, while the developers can manage the applications.
	
	Lastly, in the Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) model, the third-party provider hosts virtualized resources like hardware, software, servers, storage, networking, networking services (e.g. firewalls) and other infrastructure to deliver on-demand. You can choose to connect the “datacenter” you build in the cloud to your on-premises datacenter so that the datacenter in the cloud becomes an extension of your on-premises infrastructure.
	
	<strong>Before you move to the cloud, there are few things you should keep in mind that go against everything you have learned when architecting on-premises solutions.</strong> Keeping an open mind will let you get more for your money when moving to the cloud.
	<h2>Peak Load Time</h2>
	The first thing you do when you design an on-premises or hosted solution is figure out the peak load. Next, you purchase hardware that can handle that plus “X” percent. You need to overprovision, because not being able to meet the peak demand or future growth means that you will need to spend more on new hardware.
	
	Should you do this in the cloud? The short answer is no. It is not unusual for on-premises applications to utilize less than 20% of system resources. <strong>The cloud gives you the flexibility to scale on-demand. This means you only pay for what you need right now</strong>, and within minutes you can scale vertically or horizontally. You can save a lot of money by keeping the utilization of you system resources high, and scale up on-demand or automatically when needed.
	<h2>Pay By-the-Minute or By-the-Hour</h2>
	The second thing to keep in mind is that you will only pay for what you use in the cloud, by the minute with Azure and by the hour with Amazon Web Services (AWS).
	
	Do you have workloads that only happen at a specific time of the day, month or year? Think about only running the servers when needed. If no one is using your application from 6pm to 6am, shut down the server. If that is not an option, scale it down so that it only supports the reduced load experienced during those hours.
	<h2>End of Life</h2>
	The third thing to keep in mind is that Microsoft and Amazon update their hardware and add higher-end offerings year over year while continuing to drop prices. This means you will continue to get more for less and you will never have to worry about your hardware reaching end of life.
	
	Remember, the cloud is for everybody, but not for everything. You will get the most out of the cloud when you define your business and IT needs and adopt solutions that integrate with your strategy and on-premises environment.
	
	If you want to learn more about moving to the cloud, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> and ask if you are a candidate for a Microsoft-funded Azure one-day assessment.<h3>Recommended Posts:</h3>
	If you would like to read some of SWC’s additional blog posts on Microsoft Azure and the cloud, please check out the links below:
	<a title="Azure Pack" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack" target="_blank">Creating an Azure Environment On-Premises with Windows Azure Pack</a>
	<a title="Server 2003 End of Life" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack" target="_blank">Preparing for Server 2003 End of Life by Migrating to Microsoft Azure</a>
	<a title="Azure Software Deployment" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/deployments-azure-microsoft-cloud" target="_blank">Deployments and Rollbacks in Azure</a>
	<a title="Azure Active Directory" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-azure-reduce-helpdesk-calls-increase-security" target="_blank">How Microsoft Azure Can Reduce Help Desk Calls and Increase Security</a>
	<a title="Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/move-hyper-v-virtual-machine-into-microsoft-azure-using-system-center" target="_blank">How to Move a Hyper-V Virtual Machine into Microsoft Azure Using System Center</a>
	<a title="Autoscaling with the Cloud" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/performance-schedule-autoscaling-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Performance and Schedule Autoscaling in Microsoft Azure</a>
	<a title="Cloud Web Hosting" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/flexible-scalable-web-hosting-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Flexible and Scalable Web Hosting with Microsoft Azure</a>
	<a title="Microsoft O365" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/what-is-microsoft-365" target="_blank">How Can Office 365 Help My Organization?</a>
	<a title="Microsoft RemoteApp" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-remoteapp" target="_blank">Microsoft RemoteApp: Your Apps in the Cloud</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Azure Cloud Service" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/five-questions-to-ask-before-investing-in-cloud-service" target="_blank">Five Questions to Ask Before Investing in a Cloud Service</a>
	<h2>Let’s Build Some Cool Stuff Together</h2>
	Watch our video below to learn more about SWC’s custom application development capabilities.
	
	<a title="Custom Application" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/hsLhW7R4Md4?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/it-solutions-provider-swc-cool-stuff.png" alt="IT Solutions Provider SWC Cool Stuff" width="620" height="380" /></a>
	
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>The SWC CRM Maturity Model</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/crm-maturity-model</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 09 Apr 2015 14:04:08 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Will Robinson]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16510</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[The CRM Maturity Model is a high-level blueprint for defining which level you are at in the <a title="CRM Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm" target="_blank">customer relationship management</a> lifecycle and what tools and strategies you need to get to the next level. From an organizational standpoint, stepping up a level in the CRM Maturity Model is a big deal. With each level comes a more detailed set of processes, a defined sales pipeline with centralized data and tools that allow different departments to synchronize and create a 360 degree view of the customer lifecycle. In essence, each level will likely create more leads, deepen relationships and increase the likelihood of future business, all the while consuming less of your time.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-16519 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/blog-image.png" alt="blog-image" width="500" height="306" />
	<h2>Level 1: Ad Hoc</h2>
	At Level 1, sales professionals typically use offline tools to manage their accounts, leads, opportunities and sales tasks. Many times these “tools” are a large yellow notepad. The sales professional manages their contacts in Outlook which syncs up with their smartphone. At this level, each sales professional has their own sales process that loosely follows an organization’s process.
	
	<em>No CRM System</em>
	There is no true Customer Relation Management (CRM) system involved in Level 1. This means sales management has no visibility on what’s occurring on a daily/weekly basis without having meetings or calling sales professionals. These multi-person meetings are time consuming. The lack of visibility limits the extent to which the sales manager can help the sales professional deal with roadblocks, which is particularly troublesome if that person is new to the organization. The sales manager typically only finds out about a deal when the ink is dry on the contract. The rest of the organization has a limited ability to forecast the demand that comes from closed deals. In a services company, recruiting can fall behind. In a products company, the supply chain and assembly line falls behind.
	<h2>Level 2: Captured</h2>
	Organizations at Level 2 maturity have a CRM system where sales professionals are uploading their leads, opportunities and activities. Basic sales stages are being identified and team-based selling is starting to coalesce around the system. Data is now centralized; it’s not walking out the door when there is turnover. Sales managers can see a sales pipeline, trends and begin to help sales professionals with leads.
	
	<em>Value to Sales Professional – Familiar Tools Become More Powerful</em>
	With Level 2 maturity, there is Outlook and CRM integration. Sales professionals create opportunities or contacts in Outlook and link it to their CRM with one click—there is no need to go into a web browser. Using their phone or tablet client, the sales professional can use voice-to-text to quickly add opportunities and notes that will be created in CRM.
	<h2>Level 3: Managed</h2>
	Organizations typically at Level 3 maturity are using CRM’s workflow and rules-based engine to drive the sales process. The organization’s sales process typically has stages. Each stage has a set number of rules and data points that are required before moving to the next stage. One stage may require an NDA to be signed, for example. The qualifying stage may require the sales professional to confirm the budget or purchasing timeline.
	
	<em>Value to Sales Professional – Guided Process Reduces Sales Cycle</em>
	Every organization has processes, but when these processes are vaguely defined and loosely enforced, they can be the root of frustration and inefficiencies. Without these processes, for example, a sales professional may be told to go back and ask the potential customer for something they missed. Having the process clearly defined creates efficiency and transparency; the sales professional knows exactly what to do because they are guided through it all. This level of maturity leads to a decrease in the sales cycle.
	<h2>Level 4: Optimize</h2>
	When an organization has reached Level 4 maturity, they typically have implemented one or more of the following:
	
	<strong>1. Marketing and Sales Alignment</strong>
	<p style="padding-left: 30px;">Marketing and sales alignment occurs when you can make a connection from a marketing activity (e.g. email campaign), to a lead, to a qualified opportunity and finally to a closed deal. By implementing this alignment, the organization can quantify the value of its marketing investments and sales can be directly tied back to marketing activity.</p>
	<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em>Value to Sales Professional – Alignment Visibility</em>
	Now the sales professional can see how much marketing activity contributed to their sales. For example, CRM would show that a certain sales professional had 10 leads generated from a marketing campaign. The professional qualified the 10 leads to four opportunities. Two of those opportunities lead to a proposal of which the professional was able to win one deal. Those are tangible results that leads the sales professional to supporting future marketing efforts.</p>
	<strong>2. ERP Integration</strong>
	<p style="padding-left: 30px;">An organization at Level 4 typically integrates CRM and Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) to pull pricing data into CRM. This reduces the risk of incorrect pricing and lost revenue. CRM pushes orders into the ERP which initiates production or allocation of resources. In this situation, sales is helping the organization forecast demand. Forecasting demand is a powerful organizational tool that is a constant challenge. Being able to forecast demand has an impact on the recruiting process (services company) and production (product company) in a manufacturing plant. The increase in efficiency leads to a stronger bottom line for the organization.</p>
	<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em>Value to Sales Professional – Faster Sales Cycle</em>
	Organizations often lose business because they can’t move fast enough to answer customers. When a sales professional has always up-to-date pricing and doesn’t need to wait on other departments for information, the sales cycle decreases. Level 4 maturity leads to less stress on the sales professional as they have more time to work the sales cycle.</p>
	<strong>3. Customer Service Integration</strong>
	<p style="padding-left: 30px;">In most organizations, there is some synergy between the marketing and sales departments. However, there can be little communication between the sales and customer service departments. That all changes with Level 4 maturity. Many CRM systems including Salesforce and Microsoft Dynamics CRM have customer service capabilities. Imagine a world where marketing, sales and customer service work in tangent to manage the entire customer lifecycle. Marketing starts by nurturing the potential customer. Then, sales qualifies, understands the problem and proposes a solution. Lastly, customer service ensures the customer is happy and getting answers to their questions. This is true organizational alignment.</p>
	<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em>Value to Professional – 360 Degree View</em>
	In many organizations, the sales professional looks to the future because they don’t have visibility into how their accounts are being serviced.</p>
	<p style="padding-left: 30px;">With Level 4 maturity, the sales professional gets to look at one pane of glass (their CRM website) for a particular customer that shows opportunities, recent activities, past marketing campaigns (nurture),and service tickets (current requests and issues). A 360 degree view allows the sales professional to deepen relationships, proactively address issues, and ultimately increase the likelihood of future business. What more could a sales professional ask for?</p>
	
	The CRM Maturity Model is essential for assessing and optimizing your sales processes, but to go from one level to the next requires the right software, tools and experience. SWC has over 35 years of experience of delivering the right technology solutions to match the needs of midmarket organizations.
	
	We’re practical—we know that very few organizations need all the CRM bells and whistles. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> and we’ll assess your current strategy, processes and technology needs in order to carefully take you to the next level with the technology solutions you need.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-Download.pdf"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16522 size-medium" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-BLOG-GUIDE-300x178.png" alt="CRM-BLOG-GUIDE" width="300" height="178" /></a>

			<title>SWC Scores Its Fourth Consecutive Crain’s Chicago Business Best Places to Work Award</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/crains-best-places-to-work-2015</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 10 Apr 2015 13:53:12 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[franpeters]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16525</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of the first things people see when they sit down to interview at SWC are our <a title="Best Places to Work in Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/news/crains-chicago-business-swc-a-best-place-to-work-2015" target="_blank">Crain’s Best Places to Work</a> awards. That’s very purposeful. We’re proud of these awards and we want to instill upon candidates the premium that we place on employee happiness and fulfillment.
	
	If you’re happy and challenged each and every day, then you’re going to deliver your best work, both to the customer and to the team. So if there is one overarching goal here at SWC, one goal to rule them all, it’s just that — create a fun environment that fosters professional growth and happiness through challenging, diverse and rewarding work.
	
	This is not a management goal, and this is not a HR goal. This is a team goal, and every employee is encouraged to contribute ideas that make SWC a fun and fulfilling place to work. We’re always trying out new ideas — from a company-wide <a title="Pi Day Celebration Video" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UP07Wlv3v70" target="_blank">Pi Day celebration</a> on March 14 (3.14) with a pie-eating contest, pi reciting contest, and plenty of pizza pie, to the SWC Olympics, a two-week company-wide competition with ping pong battles, Wii tournaments, dodgeball, talent contests and myriad other events.
	
	We work hard to find talented, passionate professionals. Experience is important to us. But we are also key on passion — on a candidate’s desire and eagerness to work with a team to solve an organization’s technology problems. And when we do hire someone, we want to retain that talented individual, cultivate professional development and be a mentor for his or her career goals.
	
	Our employees want to advance in their career. They are entrepreneurial-minded individuals who are eager to learn new skills and certifications, and we reward them for that. We reward performance with monthly incentives for reaching or exceeding work utilization goals, and we also reward them for receiving certifications, while covering any associated costs.
	
	The thing we like most about being named by Crain as a Best Place to Work is the process by which they come to select businesses — the focus of which is an employee satisfaction survey by a third-party firm. It’s not just me up here saying “We’re the best,” it’s the employees saying “We’re the best, and here’s why.”
	
	What makes SWC a best place to work? The answer is different for every individual, and that’s one of the reasons why we offer so many different <a title="SWC Benefits and Perks" href="http://www.swc.com/careers/swc-benefits" target="_blank">benefits and perks</a>.
	
	It’s an honor to be recognized by Crain for the fourth consecutive year—an honor that I share with everyone at SWC.
	<h2>We’re Hiring!</h2>
	If you're looking for a dynamic full-time career in IT where you can learn, grow and enhance your skills in a fast-paced consulting environment, consider a career with SWC Technology Partners, go to our <a title="IT Careers in Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/careers" target="_blank">Chicago Careers</a> page to apply!
	<h3>Reimagine Your Career</h3>
	<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/PtJXuLTIOq4?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox;width=720;height=480;"><img src="/uploads/Blog-Video-reimagine.png" alt="Best Places to Work in Chicago" width="500" height="281" /></a><h3>RECOMMENDED POSTS</h3>
	If you would like to learn more about SWC’s corporate culture, please check out a few of our past posts:
	
	<a title="Employee Engagement " href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/ways-to-keep-employees-engaged" target="_blank">A Few Ways to Keep Employees Engaged and Have Fun in the Workplace</a>
	<a title="Work Life Balance in Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/chicago-it-solutions-provider-work-life-balance" target="_blank">Chicago Area IT Solutions Provider SWC Focuses On Work-Life Balance</a>
	<a title="SWC Incentives and Perks" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/twelve-days-of-swc" target="_blank">The Twelve Days Of SWC</a>
	<a title="Halloween at SWC" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/boogie-bot-costume-contest-happy-halloween" target="_blank">Boogie Bot Costume Contest – Happy Halloween From SWC!</a>

		<item>
			<title>Encrypt Your Email with Exchange Online Protection and Office 365</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/encrypt-email-exchange-online-office-365</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 13 Apr 2015 13:55:09 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16531</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[In an ever changing world where security has become more and more of a consideration in all aspects of technology, one area that we are asked about frequently at SWC is <a title="Security email encryption" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/it-security-worst-case-scenario" target="_blank">email encryption</a>. For many organizations it is necessary to send information that might be sensitive or contain personal data, but sending that information using standard email protocols can be dangerous. Even more importantly, your end users may not always realize the danger, and even with the best of intentions, some important information might slip into an email.
	
	There is now an easy solution for any organization that is currently on <a title="O365" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365 </a>for email or who has Exchange Online Protection (EOP) for spam filtering. As an add-on to these services, <strong>Microsoft is offering Message Encryption to ensure that all sensitive messages are protected.</strong> Since this service integrates with your existing email system, the setup and configuration is extremely easy because all of your email is already flowing through the Microsoft services.
	<h2>How does it work?</h2>
	Just like a spam filter, Office 365 Message Encryption scans every message that is sent out from your email system and looks for specific keywords or content. The rules for what content is discovered is fully customizable, and can be matched against specific words and text patterns in both the email body and attachments. Social Security numbers, credit card numbers, or just the word [Secure] in the subject are just a few of the examples of what can be monitored for and automatically encrypted.
	
	<img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/O365-EOP-blog-500px.png" alt="Microsoft Office 365" width="500" height="270" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-16532" />
	
	Once the message matches a rule, Office 365 automatically converts the message to an encrypted message and puts it into the secured website. Instead of transmitting the whole message across the Internet, a message asking the recipients to log into to the email site is transmitted. The recipients view and respond to the email using the secure and familiar Outlook Web Access interface. Since this is all based on Office 365, no additional on-premises hardware or software is needed. Once the recipient responds, Office 365 Message Encryption can be configured to automatically decrypt the response and deliver it back to your user’s inbox so that they don’t even notice the encryption.
	<h2>What if the recipient is not an Office 365 or EOP user?</h2>
	One of the key benefits of using Microsoft’s encryption service is that it integrates with Microsoft’s Live ID system to allow anyone to login and access their messages. If the recipient doesn’t have a Live ID or doesn’t want to log in, a one-time passcode can also be emailed to them.
	<h2>How do I enable this feature?</h2>
	As mentioned earlier, if you are already an Office 365 or Exchange Online Protection customer you are almost there. This feature is part of the Rights Management Suite which is included in many licenses or can be added on for a small fee. To find out if you have the proper licensing and to get help configuring your protection rules, please <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> at SWC.
	
	Not currently on Office 365 or EOP? No problem. Transitioning to Exchange Online Protection can help reduce your spam and also provide you the added benefits of email encryption. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact us</a> and we will be happy to help you determine if EOP and Office 365 Message Encryption are the right solution for your organization!<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post on Microsoft Office 365 and Exchange Online Protection, please check out a few of our past posts on related topics.
	
	<a title="Built-In Mobile Device Management in Office 365" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-mobile-device-management" target="_blank">Built-In Mobile Device Management Is Now Freely Available For Office 365 Commercial Plans</a>
	<a title="O365" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/why-swc-it-departments-like-office-365" target="_blank">Why SWC And IT Departments Like Office 365</a>
	<a title="Cloud-based EOP" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/migrating-exchange-online-protection-office-365" target="_blank">Migrating From Standalone Exchange Online Protection (EOP) to Office 365</a>
	<a title="Office 365 Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/what-is-microsoft-365" target="_blank">How Can Office 365 Help My Organization?</a>
	<a title="S4B Microsoft" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/skype-for-business-release" target="_blank">Skype for Business is Coming!</a>
	<a title="Sharepoint in the cloud" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/cloud-based-sharepoint?doing_wp_cron=1427981350.4832599163055419921875" target="_blank">SharePoint On-Premises vs. SharePoint Online (Office 365 Cloud)</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Windows 10" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/downloadable-windows-10" target="_blank">Skipping Ahead to Windows 10</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Azure" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-remoteapp" target="_blank">Microsoft RemoteApp: Your Apps in the Cloud</a>
	<a title="Microsoft 2015" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-2015" target="_blank">What Can We Expect from Microsoft in 2015?</a>
	
	<h2>How Can Office 365 Help My Organization?</h2>
	Want to learn more about how Office 365 can help your organization? Watch our Ask SWC video below.
	<a title="What is Microsoft 365" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/w_K_oM0RP1c?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Ask_SWC_Blog_Template.jpg" alt="Microsoft SharePoint Enablement" width="500" height="281" /></a>
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Manufacturers Look to Master Data Management to Solve Their Data Quality Problems</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/master-data-management-solve-data-quality</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 15 Apr 2015 13:48:05 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16541</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Today’s forward-leaning manufacturing companies are very agile and they’re making investments in their IT infrastructure. They’re investing in more applications and systems inside the firewall and lots of <a title="RemoteApp" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-remoteapp" target="_blank">applications are being run in the cloud</a>. Now, instead of having that old mainframe application that they ran their manufacturing process on, they have tens of applications where data is spread across and they all have strategic roles on what those applications do with their data.
	
	Because of all of these applications, there is often redundant or missing data in, for example, customer lists. Customer lists might be in a manufacturers’ Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) solution, accounting package, CRM type system, etc. There may be different ways of codifying a customer within the organization. There might also be different ports and analytics. It all equates to a big data mess.
	
	Some people thought that simply having a data warehouse would solve this type of master data challenge. And data warehousing is an answer for some—it’s always helpful to have your analytics in one place—but what if this data is in such a poor state and needs treatment?
	
	Enter Master Data Management (MDM). MDM tools and systems help cleanse and ensure the governance of that data. These tools have approval workflows and permissions built into them to ensure only the right changes are being made to the record. It creates a central repository for all the domain-type data that’s important to the organization.
	<h2>MDM Solves Manufacturer’s Data Quality Issues</h2>
	When we talk to manufacturers about their information processes and data management, we always ask if they have a MDM strategy. If we’re doing any kind of data integration, data warehousing or <a title="BI Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence" target="_blank">Business Intelligence</a> (BI) type projects, we almost require that MDM be put into place alongside because it will guarantee the success of those projects.
	
	SWC has implemented a number of MDM solutions with manufacturers and because so many of them have Microsoft SQL Server, the MDM capability is already there; the solutions are pre-bundled with their SQL server product. It’s just a matter of us going in there and making the necessary configurations (Check out Chad’s <a title="Business Intelligence Data Quality" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/its-the-data-quality" target="_blank">data quality</a> post for more information).
	<h2>MDM’s Impact on Manufacturers</h2>
	MDM is still very new for manufacturing clients, but it has been very impactful for them.
	
	When we have MDM conversations, it’s an easy concept for them to understand. <strong>I wish every software solution was as easy to demonstrate value and provide immediate impact. You just don’t see that with other software products.</strong> Many times you hear horror stories of how long it takes to implement a new ERP solution, whereas MDM can be done very tactically.
	
	There are instances where we went in and in less than a month we put it in place to do something tactically and provided immediate ROI.
	<h2>The Future of MDM on the Manufacturing Industry</h2>
	Looking to the future, I think the most challenging aspects of doing MDM are data integration, the linking up of applications to this model and setting up the subscriptions. I see that becoming easier to do and I feel like it’s going to be like buying an app off the App Store. It’s going to get easier to integrate your applications to the MDM strategy without having to write as much code or do so much data integration testing. It’s going to be more of a service.
	
	Manufacturers have a huge opportunity with MDM to map and manage data across multiple applications, organize data into multiple models and versions, and create cleaned, consistent data that is available to different users.
	
	We are just scratching the surface of what manufacturing can do with MDM.
	<h2>Want to learn more?</h2>
	Join us for one of our complimentary <a title="Business Intelligence Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland Business Intelligence events</a> or register for our upcoming <a title="Chicagoland Business Intelligence Networking" href="http://www.meetup.com/Business-Intelligence-Chicagoland/" target="_blank">Chicagoland Business Intelligence meetup</a>.

			<title>Windows Server and Clients – Kernel Divergence</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/windows-server-2003-end-of-life</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 14 Apr 2015 14:16:59 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16553</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Much media focus has been given to the forthcoming <a title="Windows 10 Release" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/downloadable-windows-10" target="_blank">Windows 10</a> client operating system currently in preview form with an expected release in Q3 2015. However, there has been a lot of less publicized yet quite interesting news on the server front as well. What is going on with the long-standing Windows Server 2003? Should my organization be moving to 2012 R2 if a new version is expected in 2016? What’s the future direction of Windows Server?<h2>Chicago Area IT Services and Support 630-572-0240.</h2>
	Windows Server 2003 is fast approaching its <a title="Windows Server 2003 End of Life" href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/server-cloud/products/windows-server-2003/" target="_blank">end-of-life date: July 14, 2015</a>. As with its companion client Windows XP, which exited extended support one year ago, this means that no new security hotfixes or maintenance patches will be publically released. Aging operating systems are more vulnerable to zero-day attacks and ever-evolving security threats, which can rapidly emerge in the modern cloud-connected world. <strong>Thus, if your organization still has active Server 2003 systems, it’s time to begin migrating their workloads to newer platforms.</strong> For 64-bit versions of Server 2003, it is possible to perform an in-place upgrade to <a title="Windows Server 2008 R2 Upgrade" href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd979563(v=ws.10).aspx" target="_blank">Server 2008 R2</a> if necessary. However, a much cleaner and safer approach is to do a side-by-side migration directly to <a title="Server 2012 R2" href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn303416.aspx" target="_blank">Server 2012 R2</a>.
	
	Because Server 2012 R2 has been broadly adopted and well documented for over two years, it is the most logical step for migration. Moreover, there is no reason to wait because Microsoft recently announced that <a title="Microsoft Windows Server Release Date" href="http://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-pushes-windows-server-next-back-to-2016/" target="_blank">Windows Server 2016 will not release alongside Windows 10</a>. This is a noteworthy coincidence, as it represents the first time that the client and server kernels have diverged since Windows 2003/XP. It was nice that Windows 7 and 2008 R2 shared the same internal code base because you could be assured of high interoperability with applications and a similar interface. But given the upcoming changes in both client and server paradigms, it makes sense to differentiate them going forward.
	
	Windows 10 aims to be faster-paced in general, with the new end-user features delivered regularly, although IT organizations can instead align their strategy with the “long-term serviceability branch” and opt for consistency and stability as desired. In contrast, Windows Server 2016 aims to be an even more cloud-optimized system, drawing heavily on technology derived from Microsoft Azure. In particular, the so-called <a title="Windows Serve 2016 Nano Server" href="http://www.zdnet.com/article/windows-server-2016-leaks-reveal-nano-server-protected-vm-role-plans/" target="_blank">Nano Server</a> feature will be one of its cornerstones, with refactored PowerShell CoreCLR as the primary management interface.
	
	A compatibility mode will exist to support the current generation of server roles and applications in the marketplace, such as traditional RDS farms and IIS web services, plus improvements in <a title="Virtualization Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/virtualization" target="_blank">virtualization </a>and storage. Meanwhile, the micro-services layer will move towards being the future foundation of containerized Docker applications, Windows Fabric and PaaS. In short, this means it won’t always be necessary to run a full VM in order to achieve isolation of enterprise software applications, resulting in reduced overhead and increased ability to scale dynamically.
	
	Management of this new technology will also fall under two comparable umbrellas. When the Windows 10 client OS launches later this year, an updated SCCM will release alongside it. The remainder of the System Center suite, which is more closely tied to the server release cycle, will come out in 2016.
	
	Need help aligning Server 2012 R2 or SCCM with your business needs? Let SWC’s 35 years of experience implementing technology solutions go to work for you. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact SWC</a> today and tell us about your business. Don’t know where to start with your migration? Call 630-572-0240 and we will determine the best solution that works with your current on-premises environment and your cloud computing needs.

			<title>The End is Near… Are You Prepared for Life After Windows Server 2003 Support Ends?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-windows-server-2003-ends-support</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 16 Apr 2015 14:04:38 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradellison]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16537</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[The day of reckoning is almost upon us. On July 14, 2015 Windows Server 2003 support will end. This means that Microsoft will no longer push patches and security updates, and physical and virtualized instances will be vulnerable to security threats. This is a big deal, 37 critical updates were applied in 2013 alone. Furthermore, companies that continue to run Server 2003 will fail standard compliance audits.
	
	In other words, <strong>if you are still running Windows Server 2003, you need to migrate or your business might be headed south.</strong> Fortunately, there are some very good options and the team at SWC is highly skilled at making these Windows Sever 2003 migrations.
	
	Windows 2003’s successor, Windows Server 2012 offers a wealth of improvements including integrated virtualization, enterprise-class scalability, improved security, and much more. It excels in interoperability with cross platform technologies, and given that many businesses have heterogeneous environments, this is critical. It also gives your users secure access to corporate resources on their own devices (<a title="Bring Your Own Device" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/byod-polices-mobile-device-management" target="_blank">BYOD</a>), and adds new, powerful end-user capabilities such as SSL virtual private networks and DirectAccess.
	
	Given the number of improvements from Windows Server 2003, Microsoft has said that there is a “substantial learning curve” to move directly from Windows Server 2003 to Windows Server 2012 R2. Thankfully, the SWC migration team has a wealth of experience to this end and can save you time (and headaches) getting there.
	
	Some of you might be considering moving to Windows Server 2008 in the interim. Microsoft highly discourages this approach, as they ended mainstream support in January 2015.
	<h2>What Can the Cloud Offer?</h2>
	The time is ripe to transform your datacenter and take advantage of <a title="Cloud Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud computing</a>.
	
	<strong><em>“According to IDC, 70% of CIOs will embrace a “cloud first” strategy in 2016.”</em></strong>
	
	Businesses are increasingly looking for ways to improve agility and scalability, and with the cloud’s operational model, you only use and pay only for the resources you need. This will save you money on data storage.
	
	Microsoft’s cloud computing platform and infrastructure, Microsoft Azure, is for many, the perfect solution. It’s a powerful tool for both infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) and platform-as-a-service (Paas). It lets you provision, deploy, monitor and manage nearly every aspect of your applications and infrastructure. Its hybridization allows you to meld your current on-premises environment with the cloud providing excellent scalability and flexibility for your business.
	
	Think of this as an opportunity. Migrating to a cloud-based service allows you to prepare for the next generation of hybrid cloud computing, not to mention the flexibility, agility and scalability—which alone make the move well worth it.
	
	Before you jump headfirst into the crystal clear waters of Windows Server 2012 R2 and Azure, keep in mind that this migration can be challenging. SWC can work with you to access your current environment and design an on-premises, cloud or hybrid model that best fits your organization’s needs.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	SWC hosts free Chicagoland educational events to help get organizations up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, security, IT strategy and digital marketing. Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Networking" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.

		<item>
			<title>Share Files with your Customers Quickly and Easily</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/share-files-with-customers</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 20 Apr 2015 14:07:04 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16546</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[As documents continue to grow in size and detail, it has become a challenge to share these documents with your customers and vendors. End users are often frustrated that a file is too large for their email and IT staff is amazed at the amount of growth in Exchange databases related to all of these large files. Without a centralized system provided by the organization, many end users turn to DropBox, <a title="Microsoft One Drive" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365/onedrive-for-business">Microsoft OneDrive</a> or other free services to share these documents which opens up the organization to the risk of data loss.
			
			SWC recently investigated options to solve this problem and found two systems that make sharing files with customers quickly and easy: Microsoft OneDrive for Business and Citrix ShareFile.
	
	<h2>Microsoft OneDrive for Business</h2>
	OneDrive is Microsoft’s cloud document storage service. OneDrive for Business takes all of the features of OneDrive for personal use or the old SkyDrive and centralizes it for your organization. With OneDrive for Business you can upload and share all of your documents to an easy to use web interface.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-16548 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/One-Drive-500px.png" alt="One-Drive-500px" width="500" height="270" />
	
	As with all <a title="Microsoft Cloud Solution" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services">Microsoft cloud products</a>, one of the benefits of OneDrive is that it integrates with the Microsoft Live ID system. If you are sending documents to a customer or vendor then you don’t need to create an account for them or setup a username and password. Instead, just share the documents to their email address and they can use their Live ID to access them. If you prefer to send a file that doesn’t require a log in, you can do that as well—making it easy to send files that anyone can see. As an added bonus, if your OneDrive includes Office Web Apps, your customers can view and edit the file directly in their browser instead of having to download it.
	
	OneDrive for Business also allows you to share out a folder so you can receive files form a customer or vendor.
	<h2>Citrix ShareFile</h2>
	Are you looking for more security auditing or an on-premises data storage option? Citrix ShareFile may be the solution for you. Just like with OneDrive for Business, ShareFile allows you to share out documents and folders with your customers and vendors, and it also has a web application component to easily view files in any browser. Unlike OneDrive, ShareFile also includes an option to send an upload link to your customers to easily upload their documents. With an intuitive web interface and file management system, ShareFile is one of the easiest tools we have found for sharing documents.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-16547 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Citrix-500px.png" alt="Citrix-500px" width="500" height="266" />
	
	ShareFile’s added benefit lies in its security features. ShareFile reporting allows you to report on file access by either a specific user or by a specific file/folder, so you can see exactly who accessed the files and when they were accessed. ShareFile also allows you to set user permissions to make sure that access to sensitive information is restricted. If you have sensitive data that you are concerned about storing in the cloud, ShareFile also has connectors that allow you to use its interface but store the data in an on-premises server. This lets you control and store the data locally while maintaining the easy-to-use ShareFile interface for your end users and customers.
	
	Do you need help deciding upon and deploying the right file sharing solution? <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact SWC</a> to learn more.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for our Chicagoland Luncheons</h2>
	Today's market leaders are subscribing to cloud based solutions to run their business. <a title="O365 Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365</a> provides powerful and mobile business-class applications for organizations of any size – at a fraction of the cost. Join SWC to learn more about Azure, Office 365 and the new Enterprise Mobility Suite (EMS). Register now at <a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">SWC Events</a>.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed reading this post from Aaron, please check out a few of his past posts:
	
	<a title="Azure Cloud" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack" target="_blank">Creating an Azure Environment On-Premises with Windows Azure Pack</a>
	<a title="Windows Server 2003 EOL" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/server-2003-end-of-life" target="_blank">Preparing for Server 2003 End of Life by Migrating to Microsoft Azure</a>

			<title>Mobilegeddon Has Arrived. Is Your Website Mobile-Friendly?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/mobilegeddon-mobile-friendly-website</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 21 Apr 2015 20:02:20 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Alex Heil]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16644</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[By now you have probably heard of Mobilegeddon, Google’s algorithm update that focuses on the mobile-friendliness of web pages. On February 21, Google posted a blog with this message:
	<blockquote>Starting April 21, we will be expanding our use of mobile-friendliness as a ranking signal. This change will affect mobile searches in all languages worldwide and will have a significant impact in our search results.</blockquote>
	Thankfully, for <a title="Chicago Search Engine Optimization" href="/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">Search Engine Optimization</a>, Google has made a tool to <a title="Google Mobile Friendly Test" href="https://www.google.com/webmasters/tools/mobile-friendly/" target="_blank">test the mobile-friendliness</a> of your webpage. If you’re not sure where to start with all of this, check out their <a title="Mobile Friendly website" href="https://developers.google.com/webmasters/mobile-sites/get-started/" target="_blank">mobile-friendly guide</a>.
	
	<h2>The Importance of Mobile Search</h2>
	It makes sense to award mobile-friendly sites with better rankings in mobile search results. <strong>Smartphones and tablets now account for 60 percent of total digital media time spent.</strong> What’s more, from June to November 2014, 48 percent of Google search traffic came from mobile devices.
	
	It also makes sense to penalize or demote those websites that are not mobile-friendly. How many times have you tried to find information on-the-go, only to land on a page where you had to pinch and zoom and scroll horizontally across the page? Odds are you probably left that page quickly and went somewhere else.
	
	It is important to note that Google’s new mobile algorithm will score each page of your site individually, not sitewide. Android apps will also be indexed.
	<h2>What if My Site Isn’t Mobile-Friendly?</h2>
	There are generally two ways to go about <a title="Mobile Friendly Website" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing" target="_blank">making your website mobile-friendly</a>: creating a dedicated mobile site or employing responsive design (responsive designed websites are those that automatically resize to fit any device). One is not necessarily “better” than the other; it depends on a number of factors such as the type of content you need displayed on your mobile site. If you update your content often, for example, it may be more cost-effective to invest in a responsive website where all of your updates can be made in one place.
	
	SWC has been recognized for our mobile-friendly responsive website designs. One of the latest examples of this is the <a title="Responsive Mobile Design" href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/news/best-in-class-web-design" target="_blank">IMA Best in Class Design Award</a> for Strive Logistics. For more examples of responsive website designs, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> or attend our next<a title="Digital Marketing Chicago Events" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank"> Chicagoland Internet Marketing event</a>.
	<h2>A few additional things to keep in mind:</h2>
	<ul>
		<li>This algorithm update only affects searches done on mobile devices</li>
		<li>Make sure you are not blocking CSS and javascript, as Googlebot must be allowed to crawl these in order for your page to pass mobile-friendliness test.</li>
		<li>Algorithms run in real-time, so you don’t need to wait long to be properly indexed once your site is mobile-friendly</li>
		<li>Remember, Googlebot ranks on a page-by-page basis. If you have more pressing pages that affect your daily mobile traffic, update those first.</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>The Bottom Line</h2>
	<strong>Mobile friendliness is no longer an option - it's a necessity.</strong> Don’t lose valuable mobile visits and potential business. Call 630-572-0240 to review your current website and get a pragmatic, cost-effective pathway to optimizing your website.<h3>Related Blogs</h3>
	If you enjoyed this blog, please check out a few of our related SEO and Digital Marketing blogs:
	<a title="SEO User Experience" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/user-experience-making-sustainable-seo-strategy" target="_blank">User Experience: The Makings of a Sustainable SEO Strategy</a>
	<a title="Google Twitter Deal" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/twitter-google-deal" target="_blank">Twitter Strikes Deal to Show Tweets in Google Search Results</a>
	<a title="SEO Technology" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/search-engine-technology-changing-seo" target="_blank">How Search Engine Technology Is Changing the Way We Think About SEO</a>
	<a title="Website Resign Example" href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/news/best-in-class-web-design" target="_blank">SWC Wins IMA Best in Class Design Award for Strive Logistics’ Website Redesign</a>
	
	<h3>What You Need to Know about SEO</3>
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/SEO-stats-infographic-2.png"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/SEO-stats-infographic-2-196x300.png" alt="SEO-stats-infographic-2" width="196" height="300" class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-15563" /></a>
	
	<strong>Sources</strong>
	<a href="http://www.comscore.com/Insights/Blog/Major-Mobile-Milestones-in-May-Apps-Now-Drive-Half-of-All-Time-Spent-on-Digital" target="_blank">comScore Media Metrix Multi-Platform, U.S., Feb – May 2014</a>

		<item>
			<title>Comparing CRM Software: Microsoft Dynamics vs. Salesforce</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/comparing-crm-software-microsoft-vs-salesforce</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 23 Apr 2015 13:45:19 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Will Robinson]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16672</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of the most popular requests we get asked at our <a title="Microsoft Dynamics Event" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">CRM Chicagoland luncheons</a> is to compare <a title="Microsoft Customer Management System" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management" target="_blank">Microsoft Dynamics CRM</a> to <a title="Salesforce.com CRM" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm/salesforce-com-customer-relationship-management" target="_blank">Salesforce</a>. Probably not a surprise - a vast majority of the companies we talk to who are looking at a CRM system are selecting between Microsoft and Salesforce, both leaders in the <a title="Best CRM Systems" href="http://www.gartner.com/technology/reprints.do?id=1-1XJHQ4X&amp;ct=140716&amp;st=sb" target="_blank">Gartner Magic Quadrant</a> for sales force automation.
			
			The marketing engines of both of these companies are powerful and well-funded. What companies do find is that both Microsoft and Salesforce provide a significant amount of functionality compared to other vendors. It's still rather unusual to see CRM solutions with sales pipeline management, drag and drop dashboarding for management, email marketing, marketing automation and customer service under one umbrella or product line. Most of the competitors are still trying to be great at one thing. Meanwhile, Salesforce and Microsoft are providing the ability for companies to create a 360 degree view of their existing and potential customer base – their sales pipeline.
	<h2>Microsoft vs. Salesforce</h2>
	Let's compare Microsoft to Salesforce. Which one is the best? The answer (shockingly) is that it depends and it’s always changing. That's a major benefit of vendors who provide cloud software solutions, they are constantly being updated. Here is what I tell those who attend SWC’s <a title="Chicago CRM" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">CRM events</a>:
	<h3>Microsoft Dynamics CRM Advantages</h3>
	<ul>
		<li>Simpler licensing model – most features are included</li>
		<li>Better Outlook and Office integration – better user experience and less configuration for admins</li>
		<li>Great for when you need on-premises CRM</li>
		<li>Newer User Interface</li>
		<li>Small, but growing marketplace</li>
	</ul>
	<em>Consider When:</em>
	<ul>
		<li>You have a Microsoft Enterprise Agreement – CRM licenses can be added creating licensing management efficiencies</li>
		<li>Seamless integration with Outlook is needed</li>
		<li>You’re an Office 365 customer or heavy Microsoft shop</li>
		<li>You’re a Dynamics AX customer</li>
		<li>You need on-premises custom systems integration</li>
		<li>Your budget is tight and you need features such as mobile</li>
	</ul>
	<h3>Salesforce Advantages</h3>
	<ul>
		<li>Complex pricing model – “a la carte” pricing and monthly fees to use APIs on some licenses</li>
		<li>Market leader in terms of adoption</li>
		<li>User Interface hasn't changed much in years</li>
		<li>Strong marketplace for add-ons</li>
	</ul>
	<em>Consider When:</em>
	<ul>
		<li>You are not a Microsoft shop – you can get aggressive pricing from Salesforce</li>
		<li>Salesforce AppExchange provides a vertical solution that fits your needs</li>
		<li>You need sophisticated Marketing Automation solution</li>
	</ul>
	SWC Technology Partners provides expertise in both Salesforce and Microsoft Dynamics CRM systems. If you would like us to walk you through the comparison in more detail, feel free to <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">email us</a> or call 630.572.0240. We frequently run CRM Strategy Sessions (less than week) and CRM Discovery Sessions (2-3 weeks) to help organizations figure out which product is the best solution for their needs and requirements.
	<h3>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h3>
	
	For more information on industry leading CRM solutions and sales force best practices, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> or join us for our next <a title="CRM Chicago Luncheon" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">complimentary Chicagoland event</a>.

			<title>Extending Your Domain into Microsoft Azure: It’s Not as Scary as You Think</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/extending-domain-microsoft-azure</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 27 Apr 2015 17:46:36 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16696</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[When Microsoft first released their Infrastructure as a Service (Iaas) offering within Azure, one of the most common questions was how to deal with domain controllers. For many organizations, if you can’t extend your domain into Azure then you are limited in what you can do. For many, this was initially a somewhat complicated and scary process.
	
	In the past six months, Microsoft has worked hard at updating Azure Virtual Machines and Azure Networking to make adding a domain controller into Azure safe and practical. Here’s what has changed and what you need to consider before extending your domain into Azure:
	<ol>
		<li><strong>Site-to-Site Tunnels</strong> – As with any secondary location, to extend your on-premises domain into Azure you need to have a tunnel between the two environments. Azure is now fully capable of making tunnels with all major brands of firewalls including Cisco, SonicWALL, Fortinet, Juniper, Palo Alto and many others. For organizations with multiple locations, depending on your firewall device, Azure can also establish a multi-site tunnel allowing all of your remote locations to connect to the same Azure environment.</li>
		<li><strong>Static IP Address</strong> – For any domain controller, one of the main requirements is a Static IP address to ensure that DNS can successfully connect and Active Directory requests will succeed. In previous versions of Azure, there was no option for reserving an IP address to a VM and instead there were various workarounds that risked the IP changing if the machine was shut down. In the newest version of Azure, options have been added to reserve a static IP for any VM. With one quick command your domain controller can now have a dedicated IP that is reserved and will never change, even if the machine is shut down or restarted.</li>
		<li><strong>Active Directory Database Caching</strong> – Like any database, the Active Directory database can be damaged if the server does not shut down cleanly. While this is unlikely in Azure, this was a concern because the operating system drive on all VMs uses caching technology which might not write back all changes to the database in the event of a dirty shutdown. To resolve this concern, Azure now has easy options for adding additional data disks to the domain controller that do not use caching. These drives are fully supported for the Active Directory database and ensure that the risk to the database is minimal in the event of a shutdown.</li>
	</ol>
	But what about Azure Active Directory? We are often asked if Azure AD can be used as a replacement or a supplement for a domain controller. Unfortunately, at this time Azure AD is purely a user database and is not designed for computer accounts or for managing computer logins. If you are interested in putting your domain into Microsoft Azure, your best solution is still to install a domain controller using Azure Virtual Machines.
	
	SWC has experience setting up many domain controllers in Azure and we are always <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">available to help</a> you design your deployment and extend your environment into Azure. Contact us at 630.572.0240 to learn more.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post on Microsoft Azure, please check out a few of SWC’s past related posts:
	<a title="Azure Web Hosting" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/flexible-scalable-web-hosting-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Flexible and Scalable Web Hosting with Microsoft Azure</a>
	<a title="Azure Pack" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack" target="_blank">Creating an Azure Environment On-Premises with Windows Azure Pack</a>
	<a title="Server 2003 EOL" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/server-2003-end-of-life" target="_blank">Preparing for Server 2003 End of Life by Migrating to Microsoft Azure</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Azure Deployment" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/deployments-azure-microsoft-cloud" target="_blank">Deployments and Rollbacks in Azure</a>
	<a title="Microsoft Azure Help Desk" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-azure-reduce-helpdesk-calls-increase-security" target="_blank">How Microsoft Azure Can Reduce Help Desk Calls and Increase Security</a>
	<a title="Microsoft System Center" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/move-hyper-v-virtual-machine-into-microsoft-azure-using-system-center" target="_blank">How to Move a Hyper-V Virtual Machine into Microsoft Azure Using System Center</a>
	<a title="Azure Cloud Autoscaling" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/performance-schedule-autoscaling-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Performance and Schedule Autoscaling in Microsoft Azure</a>

	</content:encoded>
