			<title>How Website Security Impacts SEO</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/website-security-search-engine-optimization</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 29 Apr 2015 13:45:53 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mary]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16700</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Certainly by now most companies have either heard about or experienced for themselves the devastating setbacks that can take place from both a revenue standpoint and a reputation standpoint when a cyber-security breach occurs. But just in case you didn’t already have enough reason to <a title="Sony Cyber Attack" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/sony-hack-malware-protection" target="_blank">not want to become the next Sony</a>, I have one more reason for you – <a title="SEO and Security" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">Search Engine Optimization (SEO)</a>. You’re not the only one who cares if your site is secure, your customers care and therefore Google cares, too.
	
	<em><strong>UPDATE:</strong> According to <a href="http://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.com/2015/05/new-research-ad-injection-economy.html">new research</a> published on <strong>May 6, 2015 </strong>from Google and UC Berkley, 5.5% of unique IP addresses are infected with adware. When you think about the number of websites that exist today, 5.5% accounts for more than 5 million websites. Google's radar for adware issues is heightened by the fact that they have received 100,000 user complaints about them in Chrome since the beginning of 2015. There are more complaints about adware than any other issue... These numbers are staggering and can only suggest that Google has taken a renewed interest in website security. We can expect more information to arise on this topic in the coming months. Stay tuned!</em>
	
	Over the past year, we’ve talked a lot about the importance of user-friendliness for SEO. As technology changes, the expectations of your users change as well. Certain features and functionalities of your website go from being nice things to have to absolute necessities for staying in the good graces of consumers. And with 93% of all online experiences beginning with a search engine, Google has a keen interest in understanding what the users want and serving up the websites that deliver it to them. This became all the more evident on April 21, 2015 when Google announced their new algorithm update which now penalizes websites that are not mobile-friendly – the update has since been coined, “<a title="Google mobile update" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/mobilegeddon-mobile-friendly-website" target="_blank">Mobilegeddon</a>.” Overnight, mobile-friendly websites went from being nice things to have to being absolutely necessary. <a title="Responsive mobile design" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/search-engine-technology-changing-seo" target="_blank">Don’t say we didn’t warn you</a>!
	
	As we continue to drive better SEO in anticipation of the changes in technology, it’s only natural that we put website security front and center. Hackers are becoming increasingly more capable of installing malicious code, redirecting your website to another, pulling private data such credit card information or removing your website completely. If a consumer lands on your website while it’s down, or worse, has their sensitive information stolen, they not only blame the website itself but also the search engine that served them the harmful link in the first place.
	
	So, what is Google doing to protect their web browsers from harmful sites? They are warning searchers by labeling potentially dangerous websites with the simple line, “This site may harm your computer” below the title of your listing in the search engine results page. Are you at risk for getting tagged with a malware warning? If so, there are steps you can take to prevent this label from happening. Ideally, of course, you’ll want to take these steps before Google identifies your site as being dangerous to consumers.
	
	Taking website security a step further, Google recently updated it’s algorithm this past August by giving a ranking boost, albeit a very weak ranking boost, to those websites that are secure with a HTTPS encryption. If you are an eCommerce website that handles sensitive passwords or credit card information, a HTTPS encryption is especially important to your business. However, with more than 200 ranking signals, regular content websites can get away without one. At least for now.
	
	That being said, just like Google’s “Mobilegeddon,” that we could spot from a mile away, all signs point to security becoming a bigger ranking factor in the coming years for all websites. Google even states that they “may decide to strengthen” the security signals in the future (hint, hint, nudge, nudge). If you have not taken steps to ensure a more secure website, here are some things you should be doing now:
	<ul>
	<ul>
		<li>Stay up-to-date on your webserver software</li>
		<li>Keep your Wordpress plugins up-to-date</li>
		<li>Verify ownership of your website</li>
		<li>Maintain the security of you own computer files</li>
		<li><a title="Cyber Security Employee Training Program" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/email-phishing" target="_blank">Train your employees on how to spot malicious files</a></li>
		<li>Monitor your site for common vulnerabilities</li>
		<li>HTTPS encryption – especially if you are handling sensitive information such as passwords or credit cards</li>
	</ul>
	</ul>
	Worried about the health of your website? Have you been hacked in the past? We can help! Our <a title="Cyber Security Solutions" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">Security Services</a> and <a title="SEO Consultants" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">SEO experts</a> can identify your site’s vulnerabilities and assist with removing malicious code, secure your site with HTTPS encryption and help keep you from suffering major setbacks in revenue, reputation and ranking due to future attacks.
	<h2>Want to learn more about SEO?</h2>
	Attend SWC’s <a title="Internet Marketing Event" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland SEO and Internet Marketing event</a> where Mark Fitzsimmons and Kristen Schmid showcase “best-in-class” examples of web design, Search Engine Optimization and digital marketing strategy. This complimentary event is a great opportunity to begin the conversation around SEO and Security and see what actually works from today’s market leaders.

	If you enjoyed this post from Mary, please check out a few of our past related posts.

	<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/ip9j7NL3S7U?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox;width=720;height=480;"><img src="/uploads/chicago-digital-marketing-seo-video.png" alt="Chicago Website Design and SEO" width="500" height="281" /><![CDATA[></script></content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>System Center 2012 R2 &amp; the Security Frontier</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/system-center-2012-r2-security</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 01 May 2015 13:46:31 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[kurtmayer]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16721</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[In a cloud-connected world, <a title="Security Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services" target="_blank">information security</a> and technical vulnerability are a rapidly evolving landscape. It seems every week there are reports of some new hack or exploit that can afflict small businesses and large corporations alike.
	
	The good news is – you may already have some powerful tools at your disposal to help guard your network, such as the <a title="Microsoft System Center" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/microsoft-system-center-2012-r2" target="_blank">Microsoft System Center 2012 R2</a> suite. <strong>While System Center won’t remove the need for dedicated security appliances and procedures, it can be used as a versatile toolset to complement your defense arsenal.</strong>
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-16722 " src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/SWC-Security-1024x538.png" alt="SWC-Security" width="474" height="249" />
	
	Patching with Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) keeps systems up-to-date and is the first line of defense against known exploits. For instance, when a recently released <a title="Web Security Update" href="https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/3002657" target="_blank">Microsoft security update like KB3002657 </a> is announced, WSUS integrated into <a title="System Center Configuration Manager" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/integrating-microsoft-system-center-configuration-manager-2012-r2" target="_blank">System Center Configuration Manager </a>(SCCM) will report in the console on which machines need it; it can then be scheduled and pushed out as per corporate policy within defined maintenance windows.
	
	Within SCCM, several other mechanisms can be useful for security purposes. Machines can be pre-provisioned with BitLocker, a full disk encryption feature and SCCM can push Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM) agents. Baselines and compliance can auto-install corporate mandated software, like Endpoint Protection for antivirus, or trigger uninstalls of unapproved applications. Software inventory and application metering provides an overview of software present in the environment. In case of a vulnerability, such as the recently disclosed <a href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/security/ms14-064.aspx" target="_blank">critical CVE-2014-6332</a>, SCCM can perform file gathering operations to report on things like version information and date/timestamps so administrators can more quickly identify affected systems. Used in conjunction with the <a title="Defense against cyber attacks" href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/security/jj653751" target="_blank">Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit </a>(EMET), remediation can be undertaken.
	
	<a title="System Center Operations Manager" href="/solutions/microsoft-system-center/operations-manager-scom">System Center Operations Manager (SCOM)</a> has a component called Audit Collection Services (ACS), which can collect logs from domain controllers into a database for analysis and reporting; or author a management pack to present a subset of this information directly within the SCOM console. SCOM can be used to coordinate approvals for Change Management when conducting emergency patching, so the process can be reviewed and tracked later. Further customization could be implemented with Orchestrator, such as to pull and parse data from other security systems. If there is need to restore in the event of corruption, call on Data Protection Manager (DPM).
	
	The System Center suite itself aspires to be secure, as many elements utilize computer or web certificates to secure communications between agents and servers when available, for things like IIS and SQL Reporting Services. Role Based Access Control (RBAC) is implemented to provide granular access levels for various tiers of IT support staff in order to grant rights only to those who need it.
	<blockquote>SWC has a knowledgeable staff of IT security professionals that can help take your security infrastructure to the next level with network intrusion detection, perimeter defense mechanisms, audits, penetration testing and security as a managed service.</blockquote>
	As previously stated, System Center won’t remove the need for dedicated security appliances and procedures but can be used to compliment your defense arsenal. So, if you’ve got it, leverage it! And, if you’re thinking about deploying it, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">ask swc</a> what you can do to maximize your ROI with Microsoft System Center!<h3>Recommended Microsoft System Center Posts</h3>

		<item>
			<title>Use Veeam Backup Copy to Replace Your Tape Drive</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/veeam-backup-security-solution</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 05 May 2015 14:04:31 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16729</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Veeam Backup and Replication is a backup application that SWC has recommended to a number of organizations. For both VMware and <a title="Microsoft Hyper-V" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/virtualization/microsoft-hyper-v" target="_blank">Hyper-V</a> virtual environments, Veeam is designed to perform virtual machine level backups so that organizations can restore anything from an individual file within a server all the way up to the entire virtual machine file as a whole. Veeam also includes tools for <a title="Microsoft Exchange Online" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365/exchange-online" target="_blank">Microsoft Exchange</a>, <a title="Microsoft Sharepoint" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint" target="_blank">SharePoint</a>, Active Directory and SQL which make restoring data to those applications quick and easy.
	
	When using any backup solution, one of the most common questions we get asked is, “How can I get rid of the tape drive?” While Veeam has tape drive support and can be configured to work with a tape system, it also has a feature called Backup Copy which can help make your tape drive no longer necessary.
	
	Veeam Backup Copy is designed to replicate your existing backup files to an alternate location. Once the Veeam software performs your regular nightly backup, Backup Copy can be scheduled to take that backup file and run an incremental backup against it to an alternate location. Since only the changes in the backup are transferred, the copy can often be done in a matter of minutes—even over a WAN connection. The benefit of Backup Copy is that because it is processing the backup files, it does not require any interaction with the virtual machine or the hypervisor, thereby having zero impact on your production systems.
	<h2>Veeam Backup Copy and the Cloud</h2>
	The target for a Veeam Backup Copy can be any Windows server with available storage. Pairing Veeam with a <a title="SWC Cloud Services" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">cloud service </a>such as Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services, or the SWC Cloud allows for easy offsite replication of your backups. Any organization that has multiple locations can also use Veeam Backup Copy to replicate backups between sites for greater redundancy.
	
	Backup Copy can be scheduled with different retention periods and synchronization schedules allowing for a similar experience to tapes but without the hassle of ever having to rotate a tape or remember to take it offsite. Backup Copy files are also archive-ready files that can be stored on external hard drives, or, if small enough, burned to media for long-term retention. These files can then be imported into any Veeam environment—not just the system that created them—for easy recovery in the event of an outage or disaster.
	<h2>WAN Accelerator Optimizes Available Bandwidth</h2>
	If your organization has a large amount of data that is changed in the backups each night, then bandwidth is often a concern. Veeam recognized this concern and created an optional component called the WAN Accelerator to help optimize any available bandwidth.
	
	By default, Veeam compresses the data to reduce the amount transferred before sending it to the target server. The WAN Accelerator takes it one step further and performs deduplication on the data as it is being transferred. In order to ensure backup integrity, the backup files themselves are not deduplicated, but the WAN Accelerator can monitor the traffic that is waiting to be sent across the link and then determine if it already exists at the target WAN Accelerator’s cache. If it does exist, instead of being transferred across the link a second time, the required data is copied from the cache at the target end, allowing for quick local copy and reduced bandwidth requirements.
	
	<strong>Bottom line:</strong> If you are sick of your tape drive and are either already using Veeam or have a virtual environment, then Veeam Backup Copy may be a good solution.
	
	At SWC, we work with a number of cloud vendors, including Veeam, to find the perfect solution to grow your organization. We believe the cloud is for everyone, but not for everything, so you’ll only get the solutions that are right for you. Plus, with our extensive technical background and experience, we know exactly what requirements to consider before moving over your applications and systems.
	
	For more information on moving to the cloud, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> or attend our next <a title="Cloud Solution Chicago Event" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Cloud Chicago luncheon</a>.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	SWC hosts free Chicagoland educational events to help get organizations up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, security, IT strategy and digital marketing. Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Networking" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.
	
	<a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/3FTMiPuY9v0?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-events.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a><h3>Recommended Posts</h3>

		<item>
			<title>QlikView vs. Tableau: Which Business Intelligence Tool is Right for My Organization?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/qlikview-vs-tableau</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 06 May 2015 21:20:19 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jordy McNamara]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16828</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Many companies looking to implement a <a title="Business Intelligence Service" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence" target="_blank">business intelligence solution</a> come to us and ask which product is the best? The answer is – it depends on a variety of factors and what your organization needs the data to do. Two popular visualization products we recommend are <a title="Tableau 8.2 Features" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/new-features-tableau-8-2" target="_blank">Tableau </a> and QlikView. Read my blog to learn more about which product is right for your organization.
	
	<h2>Chicago Area Business Intelligence Solutions 630-572-0240.</h2>
	
	Tableau is a visually rich and highly intuitive drag and drop business intelligence product that people of any skill level can use to analyze data. Tableau gives users the ability to query relational databases, cubes, cloud databases, and spreadsheets and then generate shareable graphs. Tableau also makes it easy to store data from Salesforce, Google Analytics, or any of your databases and then set up automatic refreshes to make sure everyone is working off the same up-to-date data.
	
	Similarly, QlikView also boasts easy drag and drop data analysis and visualization capabilities for the layman. Like Tableau, data from the web, databases, spreadsheets, and other areas can be integrated. Charts, tables, and graphs are wired together, and your insights are easily shareable. QlikView’s responsive interface adapts to any device, and developers can build custom apps and visualizations with open-end APIs.
	
	QlikView and Tableau offer strong dashboard and visualization capabilities. However, fundamental differences exist, making it important for any company to understand its user base, as well as how—and for what purpose—the tool will be used, before deciding which solution is the ‘right’ fit. <strong>So how do they stack up?</strong>
	<h2>Tableau vs. QlikView—Side-by-Side Comparison</h2>
	
	<table>
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td style="text-align: left;">
	<h2><span style="color: #ffffff;"><strong>Category</strong></span></h2>
	</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">
	<h2><strong> <span style="color: #ffffff;">Tableau</span></strong></h2>
	</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">
	<h2><span style="color: #ffffff;"><strong>QlikView</strong></span></h2>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Visualization Capabilities</strong></td>

	</ul>

	</td>

		<li>Extremely easy to adopt across all user types</li>
	</ul>

		<li>Intuitive to build dashboards and explore data regardless of technical ability or background</li>
		<li>Extremely easy to adopt across all user types</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Reporting</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Superior selection of visualization styles</li>
		<li>Enables easy development of creative and flexible data displays in seconds</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Strong visualization capabilities, offering less flexibility but greater interactivity</li>
		<li>More time intensive formatting process</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Miscellaneous Features</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Superior selection of visualization styles</li>
		<li>Enables easy development of creative and flexible data displays in seconds</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Strong visualization capabilities, offering less flexibility but greater interactivity</li>
		<li>More time intensive formatting process</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	</tbody>
	</table>
	
	<h2>Analysis Tools</h2>
	QlikView has been described by its users as a BI solution with a developer’s point of view and may be best suited for a company that understands its data and has concrete questions it hopes to answer. It provides strong flexibility in building a dashboard through its unique approach to data integration which provides faster calculations within the software for interactive queries and reporting. It maintains an easy reporting functionality and a clear structure with extensive filtering options that carry over from sheet to sheet.
	
	Perhaps QlikView’s greatest differentiator is its drilldown capabilities. QlikView is best leveraged by a developer or dashboard author with at least some familiarity with basic VBA programming or Excel forms experience, while consumers of the dashboard require little technical background for adoption.
	
	Tableau, in contrast, is a BI solution with an analyst’s perspective. For a company with a large amount of data available but unclear insight into what challenges it may help solve, Tableau can serve as a powerful data exploration tool that delivers insight in seconds and provides the flexibility to change views—and the question it’s answering—on the fly with just a few clicks. Its range of visualization options is unmatched, allowing its users to view the same set of data in a variety of ways.
	
	Tableau’s greatest differentiator is its intuitive design and UI, making it easy for any user, regardless of technical expertise, to very quickly build instant and real-time dashboards and perform ad-hoc, personalized analysis to inform decision making.
	
	We are big proponents of these two powerful BI tools here at SWC. To learn more about how Tableau and QlikView can propel your BI and data visualization needs, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact swc</a> or attend our next <a title="Business Intelligence Event Oak Brook" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Business Intelligence Chicagoland event</a>.
	
	<h2>SWC's Approach to Business Intelligence</h2>

			<title>What&#039;s Next for System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM)</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/sccm-updates-2015</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2015 18:56:38 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[jeffpoling]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16867</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[At the Ignite Conference, Microsoft provided exciting new details about the future of <a title="Microsoft System Center 2012 R2" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center" target="_blank">Microsoft System Center</a> Configuration Manager (SCCM). With the upcoming <a title="Release Date Windows 10" href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/downloadable-windows-10" target="_blank">release of Windows 10</a> this summer, enterprises need to be able to support the deployment and management of the new operating system on a diverse ecosystem of devices. SCCM continues to be the standard for on-premises management of those devices.
	<h2>What Is Next for Configuration Manager in 2015?</h2>
	In order to support the deployment and management of Windows 10 with existing SCCM installations, Microsoft plans to release a service pack for Configuration Manager 2012 SP1 and Configuration Manager 2012 R2.
	
	<strong>This service pack includes:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>Full support with existing features for Windows 10 deployment and management</li>
		<li>App-V publishing performance improvements</li>
		<li>Increased scalability – Hierarchies can now support 600,000 clients while primary/standalone sites can support 150,000 clients</li>
		<li>Improved Content Distribution – Improvements around content distribution for both slow and high latency networks as well as pull distribution points</li>
		<li>Support SQL 2014 as the database backend</li>
		<li>Support for conditional access policy, mobile application management and Apple Device</li>
		<li>Enrollment Program when integrating SCCM with Microsoft Intune</li>
	</ul>
	In addition to the service pack for existing SCCM installations, the technical preview of the next version of SCCM is available now.
	<h2>SCCM Technical Preview Features and Improvements:</h2>
	<ul>
		<li>In addition to the typical refresh and replace scenarios for operating system deployment, Windows 10 adds in-place upgrades. The next version of SCCM adds support for an in-place Windows 10 upgrade with OS deployment task sequences</li>
		<li>SCCM installation on Azure Virtual Machines</li>
		<li>SCCM integration with Microsoft Intune allows for the mobile device management of Windows 10 devices without the requirement to store data in the cloud. This is a key feature for managing devices that do not have internet access, such as the "Internet of Things" devices.</li>
	</ul>
	Finally, to support the deployment of Windows 10, an update for the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit is planned that will include support for Windows 10.
	
	Everyone at SWC is excited about the announcements from Microsoft this week. For additional information about the exciting updates to SCCM, subscribe to our blog.
	
	If you would like assistance planning your move to the new version of SCCM or Windows 10, please <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">reach out to SWC</a>.
	<h2>Want to learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	SWC hosts free Chicagoland educational events to help get organizations up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, security, IT strategy and digital marketing. Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Networking" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.
	
	<a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/3FTMiPuY9v0?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-events.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a><h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you would like to learn more about Microsoft System Center, please check out a few of our past posts:

			<title>Where Your CRM Implementation is Failing to Gain Traction and How to Fix It</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/how-to-fix-crm-system</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 13 May 2015 22:30:29 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Will Robinson]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16877</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[When we ask our customers why their <a title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM" href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management/crm-2013" target="_blank">CRM systems</a> are largely unused by their marketing and sales teams, there is usually a long pause that follows. We've found that long pause represents uncertainty about the true reason why the team struggles with getting a CRM system that is used throughout the organization.
	
	A recent study by <a title="CRM Study" href="http://www.merkleinc.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2013/merkle-executive-survey-effective-customer-relationship#.VUjCIvlViko" target="_blank">Merkle Inc</a>. backs up this point. Their study shows that "CRM success" fails due to the following reasons:
	<ol>
		<li>CRM projects are failing the organization</li>
		<li>Lack of ownership of customer insights</li>
		<li>Lack of management availability</li>
		<li>Lack of executive sponsorship</li>
		<li>Not an IT priority</li>
	</ol>
	Let's take these one at a time and talk about how to possibly remedy the issue.
	<h2>1. CRM Projects are Failing the Organization</h2>
	We see CRM projects not live up to the hype primarily because the system is built to solve the wrong problems or they don't solve any big problems. The first time around, companies frequently want to spend the least amount of money and time to implement the system. The initial step of defining what's important to your marketing and sales team is glossed over quickly so that the team can begin configuring the system. It's a step that feels like a waste of time, but it is not. It's actually the most important step! It requires getting decision makers in a room for a few hours a day over the course of a week. That's a big commitment to many people. However, it is well worth it. Our Discovery sessions address this challenge.
	<h2>2. Customer Insights are Lacking</h2>
	CRM systems are built to hold information about your customers. When a CRM system can provide a 360 degree view of your customer base (both potential and existing), you have hit the jackpot. A common issue arises during the early stage of the project where leadership is not in the room to define how the company measures success. This would translate into reports that provide insight into how the business is doing. These reports show up in weekly and monthly meetings as the foundation for decision making. This usage pattern will then trickle down into influencing how your sales and marketing staff manage their customer data in the CRM system.
	
	A common problem is that the project team settles for the native reporting that a CRM system provides. A common mistake is that the project team believes their company can get away with vanilla reports, when in fact, their business model is unique. The solution is to build reports that are used by the leadership team in their weekly and monthly meetings.
	<h2>3 and 4. Lack of Management Availability and Executive Sponsorship</h2>
	I lumped these two together because they are similar. If you've read points 1 and 2, you realize that this point has a major impact on the success of a CRM system. It is easy for somebody to say that a project fails because they don't have management availability and/or executive sponsorship, but 8 out of 10 times this is due to the fact that the project team has not demonstrated value to management and leadership. They don't see CRM as a game changer. It's an IT project.
	
	One scenario that we've found resonates with this group is the concept of Marketing and Sales Alignment. This is where the marketing and sales teams need to develop a business case for building a system that can measure marketing spend as it relates to sales. If a company can measure the value of their marketing spend, leadership will listen. Marketing automation and sales pipeline management systems are built to solve this problem. Some CRM systems do both. We'll be spending more time in a future article on this concept because it deserves more attention.
	<h2>5. Not an IT Priority</h2>
	I put this last in the list for a reason. If you can put a plan in place to address items 1-4, this does not become an issue. It doesn't become an issue because it will no longer be just another IT project that requires funding with no justifiable return on investment (ROI). It's easy to move a project like this to the bottom. By defining the business value of a CRM project, the project will get funded by the business and naturally move up the project list. It will become an IT priority.
	<h3>How Mature is Your CRM System?</h3>
	Click on the link below to download our free CRM Maturity Model.
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-Download.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16522 size-medium" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-BLOG-GUIDE-300x178.png" alt="CRM-BLOG-GUIDE" width="300" height="178" /></a>

			<title>Azure Static vs. Dynamic Routing Gateways – What’s the Difference &amp; Which One Should I Chose?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/azure-static-vs-dynamic-routing-gateways</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 15 May 2015 18:33:43 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16955</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[When configuring resources in Microsoft Azure, one of the first decisions you have to make as an organization is how to <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack" target="_blank">connect the on-premises environment to Azure</a>. For some organizations ExpressRoute (Azure’s dedicated circuit solution) is the answer, but for many the best choice is to create a site-to-site tunnel using an Azure gateway. In this situation, most people get their networks configured and are ready to create the gateway, when and then you notice that it asks if you want a Static Routing or Dynamic Routing gateway. There is no obvious choice between the two, and in fact the answer to the question can be somewhat complicated. To make it easier, let’s look at the differences between the two gateways:
	<h2>Static Routing Gateway</h2>
	The Static Routing Gateway is the “default” option in that almost any firewall device that can create an IPSec tunnel can connect to a Static Routing Gateway. This is because the following configuration is used for this gateway type:
	<ul>
		<li>A Static Routing Gateway uses IKEv1 for its tunnel connections. This type of tunnel is available on all devices and is the most globally compatible. IKEv2 is also available on many devices but if your firewall does not support it you will need to use a Static Routing Gateway.</li>
		<li>As the name suggests, a Static Routing gateway uses static routing for its connections. What does that mean? It means that both sides of the tunnel have hard coded rules sending specific subnets across the tunnel. This ensures that the traffic for the subnets you specify in your Azure network configuration is transmitted across the tunnel, but if you want to reconfigure your network in the future you have to modify the configuration both in Azure and your firewall. Just as with a firewall you can have static routes or you can use routing protocols (OSPF, RIP, EIGRP, etc.) the Azure Static Routing gateway is the Azure solution for static routes.</li>
	</ul>
	
	So what’s the downside of a Static Routing Gateway? The main consideration is that the static gateway is a single site-to-site connection. For example, if your organization has multiple locations and you would like to create a tunnel from all of your offices back to the same Azure gateway you can’t with a static gateway. Only one tunnel is allowed and all of the other locations will need to route through that primary office first. Static gateways also limit your ability to use point-to-site VPNs and Azure-to-Azure connections which may be of use if you are trying to connect multiple regions or services together.
	<h2>Dynamic Routing Gateway</h2>
	The Dynamic Routing Gateway is the “better” option in that it does not have the limitations of the static routing gateway. In particular, you can have multiple tunnels between on-premises locations and Azure. Dynamic Routing Gateways also support point-to-site VPNs, Azure-to-Azure connections and combinations of the above. However, for a Dynamic Routing Gateway the following configuration is required:
	<ul>
		<li>A Dynamic Routing Gateway uses the IKEv2 protocol for its tunnel connections. As discussed above, not all firewall devices support this tunneling method. If your firewall does not support IKEv2 you will need to contact the vendor to see if it is on their roadmap before you can set up a Dynamic Routing Gateway.</li>
		<li>And so what does dynamic routing mean? In dynamic routing Microsoft is expecting that you will use a routing protocol to communicate subnets across the Azure tunnel instead of sending static routes. This gives greater flexibility in your subnets and makes managing them easier because the routing protocol automatically updates the subnets transmitting across the tunnel, however – again your firewall device needs to support routing protocols across a tunnel.</li>
	</ul>
	So which gateway type do you pick? The answer really comes down to which firewall device you have. Whenever possible, you want to use a Dynamic Routing Gateway, however your firewall must support it. Unfortunately, at the time this blog is being written, many of the most common firewall types – Cisco ASAs, Palo Altos, Sonicwalls and Watchguards to name a few – either do not support IKEv2 or do not support dynamic routing across tunnels and therefore are not compatible with Dynamic Routing gateways. Microsoft maintains a useful list of which devices are and aren’t compatible with which gateway types. That list can be found here: <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/jj156075.aspx" target="_blank">VPN Devices and Azure Gateways</a>
	
	Do you need help setting up your Azure gateway or selecting the right gateway type? SWC has experience in many environments configuring the gateway that suits your organization’s your needs, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> for more information.
	<h2>Join us for lunch!</h2>
	SWC hosts free Chicagoland educational events to help get organizations up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, the cloud, security, IT strategy and digital marketing. Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Networking" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.
	<a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/3FTMiPuY9v0?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-events.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a><h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Aaron, please check out a few of his past posts:
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/veeam-backup-security-solution" target="_blank">Use Veeam Backup Copy to Replace Your Tape Drive</a>

		<item>
			<title>Data Tracking: The Foundation for Strong Business Development Tactics</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/data-tracking-business-development-tactics</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 21 May 2015 13:36:41 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Kristen Schmid]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16972</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Marketing for mid-size business can be challenging. You may not have the resources of a larger enterprise, but still have a desire to bring your “A Game” when it comes to marketing and sales. How should you effectively allocate your business development dollars? The key is to work smarter.
	
	As a mid-size business you may be fighting to gain brand recognition and leads while racing to meet sales’ need for fresh collateral. Your free time is often spent trying to meet leadership’s demands to provide quantifiable campaign returns. Often we are drowning in spreadsheets, PowerPoint slides and a desire to implement the next great idea. We realize we need technology to get it all done, but obtaining that technology is a challenge because a) you don’t have the budget or b) you have the budget but are still waiting on IT to get to you in their queue of projects. So how do you work smarter?
	
	If you’re looking for the technology roadmap with the best return on investment insights, there are great <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm">CRM</a>, <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence">marketing and analytics tools</a> geared for mid-size businesses. For those interested in more information on those tools and the pathway we’ve found most successful in this space, as well as some D-I-Y insights, you may wish to consider attending our <a href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">selling smarter thought leadership series</a>.
	
	The key to implementing any technology, is to first have an awareness of the business development tactics that garner the biggest returns. Here’s some key questions I would first start asking yourself:
	<ul>
		<li>Who are your high-value customers?</li>
		<li>How are you segmenting your customers?</li>
		<li>What defines a qualified lead?</li>
	</ul>
	These questions can help initially funnel your business development strategy. For example, let’s take the first question: Who are your high-value customers? The key term in that question is “high-value.” which can be taken many different ways. Companies may look at their top revenue producers for the year and perhaps even draw some conclusions based upon size and industry as to what makes a “high-value” customer. Do you consider profitability, or the cost to service those accounts? How about the number of referrals that they have provided resulting in future sales? Sales can often provide these anecdotal insights that then begins to drive the sales strategy.
	
	The ideal state is to be able to quantify customer value. Anecdotally it’s the outliers that are often shared as they are the most interesting, but that can bias your corporate decision making process. If you’re not tracking your sales information in a way that can be tied back to demographic data, then start. If you’re not tracking each business development interaction, then start. These are two of the primary factors in the difference between <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/how-to-fix-crm-system" target="_blank">a successful CRM implementation</a> and a failed one.
	
	Now let’s say you have the data and a bit of time – where should you start making sense of all that information? Start with identifying your high-value strategic customers. Then begin to calculate your Customer Lifetime Value (LTV). This process can be a little akin to the infamous chicken and the egg, but that’s okay – the assessment itself can provide a depth of insights that direct your tactics. For example, you may start with a prediction that your high-value customers are those that bring in the top 20% of your annual revenues. You may find that this 20% have some similarities – maybe they are all the same size company, or in the same industry or geo-location. Or maybe they all came in through the same sales person or marketing channel. Interesting right? There are a number of additional elements you need to calculate LTV, which at its most basic level it is:
	<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Average Order Value * Number of ‘Lifetime’ Purchases</strong></p>
	As you review the different insights that go into creating the calculation, you will learn valuable information regarding your target customer. Researching your target customer in turn, will provide valuable insights as to how to best reach them and where to target those business development dollars. But the foundation? The foundation is to start tracking the data.
	
	If you need help building your foundation to stronger business development tactics <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a>.
	<h2>Want to Learn more? Join us for lunch!</h2>
	SWC hosts free Chicagoland educational events to help get organizations up to speed on Microsoft’s latest technology solutions, IT strategy and digital marketing. Feel free to attend one or all of our upcoming <a title="Chicago IT Networking" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland IT events</a>.
	
	<a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/3FTMiPuY9v0?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-events.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a><h3>Recommended Posts</h3>

		<item>
			<title>Microsoft’s Annual Technology Roadmap Event Recap</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-technology-roadmap-event-recap</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 26 May 2015 14:00:47 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=16979</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC was recently selected by Microsoft to host their annual Technology Roadmap Event at their Midwest District Headquarters in Indianapolis, Indiana. The event was a huge success and we had a great turnout and engaging audience. Nearly 50 IT leaders joined us to hear Microsoft’s vision around productivity with <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365</a>, data insights with <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365/power-bi" target="_blank">Power BI</a>, the <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">Azure Cloud</a> and the <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-windows/downloadable-windows-10" target="_blank">road to Windows 10</a>.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16985" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/microsoft-technology-roadmap-blog.png" alt="microsoft-technology-roadmap-blog" width="500" height="280" /></a>
	<p style="text-align: center;">For those of you who couldn’t join us, you can download a copy of our <a href="http://www.swc.com/Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank">Microsoft Indiana Roadmap event slides</a> here.</p>
	
	One of the highlights of the event was hearing from two of our Indiana customers, T2 Systems out of Indianapolis and Ash Brokerage out of Fort Wayne speak about their decision to move to the Microsoft cloud. Here is a recap:
	<h2>T2 Systems Talks Microsoft Office 365</h2>
	Jim Hutchins, CIO and EVP of IT and Grant Dawson, Director of IT at T2 Systems spoke about their decision to move to Microsoft’s Office 365 stack and their experience leveraging <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365/exchange-online" target="_blank">Microsoft Exchange Online</a>, <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint" target="_blank">SharePoint Online</a> and Office 365 Apps. The move to Office 365 solved a business challenge, enabling them to be more flexible for Mergers and Acquisitions and freed up T2 Systems’ core team so that they could be dedicated to their customers rather than their infrastructure. One of the important points brought up by Jim was around user adoption and communication. This was key to get user buy in and champions in each department were designated to ensure successful adoption of the new technology. Jim mentioned that as they move forward with future acquisitions, he will emphasize the importance of user adoption and communication even more (a key differentiator for SWC when it comes to Office 365). When we asked Grant what new technology in Office 365 he will deploy next, Grant responded enthusiastically with <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications/skype-business" target="_blank">Skype for Business</a>. Grant feels that Skype for Business will not only enrich productivity for his end users, but will also provide tremendous cost savings by replacing their existing conference, web hosting, IM/presence and voice platforms.
	<h2>Ash Brokerage Talks Microsoft Azure</h2>
	David Threm, CIO at Ash Brokerage spoke about the decision to integrate <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services" target="_blank">Microsoft Azure</a> into their infrastructure. Ash Brokerage is currently constructing a new office building with plans to move in 2016. Rather than investing in a huge amount of capital for infrastructure such as storage, David has invested in Microsoft Azure to support the transition. Additionally, David brought up that Azure security and Disaster Recovery was something that he couldn’t hire for and he appreciates Microsoft’s emphasis on data security and redundancy. Microsoft Azure has provided David with an environment where his app developers could quickly test and build applications without burden to his already operationally consumed infrastructure team. In the past, this could cause delays to ongoing infrastructure and development projects or create additional infrastructure spend for hardware and licensing for building applications. With Microsoft Azure, David’s developers can quickly build an app on Azure and deploy services to their customers.
	
	Attendees also learned how to mobilize their workforce with Windows 10, increase business productivity with Office 365, make better decisions with their data using <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence" target="_blank">Microsoft business intelligence solutions</a>, and save time and money by extending their infrastructure to the Azure cloud. Thanks to everyone who attended made this event such a success.
	<h3>Join us for our next Microsoft Technology Event</h3>
	SWC hosts many complimentary technology events on all of Microsoft’s latest mobile, cloud, data and productivity solutions that are helping today’s businesses thrive. Register for one or all of our upcoming <a href="http://swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland Technology events</a>.
	
	<a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/3FTMiPuY9v0?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-events.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>
	
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a>
	<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Pete, check out a few of our previous posts on Microsoft solutions.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/extending-domain-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Extending Your Domain into Microsoft Azure: It’s Not as Scary as You Think</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/making-sharepoint-look-good" target="_blank">Microsoft SharePoint Helps Empower and Enable Users at M. Holland</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/everything-you-need-to-know-about-microsoft-dynamics-crm-2015-release" target="_blank">Everything You Need to Know About the Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 Release</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/predictive-analytics-microsoft-azure-machine-learning" target="_blank">Predictive Analytics Made Easy with Microsoft Azure Machine Learning</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-leads-gartner-magic-quadrant-unified-communications" target="_blank">Microsoft Leads the Gartner Magic Quadrant for Unified Communications</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-mobile-device-management" target="_blank">Built-in Mobile Device Management Is Now Freely Available for Office 365 Commercial Plans</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-2015" target="_blank">What Can We Expect from Microsoft in 2015?</a>

		<item>
			<title>Updating Multiple Records in CRM</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/updating-multiple-records-crm-add-on</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 01 Jun 2015 16:32:24 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Will Robinson]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17013</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm/microsoft-dynamics-customer-relationship-management">Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2013 and 2015</a> have powerful capabilities for sales, marketing and service automation, landing them a spot as a leader in Gartner’s Magic Quadrant for sales force automation and CRM customer engagement. If there was one chink in the armor of Dynamics CRM, it would be the ability to update multiple records at once. If you are a sales professional with dozens of opportunities, you are acutely aware of this issue. One of the most common use cases for sales professionals is to update the Estimated Close Date on opportunities. Instead of opening up each opportunity in a new window, which slows down productivity, the user makes multiple updates at once and saves the changes.
	
	SWC Technology Partners has created an add-on that allows CRM users to update multiple records on one pane of glass or view. The add-on application is called CRM Inline Editor. Here are the features of the CRM Inline Editor:
	<ul>
		<li>Create and/or edit multiple records at once without repeatedly opening new CRM windows</li>
		<li>Can be embedded in a form to quickly add related records to an existing opportunity, account, or any other record type</li>
		<li>Supports all CRM data types, and can be used with either custom or CRM standard record types Screenshots illustrate how a user can quickly add many related records (a custom rent entity) to an opportunity that represents a process for leasing retail property</li>
		<li>When you are done making your changes to the related CRM records, you can click “Save,” or click the “Add New” button to create additional records</li>
	</ul>
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-17016 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-Inline.png" alt="CRM-Inline" width="500" height="382" />
	The CRM Inline Editor can be used for more than opportunity management. More information about the CRM Inline Editor can be found on Microsoft Pinpoint. If you are interested in utilizing this add-on please <a href="http://www.swc.com/contact" target="_blank">contact us</a> or attend our next upcoming<a href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank"> Chicagoland CRM event</a>.
	<h2>Register for Our Upcoming CRM Event</h2>
	Selling Smarter: Using Data to Direct Marketing &amp; Sales Tactics Luncheon
	What asset is leveraged most by thriving organizations? Data. Please join SWC on June 3rd for a complimentary lunch and learn as we discuss how today’s growing companies can compete without spending billions on marketing, sales and technology. We’ll review the common growth challenges and discuss modern best practices including tools that can be leveraged to provide regular reporting, preferred customer segmentation, and real-time dashboard analytics. At this event, we’ll show you how these integrated solutions can help solve common business challenges and get you closer to the goal of maximizing your marketing and sales ROI. <a href="http://www.swc.com/sellingsmarter" target="_blank">Register now</a>.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/data-tracking-business-development-tactics" target="_blank">Data Tracking: The Foundation for Strong Business Development Tactics</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/how-to-fix-crm-system" target="_blank">Where Your CRM Implementation is Failing to Gain Traction and How to Fix It</a>
	<a href=" http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/integrating-microsoft-lync-dynamics-crm-call-tracking" target="_blank"> Integrating Microsoft Lync and Dynamics CRM for Call Tracking</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/dynamic-crm-2015" target="_blank">Dynamics Marketing – Everything You Ever Wanted in a Marketing Automation Platform?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/everything-you-need-to-know-about-microsoft-dynamics-crm-2015-release" target="_blank">Everything You Need to Know About the Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 Release</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/crm-maturity-model" target="_blank">The SWC CRM Maturity Model</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/the-three-main-components-crm-system" target="_blank">The Three Main Components of a CRM System</a>
	<h3>How Mature is Your Sales Process?</h3>
	Click on the link below to download our free CRM Maturity Model.

		<item>
			<title>Top 10 SWC Technology Blog Posts of 2015</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/swc-technology-partners/top-technology-blogs-2015</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 08 Jun 2015 17:02:52 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Alex Heil]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17046</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[The first half of 2015 featured a plethora of big announcements from Microsoft and Google. Not surprisingly, many of these releases, updates, and rollouts are reflected in our top 10 most popular blog posts of 2015. Microsoft Lync got a big rebrand in what is now Skype for Business, while Google made a splash with its mobile search algorithm update. Cloud and BYOD environments continue to trend as more organizations look to cut their infrastructure costs while allowing their workforce greater freedom with always-on access to productivity apps and company data.
	<ol>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/skype-for-business-release" target="_blank">Skype for Business is Coming!</a>
	One of the biggest releases of the year, Microsoft delivered the Skype for Business client patch to Lync 2013 on April 14th, while the official server release went live on May 1st. Microsoft Lync Online (now Skype for Business Online) users are treated to the familiar Skype UI. Whether you’re running your server on-premises or online, you have control over what your users see.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/microsoft-crm-social-listening" target="_blank">Social Listening in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015</a>
	One of the most compelling features in Microsoft Dynamics 2015 is social listening—the ability to analyze what people are saying on social media and on the news. With this tool you can find your key influencers, spot trends and receive alerts on what people are saying about your product or brand. You can also monitor key metrics that determine the sentiment about your business, all the while building deeper relationships with your customers.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/mobilegeddon-mobile-friendly-website" target="_blank">Mobilegeddon Has Arrived</a>
	On February 21st, Google made one of its most significant search algorithm updates to date. Now, the mobile-friendliness of a web page will be reflected in its search engine ranking. Read our post for a free tool that checks the mobile-friendliness of your website.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/identity-manager-2015" target="_blank">The Ever-Changing Landscape of Identity Management</a>
	Microsoft Identity Manager 2015 (MIM), formerly known as Forefront Identity Manager, is part of the Azure Active Directory Premium (AADP) offering and is set to release in the first half of 2015. MIM is an on-premises Identity and Access Management (IAM) system that reduces complexities in managing the identity lifecycle in organizations.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/seo/user-experience-making-sustainable-seo-strategy" target="_blank">User Experience: The Makings of a Sustainable SEO Strategy</a>
	Creating a sustainable SEO strategy doesn’t depend on the system-gaming tactics of Google’s secret algorithms. It means listening to social signals, and creating quality content with well-designed user-friendly websites.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/what-is-microsoft-365" target="_blank">How Can Office 365 Help My Organization?</a>
	The modern workplace faces challenges that Office 365 can solve for users and IT departments. Be productive anywhere on any device; cut hardware, licensing, and operation costs for IT; and reduce the burden on IT with automatic updates in the cloud using Office 365.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/cloud-based-sharepoint" target="_blank">SharePoint On-Premises vs. SharePoint Online</a>
	More and more organizations are moving to Office 365 and as such, moving to SharePoint Online as well. See why hybridization is also a popular option and how SWC can help get you there.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/dynamic-crm-2015" target="_blank">Dynamics Marketing – Everything You Ever Wanted in a Marketing Automation Platform?</a>
	Landing page creation and customization, A/B testing, triggers that allow you to conditionally react according to the action in an email message and scoring a contact’s lead based on their interactions throughout a campaign—all of these are capabilities that put Microsoft Dynamics near the top of the pack in marketing automation software. But does it have everything you ever wanted? Read our blog to learn more.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-2015" target="_blank">What Can We Expect From Microsoft in 2015?</a>
	Updates to Intune, Lync, and Azure; and the arrival of Enterprise Mobility Suite and Windows 10 on July 29th have organizations looking to the cloud to see how they can get the most out of their IT spend.</li>
		<li><a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/server-2003-end-of-life" target="_blank">Preparing for Server 2003 End of Life By Migrating to Microsoft Azure</a>
	Microsoft will no longer push patches and security updates to Server 2003. This means physical and virtualized instances will be vulnerable to security threats. Furthermore, companies that continue to run Server 2003 will fail standard compliance audits. See your options to upgrade before support ends on July 14, 2015.</li>
	</ol>
	<h3>Want to learn more about 2015’s most popular IT topics?</h3>
	
	Join us for lunch! SWC hosts many complimentary technology events on all of Microsoft’s latest mobile, cloud, data and productivity solutions that are helping today’s businesses thrive. Register for one or all of our upcoming <a href="http://swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland Technology events</a>.
	
	<a title="IT Events Chicago" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/3FTMiPuY9v0?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Blog-Video-events.png" alt="" width="620" height="380" /></a>

		<item>
			<title>Secure your Network Access with Azure Multi-Factor Authentication</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/azure-multi-factor-authentication-network-security</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 10 Jun 2015 19:57:24 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17051</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[As the mobile workplace becomes more and more common in the corporate environment, usernames and passwords are often not enough to protect an organization’s network. Just as banks, credit card companies, and sites such as <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365" target="_blank">Office 365</a>, Gmail and Facebook offer a <strong>second level of authentication</strong> via text message or phone call, many organizations are looking to do the same. This provides a higher level of confidence that the person accessing your corporate data is your employee and that any attempts to compromise user passwords will not allow for remote access. If your organization fits into this category, an easy and effective solution is implementing <strong>Azure Multi-Factor Authentication</strong>.
	<h2>How does Azure Multi-Factor Authentication work?</h2>
	Azure Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is a cloud-based service that installs a small utility into your network. For supported applications, this utility intercepts the login request and <strong>after verifying the user name and password it requests a second level of authentication from the user.</strong> This authentication can take multiple forms:
	<ol>
		<li>Azure MFA can call the user on a designated phone number. The user simply presses a key to verify that they initiated a login request.</li>
		<li>Azure MFA can send a text message to a user’s phone with a one-time password. The user enters this password into an authentication prompt to confirm their identity.</li>
		<li>Azure MFA also has a mobile app that can be installed on a user’s phone. This app provides multiple methods for verification that can be configured based on the user’s preference and the specific phone and app model.</li>
	</ol>
	Regardless of the authentication method used, once the user verifies their identity, the utility allows the login request to continue and the user is granted access to the company resource. If the secondary verification does not complete; however, the utility responds to the login request with a failure and the connection is dropped, thus protecting your resources.
	<h2>What can be protected using Azure Multi-Factor Authentication?</h2>
	There are many types of resources that can be protected by Azure MFA. Two of the most common are:
	<ol>
		<li>VPN Connections through RADIUS – The Azure MFA utility can be installed on your Windows Server-based RADIUS server and will perform the secondary authentication for all VPN connections. This ensures that any user connecting to your corporate network is verified both via the RADIUS access rules and by the multi-factor authentication. In addition, since Azure MFA integrates with the RADIUS server itself, this solution is firewall agnostic and will work with any existing firewall you might have in place that supports RADIUS.</li>
		<li>Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS) – Many organizations use ADFS for active directory application authentication both on-premises and in the cloud. Some examples of these applications are Office 365, Microsoft Dynamics CRM, Citrix ShareFile, and Salesforce.com. Azure MFA integrates into the ADFS process to require that second level of authentication when accessing these applications. In addition, ADFS also has advanced options when working with Azure MFA, including only authenticating certain applications, certain users, or only when connecting from outside the corporate network. And just as with RADIUS, because the Azure MFA integrates with ADFS, the solution is application agnostic and can apply to a large range of services.</li>
	</ol>
	Remote Desktop access, IIS based websites and many other systems can also be protected using Azure Multi-Factor authentication.
	<h3>Want to learn more?</h3>
	Azure Multi-Factor authentication can give you that extra peace of mind when considering remote access to your network. If you would like more information about securing your network access, <a href="http://www.swc.com/contact" target="_blank">contact SWC</a> or call 630.286.8138 to speak with one of our Microsoft Azure or security experts.
	<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Aaron, please check out a few of his past posts:
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/azure-static-vs-dynamic-routing-gateways" target="_blank">Azure Static vs. Dynamic Routing Gateways – What’s the Difference &amp; Which One Should I Chose?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/extending-domain-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Extending Your Domain into Microsoft Azure: It’s Not as Scary as You Think</a>

	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack" target="_blank">Creating an Azure Environment On-Premises with Windows Azure Pack</a>

		<item>
			<title>Microsoft Ignite 2015 from a SharePoint Perspective</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-ignite-2015-sharepoint</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 15 Jun 2015 14:34:20 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17062</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[By pretty much any measure, the May 2015 Microsoft Ignite conference was a big deal. Held at McCormick Place in Chicago, Microsoft combined several of its previously separate IT Pro-focused conferences into one huge event. More than 23,000 people attended, with more than 1,100 breakout sessions and countless hours of great information about Windows 10, Exchange, <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications/skype-business">Skype for Business</a>, <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint">SharePoint</a>, Office 365 and more. Over 15,000 people packed into a huge room for the Ignite Keynote, where Satya Nadella and other Microsoft execs laid out their vision for the future.
	<h2>Microsoft Ignite Keynote 2015</h2>
	There were three main points at the core of the keynote, which together define how Microsoft intends to deliver more value in today's rapidly evolving business world:
	<ul>
		<li>Create more personal computing</li>
		<li>Deliver an intelligent cloud back-end</li>
		<li>Reinvent productivity and business processes</li>
	</ul>
	The drill-down on these points highlighted Microsoft's renewed focus on the user experience across all devices, in an almost always connected world, where businesses (and their employees) have different needs and expectations than they did even a couple of years ago. Microsoft continues to accelerate their cloud-first strategy, wherein <strong>new solutions, capabilities and functionality are rolled out to their subscription-based hosted services more quickly than the traditional on-premises product offerings.</strong>
	<h2>The SharePoint Perspective</h2>
	So, what does all that mean to all the people who deploy, administer, manage and use SharePoint? For starters, what I didn’t hear a lot about were details on SharePoint 2016, which is the name for the next major version of SharePoint for on-premises deployments. Microsoft did talk about the “SharePoint Roadmap” in fairly high-level terms, but didn't get very specific. This is understandable, since SharePoint 2016 is more than a year away. But it also means that you can get a lot more insight into the future of SharePoint on-premises by looking at the <a href="http://roadmap.office.com/en-us">Office 365 Roadmap</a>. ”Cloud-first” now truly means that it is <strong>unlikely we'll see any new capabilities in SharePoint 2016 that aren't first deployed in SharePoint Online</strong> (within Office 365).
	
	The other major takeaway for me was that it isn't just about SharePoint anymore. “reinvent productivity and business processes” really means leveraging more of the whole suite of end-user tools that Microsoft provides via Office 365. All of the demonstrations I saw of “next generation portals” focused on OneDrive, Yammer and Office Delve as much as SharePoint.
	
	In particular, Delve and the Office Graph technology behind it, is very exciting. It combines search technology with analytics integration and machine learning to deliver a personal portal that is smart enough to present high-value content targeted to individual users. Here’s what it looks like:
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17063" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Delve.png" alt="Delve" width="400" height="340" />
	
	Perhaps the best part is, through the magic of Office 365, you don't have to do any work to start leveraging Office Delve. It automatically shows up on your Apps menu and it knows how to scour your SharePoint sites, OneDrive folders and other content repositories to find highly relevant content for each individual.
	<h2>What to Expect from Microsoft in 2015 and Beyond</h2>
	Microsoft's promises to create more personal computing, deliver an intelligent cloud backend and reinvent productivity and business processes will directly impact the future of SharePoint and Microsoft's investments in the product. We can expect to see SharePoint Online and the rest of the Office 365 suite evolve more quickly, with new capabilities being subsequently delivered for on-premises deployment scenarios via cumulative updates, service packs and major releases like SharePoint 2016. More than ever, business users will look to IT to provide guidance regarding how to best leverage all the new tools at their disposal. The challenge of balancing between enabling business users to do more on their own while ensuring that they don't end up causing chaos, remains. As always, SWC is here help—feel free to <a href="mailto:jeff.lanham@swc.com">reach out to me directly</a> to discuss how.
	
	Long live SharePoint!
	<h3>Free Offer from Microsoft &amp; SWC</h3>
	Map the road to business success by downloading our free guide!
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a><h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Jeff, please check out a few of his past posts on Microsoft SharePoint.

		<item>
			<title>SWC Employees Enjoy a Week of Extra Perks!</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/swc-employees-enjoys-a-week-of-extra-perks</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 19 Jun 2015 15:28:28 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[patrickorourke]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17143</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[After being recognized by <a href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/news/crains-chicago-business-swc-a-best-place-to-work-2015" target="_blank">Crain’s Chicago Business as A Best Place to Work in 2015</a> for the fourth consecutive year, we decided to hold a weeklong celebration to reward all of our team’s hard work and dedication. <em>SWC Employees – You Rock! Week</em> featured plenty of great food, treats and healthy drinks. On Friday we capped off a week of fun by celebrating with a happy hour party at Weber Grill, where a number of lucky employees took home some big prizes.
	<h2>Day 1: Full Breakfast Bar</h2>
	In true SWC fashion, we decided to start off <em>You Rock! Week </em>with a full breakfast bar! If you speak to anyone who works at SWC, then you know that we have no shortage of food around the office. Whether it’s fresh fruit Tuesdays or catered team meetings, there is always food at the center of our employee interactions. Starting the week with a nice warm breakfast for the entire office was well received by all.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17152 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/crains-1.jpg" alt="crains-1" width="400" height="331" />
	<h2>Day 2: Fruit Smoothie Tiki Bar</h2>
	What’s the only thing better than working at SWC Technology Partners on Tuesday afternoon? Enjoying an ice cold fruit smoothie from a Tiki Bar while working at SWC Technology Partners on a Tuesday afternoon. Employees lined the halls and caught up with colleagues in anticipation of the Tiki Bar. The healthy fruit smoothies were a big hit on a hot Chicago day.
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17153 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/crains-2.jpg" alt="crains-2" width="400" height="331" />
	<h2>Day 3: Gelato from Frost</h2>
	On the third day of our celebration, SWC employees were treated to tasty gelato from Frost. The small flat spoons let you really appreciate how good the gelato tastes. At least a few ice cream to gelato converts were made.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17154 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/crains-3.jpg" alt="crains-3" width="400" height="331" />
	<h2>Day 4: SWC Colors Day</h2>
	Everyone had fun dressing in their favorite SWC colors! Those who did won extra raffle tickets for Friday’s giveaways at Weber Grill. The team enjoyed debating which colleagues’ apparel was truly SWC-colortastic while taking time out to appreciate all of the great people we work with.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17155 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/crains-4.jpg" alt="crains-4" width="400" height="331" />
	<h2>Day 5: Weber Grill</h2>
	After work on Friday afternoon, everyone was invited to celebrate at a happy hour party at Weber Grill. In addition to enjoying great food and drinks, we also gave away some premium prizes including dinner cruises, a hotel stay with spa treatment, cooking classes, gift certificates and even an extra vacation day.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17156 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/crains-5.jpg" alt="crains-5" width="400" height="331" />
	
	After a fun-filled week of eating, drinking, prizes and partying, the team was more than ready for the weekend to start. Happy consultants make happy clients, and we are lucky to have a lot of happy consultants here at SWC Technology Partners.
	
	If you would like to learn more about joining our award winning team, please take a look at our <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers">current Chicago career opportunities</a>. We’d be happy to talk with you!
	
	<a title="Apply For SWC Job" href="https://careers-swc.icims.com/jobs/search?ss=1&amp;searchLocation=&amp;searchCategory=&amp;hashed=0" target="_blank"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-5195" title="apply-btn2" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/apply-btn2.png" alt="Apply For Chicago IT Job" width="142" height="40" /></a>
	
	</content:encoded>
