		<item>
			<title>What Mobile Device Support Does Your Web Application Need?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/application-development/mobile-device-web-application</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 22 Jun 2015 14:02:04 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Tim Archer]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17231</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[The answer is that it depends! As we develop web applications for our clients, part of the design process is to determine what types of mobile devices and optimizations the application needs to support.
	
	Typically the choices include the following options, ranked in order from least to most costly:
	<ol>
		<li>Desktop-only website</li>
		<li>Responsive website</li>
		<li>Mobile website</li>
		<li>Native app</li>
	</ol>
	The goal of this post is to help you understand what each choice means and the pros and cons of each.
	<h2>Desktop-Only Website</h2>
	This is the technology that has been around the longest, and it’s what most people first think of when they imagine their website. If not optimized for mobile, links may be harder to click on a mobile device, the text may be more difficult to read, and content may not display properly.
	<h2>Responsive Website</h2>
	With a responsive website, you leverage the investment already made in your desktop-only website by adding logic that allows this site to adjust itself based on the screen size of the device accessing it. Thus, it “responds” accordingly to the screen real estate.
	
	A responsive website doesn’t scroll horizontally on a mobile device, has text large enough to read without zooming, has plenty of space around buttons and links, and avoids content unplayable on a mobile device. Additionally, Google awards mobile-friendly pages with better rankings in mobile search results. <em>Refer to our blog post on the <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/mobilegeddon-mobile-friendly-website" target="_blank">impact of mobile friendliness</a> on your search rankings. </em>
	<h2>Mobile Website</h2>
	A mobile website is designed specifically for mobile devices and factors in the limitations of the platform. It is typically an entirely different website built and maintained separately from your main desktop website. For example, if your main web address is www.yourcompany.com, you may also develop touch.yourcompany.com or m.yourcompany.com and redirect to it from your main website when it detects a mobile device.
	
	Mobile websites are optimized for fast loading on limited connection speeds, content is easily accessible through touch interactions and is usually laid out as a single, vertically scrolling column. Horizontal scrolling and pop-ups are bad practices on a mobile website. Furthermore, your mobile website is usually required to be responsive as well, due to the wide range of mobile devices, screen sizes and resolutions that must be supported.
	<h2>Native App</h2>
	A native app is developed specifically for an operating system such as iOS, Android or Windows Phone. Each platform requires a separate build of the software. This approach allows the application to take advantage of the capabilities of the device such as the GPS, camera, local storage or barcode scanning. This provides the user with an experience tailored for their device.
	
	<strong>What Option Makes the Most Sense for You?</strong>
	Is your site mobile friendly? Do you want to take your legacy website and make it responsive? Need a native app built? At SWC, we can help you with any option. There is no single solution that is right for every company. Our team of user experience experts, digital designers and programmers take time to understand the ins and outs of your business so that we can design the perfect custom-tailored solution. Call us today at 630.572.0240 or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">email us</a> to see how SWC’s multi-practice expertise can help elevate your digital interactions.
	
	<table>
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Mobile Device Support</strong></td>
	<td><strong>Pros</strong></td>
	<td><strong>Cons</strong></td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Desktop-Only Website</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Easiest to build</li>
		<li>Best for certain types of web applications, such as internal data entry</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>User experience on mobile and tablet devices isn't as good</li>
		<li>No mobile search SEO benefits</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Responsive Website</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>A single website to maintain (leverage existing code)</li>
		<li>Mobile search SEO benefits</li>
		<li>One URL to access your site</li>
		<li>Less expensive than a mobile website or native app</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>A single website to maintain (can make maintenance harder, more to consider for an update)</li>
		<li>Older browser may have compatibility issues</li>
		<li>Harder to get the user experience design right</li>
		<li>Slower on mobile devices than a mobile website</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Mobile Website</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Site loads faster</li>
		<li>User experience tailored to specific screen sizes</li>
		<li>Users don't need to install an app</li>
		<li>Can redirect here automatically from your main website</li>
		<li>Mobile search SEO benefits</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Two sites need to be maintained</li>
		<li>Multiple URLs needed</li>
		<li>Can't access device such as the  camera</li>
		<li>Need to consider design tradeoffs for different types of mobile devices (tablet screen vs. phone screen)</li>
		<li>Requires you to consider changes in screen sizes as new devices come out</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Native App</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Best user experience, tailored for the device</li>
		<li>Access to device features such as GPS and camera</li>
		<li>Speed and accessibility</li>
		<li>Can work offline</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Need to build a version for each device you support</li>
		<li>More code to maintain</li>
		<li>App store approvals required for deployment</li>
		<li>Need to keep up with changes in devices</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	</tbody>
	</table>
	<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post, please read a few of our related posts:
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/mobilegeddon-mobile-friendly-website" target="_blank">Mobilegeddon Has Arrived. Is Your Website Mobile-Friendly?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/performance-schedule-autoscaling-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Performance and Schedule Autoscaling in Microsoft Azure</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/uncategorized/website-redesign-mobile-application" target="_blank">Client Success: Preferred Meals Website Redesign &amp; Mobile Application</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/application-development/custom-application-solutions-efficiently" target="_blank">Creating Great Solutions Efficiently Using Open Source Frameworks Augmented by Some Homegrown Glue and Standardization</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/deployments-azure-microsoft-cloud" target="_blank">Deployments and Rollbacks in Azure</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-design-services/responsive-web-design" target="_blank">Responsive Web Design: A Unified Cross Platform Experience</a>
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Understanding Your Azure Bill</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-azure-billing</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 24 Jun 2015 14:22:39 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Robert Peterson]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17298</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Recently ranked by Gartner as an industry leader due to its ability to help organizations do more, work faster and save money, Microsoft Azure is a great, reasonably priced <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/cloud-services">cloud offering</a>. However, the a la carte service pricing model can add up quickly if you don’t properly manage your Azure implementation. In addition to planning your cloud environment to take advantage of Azure’s sizing and scaling capabilities, it’s also important that you review and monitor your monthly Azure usage and invoice in order to understand where you’re spending your money.
	<h2>The Azure Billing Portal</h2>
	It’s important to review your Azure bill on regular basis so that you have an idea of what usage charges to expect. You are probably already reviewing the PDF version of your Azure invoice and have found that the invoice is an aggregated summary. The lack of details regarding the instance breakdown and the normalization of Cloud Services and Virtual Machine Sizing can make this process confusing. Fortunately, the Azure Billing Portal also provides an option to download the details of your statement as a CSV file. The CSV extract shows the actual usage by instance. Unfortunately, the daily usage section does not contain billing rate information, which can make detail analysis time consuming.
	<h2>Creating a PivotTable Report</h2>
	Your review should be a two-step process. The first step is to view the summary detail in Excel and create a PivotTable report on the name versus the sum of the value (see <a href="https://support.office.com/en-ca/article/Quick-start-Create-a-PivotTable-report-0c220f35-e478-49aa-beaf-24018b7f0f64" target="_blank">Microsoft’s Pivot Tutorial</a>). Typically, you’ll find that Azure App Services, Virtual Machines, and Data Services consume most of your budget. Regardless of the actual split, the initial analysis will provide you with a good idea of what parts of your bill you should be concerned about.
	
	<img class=" wp-image-17302 size-full aligncenter" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Azure-Chart.png" alt="Azure-Chart" width="500" height="324" />
	<h2>Looking At What Matters Most</h2>
	The next step is to drill into the details to see if they match your expectations. This can be done by creating a pivot on the “Details” section of the extract. In order to create the pivot and have the data aggregate correctly, you will need to remove the date from the component description. A good starting pivot would be to view “Name and Component” by sum of the consumed units.
	
	One “gotcha” when reviewing the usage of Cloud Services and Virtual Machines instances is that the consumed units are calculated as Single Processor Instances. When reviewing the details, some items to inspect are:
	<ul>
		<li>Review the services and instances that are incurring charges
	<ul>
		<li>Validate that all the services that you are charged for are actually in use</li>
		<li>Keep in mind that many items that are billed by the hour are billed regardless of activity, even if they are turned off</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
		<li>Review the units that you are being billed for
	<ul>
		<li>For items billed by the hour, compare the billed units to the number of hours in the month to determine the average processor instances used in the month. This number can be helpful when reviewing the sizing and scaling of services in your Azure environment.</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>Actively Manage the Cloud to Save Money</h2>
	Monitoring your Azure spend is an important part of making sure your company's decision to move to the cloud was the right decision. Cloud solutions are only more cost effective then on-premises solutions if they are actively managed. At SWC, we have the expertise to effectively assist you in planning, implementing, and monitoring your cloud solution. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com?subject=Tell%20me%20more%20about%20Microsoft%20Azure">Contact us</a> today and tell us about your cloud or on-premises challenges.
	<h3>Free Offer from Microsoft &amp; SWC</h3>
	Map the road to business success by downloading our free guide!
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a>
	<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Robert, please check out a few of our past related posts.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/performance-schedule-autoscaling-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Performance and Schedule Autoscaling in Microsoft Azure</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/five-questions-to-ask-before-investing-in-cloud-service" target="_blank">Five Questions to Ask Before Investing in a Cloud Service</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/server-2003-end-of-life" target="_blank">Preparing for Server 2003 End of Life by Migrating to Microsoft Azure</a>

		<item>
			<title>Using Data to Drive Sales and Marketing Tactics</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/foundation-for-building-data</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 26 Jun 2015 13:56:10 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Will Robinson]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17305</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[As a marketing or sales leader, have you ever found yourself sitting in a presentation with beautiful, data-rich dashboards that will help you do leadership things such as review the "state of the union," analyze your progress, make more informed decisions, or predict the future? SWC uses a number of tools such as Qlik, Tableau and Microsoft's recently refreshed cloud-based Power BI solution to create these beautiful works of art through data dashboards that drive the decision-making process.
	
	<img class=" wp-image-17310 size-full aligncenter" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-11.png" alt="CRM-1" width="500" height="317" />
	
	The challenge we most often see marketing and sales leaders struggle with is where to begin your journey. In our last luncheon, our BI and CRM groups combined forces to talk about the rich and powerful dashboards you can build to help drive your marketing and sales tactics. We used the analogy that the "the pyramids weren’t built in a day." Each pyramid started with one block. In our world, those blocks are your marketing and sales data.
	
	<img class=" size-full wp-image-17311 aligncenter" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-2.png" alt="CRM-2" width="500" height="317" />
	<h2>Build Your CRM Foundation</h2>
	Companies need a place for their marketing and sales teams to put their campaign, lead, customer, opportunity, and activity data. Most marketing and sales data sits in a CRM system. We use our CRM Maturity Model to help our customers understand where they are in this model. The CRM Maturity Model also helps our customers figure out what the next step is—usually a pragmatic low cost step.
	
	<img class=" size-full wp-image-17312 aligncenter" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-3.png" alt="CRM-3" width="500" height="317" />
	
	Building the foundation is about getting your data into a system where it can be cleansed and organized so that it can be reported on later. Depending on your level of adoption, you can use our CRM Maturity Model to determine how the data can be further organized and where contextual data can be added to your customer data. Contextual data helps tell a story as it creates relationships between the content and data in your CRM system. This enables you to build more meaningful reports and dashboards.
	<h2>Moving Up in the CRM Maturity Model</h2>
	Sales teams typically at the "Captured" maturity level put their leads, opportunities, activities, and account information into a CRM system. This allows sales managers to use CRM reporting tools to learn more about what their sales professionals are doing. This is basic reporting. It's a great first step. Now let's put contextual data around the information.
	
	Sales teams typically at the "Managed" maturity level implement their sales process in CRM as workflows. These workflows place rules around what data is entered. A great example would be your company's sales stages. This is really the definition of your sales funnel. The CRM workflow requires certain fields of data to be entered before moving on to the next stage in your sales process. Now you have data that describes where you are. Some examples include sales phase, industry, company size, lead source, and email campaign. Reporting on your data becomes more meaningful as the sales manager can now see relationships. These relationships provide information that leads to better decision making. Rich and powerful reports and dashboards can be created at this point.
	
	<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-17313" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-4.png" alt="CRM-4" width="500" height="288" />
	<h2>We’ll Help Establish Your Data Foundation</h2>
	As you progress through the Maturity Model, you’ll start to create visually rich dashboards that drive sales and marketing tactics. But to get there, you need to start with a solid foundation. SWC has the experience and proven methodology to help you demonstrate inexpensive and incremental wins wherever you are in the CRM Maturity Model. Want to start realizing the value of your data? <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact swc</a> today or join us for our next event on <a href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">using data to drive marketing and sales tactics</a>.
	
	
	<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Will, check out a few of our related posts.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/data-tracking-business-development-tactics" target="_blank">Data Tracking: The Foundation for Strong Business Development Tactics</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/crm-maturity-model" target="_blank">The SWC CRM Maturity Model</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/how-to-fix-crm-system" target="_blank">Where Your CRM Implementation is Failing to Gain Traction and How to Fix It</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/comparing-crm-software-microsoft-vs-salesforce" target="_blank">Comparing CRM Software: Microsoft Dynamics vs. Salesforce</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/everything-you-need-to-know-about-microsoft-dynamics-crm-2015-release" target="_blank">Everything You Need to Know About the Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 Release</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/dynamic-crm-2015" target="_blank">Dynamics Marketing – Everything You Ever Wanted in a Marketing Automation Platform?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/microsoft-crm-social-listening" target="_blank">Social Listening in Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/deploying-on-premise-dynamics-crm-to-remote-users" target="_blank">Deploying On-Premise Dynamics CRM to Remote Users</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/updating-multiple-records-crm-add-on" target="_blank">Updating Multiple Records in CRM</a>

			<title>Client Success: Simpson Technologies Managed Services Partnership</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/managed-services/simpson-managed-services-case-study</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 29 Jun 2015 14:13:47 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[susiecummings]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17411</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[SWC partners with Simpson Technologies on a variety of projects including <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/managed-services" target="_blank">IT Managed Services</a>. Watch our client success video case study below to learn more about our partnership in action.
	<h2>Simpson Technologies Partners with SWC IT Managed Services</h2>
	<a title="New Features of Tableau 8.2" href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/m8vCIikIDJY?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/simpson-case-study-play-big.png" alt="New Features of Tableau 8.2" width="474" height="262" /></a>
	
	Simpson Technologies is a 103-year-old fifth-generation family-owned business specializing in the design and production of advanced process technologies and services for the global metal casting and chemical process industries. Simpson distributes products globally and has offices in Switzerland and India. Because they are running virtually around the clock, Simpson depends on SWC Technology Partners for managed IT services which provides them with the technical expertise and 24/7 coverage needed to efficiently run their business.
	<blockquote>“I can’t imagine doing my job now without SWC. Their professionalism, their expertise, not only on the day-to-day things like support, but also looking into the future at long-term plans. Whether that be going to the cloud or using Office 365.”</blockquote>
	<strong>– Julie McMillin, Chief Information Officer</strong>
	
	As part of the service, SWC’s team worked with the executive team at Simpson to put together a strategic technical roadmap or long-term vision on how the organization could use technology to help enable and grow their business. SWC then helped upgrade Simpson’s current IT environment, putting a strong technical infrastructure in place that they could enhance and expand overtime. SWC’s managed services team now complements Simpson’s internal IT team, enabling them to be more productive and focus on more strategic projects that impact the business.
	<blockquote>“Our internal IT team needs to be functional experts in our business software. In terms of managing our network and designing our website and digital communications. Those are things we can’t have the level of expertise that SWC brings to the table. So it’s great to be able to concentrate our own IT resources on our business processes and have access to all of SWC’s expertise on everything else, and we take advantage of everything else.”</blockquote>
	<strong>– Bruce Dienst, President &amp; COO</strong>
	
	Simpson has embraced technology and knows that it will give them a competitive advantage. It’s fueling a lot of innovation and exciting conversations about where technology can go and help their business continue to grow.
	
	If you want to learn more about how SWC’s managed services team can complement your internal IT team and add value to your organization, please join us for our next<a href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank"> complimentary Managed Services event</a> or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com?subject=Tell%20me%20more%20about%20Microsoft%20Azure">contact us</a> today for a free consultation on your current IT challenges.<h2>Client Success</h2>
	If you enjoyed this SWC client success video, please check out a few of our past videos:
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/uncategorized/website-redesign-mobile-application" target="_blank">Client Success: Preferred Meals Website Redesign &amp; Mobile Application</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/making-sharepoint-look-good" target="_blank">Microsoft SharePoint Helps Empower and Enable Users at M. Holland</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/perspective/videos/leveleleven-salesforce-com-application" target="_blank">Compete: How Developing a Solution for the Salesforce.com AppExchange Launched a New Company</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/perspective/videos/integrity-payment-systems-custom-application" target="_blank">SWC Video Featuring Custom Application Development Services</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/perspective/videos/microsoft-sharepoint-customization-design" target="_blank">SWC Video Featuring Microsoft SharePoint Customization and Design</a>

		<item>
			<title>Discover the Question with Azure Machine Learning</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/azure-machine-learning-solution</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 30 Jun 2015 14:18:28 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17446</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[I’ll be the first to say that traditional/old school <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence" target="_blank">business intelligence</a> does a great job of providing answers to the questions you know you want to ask. What if you don’t know the questions? What if you are more interested in the questions than you are in the answers? Enter Azure Machine Learning!
	
	Azure Machine Learning was launched last summer to much fanfare and marketing hype. Since its inception, features and user adoption continue to increase and we are finding that almost every organization has opportunities lurking that Azure Machine Learning can help to solve.
	<h2>Radiological Society of North America (RSNA) Evaluates Azure Machine Learning</h2>
	Recently we had a discussion with Spencer Moore, Director of Information Management at RSNA, regarding the fit for their machine learning needs. After an insightful discussion on requirements and pain points, we elected to take a sample dataset and put it through the paces in a Machine Learning Proof of Concept (POC). In the POC we decided to focus on the following areas:
	<ul>
		<li>The outputs/outcomes should be easily consumed by visualization tools such as Tableau</li>
		<li>Demonstrate ease of data migration from disparate sources to the Azure ecosystem and consumption by Machine Learning experiments/models</li>
		<li>Evaluate text mining capabilities</li>
		<li>Evaluate membership churn capabilities</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>Named Entity Recognition</h2>
	One of the datasets we got from RSNA was a large export of emails, customer service comments, and phone conversation debriefs. The dataset was fairly large and most of the text conversations were more than two sentences. This turned out be a perfect dataset for evaluating NER, or <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/dn905955.aspx" target="_blank">Named Entity Recognition</a>. NER is an actual text mining task in Azure Machine Learning Studio that can interpret a block of text and automatically parse out names, organizations, and places. What’s even more useful is the task does this parsing recursively and can find many entities in single block of text. Imagine, all of these nouns or entities have been parsed from your text data, and you now have the ability to discover some of those unknown questions. For example, “Did you know that Canada is the number one location that CSRs reference in conversation debriefs?”
	<h2>Setting Up the Experiment</h2>
	NER experiments are fairly easy to build. The image below has the following steps:
	<ol>
		<li>We created a data reader that loads the text data from an Azure SQL database. We could have also used a text file, blob storage or an HDInsights Hadoop table as a source.</li>
		<li>We only want to extract named entities from text so in the second step we removed the non-text columns from the incoming dataset.</li>
		<li>The NER task only needs to have an incoming dataset and an output dataset. The output dataset is assumed to be one too many. One incoming record will have zero or many output records because the paragraph text had many recognized persons, places, or organizations.</li>
		<li>The parsed entities are written to a table in Azure SQL where we can analyze the parsed data with adhoc reporting tools (Excel, Power BI, Tableau, etc.)</li>
	</ol>
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17451 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/RSNA-image1.png" alt="RSNA-image" width="500" height="425" />
	<h3>Next Steps</h3>
	Our NER experiment was built to do named entity analysis in a batch process. In the future, we could expose the experiment as a web service and let other applications pipe their datasets into the experiment and get extracted entities as an output. The process of converting an experiment to a web service just requires a few clicks!
	<h2>Want to Learn More?</h2>
	Azure Machine Learning can augment most any BI system and if you haven’t given consideration to machine learning in your BI architecture, you should! If you would like more information about Azure Machine Learning or business intelligence in general, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact swc</a> or call 630.572.0240 to speak with one of our Microsoft Azure experts.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Chad, please read a few of his past posts on business intelligence:
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/predictive-analytics-microsoft-azure-machine-learning" target="_blank">Predictive Analytics Made Easy with Microsoft Azure Machine Learning</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/microsoft-azure-machine-learning" target="_blank">Microsoft Azure Machine Learning – A Data Tool for the Masses</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/r-you-looking-to-integrate-with-tableau" target="_blank">R You Looking to Integrate with Tableau?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/is-my-bi-fat-database-partitioning-can-help" target="_blank">Is My BI Fat? Database Partitioning Can Help!</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/its-the-data-quality" target="_blank">It’s The Data Quality</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/have-we-forgotten-how-to-fix-problems" target="_blank">Have We Forgotten How to Fix Problems?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/do-tableau-mds-make-strange-bedfellows" target="_blank">Do Tableau And MDS Make Strange Bedfellows?</a>
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Are Your Passwords A Single Factor Of Failure?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/security/lastpass-hack-prevention</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 01 Jul 2015 14:15:23 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[tommymontgomery]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17453</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last week I received a wakeup call that I had been needing for a while now. The award-winning online password manager <a href="http://arstechnica.com/security/2015/06/hack-of-cloud-based-lastpass-exposes-encrypted-master-passwords/" target="_blank">LastPass was hacked</a> and the password hashes were stolen. For those not familiar with password managers, they use a master password to store all of your passwords in a single secure place that aims to prevent the infamous “Post-It note” password problem. LastPass stores your passwords online so you can access them from anywhere on any device.
	
	The risk users of LastPass are now facing is an attacker cracking their master password and using that password to access all of that user’s credentials for every account they own. This begins to get really scary since users such as myself store passwords to every account they have including banking, investing, server systems, social media and email. This is much the same way your organization may use Active Directory as your single password for all of your services, including those in the cloud.
	<h2>Secure Your Passwords with Multi-Factor Authentication</h2>
	So how do we prevent our passwords from being that single factor of failure? We implement and use Two-Factor (2FA) or multi-factor authentication (MFA). MFA incorporates an additional physical factor into the authentication process. This second factor is usually something you have such as a cell phone that either generates a code or asks if the person logging into the account is actually you. This means an attacker would need both your username and password and your cell phone. Obviously this makes an attacker’s challenge of breaking into your account significantly harder, if not impossible. Let’s look at this process in action:
	
	When I go to log into my LastPass account it asks me for my username and password.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17460 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Security-11.png" alt="Security-1" width="500" height="299" />
	
	You can see that I only need the username and password to log in and access all of my information. Nothing about this process guarantees that the person logging in is me since an attacker could be using my stolen password.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17455 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/security-2.png" alt="security-2" width="500" height="263" />
	
	Enter the multi-factor authentication solution. This time when I go to log into LastPass I am presented with the same screen, but when I enter my credentials I receive an alert on my cell phone asking if I want to allow the login. I always have my cell phone and I can quickly approve or deny the login request. This puts me in full control and prevents attackers from taking over my account due to a security breach.
	<h2>MFA-Preventable Breaches</h2>
	My specific scenario affected me on a personal level but there are many organizations that have been breached in the past few years due to their lack of MFA. Target Corporation was a high profile example where the lack of MFA led to a massive security breach. Had Target implemented MFA for access into their networks from the outside, they would likely not have been hacked.
	
	JP Morgan Chase is another example where attackers who stole information on 83 million customers earlier this year gained access into the company's network because a server reportedly lacked MFA. I can go on and on naming specific breaches that would have been prevented by multi-factor authentication because it really is a technology that stops attackers in their tracks.
	<h2>Secure Your Organization’s Data On-Premises or in the Cloud with MFA</h2>
	So how can MFA help secure your organization’s data? Multi-factor authentication can be used with most services both on-premises and in the cloud. Some examples include Amazon Web Services (AWS), Box, Citrix, Dropbox, Facebook, Microsoft Azure, Office 365, Salesforce, SharePoint, Twitter, VPN and WordPress. If an attacker were to steal your password to an MFA-enabled service, they would not be able to access your account or data, thus keeping your information safe.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17456 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Security-3.png" alt="Security-3" width="500" height="194" />
	
	SWC has experience deploying different multi-factor authentication solutions in a variety of scenarios. We can help your organization eliminate the single factor password weakness and dramatically increase your authentication security. We invite you to <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact swc</a> about how we can help secure your data with a complimentary security assessment.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Tommy, please read a few of his past posts on related security topics.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/email-phishing" target="_blank">Don’t Take the Bait – Tips for Protecting Yourself Against Phishers</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/sony-hack-malware-protection" target="_blank">Malware Protection | How to Prevent Another Sony Hack</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/fireeye-protect-your-organization-from-an-it-security-breach" target="_blank">How Can You Protect Your Organization From An IT Security Breach?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/swc-best-practices-what-industries-are-facing-the-most-security-issues" target="_blank">What Industries Are Facing the Most Security Issues?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/it-security-worst-case-scenario" target="_blank">From a Security Perspective, What is the Worst Case Scenario?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/swc-best-practices-what-are-some-mobile-security-risks" target="_blank">What Are Some Mobile Security Risks?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/tell-me-about-the-heartbleed-bug" target="_blank">Tell Me About The Heartbleed Bug</a>
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>How Fresh Content Drives Rankings and ROI</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/fresh-content-seo</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jul 2015 12:44:24 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Kristen Schmid]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17489</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Does fresh content really matter? How frequently should a company update website content? Can fresh content actually improve SEO ranking? Content marketing or marketing via the creation of engaging, valuable, and thought-provoking content that drives customer action has been a steadily increasing trend over recent years and with good reason – the results show that content marketing impacts the customer experience.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Content-Marketing.png"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-17557 size-large" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Content-Marketing-467x1024.png" alt="Content Marketing" width="467" height="1024" /></a>
	<h2>How to Incorporate Fresh Content into Your Marketing Strategy</h2>
	In order to effectively market content, there needs to be a place to easily store the content. A company’s website is often the hub and email, social media, and other websites are often the vehicle for promotion. The challenge for most companies is finding time to develop, publish and share the content.
	
	So how do you balance the demand and identify how often you should add fresh content to your website? Here are things to consider:
	<ul>
		<li><strong>Ability to Post Content:</strong> If your website requires a developer in order to post content, then it is already getting costly to publish fresh content and there is also likely a delay. If you are in this position, you should strongly consider migrating to a more user-friendly Content Management System (CMS) that allows users to post and alter content with no developer involvement. Most of these solutions can be cost-effective, and some of the best are even free! Though not ideal, an alternative may be to implement a standalone blog which continues to reference your main website.</li>
		<li><strong>Resources to Develop Content:</strong> Those that have a lean marketing or sales team often don’t have the time to generate engaging content. Engaging content is unique and often thought-provoking or entertaining. It incorporates search engine-optimized keywords and calls to action. As a result, many companies lean on other providers to generate great content. In fact, <em><strong>writing and design were found to be the most popular functions that B2B marketers outsourced</strong></em> (according to the <a href="http://contentmarketinginstitute.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/B2B_Research_2014_CMI.pdf" target="_blank">B2B Content Marketing: 2014 Benchmarks, Budgets, and Trends—North America report</a>). <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing">Creative Services</a> are value-based and easily affordable to help provide the value without having to hire additional resources in house .</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>The Return on Investment for Fresh Content</h2>
	So we’ve spoken to the cost, but what is the actual value in developing fresh copy and how often should you be updating it? At a minimum, you want your website content to be accurate, so ask yourself:
	<ul>
		<li>Are your current products and/or services accurate on your site?</li>
		<li>Does your messaging reflect your current business and sales strategy?</li>
		<li>Does the site have up-to-date third party testimonials, certifications, etc.?</li>
	</ul>
	Remember that <em><strong>over 78% of U.S. Internet Users Research Products and Services Online before they buy in both B2B and B2C environments</strong> </em>(“Exceptional Social Media and Marketing Statistics for 2014”, Webbiquity, April 2014). They are comparing you to the competition online, and if it does not look like you are the authority, you may lose market share to your competitors.
	
	So why continue to go above and beyond, promoting new content more frequently? Here are some reasons to develop your business case:
	<ul>
		<li><strong>Demonstrates your capabilities</strong> – No one wants to read a thesis on everything you can do, but they do want tips. Show that you understand your customer’s challenges by providing insights.</li>
		<li><strong>You need to give to get</strong> – Companies need to market but consumers don’t have a reason to spend their valuable time reading advertisements. If you need to advertise a product, try coupling it with fresh content. You’re planting a seed for the future!</li>
		<li><strong>The fresher the content, the more impressions:</strong> Search engines reward content that is recent or has frequent changes with higher rankings and more impressions.</li>
	</ul>
	Until you have a good infrastructure in place with regards to website technology and resourcing, frequency may have to be limited. Once these mechanisms are in place, you can create great content at a much lower cost, providing a stronger ROI and more lead generation opportunities. Target weekly generation of fresh copy and look to grow your strategy and timing from there.
	
	To get more tips on content marketing and digital marketing strategy, attend one of our <a href="http://www.swc.com/events">Digital Marketing Strategy Luncheons</a>.</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Managing Windows 10 Users with System Center Configuration Manager</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/windows-10-user-management</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 06 Jul 2015 13:46:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Adam Bartnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17498</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Many of our customers often ask us how we empower end users and allow IT to manage a large fleet of varying desktops. One way we’re able to do this is through <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM)</a>.
	<h2>How can System Center Configuration Manager help me?</h2>
	System Center Configuration Manager 2012 R2 SP1 includes the following features:
	<ul>
		<li>Support for Windows 10 OS Deployments and imaging to existing hardware</li>
		<li>Native support for SQL Server 2014 for System Center backend infrastructure</li>
		<li>Discover exactly where and how many pieces of software are installed with Asset Intelligence</li>
		<li>Check versions of files and collect files from systems with Software Inventory</li>
		<li>Deploy Microsoft updates to Windows 10 and previous operating systems for enterprise-wide standardization</li>
		<li>Remediate non-compliant systems by utilizing baselines to automatically run scripts and change registry and other system values back to standardized values</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>How can I leverage my existing System Center investment?</h2>
	Have you already implemented a version of System Center Configuration Manager in your environment and want to leverage it for Windows 10? There are several supported on-premises scenarios:
	<ul>
		<li>If you have Configuration Manager 2012 R2 and Configuration Manager 2012:
	<ul>
		<li>Can support existing features for Windows 10
	<ul>
		<li>SP1 for R2 and SP2 for 2012 is available right now! No need to wait until Windows 10 launch!</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
		<li>If you have Configuration Manger 2007, we need to talk:
	<ul>
		<li>SCCM 2007 can support managing some features of Windows 10 with severe limits
	<ul>
		<li>No Operating System Deployment (OSD) Support</li>
		<li>Hotfix available Q4 2015</li>
		<li>Environments will need to use a different tool to support OSD.</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>A Summary of Windows 10 Support:</h2>
	
	<table style="height: 250px;" width="780">
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td width="195">Microsoft Product Versions</td>
	<td width="195">Release Vehicle</td>
	<td width="195">Release Timing</td>
	<td width="195">Windows 10 Feature Support</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>SCCM</td>
	<td>Technical Preview

	</tr>

	<td>Existing features</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>

	<td>Monthly Service Updates</td>

	</tr>

Whether you need help migrating to Windows 10 or upgrading your existing SSCM environment to support Windows 10 <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact swc</a> or call 630.572.0240. We are a Microsoft Gold Partner and have extensive experience with Windows migrations and System Center upgrades.

		<item>
			<title>Active Directory Synchronization or Federation – Which One Should I Choose?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/active-directory-synchronization-vs-federation</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 07 Jul 2015 14:08:43 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[John Benton]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17518</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the last few months, I’ve had many customers looking to move to <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365">Office 365</a> ask what the difference was between Active Directory Synchronization and Active Directory Federation. These customers needed to manage user identities and credentials in the cloud and wanted to know how these alternate solutions stack up in terms capabilities, cost and user experience. Below is a quick overview on the differences between Active Directory Synchronization and Federation.
	<h2>What is Directory Synchronization?</h2>
	Directory Synchronization is the integration of your On-premises Active Directory with an instance of Active Directory running in the Azure cloud. Synchronization essentially makes a copy of the on-premises directory objects and then propagates them to an Active Directory instance in the Azure cloud. After that, synchronization runs on a scheduled basis to push changes from the on-premises directory to the cloud instance. With few exceptions, synchronization only goes from on-premises to the cloud. If one were to create a new user on the Azure Active Directory tenant, that user would live only in the cloud and would never be propagated down to the on-premises directory. This would create a Cloud (only) Identity (see below) which would have its own login credentials and identity for Office 365 applications.
	
	Over the years, there have been several products to effect directory synchronization. FIM, Microsoft's Directory Synchronization (affectionately known as DirSync) and Azure Active Directory Sync Services tools (commonly referred to as AAD Sync). AAD Sync was the replacement for DirSync; however, both tools are being deprecated by Microsoft in favor of Azure Active Directory Connect. <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/dn757582.aspx?f=255&amp;MSPPError=-2147217396" target="_blank">Learn more about Microsoft's directory synchronization tools</a>.
	
	Since directory synchronization is much simpler to configure than single sign-on (SSO), the benefits of synchronization make it a great choice for many customer scenarios.
	<h2>What is Federation?</h2>
	Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) can be used to provide federation and single sign-on capabilities for end users who want to access Office 365 applications. Windows Server 2012 R2 includes an AD FS role that can function as an identity provider or as a federation provider. An identity provider authenticates users to provide security tokens to applications that trust AD FS (e.g. Office 365 applications). A federation provider consumes tokens from other identity providers and then provides security tokens to applications that trust AD FS.
	<h3>Comparison Summary</h3>
	
	<table>
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td>Solution</td>
	<td>Advantages</td>
	<td>Disadvantages</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong><strong>
	</strong></strong>
	<strong>AAD connect</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Single server and simple deployment</li>
		<li>Less cost, time and resource</li>
		<li>If DirSync server down, users still be able to authenticate and logon to Office 365 cloud</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>More password prompts</li>
		<li>Single identity but separate credentials, can be the same user name and password</li>
		<li>User account authenticated by Office 365 cloud</li>
		<li>No Fault tolerant and load balancing</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong><strong>
	</strong></strong>
	<strong>AD FS</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Less password prompts</li>
		<li>Single federated identity and credentials</li>
		<li>Better security</li>
		<li>User account authenticated by ADFS</li>
		<li>Fault tolerant and load balancing</li>
		<li>Transparent Single sign-on since re-entry of the password is not required.</li>
		<li>Client access filtering, which restricts access to Exchange Online to users based on their IP address.</li>
		<li>Active Directory configured login time restrictions supported</li>
		<li>Can include web pages for users to change their passwords outside the corporate network</li>
		<li>Authentication decision is made on-premises</li>
		<li>Password hashes are not synchronized to the cloud.</li>
		<li>Immediate block of a user to remove access</li>
		<li>Support for on-premises multi-factor authentication products.</li>
		<li>Some on-premises to cloud hybrid scenarios require ADFS such as hybrid search.</li>
		<li><a href="http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/12/azure-ad-microsoft-intune-and-windows-10-using-the-cloud-to-modernize-enterprise-mobility.aspx" target="_blank">ADFS on Windows Server 2016 will support conditional access control based on a device's compliance state (not yet available).</a></li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Greater cost, time and resources to implement</li>
		<li>Additional infrastructure</li>
		<li>Best practice is to deploy AD FS and Web Application Proxy (WAP)</li>
		<li>When ADFS services are down, users won’t be able authenticate to access Office 365.</li>
		<li>Adds a potential point(s) of failure</li>
		<li>SSL certificate from a public CA is required</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	</tbody>
	</table>
	
	<h2>What is the end user experience?</h2>
	Directory synchronization does not provide SSO because a user that is already logged in on-premises will still have to log in separately to Office 365. However, since the end user will only have to remember one login and password, it will appear very similar (even though in reality there are two different credentials). It will prompt for credentials when, for instance, a user accesses his mailbox in Exchange Online even though he is logged onto a domain-joined client. When the application supports “remembering” or caching the login credentials (such as Outlook), the experience is even more similar because the only time the user is prompted for credentials is on the first connection, after a password change or possibly after a configuration change.
	
	Synchronization should not be seen as a replacement for AD FS, but as an alternative for those that find it sufficient that users have the same password in Office 365 as they do on-premises.
	<h3>Expected Application Experience</h3>
	
	<table>
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td></td>
	<td>Outlook Web
	Access (OWA)</td>
	<td>Outlook
	2010/2013</td>
	<td>ActiveSync</td>
	<td>SharePoint,
	OneDrive,
	Office Web Apps</td>
	<td>Skype  for Business</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong><strong>
	</strong></strong>

	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on password change</li>
		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>

	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>

		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>

	</td>
	<td>

	<td><strong><strong>

	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on password change</li>
		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on password change</li>
		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on password change</li>
		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on password change</li>
		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on password change</li>
		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong><strong>
	</strong></strong>
	<strong>AD FS (3.0)</strong></td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Internal: Transparent</li>
		<li>External: Forms Based Prompt</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on password change</li>
		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on first connect</li>
		<li>Prompt for credentials on password change</li>
		<li>Can remember credentials</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Internal: Pop up to sign in</li>
		<li>External: Forms Based Prompt</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Transparent</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	</tbody>
	</table>
	
	<h2>How complex is your environment?</h2>
	Many clients find that the added complexity, cost and maintenance effort of AD FS outweigh the almost imperceptible differences between synchronization and federation for straightforward use cases. However, that might change for clients who have more complex use cases requiring multiple identity providers or who have applications hosted in multiple cloud environments. The good news is that you can start with synchronization and then federation can be added as requirements dictate.
	
	Let’s talk about managing your users on-premises and in the cloud. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact swc</a> for help determining the best environment for your specific business needs.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>

		<item>
			<title>What’s New with Skype for Business Server 2015?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/skype-for-business-server-2015</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 09 Jul 2015 13:47:39 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[gonzaloescarra]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17545</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[The next version of Lync Server 2013, rebranded Skype for Business 2015, was launched last month, and along with the new name comes a new set of features:
	<h2>In Place Upgrade from Lync 2013</h2>
	If you are running Lync 2013 and are at the latest patch level, you can upgrade to Skype for Business Server 2015 by going through a small series of steps and performing an in-place upgrade. Since the hardware requirements are the same as Lync 2013, an in-place upgrade makes sense and is the recommended upgrade scenario by Microsoft. If you are running Lync Server 2010 you can still upgrade to Skype for Business Server 2015, but the upgrade is a more traditional side-by-side path.
	<h2>New Server Role, the Video Interoperability Server (VIS)</h2>
	Many companies have invested in video-conferencing or telepresence systems, and now you can integrate those systems into Skype for Business for a more immersive video experience. The VIS role enables interoperability with certain approved video conferencing room systems (so far only specific Cisco Tandberg systems that support H.264) and enables a richer experience without extra investment. Oh and did I mention this new server role is free?
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-16487 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/skype-resized.png" alt="skype-resized" width="500" height="360" />
	<h2>Skype Directory Search</h2>
	In addition to being able to federate with Skype users regardless of using a Microsoft account or Skype ID, now you can search for contacts directly from your Skype for Business client. In order to gain that federation functionality, your implementation will need to be provisioned via Microsoft’s PIC or Public IM Connectivity portal, which enables the federation from Microsoft’s datacenters to your SIP domains.
	<h2>Call Quality Dashboard</h2>
	The Monitoring Reports from Lync 2013 get a brand new look and make troubleshooting call quality issues a lot easier. A new “role,” or more like a series of web-based reports that leverage the monitoring database, give you a nice dashboard that can show subnets, users, locations, conferences and other groupings that are trending with potential quality issues. Here is a sample:
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17546 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/uc-1.png" alt="uc-1" width="500" height="259" />
	<h2>SILK Codec for Peer-to-Peer calls</h2>
	More a client-side feature than a server-side feature, your peer-to-peer calls between Lync 2013 (latest update) and/or Skype for Business clients will use the SILK protocol, which was originally developed by Skype and later acquired by Microsoft. SILK is built to work around quality issues inherent to home Internet connections, such as jitter, latency and packet loss. This means clearer calls that can withstand worse network conditions than RTAudio was able to.
	<h2>SQL AlwaysOn Support</h2>
	Skype for Business Server 2015 adds support for both SQL Server AlwaysOn Availability Groups and Failover Cluster instances, in addition to the previously supported SQL Mirroring and SQL Clustering from Lync 2013.
	
	There are many other features that come with both the new Skype for Business Server 2015 and Skype for Business client. For further details you can visit the <a href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn933785.aspx" target="_blank">Microsoft TechNet article</a>.
	
	Is your organization ready for Skype for Business? Put SWC’s Microsoft Unified Communications Gold Partner status to work for you and see how our proven methodologies and enablement programs allow for a more communicative and productive workplace. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Contact swc</a> today to learn more or register for our upcoming <a href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Skype for Business luncheon</a> where I will present a demonstration of the newest Microsoft Unified Communications suite.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Gonzalo, please check out a few of SWC’s past Unified Communications posts:
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/skype-for-business-release-date" target="_blank">Skype for Business Client Release Date Announced</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/integrating-microsoft-lync-dynamics-crm-call-tracking" target="_blank">Integrating Microsoft Lync and Dynamics CRM for Call Tracking</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-lync-helps-tandem-hr-weather-storm" target="_blank">Microsoft Lync Helps Tandem HR Weather the Storm</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/microsoft-leads-gartner-magic-quadrant-unified-communications" target="_blank">Microsoft Leads the Gartner Magic Quadrant for Unified Communications</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/migrating-exchange-online-protection-office-365" target="_blank">Migrating From Standalone Exchange Online Protection (EOP) to Office 365</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/which-lync-phone-should-i-use" target="_blank">Which Lync Phone Should I Use? My Favorites Are…</a>

			<title>Windows 10 Is Coming!</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/windows-10-release</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 10 Jul 2015 13:44:03 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[mikeromp]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17597</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[The launch of Windows 10 is just around the corner (July 29th for the first phased rollout) and there is a lot of buzz being generated about Microsoft’s latest operating system. Rightfully so, Windows 10 brings many new improvements focused around productivity, mobility, and security – all while maintaining the familiar user experience your employees love.
	
	With more and more applications and services moving into the cloud, it's important to have an operating system designed with mobility in mind. Furthermore, as mobile device adoption takes off, it is vital to provide a consistent experience for users from device to device. Windows 10 brings this and more.
	<h2>Consistent User Experience Across Devices</h2>
	Windows 10 is the first Microsoft operating system that runs on the full spectrum of device types – from desktop PCs and laptops, to tablets, smartphones and Xbox. It will even help to power the Internet of Things (IoT) by running on many special-purpose embedded devices such as sensors and robotics components.
	
	With Continuum, Windows 10 brings a consistent, yet flexible, user experience across devices. When working on your tablet it provides a touch-friendly full-screen user interface that is easy to operate without a keyboard. If it detects the attachment of a keyboard it can seamless transition out of tablet mode to provide a more traditional desktop experience. It is even possible to use a mobile phone as you would a computer by attaching an external display, keyboard, and mouse!
	
	<a href=" /Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src=" /uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a>
	<h2>Manage and Empower End User Productivity</h2>
	The Windows Store brings new ways to connect employees with the applications and tools necessary to perform their jobs efficiently and effectively. All of your company’s line-of-business and other supporting applications can be presented through the Store, providing a familiar self-service model to application deployment. Rather than bothering IT to install the FTP client they need for a new project, they can simply go out and get it themselves. This is of course all under your control; there’s no need to worry about having to true-up 5,000 MS Project licenses when Gantt charts become all the rage.
	<h2>No More Complicated VPNs</h2>
	As we put more data and services into the cloud it is becoming increasingly important to protect that data with robust security controls. Two-factor (or multi-factor) authentication is one of the most effective ways to achieve this level of security without adversely affecting employee productivity. Windows 10 enhances this by making the device itself the second factor. Now, users can gain access to all of their resources from approved Windows 10 devices simply by connecting and typing in a PIN. Your security posture is greatly improved and the end-user experience is vastly simplified without having to resort to complicated VPN solutions or overly complex passwords that invariably end up on a sticky note somewhere.
	<h2>Security for Your Biggest Vulnerability</h2>
	Since we know the human element is often the weakest link in the security chain, it’s necessary to protect well-meaning employees from themselves. Windows 10 includes data loss prevention features that keep company data restricted to approved devices and network locations. Simple rules can be set up to prevent any data from leaving the control of your IT organization, or more granular rules can be created to identify and protect sensitive data based on complex criteria.
	
	It’s already obvious that Windows 10 is the next-generation operating system that will drive production for a mobile workforce, but it’s not always obvious how to get from where you are to where you want to be. SWC has the tools and experience to help guide you along the way. We can help you to build a strategic roadmap and find answers to important questions like:
	<ul>
		<li><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Preparedness</strong> </span>– Is my environment ready for Windows 10? Are all of our applications compatible and if not, what is our remediation strategy?</li>
		<li><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Deployment</strong> </span>– How do I get Windows 10 onto all of the workstations and laptops I support? What do we do with older devices and how do we make sure everyone’s data survives the transition?</li>
		<li><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Mobility</strong></span> – What if my employees want to use iPads and other mobile devices? How can Windows 10 help bridge the BYOD gap while providing a consistent experience for everybody?</li>
		<li><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Training</strong></span> – How do we teach our employees to adapt to Windows 10 without sacrificing productivity?</li>
	</ul>
	Let’s talk Windows 10. Give us a call at 630.572.0240 or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">shoot us an email</a> and tell us about your business and plans for deploying Microsoft’s next generation OS.
	<h3>You’re Invited to our Windows 10 Release Party Luncheon</h3>
	We’re teaming up with Microsoft to celebrate the release of their most anticipated OS to date: Windows 10! Be one of the first to experience the new and mobile workplace productivity capabilities of Windows 10 and Office 365. Join your local Microsoft reps and Microsoft Gold Partner SWC Technology Partners, as they discuss how the newest wave of Microsoft’s cloud, data and productivity solutions will help your organization succeed. We’ll have a number of premium giveaways and devices on hand so you can experience Windows 10 and how it will transform the way your organization gets work done. This is one party you won’t want to miss! <a href="http://bit.ly/SWCWindows10">Register now</a>.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Mike, please check out a few of SWC’s related past posts:
	
	<a href=" /blog/microsoft-system-center/windows-10-user-management" target="_blank"> Managing Windows 10 Users with System Center Configuration Manager</a>
	<a href=" /blog/cloud/microsoft-technology-roadmap-event-recap" target="_blank"> Microsoft’s Annual Technology Roadmap Event Recap</a>
	<a href=" /blog/microsoft-windows/downloadable-windows-10" target="_blank">Skipping Ahead to Windows 10</a>
	<a href=" /blog/cloud/microsoft-mobile-device-management" target="_blank">Built-in Mobile Device Management Is Now Freely Available for Office 365 Commercial Plans</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-2015" target="_blank">What Can We Expect from Microsoft In 2015?</a>
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Migrating Data into Dynamics CRM</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/data-migration</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 13 Jul 2015 20:42:26 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[joespinelli]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17601</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Most Customer Relationship Management (CRM) projects we are a part of includes some amount of data migration from the legacy systems being replaced. Typically, the migration needs to be orchestrated in a fashion that it is testable and repeatable. At SWC, we use several techniques to achieve optimal data migration. Each has its place, and there are pros and cons to each approach.
	
	<table>
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td>Approach</td>
	<td>Pro</td>
	<td>Con</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Import from flat files using data import features native to CRM</td>
	<td>Easy to use</td>
	<td>Limited capabilities</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Use Scribe software or another third party</td>
	<td>Easy to use</td>
	<td>Third party licensing costs and setup costs</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Use a SSIS package that utilizes CRM web services such as a data destination</td>
	<td>Orchestration, automation, and exception
	processing capability</td>
	<td>Setup costs</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Use a custom developed .Net application that uses CRM SDK</td>
	<td>Ultimately flexible</td>
	<td>Expensive to create and maintain</td>
	</tr>
	</tbody>
	</table>
	
	<h2>The Data-Driven, Systems Integration Case for CRM</h2>
	More and more organizations are realizing the value of adopting a CRM system, or if they already have one in place, using SWC’s proven methodologies to step up a level in the CRM Maturity Model, our blueprint for evaluating where your are in the customer relationship management lifecycle. In doing so, SWC is helping organizations realize the value of their hidden data, particularly their sales and marketing data.
	
	<a href=" /uploads/CRM-Download.pdf"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16522 size-medium" src=" /uploads/CRM-BLOG-GUIDE-300x178.png" alt="CRM-BLOG-GUIDE" width="300" height="178" /></a>
	
	Instead of pouring through mountains of data across spreadsheets and systems, CRM systems like Microsoft Dynamics CRM and Salesforce aggregate and centralize your data to provide you with rich, visual dashboards. Sales, customer service, and marketing processes are made simpler, and with automation tools you can build detailed customer profiles to more accurately qualify your customers and create targeted messages to move them through the sales funnel.
	
	Another reason why organizations are utilizing CRM systems, and one that SWC has helped a number of customers with, is for the automatic integration capabilities with other systems like fulfillment or accounting systems. For instance, an organization can create orders in an ERP system and have those flow into CRM that track sales efforts and see revenue-related data.
	<h2>Moving From On-Premises into CRM Online</h2>
	For many reasons, more and more of our customers are moving away from on-premises solutions and moving into SaaS cloud-based models. CRM solutions are no exception. Lately, we have been helping out on a few CRM on-premises to CRM Online migrations. Microsoft doesn’t provide an easy way to bring your data into your new online tenant, so SWC has created a fast, flexible solution that can pull entity data from one CRM organization and load it into another.
	
	If you are looking to move your on-premises Dynamics CRM environment to a cost saving online cloud-based solution, SWC can help you get there. Contact us now to discuss your data challenges.<h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Joe, please check out a few of our past related CRM posts.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/foundation-for-building-data" target="_blank">Using Data to Drive Sales and Marketing Tactics</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/data-tracking-business-development-tactics" target="_blank">Data Tracking: The Foundation for Strong Business Development Tactics</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/how-to-fix-crm-system" target="_blank">Where Your CRM Implementation is Failing to Gain Traction and How to Fix It</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/comparing-crm-software-microsoft-vs-salesforce" target="_blank">Comparing CRM Software: Microsoft Dynamics vs. Salesforce</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/everything-you-need-to-know-about-microsoft-dynamics-crm-2015-release" target="_blank">Everything You Need to Know About the Microsoft Dynamics CRM 2015 Release</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/deploying-on-premise-dynamics-crm-to-remote-users" target="_blank">Deploying On-Premise Dynamics CRM to Remote Users</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/salesforce-com-crm-appexchange-launched-new-company" target="_blank">Compete: How Developing a Solution for the Salesforce.com AppExchange Launched a New Company</a>
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>What Is It Like to Have an Inside Sales Job at SWC?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/inside-sales-job-at-swc</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 08 Jul 2015 14:51:38 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jill]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17605</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Inside Sales team plays a key role within SWC Technology Partners. Our sales reps reach out to prospective clients to better understand their specific business challenges and help them find technology solutions that solve those challenges. I spoke with two members of SWC’s Inside Sales team to learn what makes them successful.
	
	Elaine Green started with the Inside Sales team in 2009 as an intern. That internship converted into a permanent role with the team and she is now the team lead. Eric Jandacek joined the team in 2013 and is one of our top salespeople.
	<h2>Why did you join the Inside Sales team?</h2>
	<img class="alignleft wp-image-17610 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/elaine-blog.png" alt="elaine-blog" width="120" height="120" />
	
	Elaine: As an intern, I already knew I loved the culture at SWC and wanted to grow with the company, so the Inside Sales role was a great place to start. Inside sales reps research and contact organizations to offer SWC’s services. But it’s not a typical sales role. Our sales team is more consultative-minded and seek to understand an organization’s business challenges. They have a deep overall knowledge of SWC’s offerings. It’s a lot of cold calling, but it’s made easier by the fact that SWC has such a great reputation and existing client list when making those initial connections. We’re not pushing a product; we’re offering a deeper level of partnership that you don’t often see.
	
	<img class="alignleft wp-image-17608 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/eric-blog.png" alt="eric-blog" width="120" height="120" />
	
	Eric: I knew I wanted to get into technology sales after college. I liked talking to people and building those relationships. I liked solving problems. And I knew that technology was a growing industry that was only going to get bigger. This was a great opportunity to get my foot in the door with a really reputable company and learn a lot.
	<h2>What are some of the great things about our Inside Sales role?</h2>
	<img class="alignleft wp-image-17610 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/elaine-blog.png" alt="elaine-blog" width="120" height="120" />
	
	Elaine: One is that you will learn a ton. You’ll get to work with a variety of technologies and business verticals. We don’t silo off technical areas. You will get a well-rounded background in both software development and digital marketing as well as managed services and infrastructure engineering. I didn’t have a technology background when I started, but now I feel like I have a really strong understanding of the industry as a whole. I don’t know if I could have gotten that anywhere else.
	
	<img class="alignleft wp-image-17608 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/eric-blog.png" alt="eric-blog" width="120" height="120" />
	
	Eric: The earning potential is great. Unlike a lot of places which operate on mainly a commission structure, we’re compensated with a competitive base salary. Total earning potential with the role is uncapped with additional commission. I don’t feel micromanaged. Ultimately, I’m responsible for how successful I will be, which I like a lot.
	<h2>What are some of the challenges of the role?</h2>
	<img class="alignleft wp-image-17608 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/eric-blog.png" alt="eric-blog" width="120" height="120" />
	
	Eric: Sales isn’t for everyone. You have to be self-motivated and organized. It can be very rewarding, but also frustrating at times, but that’s the nature of the business. If you are persistent, have a positive attitude and set your sights on the big picture, you can be very successful here.
	
	<img class="alignleft wp-image-17610 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/elaine-blog.png" alt="elaine-blog" width="120" height="120" />
	
	Elaine: There is always someone willing to talk to you if you need advice. We really have great mentors here. The people are probably what I love best about working at SWC, they want you to do well. If you are ambitious and not afraid of hard work, this is definitely a place where you can succeed.
	
	Interested in learning more about joining our Inside Sales team or any of our other roles at SWC? Check out our <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers" target="_blank">careers page</a> or <a href="http://www.swc.com/contact" target="_blank">contact us</a> at to learn more!<h3><strong>Recommended Past Post</strong></h3>
	If you would like to get a behind the scenes look at SWC, please check out some of our past posts:
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/swc-employees-enjoys-a-week-of-extra-perks" target="_blank">SWC Employees Enjoy a Week of Extra Perks!</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/crains-best-places-to-work-2015" target="_blank">SWC Scores Its Fourth Consecutive Crain’s Chicago Business Best Places to Work Award</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/why-it-solutions-provider-swc-was-the-right-choice" target="_blank">Why SWC Was The Right Choice For Me</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/ways-to-keep-employees-engaged" target="_blank">A Few Ways to Keep Employees Engaged and Have Fun in the Workplace</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/chicago-full-service-it-solutions-providers-internship-program" target="_blank">Chicago Area Full-Service IT Solutions Providers’ Internship Program</a>
