		<item>
			<title>Protect Your DMZ Networks in the Cloud with Azure Network Security Groups</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/dmz-network-protection</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 14 Jul 2015 14:00:41 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17622</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[In most organizations, the on-premises network is segregated into both a local network and one or more DMZ networks. These DMZ networks are used to segregate off systems and are often required for compliance and security purposes. However, for most cloud services—usually by default—all subnets within a private network have full access to all others, so the question becomes <strong>how to create these DMZ networks to ensure the proper level of security.</strong>
	
	<strong>In Microsoft Azure, the answer is Network Security Groups (NSGs).</strong> Network Security Groups are a full access control list-(ACL) based solution that can be applied at the virtual machine or at the subnet level. These groups replace the native Virtual Machine (VM) endpoint functionality and allow for extremely granular management of access to your devices for both inbound and outbound network traffic. These ACLs can be configured by IP address or subnet and then further by protocol and port to ensure that the exact level of access has been granted to the system(s). By default, Network Security Groups also include tags for the Internet and for the Virtual Network to make assigning permissions easier.
	
	For example, <strong>if your organization has a server in Azure that contains sensitive information </strong> such as credit card data or social security numbers, <strong>you may want to limit inbound access to this server</strong> only via a specific port for the database, and only from certain source servers. On the reverse, you may also want to block outbound internet access from this server so that anyone accessing the server can’t connect to other sites and upload data. All of these changes can be specified via a Network Security Group. As an added feature, when applying a Network Security Group at the VM level, the usual firewall limitations of access to devices in the same subnet always being allowed do not apply. Even if a server is in the same IP range as this resource, it will be blocked unless specifically allowed by the NSG.
	
	When applying Network Security Groups there are a few things to consider. First, currently, <strong>the only way to setup a Network Security Group is via Powershell</strong>. Also, once a Network Security Group is applied the usual Endpoint functionality in the Azure web console will no longer be applicable and any changes made via that site will be ignored. However, since these groups can be applied on a VM or subnet basis it is possible to have a mixed environment with most systems using the standard Endpoint functionality and only DMZ-based systems using NSGs. Finally, just like any access control list-based security, it is possible to fully block all access to a device if an NSG is implemented incorrectly, and so care must be taken when designing the ACLs.
	
	At SWC, we have the experience to help design out your DMZ environment in Azure and implement the Network Security Groups to make this possible. Interested in adding this security to your environment? Contact SWC and tell us about your business requirements.
	<h3>Free offer from Microsoft &amp; SWC</h3>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a><h3>Recommended Posts</h3>
	If you enjoyed this post from Aaron, please check out a few of our past related Azure posts.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/azure-multi-factor-authentication-network-security" target="_blank">Secure your Network Access with Azure Multi-Factor Authentication</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/azure-static-vs-dynamic-routing-gateways" target="_blank">Azure Static vs. Dynamic Routing Gateways – What’s the Difference &amp; Which One Should I Chose?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/extending-domain-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Extending Your Domain into Microsoft Azure: It’s Not as Scary as You Think</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/windows-azure-pack" target="_blank">Creating an Azure Environment On-Premises with Windows Azure Pack</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/server-2003-end-of-life" target="_blank">Preparing for Server 2003 End of Life by Migrating to Microsoft Azure</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/move-hyper-v-virtual-machine-into-microsoft-azure-using-system-center" target="_blank">How to Move a Hyper-V Virtual Machine into Microsoft Azure Using System Center</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/flexible-scalable-web-hosting-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Flexible and Scalable Web Hosting with Microsoft Azure</a>

		<item>
			<title>Can Your Business Afford Downtime or Data Loss?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/disaster-recovery-plans/downtime-data-loss</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 15 Jul 2015 17:08:42 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mark Weiss]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17638</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>Mitigate downtime and restore data with disaster recovery and high availability systems.</em>
	
	Most businesses today run 24/7 and can’t afford server, appliance or system downtime. Having a disaster recovery or high availability system is necessary to mitigate the risk and impact to a business during such a time. Since these two terms are often confused, let’s first define them.
	<ul>
		<li><strong>High availability: </strong>A secondary server, appliance or system is in place that can immediately take over if a primary system becomes unavailable (with little to no downtime).</li>
		<li><strong>Disaster Recovery (DR): </strong>A system or process to restore a server or system in the event of an unexpected event. There is downtime experienced and the process to restore service typically requires a human decision to initiate.</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>Let’s Start with Disaster Recovery</h2>
	I typically encourage clients to start with disaster recovery. The ability to restore data or recover services should be foundational to any IT organization. Today, most organizations cannot afford to be without priority one applications for more than an hour.
	
	The good news is there are many options that can simplify the implementation of a Disaster Recovery plan and keep costs reasonably low while remaining flexible in the levels of expectations around recovery time.
	
	<strong>If your organization already has a Disaster Recovery plan, it’s importantly to periodically address these questions:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>When was the last time it was reviewed?
	<ul>
		<li>Is the Disaster Recovery plan’s server inventory accurate?</li>
		<li>Are system dependencies clearly defined?</li>
		<li>Is the plan updated when new servers are provisioned?</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
		<li>Has it been reviewed by other business units and agreed upon that it meets the business’s needs?</li>
		<li>How rigorous has testing been?
	<ul>
		<li>Are business units included in testing and determining a test’s success?</li>
		<li>How often are tests being performed?</li>
		<li>Are the Disaster Recovery testing procedures well documented?</li>
	</ul>
	</li>
	</ul>
	<strong>If your organization doesn’t have a Disaster Recovery plan, you need to ask:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>Is the business in agreement that no formal Disaster Recovery plan is needed?</li>
		<li>Has a business impact analysis been performed to help determine what the impact of downtime is?</li>
		<li>What is the current level of certainty the business can recover from a disaster?</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>Implementing a Disaster Recovery Plan</h2>
	Your Disaster Recovery plan will be successful when you treat it as an ever-changing necessity that is part of day-to-day process. For example, part of the server provisioning process should address the Disaster Recovery updates needed. Here are some steps to help you get started:
	<ol>
		<li>Focus initial efforts on clearly defining the business requirements, not the tools. Select a tool that addresses the business requirements; going the other direction can cause complications down the road.</li>
		<li>Determine who will be responsible to test all services during a Disaster Recovery incident. This needs to include application owners and process owners.</li>
		<li>Instead of looking at Disaster Recovery using a “server by server” approach, map out the services IT is responsible to deliver and which servers are needed within each service. This approach can help move the conversations along with the other stakeholders and simplify discussions on recovery time objective, recovery point objective, etc.</li>
		<li>Discuss the priority of servers, services and applications. During the first iteration of a Disaster Recovery planning project, most organizations I’ve worked with will classify nearly all of the services as “priority one.” While they are all important, when putting a formal Disaster Recovery plan together, it’s critical to specify which servers and services take priority.</li>
	</ol>
	There are several options available for organizations to get a Disaster Recovery strategy in place, including cloud-based options that do not require a capital investment in additional hardware.
	<h2>Do You Need High Availability?</h2>
	Even though Disaster Recovery is often confused with high availability, highly available systems tend to be completely different conversations than Disaster Recovery. There are many factors to consider when leveraging highly available systems including: additional licensing requirements, more sophisticated systems management/maintenance procedures, available data center capacity, etc. You should also consider:
	<ul>
		<li>Utilizing virtualization for their native high availability features is a start, but going deeper into enterprise application’s native availability features (like Exchange DAG, SQL AlwaysOn Availability Groups, file replication, etc.) is a critical component of high system availability.</li>
		<li>Not all applications will require or support high availability configurations. Clearly document which applications should be highly available, highly recoverable, or both.</li>
		<li>IT should get input from other business units to determine what level of protection is truly necessary to the business. For example, active/active configurations may have different cost structures than active/passive.</li>
	</ul>
	The above factors are just some of the considerations to be addressed during Disaster Recovery or availability conversations. SWC can help your organization with service delivery strategy – Disaster Recovery or Business Continuity planning as well as system high availability architecture design, implementation, and performing functional testing to ensure service recoverability.
	
	Take the first step towards mitigating downtime or restoring data loss. Call us at 630.572.0240 or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">email one of our subject matter experts</a>.</content:encoded>

			<title>Windows 10: Windows as a Service</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/windows-10-as-a-service</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jul 2015 14:31:25 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Brian Knackstedt]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17687</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[With the release of <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/windows-10-release" target="_blank">Windows 10 fast approaching</a>, clients are asking about Windows as a Service. This new concept can be confusing when compared to Microsoft’s traditional update model.
	<h2>What is Windows as a Service?</h2>
	Windows as a Service is about bringing new and enhanced Windows features to the consumer faster, while allowing enterprises to update at their own pace. Windows 10 has been rumored to be the last version of Windows. Therefore, instead of big product releases, Windows will receive continual security and feature updates much like Office 365 or Gmail.
	
	Patch Tuesday will still exist and security updates will continue to be delivered. Also, Microsoft has no plans to charge for this service, just as it has not charged for the Windows Update service.
	<h2>Why has the feature update process changed?</h2>
	Microsoft recognizes that users want transparency when it comes to new features; they want to be part of the development process and for their feedback to be heard. Consumers no longer want to wait the typical three years between OS releases to take advantage of the latest technology. On the other hand, enterprises want stability, predictability, and flexibility. Enterprises have mission critical systems with long support lifecycles where new features may not be needed. These differences have led Microsoft to reevaluate how features are introduced into the market. Now, as features are developed, they will be released as branches of the OS.
	<h2>How will Microsoft bring new features to the consumer?</h2>
	A branch will be started under the Windows Insider Program. This is where users can test the latest features and provide direct feedback to Microsoft using the feedback app. Once finalized, it will be released to Windows Update as the Current Branch (CB).
	<h2>How will Microsoft bring new features to businesses?</h2>
	After four months of validation through Windows Update, the branch will be available in the new Windows Update for Business as a Current Branch for Business (CBB) service. Businesses using this service will have up to eight months to validate and deploy the CBB. To ensure compliance, Microsoft will be making security updates dependent on branches. Business have the flexibility to have different systems running different branches. Branches can even be skipped since they are cumulative.
	<h2>How will mission critical systems and long support life cycles be handled?</h2>
	A special Long Term Servicing Branch (LTSB) will be available for enterprises that want the latest security updates (much like a service pack) but don’t want to impact their mission critical systems with new features. Microsoft is committed to supporting each Long Term Servicing Branch for 10 years. The Long Term Servicing Branch will require Windows Server Update Service and Windows Enterprise edition.
	<h2>What about my existing deployment tools?</h2>
	Microsoft has stated that all existing update deployment tools, such as Windows Server Update Service and System Center Configuration Manager, will continue to work as expected. See how System Center Configuration Manager helps you <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/windows-10-user-management" target="_blank">manage your users</a>.
	<h3>A Summary of Windows Branches</h3>
	
	<table>
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td>B<strong>ranch</strong></td>
	<td><strong>Description</strong></td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Insider Branch</strong></td>
	<td>Several million members of the Windows Insider program will be the first to receive the latest and greatest features Microsoft has to offer. These users will be allowed to test and provider direct feedback to Microsoft.</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Current Branch (CB)</strong></td>
	<td>Windows Update is used by hundreds of millions of users. As features are made generally available, users of Windows Update will be automatically opted into these new features.</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Current Branch for Business (CBB)</strong></td>
	<td>This branch will be distributed through Microsoft's new Windows Update for Business (WUB). Microsoft will promote a current branch after four months and allow business eight months to prepare for broad deployment. Requires Windows Pro or Enterprise.</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td><strong>Long-Term Servicing Branch (LTSB)</strong></td>
	<td>Distributed through WSUS, this branch will contain security updates only. While security updates will continue to be deployed as they are released, this branch can be thought of as Microsoft's traditional service pack model. Requires Windows Enterprise.</td>
	</tr>
	</tbody>
	</table>
	
	<h2>Conclusion</h2>
	It’s exciting to see Microsoft bringing users closer to the development process and at the same time bringing new features to market faster.
	
	How will the new Windows 10 and Windows as a Service impact your business? What should your implementation strategy be?
	
	Give us a call at 630.572.0240 or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">send us an email</a> and tell us about your business. As a Microsoft Certified Gold Partner and an award-winning multi-practice IT consulting firm, we have the breadth and depth to grow your business across a full spectrum of IT solutions.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17688 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/windows-as-a-service.jpg" alt="windows-as-a-service" width="795" height="441" /></content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Customer Data Confidentiality in Microsoft Office 365</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/data-confidentiality-microsoft-office-365</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 21 Jul 2015 13:42:32 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[jefflanham]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17720</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[As more organizations consider moving some (or all) of their information technology out of their own datacenters or “closets” into Microsoft's cloud services – Office 365 and Azure, there are a host of considerations that need to be addressed. From a functional perspective, Exchange Online, SharePoint Online, and the rest of the back-end products in the Office 365 suite are continually improving, and many of the technical caveats have been addressed. Microsoft is truly making good on their “cloud first” promise, and for some time now, enhancements to Exchange, SharePoint, and other suite products are being rolled out to Office 365 Online before they are even made available for on-premises deployments.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a>
	<h2>The Last Frontier</h2>
	For many types of organizations, the legal, compliance, security, and confidentiality issues are the “last frontier.” Even if you believe that Microsoft's cloud offering has the functional and technical capabilities to meet your needs, you still have to trust that Microsoft will keep your data safe, secure and confidential, not just hackers and terrorists, but also from the government and even Microsoft itself. To its credit, Microsoft has been doing a better job of opening up about key aspects of its Office 365 solutions, and the <a href="https://products.office.com/en-us/business/office-365-trust-center-cloud-computing-security" target="_blank">Office 365 Trust Center</a> is a great resource for understanding how your data will be protected. In most cases, <strong>your ‘company jewels’ will be safer and more secure in the Microsoft cloud than they would be on your own internal servers,</strong> and that is good enough for many types of organizations.
	
	But what about scenarios where you need <em>absolute assurance</em> that no unauthorized parties (including Microsoft support engineers) will have access to your most sensitive data? Law firms are a good example: confidential documents and correspondence are subject to “attorney-client privilege,” and disclosure to anyone (including Microsoft support engineers) constitutes a “breach of privilege” that can have significant negative consequences for both client and attorney. Does Office 365 provide the level of confidentiality required to support such scenarios?
	<h2>New Tools for Managing Sensitive Data</h2>
	The answer is: almost, but not quite yet. While your customer data is encrypted in Office 365, and there is a robust lockbox process in place that ensures no one at Microsoft has open access to your data, you still can't be entirely sure when or why it's being accessed. The good news is that <strong>new capabilities are coming to Office 365 that will ensure fully-compliant privacy and confidentiality of your sensitive data.</strong> Microsoft recently announced <a href="https://blogs.office.com/2015/04/21/announcing-customer-lockbox-for-office-365/" target="_blank">Customer Lockbox</a>, which will provide customers with the ability to explicitly approve or reject any request for access to their data, whether for support purposes or whatever. Additionally, the <a href="https://blogs.office.com/2015/04/21/enhancing-transparency-and-control-for-office-365-customers/" target="_blank">Enhancing transparency and control for Office 365 customers</a> blog article indicates that, in 2016, Microsoft expects to enable customers to generate and control their own keys for encrypting content in Office 365. Finally, the <a href="https://blogs.office.com/2015/04/21/announcing-the-new-office-365-management-activity-api-for-security-and-compliance-monitoring/" target="_blank">new Office 365 Management Activity API</a> will enable custom reports and push notifications for customer data access events.
	<h2>Conclusion</h2>
	Microsoft is clearly taking the need to provide maximum security, confidentiality and transparency for its customers' sensitive data in Office 365 seriously. If you have previously written off Office 365 due to privacy concerns, it might be time to reconsider. As always, SWC stands ready to help you evaluate Office 365 (and many other potential options), so you can make the best decisions about what's right for your business, now and in the future.
	
	To learn more, please join us at our upcoming <a href="http://www.swc.com/events">Chicagoland Office 365 events</a>, call 630.572.0240 or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">email</a> one of our technology experts.
	<h3>Recommended Posts:</h3>
	If you would like to learn more, please check out some of our related past posts:
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-technology-roadmap-event-recap" target="_blank">Microsoft’s Annual Technology Roadmap Event Recap</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/what-is-microsoft-365" target="_blank">How Can Office 365 Help My Organization?</a>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/encrypt-email-exchange-online-office-365" target="_blank">Encrypt Your Email with Exchange Online Protection and Office 365</a>
	></content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Benefits of Using WordPress Content Management System (CMS)</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/wordpress-content-management-system</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 23 Jul 2015 15:32:44 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mary]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17732</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[In today’s fast-paced world, a good CMS has transitioned from being a nice thing to have to an absolute necessity. If you aren’t familiar with what a CMS can do, here is the quick definition: <em>Content Management System (CMS) is a software that allows you to create, update and publish content and multimedia on your website or blog without extensive coding knowledge.</em>
	<h2>Why a CMS is Necessary</h2>
	<ul>
		<li><span style="text-decoration: underline;">C<strong>ontent is King:</strong></span> A CMS allows you the capability to quickly <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/fresh-content-seo" target="_blank">produce fresh content to drive rankings and ROI</a></li>
		<li><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Time is Money:</strong></span> Third party turnaround can take days, or even weeks. This won’t cut it when your competition is able to make the same changes in mere seconds.</li>
		<li><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Control is Key:</strong></span> What happens when you have a custom website built by a programmer… who then decides to not work for you anymore? Most developers today know their way around WordPress, but very few would easily be able to come in and decipher the unique complexity of a custom built website designed by a single individual.</li>
	</ul>
	<h2>Why WordPress is the Right Choice</h2>
	There are several CMS platforms available, but WordPress is far and away the best option for your content marketing efforts. People often make the mistake of classifying WordPress as a simple blogging tool. While this was once true, WordPress has evolved into a fully-functioning content management system <a href="http://w3techs.com/technologies/overview/content_management/all" target="_blank">responsible for more than 24% of all websites, that is a content management system market share of 60.4%</a>! The website you’re on right now uses WordPress, as well as millions of the most prominent brands in the world, including The New Yorker, Ford, Sony Music, Google Ventures, eBay and many more.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17745" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/WordPress-CMS.jpg" alt="WordPress-CMS" width="550" height="354" />
	
	So why do so many companies rely on WordPress to power their digital assets and content marketing efforts? Let’s explore some of the many advantages of WordPress.
	
	<strong>User-Friendliness</strong>
	One of the biggest advantages of WordPress is its user-friendliness. If you have the basic skills to edit a Word document, you already have what it takes to edit and create webpages in WordPress.
	
	<strong>Open-Source</strong>
	WordPress allows anyone to access its blueprints, manipulate and redistribute it to the masses. Developers create templates and custom features in the form of plugins, many of which are free.
	
	<strong>Cost-Effective</strong>
	Since WordPress is an open source CMS platform, there are no licensing costs. You are free to download templates and add-ons already created by developers and use them in any way you like. To get a more exclusive feel, hiring a third party <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing" target="_blank">internet marketing agency</a> to provide unique design elements, branding and SEO expertise is recommended. Nonetheless, the cost of these customizations become significantly reduced when the basic framework is already in place.
	
	<strong>Security</strong>
	With all this free access, there is a popular misconception that WordPress is not secure. The truth is, security threats are everywhere. WordPress is the most widely used CMS in the world, so naturally security breaches happen – as they do with non-WordPress sites as well. The differentiating factor between a secure site and a non-secure site are the people involved in developing and maintaining it.
	
	<strong>Search Engine Optimization (SEO) Friendly </strong>
	Just by choosing WordPress, you’re automatically taking care of around 80% to 90% of the mechanics of Search Engine Optimization (SEO). In other words, the construction of WordPress’ code is engineered in a way that search engines find very inviting for indexing. But don’t take my word for it, this statement comes straight from <a href="http://wordpress.tv/2009/05/30/matt-cutts-google-sf09/" target="_blank">Google</a>. You can’t just “set it and forget it” though. To fully realize the benefits of a SEO-optimized website, hiring an <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">SEO agency</a> for ongoing keyword, competition and traffic analysis is highly recommended.
	
	<strong>Control</strong>
	You may want to think twice before working with a digital agency that builds your website on a custom-built CMS. Should you ever decide to take a different direction, or worse, come to find out your agency isn’t delivering what they promised, it won’t be easy to part ways. Why? Because your website is trapped inside their technology! The only way to get it back is in the form of a confusing mess of site files, forcing you to essentially rebuild your website from scratch.
	<h2>WordPress and Content Marketing for the Future</h2>
	WordPress offers so much more than a quick and easy way to get a site up and running. This blogging-based software has revolutionized the way websites are constructed. The speed at which content can now be produced, altered and shared with the masses has forever changed the expectations of consumers and created several new avenues to reach your target market. Whether you’re launching a new business or you’re considering revamping your existing website, selecting a CMS is a vital first step in taking your marketing efforts to the next level.
	
	For more information on WordPress website development or to learn how to utilize your website and other digital channels to increase ROI, attend our next <a href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Digital Marketing Luncheon</a>.
	<h2>Want to learn more about SEO?</h2>
	Attend SWC’s <a title="Internet Marketing Event" href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland SEO and Internet Marketing event</a> where Mark Fitzsimmons and Kristen Schmid showcase “best-in-class” examples of web design, Search Engine Optimization and digital marketing strategy. This complimentary event is a great opportunity to begin the conversation around SEO and Security and see what actually works from today’s market leaders.
	<h2>Download Our Infographic</h2>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-seo-stats-infographic-012015.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-15447" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-seo-stats-infographic-sm-012015.png" alt="SWC SEO Stats Infographic SM" width="500" height="764" /></a></content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>The IoT Tidal Wave is Here! Are You Ready?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/iot-today-are-you-ready</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 27 Jul 2015 14:14:59 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17767</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[We are now fully immersed in the information age. Organizations large and small are swimming (and some sinking) in data! When I started my <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/business-intelligence">business intelligence</a> (BI) career, the data was mostly trapped in systems and retrieving that data was a fairly straightforward task. Today, new and interesting data challenges crop up out of all kinds of unexpected places.
	
	Though not a new idea, the rise of the “Internet of Things” or IoT is an emerging challenge for analytics. But is there value in IoT data?
	<h2>Early IoT Beginnings</h2>
	Way back in the early ‘90s I got my first exposure to IoT (when it wasn’t called IoT). I was in college at North Dakota State University in Fargo, ND and my father was growing his electrical contracting business into some new markets. One of those new markets was potato warehouse storage systems. These warehouses were typically very large and situated in the middle of nowhere out in the Red River Valley of ND. It was not practical to have human resources manually monitoring these systems, so automation was absolutely necessary.
	
	To guarantee a quality product and ensure that spuds harvested in September could be stored until June required a fair amount of instrumentation and technology. In particular, these warehouse systems needed to monitor and regulate temperature, humidity, and airflow. Enter the precursor to IoT. At the time I really didn’t grasp how important and pervasive this type of technology would become. I can still remember my dad checking on his systems with his laptop and 9600 baud modem, running reports on temperature and humidity and marking remote adjustments to ensure storage conditions.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17768" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/baud-modem-1024x568.jpg" alt="baud-modem" width="500" height="277" />
	<h2>Why I Should Care About the Internet of Things?</h2>
	IoT data is large, in many cases extremely redundant, and often unstructured in its root form. But there is value there, and organizations committed to <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/qlikview-vs-tableau" target="_blank">analytics and business intelligence</a> should be taking note, or at the very least, taking stock of what is out there. Most organizations don’t have unlimited IT budgets to see if there is value in the latest BI trend. Decision makers need to be pragmatic about IoT data. When my clients ask about IoT, I always suggest that they start with these discovery topics:
	<ul>
		<li>Catalog your sources</li>
		<li>What data do you have, can you have and should you have from candidate IoT sources?</li>
		<li>Assuming that this data can be accessed, stored and possibly transformed, will there be any business value to this data.</li>
		<li>What decisions and levers can I pull with access to this data?</li>
		<li>Could my business use this <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/master-data-management-solve-data-quality" target="_blank">data to make tactical predictions</a> for the future?</li>
		<li>Which sources have the highest value? Aim for the low hanging fruit first.</li>
		<li>What is my cost to develop these sources into useable information that can drive my business? Some sources will incur more cost for data preparation and cleansing.</li>
	</ul>
	It’s important to have definitive answers to these questions when embarking on an IoT project or any new data source that you want integrated with your analytics systems—whether it be an enterprise data warehouse, data lake, data mart or database. Do you have questions about IoT or analytics in general? If you would like more information about IoT or what business intelligence can do you for your organization, <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact swc</a> or call 630.572.0240 to speak with one of our BI experts.</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Meet the Office 365 Compliance Center</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/office-365-compliance-center</link>
			<pubDate>Thu, 30 Jul 2015 16:44:12 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Sam Murcio]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17842</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Is your organization asking the following data compliance and data management questions?
	<ul>
		<li>Is there a more efficient method of managing compliance across my tenant?</li>
		<li>How can I give non-admins access to perform compliance activities without providing them admin rights?</li>
		<li>Can I search through all data in my tenant without setting up an eDiscovery site and cases?</li>
		<li>Can I easily view all users with archiving enabled, or can I bulk enable\disable archiving without PowerShell?</li>
		<li>What if I do not want to <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-mobile-device-management" target="_blank">wipe <em>all</em> the data</a> from my users’ personal mobile devices?</li>
		<li>My organization has been subpoenaed to provide mailbox data. Do I really need to configure and setup sites in SharePoint for eDiscovery?</li>
		<li>I require mobile device management, but the Exchange Online mobile device policy doesn’t cut it, and I do not want to purchase Intune or other 3rd party solutions. Are there any other built-in options?</li>
		<li>I have tons of mail data in a third party archiving solution or PSTs dispersed throughout my organization. How can I get this data into Office 365 securely?</li>
		<li>I want to migrate entire file shares, maybe even an entire file server into <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/cloud-based-sharepoint" target="_blank">SharePoint Online</a>. Is there a relatively easy and secure method available?</li>
	</ul>
	If so, Microsoft Office 365 Compliance Center has your answers.
	
	Microsoft understands organizations require comprehensive features to manage and secure the data imported and created in Office 365. With that said, let’s take a look at why, in my opinion, it is <strong>one of the most important updates and features added to Office 365</strong>.
	<h2>Compliance Tasks Have Never Been Easier</h2>
	The Office 365 Compliance Center consolidates the core compliance-related features administrators use to manage and secure their tenant data across Office 365, Exchange Online, and SharePoint Online. You may recognize some functions in this new management portal. Microsoft has moved and will continue to move features into this console from their respective services; for example, archiving and retention from Exchange Online.
	
	The new center makes the sometimes dreaded compliance tasks easier to access and manage. Global admins in Office 365 can access the compliance center through the Office 365 Admin portal, the link is located under the Admin heading in the navigation page. It is also accessible via a dedicated link: <a href="https://compliance.protection.outlook.com/" target="_blank">https://compliance.protection.outlook.com</a>, which can be accessed by your non-technical workers without having to grant administrative rights to your entire tenant.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17844 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/o365-comp-center-image-1.jpg" alt="o365-comp-center-image-1" width="500" height="187" />
	<h2>Permissions in the Office 365 Compliance Center</h2>
	One of the key components which makes access to and management of the Compliance Center an almost enjoyable experience is the <strong>inclusion of the Role Based Access Control (RBAC) permissions</strong> model. RBAC allows you to grant task-specific permissions to users. These permissions will allow the user to access the compliance center directly and perform only their assigned administrative responsibilities.
	
	It is important to note that the RBAC permissions in the Compliance Center are specific only to this console, and membership does not carry over to other Office 365 services. Also, some of the Compliance Center features require additional permissions to be assigned in the respective service. For example, to manage Retention, a user must also be added to the Compliance or Records RBAC group in Exchange Online. As always, <strong>you want to assign the least amount of privileges required for a user to perform their administrative tasks</strong>. Below is a table listing the different administrative roles, their inherited roles, and a description to help you determine where to add your compliance officers.
	
	<table>
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td>RBAC Group</td>
	<td>Roles</td>
	<td>Description</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>ComplianceAdministrator</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Organization Configuration</li>
		<li>View-Only Audit Logs</li>
		<li>View-Only Recipients</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Manages settings for the core compliance features; DLP, device management, reports, auditing, etc.</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>eDiscoveryManager</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Case Management</li>
		<li>Compliance Search</li>
		<li>Export</li>
		<li>Hold</li>
		<li>Preview</li>
		<li>Review</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Can perform searches against and place on hold mailboxes, SharePoint Online sites, and OneDrive for Business content</li>
		<li>Can access the new Compliance Share feature</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>OrganizationManagement</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Audit Logs</li>
		<li>Organization Configuration</li>
		<li>Role Management</li>
		<li>Search And Purge</li>
		<li>View-Only Audit Logs</li>
		<li>View-Only Recipients</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Can add or remove permissions to Compliance Center features</li>
		<li>Manges settings for the core compliance features; DLP, device management, reports, auditing, etc.</li>
		<li>Members of the Office 365 Global Admins RBAC group are automatically added this group</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Reviewer</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Review</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	<td>
	<ul>
		<li>Can perform analytics on assigned documents using the soon to arrive tool, Zoom</li>
	</ul>
	</td>
	</tr>
	</tbody>
	</table>
	
	<h2>What Can I Accomplish in the Office 365 Compliance Center?</h2>
	Not sold yet on the new Compliance Center just by the easier management of permissions and access? Let’s walk through some of the readily available and most used features in the console; I’m sure there’ll be a few items that will make you a fan.
	<h2>Archiving</h2>
	Mail archiving is a service that has been available since Exchange 2010 SP2, so it’s not a new feature by any means. However, the management tasks available in the Compliance Center make managing the service a super simple administrative task.
	<ul>
		<li>Easily view which users have mail archiving enabled or disabled</li>
		<li>Enable or disable archiving one user at a time or in bulk</li>
		<li>Quick view of a user’s mailbox usage stats</li>
	</ul>
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17845 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/o365-comp-center-image-2.jpg" alt="o365-comp-center-image-2" width="500" height="234" />
	<h2>Device Management</h2>
	Unlike Archiving, this feature is not another management tool for similar services already available in Exchange Online; mobile device access rules and mobile device mailbox policies. In actuality, the mobile device management policies will take precedence and override any mobile device policies currently configured through Exchange Online in your tenant—something to keep in mind before deploying to your users. The features available through this service leverage Microsoft Intune and Microsoft Azure Active Directory, and are available at no added cost to all commercial Office 365 plans.
	
	Below is a limited comparison list of mobile device controls available in Office 365 via <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-mobile-device-management" target="_blank">mobile device management </a>and Exchange Online:
	
	<table>
	<tbody>
	<tr>
	<td>Feature</td>
	<td>Mobile Device Management (MDM)</td>
	<td>Exchange Online</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Restrict access to email</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Require the use of a password on device</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Require encryption on device</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Exclude users from access restrictions</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Perform remote wipe</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Device enrollment required</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Restrict access to documents</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">No</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Restrict jailbroken devices</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">No</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Managed email profiles</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">No</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Advanced system, application, and device settings</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">No</td>
	</tr>
	<tr>
	<td>Perform selective wipe</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">Yes</td>
	<td style="text-align: center;">No</td>
	</tr>
	</tbody>
	</table>
	
	<h2>eDiscovery</h2>
	eDiscovery is another service which is already well incorporated into Microsoft services; in Office 365 eDiscovery can be used to search and place data in mailboxes, SharePoint Online sites, and <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/share-files-with-customers" target="_blank">OneDrive for Business</a> locations on hold. These searches or cases can be used to preserve data indefinitely and also export it from your tenant when required for legal reasons.
	
	In the not so distant past, in order to allow your non-admin compliance officers or HR team access to eDiscovery, you were required to manually create an eDiscovery Center in SharePoint Online. This site had to be configured correctly with the necessary permissions and connectivity to Exchange Online. Not anymore; the first time an administrator accesses the eDiscovery feature through the Compliance Center, the eDiscovery Center is automatically created and configured for you. Your only next step is to assign users to the eDiscoveryManager RBAC group to allow access.
	<h2>Retention</h2>
	The retention Compliance Center feature gives administrators granular control to the life cycle of data in their tenant. Through this feature, administrators can create and manage retention tags and retention polices for mailboxes, as well as document deletion policies for SharePoint Online and <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/share-files-with-customers" target="_blank">OneDrive for Business</a>. These policies are located in the Deletion section as they determine how long data should be present in your tenant before being acted upon.
	
	There is also a Preserve section available in the Retention feature; preservation polices allow you to keep data across your tenant for a specified amount of time (think query-based in-place holds).
	<h2>Import</h2>
	This is one of the newer features to come to the Compliance Center and it is a highly welcomed addition for administrators or IT consultants, especially individuals carrying out the actual migrations to Office 365. Import allows administrators to do just that—import mail data from PST files to Exchange Online mailboxes, as well as import files from network shares or on-premises SharePoint libraries into SharePoint Online.
	
	The data can be uploaded directly to Office 365 over your network, or it can be transferred onto hard drives and shipped to Microsoft data centers. You no longer have to deal with third party data ingestion tools, or worse yet, manually copying data using Outlook or a File Explorer session which constantly times out.
	
	Some of the key aspects of the Import service are:
	<ul>
		<li>Import PST mail data directly to specified users</li>
		<li>Import mail data to a user’s primary mailbox or archive mailbox</li>
		<li>Importing PSTs into a user’s archive mailbox allowing for an unlimited amount of data</li>
		<li>Files can be imported from network file shares or on-premises SharePoint libraries</li>
		<li>Share permissions can be maintained when importing files to SharePoint Online</li>
		<li>Network uploads are performed using command line tools, the Microsoft Azure AZCopy Tool and the SharePoint Online Management Shell</li>
		<li>Network uploads can be secured by using HTTPS</li>
		<li>All drives shipped to Microsoft must be prepared with the Microsoft Azure Import/Export Tool</li>
		<li>Drive shipping accepts only the common 3.5 inch SATA II/III drives</li>
		<li>Drives require the common NTFS formatting</li>
		<li>Only drives up to 4TB are supported</li>
		<li>All drives shipped to Microsoft must be encrypted using the provided BitLocker encryption keys</li>
		<li>BitLocker encryption keys are uploaded directly through the Compliance Center and not available to anyone</li>
		<li>If an extra layer of encryption is required, O365Protect can be used to encrypt data</li>
		<li>Destination of data is specified via “PST to user” and “file to location” CSV mapping files</li>
		<li>Data is temporarily ingested and stored in a secure and unique Azure storage space</li>
		<li>Azure Storage Explorer can be used to view the contents of your tenants dedicated storage location</li>
		<li><strong>As of this writing, this service is free for all valid Office 365 tenants</strong></li>
	</ul>
	<h2>Ok, I’m Sold. Now What?</h2>
	As you can see, the Office 365 Compliance Center is making the managing of compliance in your tenant easier, more efficient and transparent. And this is just the beginning; like everything else in Office 365, compliance feature development is moving at a feverish pace and we must keep up if we are to keep our organizations compliant. If you would like to further discuss how compliance can be better utilized and deployed in your tenant, or if you have further questions on any of the items covered here, let our team of Office 365 experts at SWC Technology Partners assist you. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Email us</a> or call us at 630.572.0240 today.
	Stay tuned, as my next blog will take a look at some of the newer functionality Microsoft will be adding to Compliance Center.
	<h3>Map the Road to Business Success with Microsoft &amp; SWC</h3>
	<a href=" /Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src=" /uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a></content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>The Great Patch Race</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/security/security-patch</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 05 Aug 2015 14:51:47 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[tommymontgomery]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17884</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Managing patches for vulnerabilities is quickly becoming a full time job for companies. In response to attackers’ willingness to pay to leverage new vulnerabilities to infect your systems, a thriving exploit broker scene has emerged. This has fueled the explosion of zero-day exploits as well as subsequent patches that are released by vendors such as Microsoft and Adobe. The result is a full on race to patch your systems before attackers exploit any vulnerabilities. The time to exploit systems is getting shorter and shorter—to the point where it is no longer feasible to test patches, notify users and finally push the fix to all of your systems.
	<h2>Zero-day Protection</h2>
	So what are we left to do if we can’t patch fast enough? This is where true zero-day or signatureless protection comes in. Traditional antivirus (A/V) uses signatures that are created once a sample of a piece of malware is found. If there is no signature for the malicious software then your A/V will allow the application to execute. This poses an obvious problem if the A/V vendor cannot access a sample and write a corresponding signature fast enough. Zero-day protection does not rely on such signatures, instead it looks at how the malware behaves and makes a determination if it should be allowed to run. This model does not rely on acquiring a sample, having a signature or even knowing about a vulnerability. Rather, <strong>it’s protection by default</strong>.
	<h2>SWC’s Malware Protection Plan</h2>
	SWC has developed a zero-day protection plan to mitigate vulnerabilities and provide companies time to test patches and deploy at their own pace. <strong>Companies will never win the patch race against attackers</strong>; it’s simply too daunting to patch your entire environment every time a 3rd party or critical Microsoft patch is released.
	
	Our approach consists of network border protection with appliances such as FireEye, Palo Alto or Fortinet sandboxing appliances. The latter two can also serve as functional Next-Gen firewalls with AD integration to gain better visibility into the network. To keep with the defense in depth (DiD) principle, endpoint signatureless zero-day protection such as Malwarebytes Endpoint Enterprise (Anti-Malware and Anti-Exploit), as well as application whitelisting (i.e. Bit9) is also recommended. Together, these products wrap signatureless zero-day protection around your endpoints and servers, which <strong>buys you the time you need to test and deploy patches in a consistent and safe fashion without racing the attackers.</strong>
	<h2>Train Your Users to Identify Possible Attacks</h2>
	When attackers do launch their attacks, they commonly start with a <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/email-phishing" target="_blank">phishing email</a> that attempts to trick a user into clicking a malicious link or opening an exploit-rigged file. <strong>It’s very important to train users how to identify and deal with phishing emails.</strong> Assess how likely your users are to click on malicious emails and then tailor a security awareness program to address your risks. <strong>SWC has a robust phishing assessment program </strong>that can pinpoint users that are susceptible to phishing attacks and then train them on how to spot a phish before it’s too late.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-16121 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/security-awareness-training.jpg" alt="security-awareness-training" width="500" height="441" /></a>
	<h2>Reduce Your Risk of Zero-Day Vulnerabilities with SWC’s Security Expertise</h2>
	SWC has been deploying zero-day protection and anti-phishing solutions in a variety of scenarios and verticals. We can help your organization reduce the risk of zero-day vulnerabilities and phishing attacks. We invite you to <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">contact SWC</a> (630.572.0240) about how we can help secure your systems with advanced protection capabilities.</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>IT Leaders Are Excited About Windows 10 Features</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/windows-10-features</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 07 Aug 2015 13:17:31 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[petelee]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17898</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Windows 10 was recently unveiled to the world on July 29th with much fanfare and expectation. That was validated when SWC’s Windows 10 release luncheons at The Gage on Michigan Avenue in Downtown Chicago and Maggiano’s Little Italy in Oak Brook attracted at-capacity crowds of IT leaders. According to local Microsoft representatives, the event at Maggiano’s with over 150 total attendees was one of the largest Windows 10 events hosted in Chicagoland.
	
	At these events, SWC, Microsoft and partners demoed how the new operating system is familiar, secure, productive, and flexible. Here are some highlights:
	<h2>Virtual Desktop</h2>
	Not to be confused with <strong>desktop virtualization</strong>, which is where you run a virtual operating system instance separate from your physical computer, a <strong>virtual desktop</strong> is a way of extending your workspace beyond what is shown on the screen at that moment. Windows 10 virtual desktops allow you to have multiple workspace windows running, each with its own programs. For instance, you might have separate work or personal virtual desktops. You can easily toggle between them—just click the “Task View” button in the bottom left of the Taskbar or press the Windows key + Tab. You can also move programs between virtual desktops.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-17899" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/virtual-desktop.png" alt="virtual-desktop" width="500" height="258" />
	<em>Photo courtesy of Microsoft</em>
	<h2>Continuum</h2>
	Continuum allows everyone to have the best Windows 10 experience as they move from device to device while adapting to the way the device is being used. For instance, if you are using a Surface Pro 3 and detach the keyboard, Windows 10 will ask you if you want to enter Tablet Mode. It will then switch over to a larger, more touch-friendly design.
	<h2>Start Menu</h2>
	The Windows 10 Start Menu will attract fans of Windows 7 and Windows 8 alike. Similar to Windows 7, the Windows 10 Start Menu features shortcuts and the ability to search and scroll through all of your applications. It also includes live tiles that you can add, resize, and rearrange. You can further customize the Start Menu by adjusting the size, color, shortcuts, and by grouping applications.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-17900" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/virtual-desktop-menu.jpg" alt="virtual-desktop-menu" width="500" height="326" />
	<em>Photo courtesy of Microsoft</em>
	<h2>Security</h2>
	Security was top of mind for attendees, and the majority of their questions and feedback centered on Window's 10 security. IT administrators will be happy with the ease of use of built-in features like two-factor authentication, data loss protection (DLP), and VPN. DLP distinguishes between personal and corporate data while encrypting data as it arrives on your device from corporate locations. In addition, Windows 10 has features to prevent security attacks and malware that allow IT administrators to determine which apps are trustworthy, and if necessary, lockdown devices and apps that haven’t been signed using a Microsoft-provided signing service.
	<h2>Cortana</h2>
	Cortana is your personal digital assistant. Click the microphone icon and ask Cortana to find a file, set up a meeting, compose an email, tell you a joke and much more.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-17901" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/cortana-digital-assistant.png" alt="cortana-digital-assistant" width="316" height="500" />
	<em>Photo courtesy of Microsoft</em>
	<h2>Microsoft Edge</h2>
	Microsoft’s new Edge browser allows you to take notes or highlight information directly on webpages to save and share. There is also a Reading View that removes the distractions from a webpage to allow you to focus in on the article. Cortana is built into Microsoft Edge and can reveal instant answers to your queries without even having to explore search engine results.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-17902" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Microsoft-edge.png" alt="Microsoft-edge" width="500" height="373" />
	<em>Photo courtesy of Microsoft</em>
	<h2>Internet of Things and Business Intelligence</h2>
	Chad Dotzenrod, Director of Business Intelligence for SWC, showed how the <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/iot-today-are-you-ready" target="_blank">Internet of Things (IoT)</a> and Power BI already exist in lots of daily tech like mall kiosks, automobiles, and security systems. He demonstrated how simply typing a query like, “Which territory had the most sales in 2013” instantly returned the answer in the form of rich visuals like graphs and charts. He also used Power BI to tap into Twitter conversations and display real-time sentiment on a particular topic.
	
	We’re very excited where Microsoft is taking BI and eagerly awaiting Q4 when Cortana is integrated into the Power BI stack.
	<h2>Windows 10</h2>
	Many organizations are already making plans to upgrade to the powerfully productive and secure Windows 10 OS, so if you’d like to take your workplace to the next level, give us a call at 630.572.0240 or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">send us an email</a> and tell us about your business requirements.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Windows-10-Deck.pdf "><img class="alignnone wp-image-17910" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Windows-10-GTM-Deck.png" alt="Windows 10 GTM Deck" width="500" height="375" /></a></content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>The Evolution of SharePoint</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/customization-evolution</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 10 Aug 2015 17:02:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Roberto Valadez]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17913</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[As a SWC SharePoint Principal Consultant since 2008, I’ve experienced the evolution of the product. At SWC, we’ve helped many customers <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-sharepoint/swc-sharepoint-way" target="_blank">customize their SharePoint environments</a> — from the basic “I want to make SharePoint not look like SharePoint” to adding out-of-the-box functionality.
	<h2>SharePoint 2007 Introduces API</h2>
	SharePoint 2007 simplified these customizations for developers. In this version, Microsoft created an official application programming interface (API) for SharePoint. It allowed developers to package their customizations into features that could easily be turned on or off by end users. It also introduced an easier way to brand SharePoint by utilizing Master Pages for a consistent look and feel. Master Pages allow SharePoint to maintain a consistent header and top/left navigation area. That was good news for us since branding was the first thing we wanted to change in SharePoint 2007.
	
	Another improvement in SharePoint 2007 was the introduction of web parts. A web part is essentially a single configurable/reusable component or widget that can be used across many sites and site collections.
	
	The most important improvement was the unification of the backend components. This meant that all SharePoint customizations had to utilize the .NET framework. This made perfect sense since SharePoint and .NET are both Microsoft products. The only downside was that this meant no customizations could be written in other programming languages—even older Microsoft languages like VB and ASP.
	<h2>SharePoint 2013 Introduces App Model</h2>
	SharePoint introduced the now familiar “App Model” concept. This is a re-imagined concept for how customizations are created and utilized within both <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/cloud-based-sharepoint" target="_blank">on-premises and Office 365 instances of SharePoint</a>.
	
	In SharePoint 2013, <strong>users can purchase and install pre-approved third party customizations and tools to use on their instance of SharePoint.</strong> Companies can even go as far as customizing what apps are available to users within their own instance of the app store.
	
	At its core, the App Model changes how customizations are written, deployed and managed within SharePoint. Currently there are two types of apps that are supported by the App Model:
	<ul>
		<li><strong>SharePoint Hosted Apps:</strong> <a href="https://store.office.com/appshome.aspx?productgroup=SharePoint" target="_blank">SharePoint apps</a> are hosted within the SharePoint infrastructure, and they are generally geared towards SharePoint components. These apps will typically only use client side API’s such as JSOM (JavaScript Object Model) or REST.</li>
		<li><strong>Provider Hosted Apps:</strong> These apps are always externally hosted and will contain at least one remote component. This component can be anything from a service to a database to store data/information. What makes these apps so flexible is their ability to be hosted on any web technology stack—even apache and Linux servers.</li>
	</ul>
	As with any new technology or framework, there are good things about the new App Model, and there are not-so-good things.
	
	<strong>The Good:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li><strong>The App Model now makes it possible for developers to create their customizations in any language,</strong> not just .NET. It allows developers to host their applications on external systems while still providing access to SharePoint. This is a huge advantage simply because developers can now use the language or technology stack they are most comfortable in, and it allows developers to select the appropriate hosting options that best meets their needs; all developers have to do is learn is the SharePoint API.</li>
		<li>With the use of the app store, SharePoint allows for third party companies to distribute their tools and customizations globally.</li>
		<li>Since customizations for SharePoint no longer require you to deploy full trusted libraries to the Global Assembly Cache (GAC), SharePoint environments are now more secure and stable.</li>
	</ul>
	<strong>The Not-So-Good:</strong>
	<ul>
		<li>With the introduction of the new App Model, and with more and more companies moving to the cloud, any customization that has been done to SharePoint before the 2013 release will have to be re-designed and implemented in the new App Model methodology.</li>
		<li>Many of the customizations and freedoms we took for granted in our code now become a bit more challenging and require extra effort to develop.</li>
	</ul>
	[caption id="attachment_17916" align="alignnone" width="700"]<img class="wp-image-17916" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/sharepoint-evolution.jpg" alt="Image courtesy of Microsoft TechNet" width="700" height="368" /> Image courtesy of Microsoft TechNet[/caption]
	
	All in all, I believe the new App Model is a move in the right direction, especially if SharePoint wants to keep up with the push toward the cloud. By adopting the app store concept that has been successfully employed by other big organizations like Google and Apple, Microsoft is opening the doors for great ideas to be developed for the community without the need to wait for Microsoft to provide those features. Some might consider the App Model to have too many limitations; however, the increased security and stability that it introduces makes it a big step in the right direction.
	
	Whether you are new to SharePoint or need to increase user adoption, SWC will work with you to make sure your SharePoint site is a go-to hub for content management and collaboration. Attend our next <a href="http://www.swc.com/sharepoint-luncheon-2-website" target="_blank">complimentary SharePoint luncheon</a> and see for yourself, or give us a call at 630.572.0240 or send us an email and tell us about your business goals.</content:encoded>

			<wp:postmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_opengraph-title</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Is Your Business Evolving with SharePoint?]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:postmeta>
			<wp:postmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_opengraph-description</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[With SharePoint 2013’s App Model and the upcoming release of SharePoint 2016, customizing and getting your users to adopt SharePoint is easier than ever.]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:postmeta>
			<wp:postmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_opengraph-image</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[http://www.swc.com/uploads/sharepoint-evolution.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:postmeta>
			<wp:postmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_title</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[SharePoint Customization Development Evolution]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:postmeta>
			<wp:postmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_metadesc</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[With SharePoint 2013’s App Model and the upcoming release of SharePoint 2016, customizing and getting your users to adopt SharePoint is easier than ever.]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:postmeta>
			<wp:postmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_meta-robots-noindex</wp:meta_key>

		<item>
			<title>System Center 2016 Technical Preview 2 Features</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/system-center-2016-preview</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 11 Aug 2015 21:58:42 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[bradellison]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17926</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Microsoft System Center 2016 is knocking on the door, and it’s chocked full of new features that are exciting all of us here as SWC. While only in Technical Preview 2 at the moment, we can expect System Center 2016 to be released early next year - and can already tell it's definitely worthy of migration. We are also excited to announce the expected release of system center Configuration Manager (SCCM) 2016 within the next few months, decoupled from the rest of the suite.
	<h2>New Features in Microsoft System Center 2016</h2>
	In announcing Technical Preview 2, Microsoft noted some of its favorite new System Center 2016. It now supports things like “mixed mode cluster upgrades” and it allows “enhanced scale-out file server management.” Microsoft also added the feature, “Desired State Configuration” support for managing Linux devices, which is a really cool PowerShell-enabled scheme for setting an optimal configuration state. Additionally, Microsoft System Center 2016 has improved monitoring of the LAMP stack (Linux, Apache, MySQL and PHP).
	
	Microsoft System Center 2016 Technical Preview 2 also complements Microsoft Operations Management Suite (<a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/server-cloud/operations-management-suite/Overview.aspx?WT.mc_id=Blog_SC_Announce_TTD" target="_blank">OMS</a>). Introduced during the Microsoft Ignite event, OMS is conceived as a standalone or complementary solution for organizations with hybrid environments to manage. Here's how a Microsoft spokesperson described OMS:
	
	<em>“OMS is a set of cloud-based services that customers can start using right away to simplify hybrid cloud management. Customers can either use OMS directly, or to complement their existing System Center management solutions with cross-cloud management capabilities, cloud-based log analytics, and additional core management capabilities such as protection, automation and security. As a cloud service, OMS offers customers rapid time to value without the complexity of deploying and integrating the various services.”</em>
	
	Furthermore, evaluators can use System Center 2016 Technical Preview 2 to test <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/windows-10-features" target="_blank">Windows 10</a> in-place upgrades. The upgrades can be performed from Windows 7, Windows 8 and Windows 8.1 client versions.
	
	Technical Preview 2 can also be used to test mobile application management for devices running Android 4 and later, iOS 7, and older versions of iOS. One of my favorite features is the ability to restrict copy and paste operations between managed applications and personal applications via SCCM.
	
	Technical Preview 2 also works with Microsoft Intune to protect data accessed via mobile devices. This allows users to test a passcode reset capability as well as a remote lock control feature.
	
	Finally, Microsoft described at <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/sharepoint/microsoft-ignite-2015-sharepoint" target="_blank">Ignite </a>that Technical Preview 2 is the first iteration of the product to enable Windows 10 <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/microsoft-mobile-device-management" target="_blank">mobile device management</a> for devices that are to remain on-premises. What this means is that we can control the means of management for embedded devices or "<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/iot-today-are-you-ready" target="_blank">Internet of Things</a>" types of devices, and/or highly regulated customers/networks. There’s always an element of security nowadays, and Microsoft has incorporated it into System Center 2016 quite nicely.
	<h2>Windows 10 Support</h2>
	In short, <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center" target="_blank">Microsoft System Center</a> has provided and will continue to provide enterprise-class capabilities around streamlining your data center operations while enabling an ever-increasing mobile workforce. Whether you are looking to migrate to System Center 2016 or allow your existing System Center 2012 environment to support Windows 10, feel free to drop by <a href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">our next System Center event</a> or give us a call at (630.572.0240) to discuss how our technical experts can help.</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>What’s the Best Way to Serve up Mobile Content?</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/types-of-mobile-websites</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 17 Aug 2015 14:16:37 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jim Schmitz]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17952</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Mobile content is a dish best served with your target audience in mind. With the way mobile trends are going, there is tremendous value in <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/fresh-content-seo" target="_blank">presenting your content</a> in a way that makes it easily consumable on a smartphone.
	
	If content is not easy to access via a mobile device, users will find another source for that content. Google has even adjusted their search algorithm so that <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/mobilegeddon-mobile-friendly-website" target="_blank">mobile-friendly sites receive a higher ranking</a> in searches made on a mobile device.
	
	But what is the best way to get your content in front of your target audience? Do you develop an app? Do you build a mobile version of your website? What about responsive design or a web app (is that even different than a “regular” app)?
	
	It’s essential to list the <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/application-development/mobile-device-web-application" target="_blank">pros and cons</a> of each of these solutions and help you find the one that will suit you best.
	
	As a designer and business analyst who has worked with all of these technologies, I’d like to start you on that path, but first, let’s define them.
	
	<img class="aligncenter wp-image-17957" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/OG-responsive.gif" alt="OG-responsive" width="500" height="263" />
	<h2>The App</h2>
	A mobile application, or app, is a program that is installed on a mobile device. Each operating system has a store where you can go to download apps for that device. Apps require you to agree to varying degrees of permissions before they can be installed.
	<h2>The Mobile Site</h2>
	Usually, a mobile site is built after there is already an existing non-mobile site. When a user enters a non-mobile URL on a mobile device, the system recognizes that and redirects them to the mobile site.
	
	Mobile sites can access various phone functionalities, but the user needs to actively give permission when they get to the site.
	<h2>The Responsive Site</h2>
	A website utilizing responsive design, also known as a responsive site, is a website that is designed to display differently depending on the device that is viewing it. Whether it is accessed on a desktop, tablet, or smart phone, the site knows the size of the screen and displays the page accordingly.
	<h2>The Web App</h2>
	A website application, almost always called a web app, is the least known of the options. It is a website accessed through a browser, but it is designed to look and function like an application. For all intents and purposes, it is just a mobile website. But where most websites are designed to serve information to a user, the web app is designed to be more “functional.”
	<h2>What Are Your Business Requirements?</h2>
	Let’s look at each of these pros/cons and examine some user tendencies to see how they might meet or fail to meet your business requirements.
	<h2>Online vs. Off-Line</h2>
	If your goal is for users to be able to access content while offline, an app is the way to go. Obviously, there are limitations: namely, the fact that all the content needs to be cached on the device.
	
	<h2>Accessibility</h2>
	
	A mobile site, a responsive site, and a web app can usually be used from any type of mobile device, whereas an app must have a different version created for each platform. And while it is true that there are technologies that let you build the app once and then “compile” it into different versions for each mobile operating system, these tools have limitations and will almost always produce less efficient code than if they were developed for one specific platform at a time.
	<h2>Ease of Access</h2>
	It is often easier to click on an app than it is to open your web browser and find a website. But users can be reluctant to download an app for something they do not think they will do very often, and there is an adoption curve with an app.
	<h2>Trust</h2>
	Research shows that a user is more likely to trust an app with personal information than they would trust a mobile website with the same information. There are a lot of complex sociological reasons for this, but the net result is that users are more willing to enter their credit card number in the Amazon app than on the Amazon mobile website.
	<h2>Development</h2>
	Development considerations take two forms: expertise and cost.
	
	Each of the options requires a (slightly) different skillset to create. Even if you are paying someone to create the app/site, you need to consider maintenance. You either need someone on staff who can make the updates, or you will be paying someone every time you want changes.
	
	If you build a mobile site, every time you make an update to the desktop site, you (generally) have to make it in on the mobile site as well. If you employ responsive design; however, you only have to make the change once. Depending on how the solution is created, and app may or may not need to be developed separately for each device type.
	<h2>Publishing</h2>
	Publishing information to a website is relatively easy. Apps are a different story. It takes approval time and can cost a fee for an app to be published to an app store.
	<h2>The Verdict</h2>
	In order to arrive at the right solution, you <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/custom-application-development-what-sets-swc-apart" target="_blank">need the right developer</a>. That’s where SWC comes in. We take a pragmatic approach to understanding your business needs in crafting a roadmap that solves your biggest challenges. Whether the answer is an app, a mobile website, a responsive site or a web app, our teams have the expertise and experience to tackle any project. <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">Send us an email</a> or call us today at 630.572.0240.
	</content:encoded>
