		<item>
			<title>Office 365, Azure AD and Windows 10: Domain Controller Optional</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/azure-active-directory-and-windows-10</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 19 Aug 2015 15:32:37 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[aaronsaposnik]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17961</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[When Azure Active Directory (AD) was first released, many companies asked, “Can this replace my on-premises Domain Controllers?” For Windows 7 and Windows 8/8.1, the answer is “no” because Azure AD cannot connect to the computers. However, with the recent release of <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft/windows-10-features" target="_blank">Windows 10</a>, the answer to this question gets a lot more interesting. Read on to see what I mean.
	<h2>Windows 10 and Azure AD Join</h2>
	<a href="http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/05/13/azure-active-directory-and-windows-10-making-the-enterprise-cloud-a-reality.aspx" target="_blank">Azure AD Join is a new feature in Windows 10</a> that allows a computer to associate directly with your Office 365 Azure AD tenant. Setup is simple: First, a user is prompted whether they want to connect to an organization account (Office 365) or whether they want to join a domain. If they choose to associate with an organization account, all it takes is the Office 365 user name and password and the computer will automatically connect and associate with Azure AD. Once the join is complete, single sign-on (SSO) is handled by the computer just as it would with a domain joined machine. Also, any online services or policies that are applied to the user can be easily managed centrally via <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/extending-domain-microsoft-azure" target="_blank">Azure AD</a>. These policies might include Intune or other device management services. This allows for automatic deployment of management tools as part of the joining process.
	
	[caption id="attachment_17962" align="aligncenter" width="500"]<img class="wp-image-17962" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Azure-Active-Directory-OG.jpg" alt="Image courtesy Microsoft" width="500" height="363" /> Image courtesy Microsoft[/caption]
	<h2>Can I Join a Domain and Azure AD?</h2>
	Unfortunately, with the initial release of Windows 10, each user can only connect to one or the other. If a user is looking to join to a domain, they can later associate <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/cloud/active-directory-synchronization-vs-federation" target="_blank">their Office 365 account with their domain</a> account, but it won’t be a true Azure AD Join. Similarly, if a user performs an Azure AD Join, then they won’t be able to later use that same account with a domain.
	<h2>So Which Should I Use?</h2>
	Both are very useful and whichever option you choose often depends on the type of user. For a remote machine that will rarely, if ever, communicate with the on-premises domain, using Azure AD Join may be the way to go because it provides many of the same management and monitoring benefits without requiring local access.
	
	Similarly, for smaller organizations or organizations with many remote offices that don’t have domain controllers, Azure AD Join is very beneficial. As an added bonus, since Azure AD Join can work off of synchronized users to your existing domain, you can still have the same accounts and passwords in both systems.
	
	For the standard office environment with users local to the servers, or networking in place to allow for easy domain controller communication, using Active Directory is likely still your best option. You will continue to have the same domain experience everyone has come to expect, while at the same time the SSO options with Azure and Office 365 via Azure AD Connect and ADFS will continue to be available. As of now, Active Directory also still provides the larger feature set for the management and monitoring of systems via <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/microsoft-system-center/system-center-2016-preview" target="_blank">SCCM </a>and group policies, and so is recommended for environments that require that higher level of control.
	<h2>Flexibility to Manage Different User Sets</h2>
	Whichever you choose, keep in mind that you can always mix and match. For instance, if you have a central office but also have some remote users, you can use a combination of both the traditional Active Directory and Azure AD Join to provide the best experience to each user set. With Azure AD Join, Active Directory and Windows 10 you now have a lot more management flexibility than ever before.
	
	Would you like more information on Windows 10 and your domain options? Give our infrastructure experts a call at 630.572.0240 or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">send us an email</a> and we’ll help you determine which domain option(s) are right for you.
	
	<h2>Map the Road to Business Success with Microsoft &amp; SWC</h2>
	<a href=" /Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src=" /uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a>
	</content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
			<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
			<wp:post_name>azure-active-directory-and-windows-10</wp:post_name>
			<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
			<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
			<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
			<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
			<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
			<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
			<category domain="post_tag" nicename="azure"><![CDATA[Azure]]></category>
			<category domain="post_tag" nicename="azure-ad"><![CDATA[Azure AD]]></category>
			<category domain="category" nicename="cloud"><![CDATA[Cloud]]></category>
			<category domain="post_tag" nicename="office-365"><![CDATA[Office 365]]></category>
			<category domain="post_tag" nicename="windows-10"><![CDATA[Windows 10]]></category>
			<wp:postmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>

		<item>
			<title>Microsoft’s Acquisitions Creating a CRM Renaissance</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/microsoft-dynamics-new-acquisition</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 21 Aug 2015 14:44:30 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Will Robinson]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=17966</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Are we seeing a renaissance at Microsoft when it comes to using <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/crm" target="_blank">Microsoft's Dynamics CRM</a> to service customers pre and post-sale? Two recent acquisitions by Microsoft confirm that the recent realignment of their Dynamics CRM to the Cloud and Enterprise (C+E) team was a strategic doubling down on the CRM market.
	<h2>Microsoft Acquires Global Provider of Field Service Management Systems</h2>
	The recent announcement of <a href="http://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2015/07/16/microsoft-acquires-fieldone-global-provider-of-field-service-management-solutions-for-the-enterprise/" target="_blank">Microsoft’s acquisition of FieldOne</a> gives Dynamics CRM more depth of functionality for their customer service module. FieldOne is already in the cloud which aligns well with their <a href="https://news.microsoft.com/2014/01/07/microsoft-acquires-parature-to-add-leading-customer-self-service-suite-to-microsoft-dynamics-crm/" target="_blank">Parature acquisition</a>, new <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/data-migration" target="_blank">Microsoft Dynamics Marketing </a>(MDM), and core CRM Online services.
	
	It will be interesting to see what this means for customers who use on-premises CRM. Right now, the experience with on-premises customers who use Parature or MDM is a bit disjointed; it feels like you are using software from two vendors. This will inevitably get better over time—something we are familiar with across many Microsoft-acquired and integrated products.
	<h2>Microsoft Acquires FantasySalesTeam’s Gamification Platform</h2>
	More recently, Microsoft announced the <a href="https://blogs.microsoft.com/blog/2015/08/03/microsoft-acquires-fantasysalesteam-an-innovative-sales-gamification-platform-to-help-organizations-increase-productivity/" target="_blank">acquisition of FantasySalesTeam</a>, a sales gamification platform tied to CRM that helps boost sales productivity through team-based competition.
	
	Gamification is being used more and more in sales/contact centers. Basically, it's designed to make the sales process more rewarding by motivating employees to accomplish goals and hit stated metrics.
	
	In contact centers, the quicker the customer service representative can resolve an issue, the more tickets they can get to in a day. What's interesting about this acquisition is that FantasySalesTeam is taking on gamification for sales teams. For those of us in sales, we know that many times motivating sales professionals is a little bit like herding cats. This acquisition has some "cool" factor built in because they are tying a sports fan concept into a business process. We can't wait to see how this turns out.
	<h2>The New and Improved Microsoft Dynamics</h2>
	Microsoft is doubling down on improving worker productivity within their already feature-rich and competitively-priced Dynamics CRM suite of products. Recent acquisitions only add to its value. If you would like to learn more about how your organization can take advantage of <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/customer-relationship-management/crm-maturity-model" target="_blank">managing your customer lifecycle</a>—from marketing to sales to service—give us a call at 630.572.0240 or <a href="mailto:info@swc.com">email us</a> email us about your business challenges.
	<h3>How Mature is Your Sales Process?</h3>
	Click on the link below to download our free CRM Maturity Model.
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/CRM-Download.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16522 size-medium" src="/uploads/CRM-BLOG-GUIDE.png" alt="CRM-BLOG-GUIDE" width="472" height="280" /></a></content:encoded>

			<title>Beyond the Job Posting: Life as an Application Software Developer at SWC</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/application-software-developer-jobs</link>
			<pubDate>Mon, 24 Aug 2015 14:54:47 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[franpeters]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=18016</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Walter Hogan is a Senior Consultant on the application development side of SWC’s Software Solutions Group. Walter loves the variety of <a href="http://www.swc.com/coolstuff" target="_blank">cool projects</a> he gets to work on at SWC and also being part of a dynamic team where he is constantly motivated, challenged and able to learn and grow his skills.
	
	We sat down with Walter to give potential applicants a glimpse of what it’s like to be an Application Software Developer at SWC.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>You’ve been working at SWC for a while now. What makes SWC a great place to work?</strong></h4>
	<h4></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png"><img class="  wp-image-18045 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png" alt="Walter-Hogan" width="120" height="120" /></a>My answer is the same for “What makes SWC a great place to work?” and “What’s the most challenging thing about working at SWC?” It’s the variety. Everything we do here is very fast-paced. Typically, internal IT works at a much slower pace because you have specific projects that you’re working towards, but we work on many diverse projects simultaneously.
	
	It’s fun and it’s challenging because there is constant change. I think being challenged every day is a pillar of any great IT position, and that challenge keeps you happy, motivated, and it whets your appetite to learn and grow your skills.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>What technologies do you utilize in your role?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18045 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png" alt="Walter-Hogan" width="120" height="120" /></a>I work with .NET and SQL and I split my time between application development and business intelligence (BI).
	
	With the Application Software Developer role, we like to see someone with a diverse technology background come in the door—someone with experience in technologies such as .NET, SQL, C#, Java, SharePoint, CRM, and BI.
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>What qualities make a successful Application Software Developer?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18045 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png" alt="Walter-Hogan" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	
	We try to understand a candidate’s personal career goals; do they see themselves starting to manage projects, or are they more of the technical type where they want to architect a solution but not necessarily be client-facing? If they do have an interest in being client-facing, we’d like to see related experience and understand different scenarios and challenges in communicating with clients.
	
	<strong><a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a></strong>
	<h4><strong>What are some day-to-day challenges that an Application Software Developer will face?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18045 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png" alt="Walter-Hogan" width="120" height="120" /></a>It’s one of the reasons I love my job, but managing time is one of the more difficult aspects of software development. I think that never really goes away because things are constantly changing. But if you stay organized and know how to prioritize, you can succeed. One thing I tell people coming in is that consulting is a lot different than an internal IT position. We have to be accountable for our time. That was probably the hardest thing I faced my first year here: having to figure out what I did for 8 hours and then log it. But that comes with time and experience; you learn to manage your time better.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>What was one of the most memorable projects you’ve worked on?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18045 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png" alt="Walter-Hogan" width="120" height="120" /></a>I have been fortunate enough to work on some of the biggest projects that our Software Solutions Group has ever undertaken. One in particular involved the processing of a huge volume of transactions—millions of records per day—and the application we were building needed to take into account a number of performance considerations. We couldn’t just use the first approach we came up with; we had to run different scenarios.
	
	It was difficult because the client wanted results on a tight deadline, but having that sense of accomplishment upon successful delivery to a happy client made it all worthwhile. It definitely was a growing experience. We took a lot of skills away from that.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>How is the work-life balance at SWC?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18045 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png" alt="Walter-Hogan" width="120" height="120" /></a>SWC has always made work-life balance a priority on many levels. Whether we are having a team meeting or a one-on-one meeting, work-life balance is often woven into the conversation. Occasionally it happens where there is a pressing issue and they ask for volunteers for a project, but I can think of only one time ever where it needed to be me. That’s something I appreciate because overtime has been expected at my prior jobs. People are more willing to put in the time when it’s not mandated.
	
	<strong><a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a></strong>
	<h4><strong>What professional development opportunities are there?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18045 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png" alt="Walter-Hogan" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	
	Typically, people who are in our field have a desire to keep learning, and SWC promotes that for us in Software because we have career advocates assigned to everyone. We meet with our career advocates every two weeks and they help coach us with our careers, give us advice and advocate for our professional development. Every time I’ve ever wanted to do something new, that’s the first place I go. I’ve learned new skills and technologies because I’ve asked my career advocate, “How do I get involved in the next project doing [this]?” SWC has a great career development program.
	
	The incentive system here encourages learning and skillset growth as well. You get incentives based on the level of certification you complete. The incentives are also based on company need. You’ll get incentives for certifications no matter what, but if you receive a certification that the company needs, they may offer a higher rate so that more people will be motivated to take the tests.
	
	<strong><a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a></strong>
	<h4><strong>What are some of your favorite SWC perks and experiences?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18045 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Walter-Hogan.png" alt="Walter-Hogan" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	
	The holiday party, summer outing, weekly beer o’clock, constant company lunches…it’s a long (and growing) <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers/swc-benefits" target="_blank">list of career perks</a>!
	
	Interested in learning more about joining our team as an Application Software Developer? Check out our <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers" target="_blank">careers page</a> or <a href="http://www.swc.com/contact" target="_blank">contact us</a> at to learn more! We have a variety of open positions on our technology, digital and business teams.</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Keyword Research for Modern Search Engine Optimization</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/digital-marketing/keyword-research</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 26 Aug 2015 13:53:42 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mary]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=18072</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you’ve ever wondered, “Why am I not showing up in Google for my primary keywords?” You’re not alone. Everyone wants better search ranking and they’re looking to Search Engine Optimization (SEO) for answers.
	
	The trouble is, SEO keeps changing! In the beginning, there were keywords… lots of them, all over the page. This made it easy for almost anyone to start stuffing and ranking. Today, the method to increase ranking potential is much more complex. Even if a page does not include the exact keyword used in a search query, it may still rank higher than a page that does. Given this change in Google’s algorithm, it’s natural to wonder: Do keywords still matter?
	<h2>SEO Is Not Dead</h2>
	As long there are search engines and you want your business to be found in them, SEO will always exist. The methods may change, but the goal remains the same. As the complexities of Google’s ranking algorithm continue to evolve at great speed, appointing a <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/digital-marketing/search-engine-optimization" target="_blank">dedicated SEO expert</a> has become a necessity for many organizations. Even <a href="http://gadgets.ndtv.com/internet/opinion/google-is-hiring-an-seo-expert-to-do-better-in-google-rankings-716106" target="_blank">Google is seeking an SEO expert</a> to increase rankings for its own products pages!
	
	If you’re looking for help researching, evaluating and placing keywords on your website for better optimization, there are some steps you should consider beyond just researching keyword volume and competition.
	<h2>What to Consider When Doing Keyword Research</h2>
	<h4>Target Audience</h4>
	Keyword research no longer begins with a keyword. It begins with the user. Google says it themselves:
	<blockquote>People communicate with each other by conversation, not by typing keywords – and we’ve been hard at work to make Google understand and answer your questions more like people do.</blockquote>
	- Amit Singhal, Senior Vice President of Google
	
	Before you even begin plugging keywords into research tools such as Google AdWords Keyword Planner, define the demographics of your audience, such as age, gender and geographical location. More importantly, understand what they need, their pain points, and how you’re specific products or services can give them what they want. This means searching for the most relevant keyword phrases and using them naturally in your content instead of employing the same strict keyword over and over again. By beginning your keyword research with the user, you’re not only writing content your target audience will love, you’re writing content the search engines will love as well.
	<h4>TF*IDF</h4>
	There are more than 6 billion searches conducted in Google per day. Over the years, that adds up to a massive amount of information Google can use to understand how certain phrases tend to predict other phrases. This allows Google to move beyond its dependency on keyword frequency alone and utilize more complex algorithms in the form of Term-Frequency Inverses-Document Frequency (TF*IDF).
	
	Term frequency (TF) is how many times a term is used on a page proportional to the length of the page. This helps identify keyword stuffing. Inversion Document Frequency (IDF) measures the importance of a specific term for relevancy based on the entire web. Keeping this measurement in mind, you’ll want to avoid keyword stuffing while also examining synonyms and language that is semantically related to your primary keyword in order to provide better contextual signals to search engines.
	<h4>Keyword Placement</h4>
	Every website is made up of different parts: header, body content, images, sidebars, footers and more. Search engines give higher priority to the content that populates certain areas of a webpage. For example, if you are optimizing for your Pet Store business, placing the keyword phrase “Chicago Pet Store” once in the HTML tag, once in the header and once in the body content is more effective than stuffing it 10 times in a single paragraph.
	
	Google uses signals in the HTML of your website to identify where the prominent areas of your page are located. Header tags, HTML titles and schema tags are ways to help the search engines understand the context of your page. Whether you’re building a website from scratch or looking for ways to enhance your website for SEO, it’s important that the development team is working side-by-side an SEO specialist to ensure search engines are able to find and index the most important pieces of content.
	<h2>Want to Learn More About SEO and Digital Marketing Strategies?</h2>
	Utilizing these keyword research techniques to identify and implement keywords will give your website some powerful contextual signals. However, this is just the first step in search engine optimization. There are many other factors that also contribute to the ranking potential of your website.
	
	For more information on search engine optimization, web design and digital marketing strategies, attend one of our <a href="http://www.swc.com/events" target="_blank">Chicagoland SEO and Internet Marketing events</a>. This complimentary event is a great opportunity to begin the conversation around keywords and SEO, and see what actually works from today’s market leaders.
	<h2>Download Our Infographic</h2>
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-seo-stats-infographic-012015.png" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-15447 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/swc-seo-stats-infographic-sm-012015.png" alt="SWC SEO Stats Infographic SM" width="500" height="764" /></a></content:encoded>
			<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:post_date>2015-08-26 08:53:42</wp:post_date>
			<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-08-26 13:53:42</wp:post_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
			<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
			<wp:post_name>keyword-research</wp:post_name>
			<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
			<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
			<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
			<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
			<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

			<category domain="post_tag" nicename="digital-marketing"><![CDATA[digital marketing]]></category>
			<category domain="category" nicename="digital-marketing"><![CDATA[Digital Marketing]]></category>
			<category domain="post_tag" nicename="keyword-research"><![CDATA[keyword research]]></category>

		<item>
			<title>Make Phone Calls from Office 365 with Skype for Business Online</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/unified-communications/phone-calls-from-office-365-with-skype-for-business</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 04 Sep 2015 20:25:09 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[anthonycaragol]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=18140</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[You’ll soon be able to make phone calls from Office 365 with <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications/skype-business">Skype for Business</a> Online. We’re getting tons of questions from <a href="http://www.swc.com/swc-technology-partners/news/10-things-every-skype-for-business-administrator-should-know">Skype for Business Administrators</a> at SWC and I’d like to take a moment to address a few of them.
	<h2>What does this mean for making phone calls with Skype for Business?</h2>
	Very simply, right now Office 365 tenants selected for the preview can assign phone numbers to their users and make inbound and outbound calls from their Skype for Business clients. They can also host conferences with PSTN connectivity—all within Microsoft’s cloud.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-18141" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Skype-For-Business-Image.jpg" alt="Skype-For-Business-Image" width="500" height="267" />
	<h2>Can it replace my PBX?</h2>
	That’s exactly the intention, but not today, and maybe not this year. The first wave of the enhancements will allow for basic inbound and outbound calling, conferencing, and voicemail. Full feature parity including response/hunt groups, common area phones, E911, and more serious reporting won’t be available until a later date. <strong>If you’re running in a small office with very simple requirements, you might be a good candidate for the first wave.</strong>
	<h2>Is it a good idea to put my PBX in the cloud?</h2>
	Someday it will be strange to have telephony on premises, but it’s going to be a slow transition. Regardless of the location of the phone system, there are still many factors to consider and your network quality is key. If you don’t need much and can tolerate a few poor quality calls, outsourcing may be a no-brainer. If you have complex requirements including reporting, call centers, multiple E911 locations, and need to guarantee quality voice calls, a comprehensive deployment plan and careful planning are critical to success. It’s also important to keep in mind that you also have the option to outsource a portion of the system while keeping the most critical components in your infrastructure.
	<h2>What do you think of it so far?</h2>
	To be honest, it’s fantastic. <strong>I haven’t had any serious issues and call quality has far exceeded my expectations.</strong> We at SWC are very excited to see this take shape.
	<h2>When will the ability to make phone calls from Office 365 be available?</h2>
	The basics will be available before the end of this year. More advanced features will roll out in 2016.
	<h2>I want to replace my PBX now, should I wait?</h2>
	Not necessarily. If you have a phone system that needs to be replaced, all of the features are available right now in Skype for Business which can run in your own datacenter. It can be configured in a hybrid approach so that when the cloud is ready, you will be too.
	
	Make your workplace a more communicative and productive one with Skype for Business. Join me for SWC’s complimentary <a href="http://www.swc.com/skype-for-business-event">Skype for Business Luncheon</a> to learn more about Skype for Business Online, or contact one of our <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/unified-communications">unified communications experts</a> and we’ll put our Microsoft Unified Communications Gold Partner status to work for you.
	<h2>Watch Anthony’s presentation:</h2>
	<a href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/TiWeu6QbPdc?rel=0&amp;autoplay=0" rel="shadowbox;width=720;height=480;"><img src="/uploads/Skype-for-business-presentation.jpg" alt="Chicago Ignite Skype for Business" width="500" height="281" /></a>
	
	</content:encoded>

			<title>Beyond the Job Posting: Life as an Engagement Manager at SWC</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/business-engagement-manager</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 16 Sep 2015 16:59:38 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[franpeters]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=18148</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Brad Ellison is an Engagement Manager at SWC Technology Partners. This client facing role allows him to utilize his sales and interpersonal communication skills to build long-term relationships with SWC’s customers. His extensive background and former role at SWC as a Senior Network Engineer has allowed him to become the leader of SWC’s <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/service-manager">Microsoft System Center practice</a>.
	
	We sat down with Brad to give those seeking a <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers">career in business and technology</a> a glimpse of what it’s like to be an <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers/chicago-business-engagement-manager-job">Engagement Manager</a> at SWC.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>HOW DID YOUR EXPERIENCE AS A NETWORK ENGINEER PREPARE YOU FOR THE ROLE AS AN ENGAGEMENT MANAGER?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18155 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png" alt="brad-ellison" width="120" height="120" /></a>My background as a Senior Network Engineer has allowed me to take the conversation deeper than most “sales guys”. I can talk about the actual solution design to clients’ IT departments and can speak with business leaders on the productivity and efficiency gains SWC’s solutions provide their businesses. I know how our proposed solutions plays with existing technologies and systems which allows me to build value for my customers in that I’m able to take an idea and help mold it into an exact solution.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>WHAT QUALITIES MAKE A SUCCESSFUL BUSINESS ENGAGEMENT MANAGER?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18155 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png" alt="brad-ellison" width="120" height="120" /></a>First and foremost, a successful EM has a true and deep passion for helping the customer succeed. This means providing exact solutions to specific business challenges. When that happens, everyone in the process is successful and the partnership strengthens.
	
	A successful EM is personable and has strong leadership and organizational skills. Public speaking and the ability to command meetings is also a must.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>WHAT’S YOUR FAVORITE PART OF YOUR JOB AT SWC TECHNOLOGY PARTNERS?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18155 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png" alt="brad-ellison" width="120" height="120" /></a>My favorite part is seeing a project come together and having that feeling of accomplishment when the client is completely satisfied and starts to see efficiency gains from the newly implemented solution. I also love being able to meet new people and present at our <a href="http://www.swc.com/events">complimentary technology luncheons</a>.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>HOW HAS SWC ENABLED YOUR PERSONAL AND PROFESSIONAL CAREER?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18155 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png" alt="brad-ellison" width="120" height="120" /></a>There are a lot of people here that I consider true friends. Not only are they fun to go out with, but I’m always learning from them. Professionally, if you are willing to work hard at SWC, the opportunities are endless. One thing leadership does very well is work to create those opportunities that allow the team to mature and grow. They reward you for your willingness to learn and grow your skills.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>WHAT ARE SOME OF YOUR FAVORITE SWC CAREER PERKS AND EXPERIENCES?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18155 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png" alt="brad-ellison" width="120" height="120" /></a>I love the golf outings, the abundance of free food, and the events that our Wellness Committee organizes. SWC looks out for our health while at the same time tempting us with great <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers/swc-benefits">perks </a>and tasty treats.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>WHAT WAS THE MOST CHALLENGING AND/OR REWARDING SYSTEM CENTER PROJECT YOU HAVE BEEN A PART OF?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18155 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png" alt="brad-ellison" width="120" height="120" /></a>The most rewarding System Center project I’ve been part of was when we helped a customer go from a situation where they were spending an immense amount of time manually deploying PCs, reacting to infrastructure and applications challenges and haphazardly managing help desk incidents. There was a lack of both a formal process and the tools necessary to automate these tasks.
	
	By helping them deploy <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/configuration-manager-sccm">SCCM</a>, <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/operations-manager-scom">SCOM</a>, <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-system-center/service-manager">SCSM </a>and Orchestrator, and providing the necessary information, training and tools to allow them to be successful; our customer been able to provide better support to the business and free up their lean and mean IT staff to focus on more value-added initiatives. It was a huge success for our customer which will allow them to reap the benefits of this solution for a long time to come.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18068 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/fran-peters-circle.png" alt="fran-peters-circle" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>ARE WE EVER GOING TO SEE ANOTHER BEERS WITH BRAD? THE PEOPLE ARE THIRSTY FOR A NEW EPISODE.</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18155 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/brad-ellison.png" alt="brad-ellison" width="120" height="120" /></a>It certainly has been a while since we’ve done a <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/events/beers-with-brad-cio-tech-talk">Beers with Brad</a> episode and it brings back fond memories when customers recognize me out of the blue from past shows. I absolutely look forward to doing more episodes focused on diving in to today’s most pressing and top of mind IT and business topics (such as security), while maintaining a light atmosphere full of beer, banter and Brad. Stay tuned!
	
	Interested in learning more about joining our team as an Engagement Manager? Check out <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers">careers at SWC</a> or <a href="http://www.swc.com/contact">contact us</a> at to learn more! We have a variety of open positions on our technology, digital and business teams.
	
	</content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Power BI and IoT:  A Game Changer for Real-time Analytics</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/business-intelligence/power-bi-and-iot-for-real-time-analytics</link>
			<pubDate>Fri, 11 Sep 2015 15:58:37 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[chaddotzenrod]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=18159</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Since last spring, <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/microsoft-office-365/power-bi">Power BI</a> has had the capability to accept live stream data from the <a href="http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/stream-analytics/">Azure Stream Analytics</a> service. We, SWC, started to tinker with the offering during the summer and built our first streaming dashboard with a Twitter sentiment feed. It was a lot of fun and surprisingly easy to build. With our feet wet and our appetites whet, we decided to build something a bit more practical.
	<h2>Enter the Internet of Plants</h2>
	Yes, you read that right; we’re building a small <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_of_Things" target="_blank">IoT</a> demo environment of networked potted plants.
	
	<a title="Internet Of Plants - A Power BI and Microsoft Azure Demo " href="http://www.youtube.com/embed/mq3g6AO9ZUM?rel=0" rel="shadowbox; player=iframe; width=720; height=480"><img src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Internet-of-plants.jpg" alt="New Features of Tableau 8.2" width="474" height="262" /></a>
	
	Using <a href="https://www.raspberrypi.org/products/raspberry-pi-2-model-b/" target="_blank">Raspberry Pi 2</a> , <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=48232" target="_blank">Windows 10 Core Edition</a> and various commodity sensors and Wi-Fi adapters, we will be collecting plant health data such as moisture/humidity, temperature, and light. That information will be sent to Azure for processing and then outputted to Power BI for analysis. All in all, the cost for each device fully configured has been under $80.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-18160" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/internet-of-plants.png" alt="internet-of-plants" width="650" height="396" />
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-18161" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/internet-of-things-2.png" alt="internet-of-things-2" width="650" height="266" />
	<h2>What Does this Mean for My Business?</h2>
	The internet of plants demo is fun and does a good job of demonstrating the capability of the Microsoft BI platform for your business. Many organizations, particularly in manufacturing, collect massive amounts of sensor data from many devices. Until now, the analysis of that sensor data was often done via proprietary solutions or isn’t analyzed in a timely fashion due to the technical challenges of getting the data in format that business users can understand. Azure and Power BI greatly simplify the architecture and allow for easier and cheaper real-time analytics.
	
	Over the next few months the SWC Business Intelligence team will be showcasing our IoT solutions at <a href="http://www.swc.com/events">luncheons </a>and <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Business-Intelligence-Chicagoland/">meetups</a>, and we welcome you to come and take a look for yourselves. These events are a great opportunity to network, ask questions and build out your corporate IoT and analytics strategy. We look forward to sharing our expertise!
	
	If you would like more information about IoT or what business intelligence can do you for your organization, <a href="http://www.swc.com/contact">contact SWC</a> or call 630.572.0240 to speak with one of our BI experts.
	<h2>Map the Road to Business Success with Microsoft &amp; SWC</h2>
	<a href=" /Microsoft-Technology-Roadmap.pdf" target="_blank"><img class="alignnone wp-image-16983" src=" /uploads/technology-roadmap-download.png" alt="technology-roadmap-download" width="400" height="237" /></a>
	
	<a </content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Protect Your End Users from Phishing Attacks with Security Awareness Training</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/security/protect-from-phishing-attacks-with-security-awareness-training</link>
			<pubDate>Tue, 08 Sep 2015 17:39:48 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[viraldhimar]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=18166</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Does this exchanges between employees in finance departments and the CEO of the company sound familiar?
	
	<em>“What’s with that email you sent?”
	“What email?”
	“The one where you told me to wire money to that bank in China.”
	“I never sent such an email.”</em>
	
	CEO fraud usually starts with thieves either <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/email-phishing">phishing </a>an executive and gaining access to that individual’s email, or emailing employees from look-alike domains. For example, if the domain name for the organization is abc.com, the thieves might send emails from abc.co. To date the FBI has calculated <a href="http://krebsonsecurity.com/2015/08/fbi-1-2b-lost-to-business-email-scams/">the loss from CEO fraud to be at $1.2 billion</a>.
	
	<img class="alignnone wp-image-18167" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/phishing.png" alt="phishing" width="650" height="341" />
	
	These types of emails often don’t get caught or quarantined and are targeted to specific people in the organization. The thieves usually do their homework and scour the web for any information about a company (LinkedIn). Once they’ve built up a good knowledge base, they go after those they know will likely fall prey to the “CEO’s” demands to wire money.
	
	These thieves have gone to school and done their homework. Now, organizations and their employees must do the same. <strong>Security awareness training</strong> is paramount in today’s world. Employees need to know how to recognize simple yet key indicators in phishing emails. Key indicators include looking at the “from” address, the body of the email (English is usually not the attackers first language), and perhaps the easiest indicator, the origin of the bank where the money needs to be wired to. If your organization has never conducted operations in countries such as China or Russia, why would a CEO request such a transfer? <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/security/lastpass-hack-prevention" target="_blank">Two-factor or multi-factor authentication</a> should be a must for transferring large sums of money.
	
	The “CEO Fraud” example above is just one of many ways attackers go after employees via email. Attackers can also embed links in emails with malicious executables, and all it takes is one person to click that link and the network could be compromised.
	
	SWC offers comprehensive <a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services/security-managed-services" target="_blank">security awareness training</a> to educate end users on how to detect these malicious scenarios. We also offer phishing campaigns simulated from an attacker’s perspective to gain an understanding of whether or not your users are clicking on these emails, as well as implementing right-sized technologies to assist a company’s overall security.
	
	Want to learn more? Contact one of our security professionals. (I promise it’s not a bad link…or is it?)
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/solutions/security-services"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-16121 size-full" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/security-awareness-training.jpg" alt="security-awareness-training" width="500" height="441" /></a>
	</content:encoded>
			<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>Beyond the Job Posting: Life as an Associate Engineer at SWC</title>
			<link>http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/associate-engineer</link>
			<pubDate>Wed, 02 Sep 2015 13:59:19 +0000</pubDate>
			<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jill]]></dc:creator>
			<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.swc.com/?p=18173</guid>
			<description></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[Zeba Hasan is on the Network Operations Center (NOC) team in SWC’s Managed Services practice. Zeba enjoys working at SWC because we have a great corporate culture and team dynamic, she also enjoys all of the professional development opportunities SWC provides her to grow in her career.
	
	We sat down with Zeba to give potential applicants a glimpse of what it’s like to be an <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers/chicago-information-technology-associate-engineer-job">Associate Engineer</a> at SWC.
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18177 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png" alt="jill-photo" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	<h4><strong>What makes SWC a great place to work?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18178 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png" alt="Zeba-careers" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	
	What makes SWC <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/crains-best-places-to-work-2015" target="_blank">a great place to work</a> is a combination of things, namely the culture, people, and the team environment. It’s very well-rounded and professional, but at the same time we have a lot of fun here with company activities and celebrations. SWC really likes to celebrate our achievements!
	
	<strong><a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18177 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png" alt="jill-photo" width="120" height="120" /></a></strong>
	<h4><strong>What skills and qualities make a successful Associate Engineer? </strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18178 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png" alt="Zeba-careers" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	
	Since we do consulting for a multitude of clients, it’s really helpful for anyone applying for the Associate Engineer position to have been in consulting or worked with many different clients at the same time.
	
	As far as skills, you need to have a little bit of everything when you’re coming into consulting—not just technical skills, but organizational and writing as well.
	
	Personality-wise, we look for someone who is eager to learn. There is a lot to learn here, but it’s never too overwhelming because we have such a great team; everyone wants to help you. And because there is a lot to learn, you are always growing your skills, which in IT is absolutely essential.
	
	<strong><a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18177 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png" alt="jill-photo" width="120" height="120" /></a></strong>
	<h4><strong>How is the work-life balance at SWC?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18178 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png" alt="Zeba-careers" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/careers/chicago-it-solutions-provider-work-life-balance" target="_blank">Work/life is really well balanced</a>, especially for an IT consulting firm. Employees say that SWC is fundamentally different from their previous places of employment, and I would have to completely agree based on my past positions.
	
	In many IT jobs, you are expected to work overtime and always be on the grid. At SWC, there are times you will also have to work overtime, but we take turns doing it. On our particular team, we have pager duty or are “on call” once every six weeks – which is not bad at all! We have one person “on pager” from the NOC, service desk, and escalations team in case of an emergency, or if our afterhours team gets overwhelmed. They can then call us for help.
	
	<strong><a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18177 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png" alt="jill-photo" width="120" height="120" /></a></strong>
	<h4><strong>What professional development opportunities are there?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18178 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png" alt="Zeba-careers" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	
	The great thing about SWC is that they will help put you on the <a href="http://www.swc.com/blog/ask-swc/what-are-your-favorite-career-development-initiatives" target="_blank">career path</a> you want to go down. We have regular meetings with our career advocates to make sure we are on the right track to grow our skills and pursue our areas of interest. If you are good at what you do and exceed expectations then you will find that there are many different paths you can take.
	
	SWC also covers the cost of certifications. If it’s in line with your career goals, they will make sure you are working towards at least one certification.
	
	<strong><a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18177 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/jill-photo.png" alt="jill-photo" width="120" height="120" /></a></strong>
	<h4><strong>What are some of your favorite SWC perks and experiences?</strong></h4>
	&nbsp;
	
	<a href="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-18178 alignleft" src="http://www.swc.com/uploads/Zeba-careers.png" alt="Zeba-careers" width="120" height="120" /></a>
	
	SWC does a lot for their employees and I appreciate that. There is always free food and drinks. They are always looking for new, creative ways to celebrate our achievements, so there are lots of events and parties. They even treated us to a manicure/pedicure one time!
	
	Interested in learning more about joining our team as an Associate Engineer? Check out our <a href="http://www.swc.com/careers">IT Careers</a> or <a href="http://www.swc.com/contact">contact us</a> at to learn more! We have a variety of open positions on our technology, digital and business teams.
	
	</content:encoded>
